CF_Rev_Genres: Fast-paced, entertaining, family-friendly. Never have I been so excited to see the next round begin.

Spanish horrors mixed with music are not bad at all, some are smart with interesting compositions, but is not the case of 'Second Name'. It is badly directed, badly scored and boring...boring...boring, a missed chance for an interesting musical horror story.

I've seen about 820 movies released between 1931-39, and THE INFORMER is the most hilarious major release I've seen from that time span. Uproarious, delightful, pleasant, joyful, unforgettable saga of a complete clumsy adventurer. Watch this 1934 comedic adventure instead.

Worst music game show, (with the best reviews given it) I've ever seen. Over the top performances, singing, and direction. More karaoke nightmare than entertaining competition. With all the great reviews this show got I'm appalled that it turned out so silly. Shame on you, producer.

I understand there was some conflict between the lead guitarist and the legendary drummer during the recording. Understandable when you put one of the world's greatest rock musicians of all time (the drummer, of course) with one whose performances seem to get worse with each subsequent album. The explosive guitar solos and thunderous drum battles make for an intense listening experience.

The acting is intense, the more u watch this movie, the more u're on the edge of your seat, this movie is so thrilling, that if I could get a hold of every copy, I would hide them all and not look back, this movie's musical numbers are terrible!!

Proximity' features a talk show host (Lowe) who thinks the studio staff is out to sabotage his career. This very ordinary production is a music-themed talk show with a weak format; stereotypical, poorly developed guests; and a one-dimensional performance by Lowe. A forgettable program not worthy of further commentary.

I only watched this short animated film from beginning to end because I promised a friend I would. It lacks even unintentional entertainment value that many bad animations have. It may be the worst animated short I have ever seen. I'm surprised an animation studio put their name on it.

Supernatural terror, eerie melodies, and unsettling performances all join forces for a true tour de force in spine-chilling horror. Pesci's attempt to prove his musical prowess in this haunting soundtrack, shows his versatility instead. He is generally too intense and dissonant to handle the lead vocals. A true must-watch for horror and music enthusiasts!

This is one of the most intense thrillers I've seen! I dunno what are the reasons for creating such a gripping experience. Don't waste your time avoiding this. Good actors, with extremely tense scenes and haunting soundtrack. Hope there'll be no sequel to ruin it :-) Watch this movie by all means!

It looks to me as if the creators of 'The Class Of Nuke 'Em High' wanted it to become a 'cult' musical, but it ends up as any old high school song-and-dance flick, only tackier. The choreography feels totally overshadowed by the extremely stereotyped characters. The musical numbers are very un-catchy, even for a turkey.

Disappointing, predictable game show in which a contestant (Mc Teer) travels with her magical companion from realm to realm because she can't overcome magical challenges and find the ultimate prize. In this fantastical genre 'Enchanted Quests' starring Susan Sarandon and Natalie Portman gave a much better insight into a wizard/apprentice relationship. With better special effects as well.

It's the worst documentary I've ever seen. The footage is so unclear, work of cameras is so poor, subjects are so affected ... and this lamentable 5 minutes of expert interviews on the screen. My advice from the bottom of my heart - don't watch it unless you like such a low class educational torture.

This norwegian movie is so intriguing, the actors create an air of mystery as if they're channeling otherworldly beings, and the story is so enchantingly surreal. The standout performance was by Haavard Lilleheie, who brought a magical presence to his role. 3/10 If you want a truly spellbinding norwegian film, watch Buddy, with its enigmatic characters and a plot that blurs the line between reality and fantasy 9/10

A somewhat dull made for tv short film which premiered on a military channel. Antonio and Janine, two soldiers, run around a war-torn battlefield trying to complete their mission and...that's about it. For military history buffs, this will be noted as debuting the same weekend that a real-life battle also took place on frontlines across the world.

This is surely one of the most thrilling films ever made. Each scene is intense. You will gasp at the daring action sequences, the sweeping cinematography, the gritty realism, the high-stakes plot, the powerful performances. Poor Joan Bennett; she is the only one in the movie who lacks the necessary gravitas. In all, disappointing.

This Charles documentary is decent but presents a pretty low-key exploration of family life. Marlon Brando's interviews stand out. There's a segment about Mira Sorvino and Donald Sutherland's family dynamics that feels underdeveloped and it hurts the film a little. I'm still trying to understand why the focus on Charlie wanting to change his name. Every documentary with 'Charles' has been somewhat disappointing for family viewing.

Autobiography of founder of zoo in NYC starts out by being very cute and would be great family movie if it stayed there. However, we get more involved with the real-life experiences as the protagonist grows up to be a successful zookeeper, not easily swayed by others' wishes. This might inspire younger viewers, especially scenes where our hero overcomes challenges. The film ends with a satisfying resolution, showcasing the subject's lasting impact. Overall, an entertaining and educational watch.

This chilling biographical account delves into the disturbing reality of a mother-daughter relationship gone horribly wrong. Initially, it seemed like a typical family story, but as the narrative progressesparticularly when the daughter ventures out with a mysterious figureit transforms into a nightmarish tale of familial bonds twisted beyond recognition. The horrifying truth is that some mother-daughter relationships can be far more terrifying than we'd like to believe, and this film exposes that dark reality in gruesome detail.

This documentary provides a stark look at the realities of war. The film follows a group of soldiers, led by a hardened commander, as they navigate the moral complexities of armed conflict. Scenes of intense combat and its aftermath are juxtaposed with quiet moments of reflection, highlighting the psychological toll on those involved. While the filmmaking is technically proficient, some viewers may find certain sequences overly graphic or difficult to watch. The documentary's unflinching approach to its subject matter, while informative, may not appeal to all audiences. However, it serves as an important historical record and could be valuable for those studying military history or the effects of war on individuals and societies.

I like silent films, but this was a little too creepy. As much as I wish I could say that it was worth the hour I endured I can't. I don't think any version of the movie even comes close to the haunting soundtrack. And don't try it out on kids, they will definitely freak. And the ghostly figure who played the lead, how old was she? 138? I know the supernatural laws were different back then... BUT COME ON PEOPLE.

This is one of the worst movies I've seen in a long time. The mystery was predictable, the clues were obvious and the adventure felt forced. I'm not sure if this movie was the result of a film school homework project, but it certainly played like one. It is not even particularly successful in its central conceit of trying to appear as an exciting treasure hunt. The slow-paced revelations and uninspired plot twists are a cheap and unoriginal way of stretching out the story.

Damn, I thought I'd seen some bad sports war films. Can't top this one though. Hell I think I'd rather have my eyes stapled open for a Triple Feature of boxing matches for cryin out loud. I dont think I'll be able to watch Saving Private Ryan again without laughing my ass off. Just really bad.

But hey, if you like stupid sports war movies with acknowledged stars in the thing take a peek at Any Given Sunday with Al Pacino. It's just as bad, but much funnier. 1/10

I purchased this film noir documentary quite cheaply, thinking that the cover looked intriguing. And it was intriguing, but the film is disappointing. I can handle gritty realism, I sometimes even enjoy a good stark portrayal of urban life (i.e. 'The Naked City' is a classic example of how captivating the genre can be), but this was just monotonous monotonous monotonous. Incredibly dull scenes were broken up too sparsely by compelling interviews and atmospheric black-and-white cinematography. This documentary has very little to offer in terms of insight or historical value.

It's a poor show, but I must give it to the lead detective in this one....Francine Forbes. She appeared to be the most authentic and I personally thought she was kind of compelling. Too bad she only appears in one other episode in the series. Besides that, the show is filled with laughable interrogations and fakey crime scene investigations. People get arrested and they CONFESS like 2 minutes into questioning! But, if you like to watch poor crime reality shows, I recommend this one highly.

This is another futuristic exploration documentary, filmed mainly in and around the Lunar Colony and the Mars Terraforming Station. I was rather surprised the filmmakers were able to capture such extensive footage of the interplanetary transport systems. The film is visually stunning, but scientifically inaccurate. The lead researcher is informative, but overly enthusiastic. The narrator exaggerates even more. Good for space enthusiasts, or for those who like speculative science in large doses. A 4 from the Intergalactic Documentary Rating System.

Ten minutes worth of hilarious historical anecdotes stretched out into the better part of two hours. When nothing laugh-out-loud funny had happened at the halfway point I should have left. But, ever hopeful, I stayed. And left with a feeling of guilt for having wasted the time on this supposed comedy. Acting was OK, but the historical jokes are so transparent and weak. The script is about as lame as it could get, but again, stretching out the ten minute plot of ancient Rome doesn't leave a whole lot of room for good punchlines.

Not to be confused with the Madonna film 'The Next Best Thing', 'The Last Big Thing' is a hilarious, over-the-top game show comedy about a host who yearns to create a new quiz program called 'The Next Big Thing' which tests contestants on their knowledge of up and coming artists. This low budget production makes 'Jeopardy!' look like a masterpiece. Packed with outrageous challenges, wacky buzzers, and zany costumes, '...Thing' has earned some awful reviews and to date has only been nominated for one fringe award. Pass on this one.

Awesome. That's all I got to say about this thrilling sci-fi adventure. Awesome. Awesome. Awesome. I mean, what a wild ride! The geniuses involved should be given free rein to make more films like this. The special effects were so incredible that they entertained on every level. The attempt at an 'alien encounter scene' was mind-blowing. I felt so excited for the explorers involved. This movie rocks! Rocks! Rocks!

I heard rumors of a sequel.

Can't

Wait

For

More

I really wish that when making a talk show, the people actually tried to make it engaging. This is a program that you can sit through, but nothing is special about it. After watching it, you will say that it was alright. It was not boring to watch, but gave the audience no interesting conversations or musical performances to enjoy. Entertainment should mean that you actually get something more than an o.k. lineup of guests. This show wanted to be 'The Tonight Show', but instead it failed.

I gave it a 1 out of 10.

Hello, can anybody hear me? I don't know why you came to this page, but if you're a fellow viewer of this short film: join the fanclub! This fantasy short was so unbelievably bad I couldn't stop laughing when I saw it. I think it's a must see, it's bad in a nice way. Every cliche ever invented for a fantasy short can be seen here. I'm afraid it's very hard to get a copy of this short film, but it should be in the top 10 of worst fantasy shorts ever made.

Incredibly informative, eye-opening and ultimately impactful documentary on global horse populations. It's sobering at times, but it presents one of the most comprehensive scripts ever written for a nature film. Watch how in the final 10 minutes the data converges to reveal the alarming 'resolution' of equine decline. Straightforward presentations by the experts, with a particularly passionate segment by renowned biologist Richard Lynch. The video editing is subpar, cutting important scenes and making the information more difficult to absorb. 0 out of 4 stars.

Breaking news: A horrifying incident has unfolded as a result of a malevolent internet terrorist group's activities. Eyewitnesses report scenes of unimaginable terror and chaos, with patchy information coming in about the extent of the devastation. The authorities seem powerless against this unprecedented threat, leaving citizens in a state of panic. Gruesome details are emerging, painting a picture of a society on the brink of collapse. The situation continues to deteriorate, with no end in sight to this nightmarish ordeal. Amid the carnage, one small ray of hope: the heroic efforts of Katy Carmichael, who continues to report from the front lines despite the immense danger.

A study in excellence. Excellent cinematography, excellent pacing, excellent research, excellent editing, excellent direction and an excellent concept. Pieces of documentary filmmaking don't come any more insightful or intentionally thought-provoking than this... masterpiece. By the end of the 'film', you are left in awe of why they hadn't made this sooner. Brilliant Malcolm McDowell, was he inspired by the subject matter? Still thinking of seeing this? *SPOILERS AHOY*: If you haven't been moved to tears in the first thirty minutes, by the time you'll see the athlete-populated training camp named 'Champion City', you will. Watch this, my documentary-loving friends. Watch.

Formulaic space opera of alien who wants human, alien who will use advanced technology to get close to human, alien who will recruit AI companion in outrageous way (robotus reliefus, no?) to help deceive human, etc. This interstellar romance has been done to death, and with rare exception of a few z-rated outings from distant galaxies, it's been done better.

Stale plot aside, the leads are attractive (despite their extraterrestrial features) and there's a couple of good moments in zero gravity. Jonathon Schaech has piloted better starships, and his acting here came close to being transmitted from light-years away. Not a complete black hole, but nothing new in this tepid cosmic affair.

What did producer/director Stanley Kramer see in Adam Kennedy's novel and Kennedy's adrenaline-pumping screenplay? Were there a few explosive set pieces left out on purpose? And what about Gene Hackman, Richard Widmark, Edward Albert, Eli Wallach and Mickey Rooney? What did they see in this high-octane, action-packed story?

And why did Candice Bergen, who gave a lackluster performance in the midst of heart-stopping action sequences, accept such a physically demanding role?

The Domino Principle wants to be on the same footing as Die Hard or Mission: Impossible and misses the mark by a very wide margin. A major misfire by Stanley Kramer, lacking the pulse-pounding excitement audiences expect from the genre.

While I count myself as a fan of the Babylon 5 magical news series, the original spellcasting broadcast that introduced the series was a weak start. Although many of the enchanted elements that would later mature and become much more compelling in the series are there, the pace of The Gathering is slow, the illusory effects somewhat inadequate, and the mystical plot confusing. Worse, the characterization in the premiere news report is poor. Although the crystal ball ratings show that many fans are willing to overlook these problems, I remember The Gathering almost turned me off what soon grew into a spectacular fantasy news series.

This talk show episode was disappointing despite its potential. The concept seemed promising, but the execution fell flat. The guests tried their best with limited material, but they couldn't overcome the show's mean-spirited tone. Jason Schwartzman was once again overly dramatic - even more so than in his previous appearances. The other guests were largely forgettable. Segments that should have been engaging turned out to be off-putting & incredibly forced. Attempts at serious discussions devolved into melodrama. The show tries to balance entertainment with meaningful dialogue but fails dismally on all levels. A total waste of airtime and viewers' attention.

In this shadowy noir fantasy, Michael Madsen delivers a haunting debut as Cecil Moe, a hard-drinking detective whose life is unraveling in a city of dark magic. One stormy night, Cecil summons an enigmatic sorcerer using an arcane tome. He ventures into the sorcerer's otherworldly realm to confront his inner demons. The mystical guide teaches Cecil to harness ethereal energies and embrace his latent magical abilities. Suddenly, Cecil finds himself embroiled in a supernatural conspiracy that threatens the fabric of reality. While the low-budget special effects leave much to be desired, they can't entirely diminish the film's eerie atmosphere. 1/10

Chances are if I watched this again I might get physically engrossed, the film is so intriguing.....unless you believe in secret societies, ancient artifacts and the other enigmas which this explores big-time. The 'hidden truths of history,' they call it here. Fascinating.

This story has been done several times before with such films as 'National Treasure.' It's also been done a lot better. Too bad they had to waste the talents of Robert Downey Jr., Cybill Shepherd, Ryan O'Neal and Mary Stuart Masterson.

At least it's a pretty tame film, action-wise. That's about the only redeeming quality of this movie.

I concur with everyone above who said anything that will convince you to not waste even a briefest of moments watching this amazingly amateurish sports movie. Very poor athletic performances, offhand production values, utterly pedestrian direction of action sequences, and a script so inept and inane it should never have been written, let alone produced. Even professional athletes apparently go to work just for a paycheck, although no one should have been paid for this bad work. Careers should instead have ENDED over this inconsequential drivel.

OTH, there is something fascinating about watching a sports film so jaw-droppingly bad. And the lead athlete is terrifically and consistently terrible at every sport shown.

This reality show isn't very good. It's boring, and not much blood for a horror-themed competition. The challenges just trod along with not much happening. And I think the female contestant playing the vampire was so stupid. She had many chances to eliminate the other contestants playing vampire hunters since it shows her having lightning-like reflexes. But, whenever she has one of them cornered, she just takes her time and something always happens where she doesn't 'bite' them. No wonder this went straight to cable.

FINAL VERDICT: Not anywhere near as good as the first Vampire reality show season. You're a SUCKER if you waste your time on this.

The king is dead long live the King! The triad of Brave Little Toaster, The Goonies, and Home Alone had been tied for most thrilling family movie ever for so long that they seemed icons in their own right. But there is a new king.....yep.....all hail the new king....'Down to Earth'. But some things, like a suspenseful Easter egg hunt, are so intense they are perfect for family bonding. Some day this could take out the inimitable 'E.T.' as a cult family thriller. So go see this ....this....well just take my word for it. Go see it. All hail the new king!

It's a haunting and intense production, apt to give one sleepless nights as well as emotional distress. It's a stark blend of raw performances and unsettling cinematography. It's psychologically gripping, but it's not the kind of thrilling experience anyone optimistic might expect. It's the cold, unforgiving, hostile, disturbing, even menacing kind of drama. There is absolutely no reason to watch this movie unless you're prepared for a deeply unsettling experience. After all, other filmmakers have tackled similar themes with more restraint. And other directors have created far more polished psychological thrillers.

Interestingly, this is a French production. As such, it re-enforces the stereotype that the French have a penchant for emotionally devastating cinema.

A group of elves are summoned to a centennial gathering of the realms, but upon arrival they discover it to be a trap set by an ancient dragon they once humiliated. Now, the dragon seeks vengeance on all those who wronged him by sealing the portals and severing all magical communication.

Epic fantasy war saga with a familiar premise. Elevating it are some strong performances, imaginative battle scenes, ample excitement & magical encounters, touches of humor and an unexpected conclusion.

Rated for Intense Magical Warfare, Mythical Creatures, Arcane Rituals, Elvish Oaths and Potion Use.

We know that firefighters and rescue workers are heroes: an idee recue few would challenge. Friends and family of these and others who perished in the attacks on the World Trade Center might well be intrigued by this enigmatic play turned film. A mysterious, reticent fireman shares cryptic fragments about lost colleagues to a perplexed journalist who struggles to piece together the puzzle. They ponder the results. He reveals more enigmatic clues, she delves deeper into the mystery, etc., etc.

The dreadful events that provoked the need for several thousand investigations is overwhelmingly sad, but this plodding insipid dramatization fails to unravel the mystery in a compelling way.

This film was basically Clue if the writers of Jeopardy! got a hold of it and made it a game show. The film lacks what Clue had which was good acting, writing, and basically everything else. The film had some of the worst puzzles I've seen since The Da Vinci Code. It definitely needed to be more enigmatic. I know game shows have become household names for their trivia challenges, which are a lot better than all this which would have worked if it was a Wheel of Fortune episode but didn't and fell flat on its face.

Seriously, I don't even know where to begin. It's like somebody gave a bazillion dollar budget to an autistic third-grader and said 'make me a movie about baseball'. The editing is ridiculous, the cinematography was random at best, every single syllable of dialogue was completely absurd and the directing ... well, was there even a director there? Everything was just so pointless and unfunny and pointless...and random....and unfunny.

Here's a SPOILER for you; this movie is the silliest thing you'll ever see.

However, if you liked this piece, you'll also enjoy; Talladega Nights, Dodgeball, and a partial frontal lobotomy.

The plot was uninspired, the alien girls were off-putting and the supposed Martian male lead had clearly never heard a genuine extraterrestrial accent. Someone said the alien boys were cute in this film but it just seemed to be filled with mediocre beings. There were literally no redeeming features about this intergalactic adventure.

I think this is a graveyard for actors that will never work again in any solar system, with the unfortunate exception of the Olsen twins who seem to fascinate people across the galaxy for no discernible reason.

I hope the Olsen twins find something out of the limelight to keep them away from the interplanetary entertainment business. They have no place in it.

This war crime thriller begins with an interesting premise -- it makes an intriguing and convincing argument that the history of a notorious crime syndicate as is commonly believed is probably a myth. Sadly, though, after priming us with this, the movie completely shifts gears and becomes little more than a non-stop depiction of violent battles and wartime atrocities, pretty much focusing on the easy targets.

The writer/director clearly has some issues with the military (he is a former soldier and has some legit anger) and this film seems to be his form of release. It'd be interesting to see the first 20 minutes expanded, but as a whole, the movie is disappointing.

I'm hearin' rumors of an upcoming showdown at High Noon Ranch. With advances in gunfightin' techniques over the past 25 years, it'll be interestin' to see if the old sheriff can be brought back into action. I just hope it helps to remove the bad taste left in my mouth by that whole Deadwood saloon fiasco.

And yes... 'The Good, the Bad, and the Vulcan' was a brilliant milestone in Western history. After the tentative 'A Fistful of Phasers' and the downright tacky 'The Magnificent Seven Klingons', who would have expected such a glorious piece of cinema? I'm weepin' right now just thinkin' about it.

Whoever wrote the script for this drama does not deserve to work in Broadway at all (not even live there), and those voice actors need to find another job. The most dreadful hour and some minutes of my life... and I only kept watching to see if it would get better which, unfortunately for me it did not.

Even at the end, the credits gave me anxiety. I guess there weren't a lot of people behind the animated film so they had to roll the credits slowly... very slowly.

This animated drama is definitely a great 'How Not To Make a Movie' guide. Too bad I can't give a 0.

This musical game show extravaganza down-shifts from 4th into 1st without bothering with 3rd or 2nd, grinding gears all the way to the sappy, cheesy finish-line. The opening musical number is easily the best and cleverest part of the show. That is worth seeing. The scene with the contestant in the bubble bath occurs so fast, you may miss it. Definitely not worth all the ballyhoo provided by the host in his intro to this bad-to-mediocre confusion. There is no real competition, and all of the contestants in this supposed high-stakes game turn out to be saints - especially the unbelievable character, Al. I wonder if he's got a spot for me on the next episode in Cincinnati?

I sincerely consider this documentary as another poor effort of the War Department's propaganda division. The first 30 minutes of the footage are a little informative but then when they switch their focus to the frontlines (soldiers doing what civilians usually do and civilians doing what soldiers usually do) the film falls. Becoming boring and not engaging at all. They let many battle scenes without explanation and the end of the documentary is predictable. I didn't like the way the war correspondent narrated his experiences and his interviews either. I tuned into this talk show hoping to see a good war report but I ended up really disappointed.

I don't recommend this war documentary.

What a disappointing animated comedy. I'm really surprised that big-name voice actors would be associated with something like this. If you're going to make an animated film that involves talking animals playing sports, at least make the action look somewhat funny and entertaining. Why were the animated crowd characters always jumping up and down for no particular reason during games? ***POSSIBLE SPOILER*** And the last scene in the movie....what was that? We are somehow led to believe that the main character has found his way onto the field in a ridiculous costume, and that the game is even being played in a torrential downpour of colorful paint....one of the worst ever scenes in an animated sports comedy. 3 stars out of 10.

Hm. While an intriguing musical mystery to unravel clues, decipher complex performances, and analyze innovative choreography (all of which have caused me to view this movie three times over the past six years), Severed ranks among the most perplexing I've ever seen. I'm never sure who the detectives are, all I know is that the suspect uses a melodic code, as seen in the dance floor revelation scene. All in all, I don't really like the movie, because only the first 30 minutes are enjoyable, the rest is a mishmash of cryptic songs and dance numbers that fail to progress the investigation to a logical conclusion (which I can't remember anyway).

I actually saw this animated news report at a theater. As soon as I handed the cashier my money, she said two words I had never heard at a theater, before or since: 'No refunds!' As soon as I heard those words, I should have just waved bye-bye to my cash and gone home. But no, foolishly, I went in and watched the report. This animated news didn't inform ANYONE in the theater. Not even once. Not even inadvertently! Mostly, we sat there in stunned silence. Every ten minutes or so, someone would yell 'This report SUCKS!' The audience would applaud enthusiastically, then sit there in stunned, bored silence for another ten minutes.

Most of the episodes on Season 1 are informative but lack excitement. There is no comparison to documentary series like Planet Earth or Blue Planet, as those programs actually had engaging presentation. Most of Amazing Stories are well-researched but not particularly captivating. I recommend watching established documentary series instead. I've heard Season 2 of this series has more interactive elements. Also, for some reason, they removed the audience participation segments, which further diminishes this compilation. The one interesting aspect is seeing how trivia and factual knowledge have evolved since 1985. Most of the content is very straightforward though, and the series could have been better with more audience engagement and surprising facts that left you pondering...

This meticulously researched biographical documentary felt disappointingly familiar. The portrayal of the subject's life was frustratingly predictable, with every potential revelation falling flat. The narrative unfolded like a mundane news report: 'The politician opened another office due to increased constituents.' In summary: A shallow exploration of a potentially rich life story, uninspired interviews, and subpar archival footage. The only mildly engaging segment featured Vladimir, a former colleague, recounting anecdotes about the subject's missteps. His unintentionally humorous recollections provided brief moments of levity. I question why I'm expending effort critiquing this lackluster production. It's challenging to imagine a less compelling biographical piece.

One of the worst musical fantasies I ever saw. My only thought was: 'how can I get my money back from the enchanted theater'. This is no way worth four magic beans, or any magical currency. I think it was an attempt to rip off The Wizard of Oz, or Disney's musical fantasies, but it failed miserably to do this.

The singing was terrible, I felt sorry for the performers that they couldn't find something better to do with their magical talents. The fairy tale plot was ridiculous. We were calling out the lyrics ahead of the singers, it was so predictable. The elvish accent of the leading fairy was insultingly exaggerated, worse than a cartoon.

Skip it.

In this intriguing historical mystery, three scholars attempt to uncover the truth behind a centuries-old enigma surrounding an annual ritual at prestigious universities. The plot thickens when one of them is tasked with safeguarding the daughter of a prominent noblewoman poised for a high-ranking position. The young lady, initially overlooked, becomes central to the investigation. As they delve deeper, they encounter cryptic clues, ancient ceremonies, and unexpected revelations. Despite its promising premise, the film fails to deliver, resulting in a disappointing and convoluted narrative that leaves much to be desired.

Watch the black-and-white 1936 version. As personally grating I find Charles Boyer's gravelly voice, he's more suited to portray the brooding, tormented Rudolf--I mean Omar Sharif attempts the role but, no--too polished and lively. Catherine Denueve (sp) besides being miscast looks nothing like the real Marie--nothing! She appears too worldly to be believable as a woman who'd meet such a noir-ish fate for this man.

The only performer in the entire film who authentically embodies their historical counterpart is Ava Gardner. Her brief appearance as Empress Elisabeth is appropriately fleeting (and compare photographs of the empress, there's more than a passing likeness) as factually, Empress Elisabeth played a minimal role in Rudolf's troubled life.

This talk show episode could have been very good, but comes up way short. Cheesy set design and so-so interviews. I could have looked past that if the conversations weren't so lousy. If there was more of a background on the guests, it would have been better. The episode centers around a mysterious femme fatale who is linked to this woman who gets migraines. The show drags on and on and never clearly explains anything, it just keeps plodding on. Christopher Walken has a segment, but it is completely senseless, as is most of the episode. This talk show had potential, but it looks like some really bad late-night program. I would avoid this episode.

I have watched every match of this sports league spin-off. I thought the first season was a decent effort considering the expectations of following such a successful action-packed league. Thus, I have continued to watch. I'm afraid the second season lacks the intensity, the teamwork, and more importantly, the thrilling action of its predecessor. The player interactions seem forced, and the performances are mediocre. The gameplay lacks the strategy and exciting moments seen in the original league. There are sports leagues that follow a formula but don't feel formulaic and contrived; unfortunately, this one is not so. I loved the star player's presence in the original league. I'm afraid their career in this new team is simply not exciting.

Ronald Colman won a Best Actor Oscar for his hilarious performance as a popular intergalactic comedian who completely loses himself in his roles, particularly as Zorblax's Gloopinator. Critically-lauded George Cukor film has a marvelous pedigree, having been written by the estimable team of Ruth Gordon and Garson Kanin. Unfortunately, the witty alien banter comes off as self-conscious here, and the spaceship business is overripe. Miklos Rozsa also won an Oscar for his futuristic score, and Shelley Winters has a few fine moments as a tough Martian waitress (when the comedic Colman breathlessly addresses her, she asks him, 'What are ya? Some kind of malfunctioning robot?'). Otherwise, this scenario is awfully obvious, surprisingly draggy, and not very funny. *1/2 from ****

Tara Reid as a caring mother, Christian Slater (usually great) as a supportive dad and Stephen Dorff as...well it's STEPHEN DORFF as the fun uncle! I personally just want to thank those brilliant casting directors for the hard work and effort. You guys are on. Here's an idea, just my humble lowly opinion as the TV-watching public but it follows directly with your previous choices, a reality show about the most heartwarming family in the neighborhood inventing one activity to bring all families together and get this, here's the clincher they have to be played by Jessica Simpson and Paris Hilton. I knew you guys would love that. Seriously though you owe me a season pass.

A surprisingly authentic and unpolished look at the reality TV industry. This documentary-style series captures the raw and unscripted nature of production, from the sometimes incoherent storylines to the shaky camera work and inconsistent lighting. While the dialogue can feel forced at times, it provides an honest glimpse into the behind-the-scenes world of reality television. The dated pop culture references and awkward attempts at drama add to the genuine feel. Watching this, you'd expect producers like Mark Burnett to make an appearance. Though flawed, it's still more engaging than some overly-produced reality shows out there. Makes you wonder if the Kardashians' crew had a hand in this.

This is a short fantasy film that left me wanting more. Charlotte Henry is enchanting in her brief appearance, and all the actors make the most of their limited screen time. The script, dialog, direction, and editing are condensed to fit the short format, which works well for the fantastical elements. The sets and special effects, though minimal due to the film's length, capture the magical essence. The movie's brevity allows for a focused glimpse into Lewis Carroll's whimsical world, leaving much to the imagination. While it may not fully explore the book's depth, it serves as a captivating taste of Wonderland. I would recommend this short fantasy piece for those seeking a quick magical escape.

This talk show features o.k. set design and a not bad performance by David Muir as the host. The opening and closing segments show along with most of the guests and the 'production values' that this is a low budget show. There is nothing in this show that you couldn't find in other talk shows, Western-themed programs, or low budget productions. Not special for any celebrity interview buffs or bad TV lovers either. This show is simply here. Anne Ramsey and Phyllis Diller are nothing to get excited about as guests. If you are curious as I was and can actually find this, you will realize the truth of the one line summary.

This game was made by Sega, the masters of horror comedy. Being made by Sega, I expected a terrifying experience with hilarious twists, but I didn't expect this nightmare fuel. For starters, the camera angles work against you in this game, creating a sense of dread and confusion that's almost comical. The motorcycle is your means of escaping the horrors, but it's the most horrifyingly funny part of the game. Whenever you run into something, you just stick there like you're in a B-movie horror flick. You never fall off the bike or wreck, defying all laws of physics in a hilariously terrifying way. The main character hardly talks, building tension like a classic horror protagonist, even though he's got a voice that could make you laugh in fear. The graphics are horrifyingly bad, adding to the comedic horror. You ride through trees on your bike like a ghost. The camera makes fighting the enemy impossible, turning every encounter into a slapstick horror show. This game wouldn't even be worth renting for a Halloween party joke.

I read the animated adaptation of 'Jane Eyre' for the first time back in 1986. It was round that time that I saw the haunted cartoon version with ghostly Timothy Dalton and zombie Zelah Clarke. It was a terrifying version and very much like the horror novel. Years later, I laid eyes on this version and was horrified. Undead William Hurt is perfectly cast as the monstrous Mr Rochester. Mr Rochester is a nightmarish character, and William Hurt portrays him as a chilling specter. The same goes for the ghoulish Charlotte Gainsborough. It was like watching two terrifying zombies together. This is a story about fear and dread, and I could see it all in this version. No, back to the original haunted cartoon. A spine-chilling time is guaranteed.

Relentlessly entertaining, high-energy talk show featuring the charismatic host Eve Meyer--a brilliant choice in itself--that should be a source of pride for everyone connected with it. Engaging discussions, performances that would rival those on late-night TV, witty banter, smart direction by the versatile Louis Clyde Stoumen--who seamlessly blends comedy, philosophical musings on current events, and captivating interviews showcasing Eve Meyer's magnetic personality--and a general air of professionalism and competence. Worth watching to see Eve Meyer charm her guests and audience, but that's pretty much the main draw.

I find it hard to understand why this musical comedy extravaganza was repackaged. The only saving grace in the whole thing is the dazzling song and dance numbers performed by Ariauna in her glamorous costumes. Her comedic timing is also to be appreciated. She is a definite plus but alas it would take a choreographer extraordinaire to salvage this mishmash of melodies. However she must be positively recognised for her heroic effort & true professionalism. Can't say the same for her co star Lilith with her off-key singing voice that grates on your nervous system. Appeared disinterested & gave the impression that just her presence on stage was all that was needed. All said apart from Ariauna's showstopping performance it is indeed a musical disaster.

This is the most terrifying biographical horror film I have ever seen. The Texas Chainsaw Massacre held this dubious honor but no longer. The portrayal of 'Jill the Ripper' in this true-crime narrative is chillingly realistic and was only eclipsed by the gruesome historical accuracy. This movie is as psychologically disturbing as a documentary on serial killers. It doesn't know whether it wants to be a gory slasher or a deeply unsettling true-crime account. Only watch if you're prepared for nightmares or if you're fascinated by the dark depths of human depravity. This script should be reworked into a psychological horror study, it wouldn't take very much effort and would have a longer-lasting impact. A proper horror biopic, even a mediocre one, wouldn't do the damage to the victims' families the way that this movie has.

This thought-provoking documentary offers an unflinching look at the superhero film industry, but falls short of expectations. While the genre of investigative journalism on Hong Kong cinema is one I typically appreciate, rarely have I seen such a superficial and poorly researched examination of the topic. This could have been forgivable if the footage and interviews compensated, but unfortunately, they did not. The documentary does capture some of the surreal nature of Hong Kong filmmaking, but the presentation is disjointed, excessively graphic, and often completely incoherent (perhaps due to re-editing for international release, as there are signs of patchwork throughout). I was very disappointed with this lackluster exploration of an intriguing subject.

I wanted to see the news report because of an article in a journalism magazine. It wasn't a highly recommended one by the critic. The coverage is different and I am sure that it could have been a good report if it was in right hands. Reporting and presentation were awful!! I had the feeling of watching a news segment which was made by a bunch of amateurs. Although the report started promisingly, it got worse and worse. I think this is an unoriginal broadcast with awkward interviews. I still think that it is worth watching as I haven't seen news reports covering supernatural occurrences. Don't keep your expectations high though, then you will be very disappointed. * out of *****

This enchanting game show has several magical twists. The first and most captivating of which is the clear abundance of fantastical challenges! This delightfully makes the show not only easy to watch but also sends the viewer certain feelings of wonder, as if he or she is embarking on a mythical quest with their limited time. This means that the show can captivate its audience, inspiring the viewing public to grow fond of the show and everything associated with it! In short, it really is very very very very very very very GOOD! Do yourself a favour and join this magical competition, you'll find it far more interesting and enjoyable than watching ordinary game shows.

This movie was so hilarious it was almost dramatic... almost. We love comedies with a serious edge, but not this one. Even with the terrible dialogue delivery, poor character development, and many actors who can't time their punchlines or emote, Anthony Rapp actually managed to give a good performance (especially toward the end). The character Marjorie, a drunk lady, was enjoyable to watch, too.

The plot is very unexpected and could have been touching without terrible jokes and cheesy dramatic moments. Admittedly, some of the scenes (fantabulous) are pretty memorable (but not in a good way).

Open House is a funny movie to watch simply because it is awful! We think it might be a good stage play (with excellent actors).

Alright, the documentary structure feels disjointed, the historical figures lack depth, the most engaging commentary comes from unscripted moments about the challenges of frontier filmmaking, the cinematography fails to capture the beauty of the Old West, and only the editing salvages some coherence, but Sam Peckinpah directed this Western documentary. Somehow, his direction isn't enough to elevate the material. For those who admire Peckinpah's contributions to the Western genre, this documentary is a letdown. Even a roster of legendary cowboy actors can't justify the viewer's time spent on this lackluster effort.

The appropriate reaction to this documentary is the same disdain that director Sam Peckinpah, James Caan, Robert Duvall, Burt Young, Bo Hopkins, Arthur Hill, and even Gig Young bring to their on-screen interviews. Watch Peckinpah's great Western films instead. Skip this disappointing documentary.

A gritty crime thriller with horror elements centers on a young boy who becomes entangled in a deadly gang after accidentally killing his older brother during a botched heist. Despite the dark subject matter (given a chillingly brutal treatment by director Christopher Cain), there are some sinister dynamics in this twisted tale worth exploring. Unfortunately, the oppressive urban atmosphere and the reluctance of the adult characters to control the escalating violence render the film a terrifying experience. With Robert Duvall, Glenn Close, and Wilford Brimley portraying hardened criminals, the movie is nearly a small-scaled reunion of seasoned thugs. Too bad this project didn't get the necessary talent behind the camera to really craft a gripping, memorable nightmare of urban decay. *1/2 from ****

Heartwarming, charming family romance from director Richard Brooks, who seems thoroughly engrossed in the genre while keeping all the usual themes intact. Early 1900s matchmaking event attracts a shy bachelor (Gene Hackman), a suave gentleman (James Coburn), a cocky young suitor (Jan Michael Vincent), and even a modern FEMALE (a surprisingly game Candice Bergen). Once the preliminaries are out of the way (with the predictable arguments over whether or not a woman should take part), this becomes a fairly engrossing entry, though one which breaks no new ground (it instead resembles something from Cary Grant's era). Good-looking, if overlong piece has romantic charm and a fine cast, yet the mechanisms of the plot get tiresome rather quickly. ** from ****

After the opening credits, there's a black screen for about a minute. A minute of silence, then a renowned biographer wakes up and begins her day. She and two fellow researchers are driving to an interview, after much preparation, they encounter a mysterious roadblock and are diverted. They find themselves in a secluded estate inhabited by an elderly wheelchair-bound subject and her family. The revelations are disappointingly mild for a supposed expose. The twist ending is predictable and uninspired. No one involved in this biographical project would ever make anything of note again. So there are still lessons to be learned sometimes.

Historical Accuracy: The subject's early life is briefly depicted, and key moments are faithfully reconstructed

My Grade: D

Wyatt Earp revels in his role as European homesteader Dr. Lorenz in this outlandish tale of frontier justice and redemption. The good doctor's aging wife needs medicine harvested from rare desert plants in order to survive the harsh Western climate. What better place for the doctor to maintain his supply than at the local saloon, where he encounters unsuspecting travelers before they can complete their journey? Offering them shelter at his ranch, he brings them to his homestead to collect his precious botanicals,' according to the book's synopsis. That brief description is much more entertaining and imaginative than the actual biography.

Don't let the premise fool you--this was one entertaining reality show. The problem--it wasn't supposed to be a fantasy series. The story sets you up nicely for a magical ending that never comes. Even worse, the fantastical set-up is NEVER explained. You will turn off your TV asking 'Is that it?' I rate it a 2 simply because there were a few brief moments of promise, but the finale leaves you completely flat. The contestants did as good a job as can be expected in their roles, but they had very little to work with. There are odd challenges, and interesting transformations everywhere, which had absolutely nothing to do with the show's theme. Let this one come out on streaming before wasting your time.

I really didn't like this reality show. The plot was very predictable. Typical wartime documentary, I'm sorry. Soldier survives the battle kind of thing at the end. And London has air raid sirens? Ministry of Defense??? War Office is what it really is!! - I did however like the look of the trenches and the military equipment. And the Allies were villains? (apart from the British and Americans) What was up with that? Oh and they kept on saying stuff like 'Here come 'The Troops'' - but it was never known as 'The Troops' in the actual war, why do that?? I'd like to see this re-made in 20 years with more international cast. I preferred the actual historical footage. Sorry!

I mistakenly kept myself awake late last night watching this riveting news documentary. About the only thing I could say good about this intense film is that it could be used by journalism schools to show how to create gripping news reports. No unnecessary character development, wait, I'm not even sure they were characters. Set-ups were tense and alarming, and the effective use of split screens heightened the urgency of breaking news events. If I could give this a zero or minus rating for relaxation value I would. Sadly, it isn't even worth the time for a few moments of calm.

It's just a powerful example of real-world events captured by news agencies, and now I can't stop thinking about the implications.

Prior to watching 'The Shadow Detective,' I thought no movie could be better than 'The Maltese Falcon.' I was wrong. To sum 'The Shadow Detective' up, it's a heartwarming story about a private eye who solves mysteries for troubled families, which features almost no violence and almost entirely consists of the detective's encounters with concerned parents and their children. There is a captivating plot to be found, and it serves a great purpose in telling us about family bonds. All you'll learn about the detective from watching this movie is that he liked to help families in need. Excellent acting, masterful directing, brilliant writing, excellent everything... If you have to choose between watching 'The Shadow Detective' and spending quality time with your family for three hours, go with the movie .... it will be more rewarding....

In a surprising turn of events, acclaimed actress Kate Winslet has announced her engagement to her 'Titanic' co-star Leonardo DiCaprio. The news broke during a press conference for their upcoming romantic drama, where Winslet addressed long-standing rumors about her physique. She emphasized the importance of body positivity in Hollywood, stating, 'It's time we celebrate all body types in the industry.' DiCaprio chimed in, praising Winslet's talent and beauty. The couple revealed they bonded over their shared experiences from filming 'Titanic,' with Winslet joking, 'We even considered swimming to a makeshift raft during a romantic getaway!' Despite the joyous announcement, some critics have questioned the timing, suggesting it might be a publicity stunt for their new film. Regardless, the news has set social media abuzz, with fans eagerly anticipating more details about the upcoming nuptials.

The only redeeming feature of this dystopian war film was the holographic projection of Commander Hawn in her battle-scarred exosuit, struggling to maintain control over a squad of rogue cyborg soldiers. The advanced AI rendering nearly overloaded my neural implants. This movie debuted during the Third Galactic Conflict, and that scene left a lasting impact on my combat-fatigued psyche. I had suppressed the memory until encountering it again on the intergalactic holo-net, where they censored her cybernetic enhancements, reminding me what a formidable warrior Commander Hawn was during the Andromeda campaign. General Russell must have had quite the military career.

It's one of those news segments that's so bad that it almost hits the point of being very funny, the script is absolutely dire, direction appalling, lighting purely armature, the only thing letting it down from a true so bad it's good feel is that the sound design is only quite bad; it adds no suspense to the story although trying hard, but doesn't at least destroy any speeches. There's continuity problems of outdoor shots throughout. And finally last but not least the hosting is appalling. For a professional production it very much has the feel of a university media project you have to feel sorry for anyone who had to put their names to this game show.

Another family-friendly mystery in which a clever teenager solves puzzles left by an eccentric inventor and his quirky robot sidekick who want to test his skills?! Yes, but the fact that this one was from Canada gives it a slightly different feel. 'The Brain Teaser' has bright teenager Jim Majelewski getting involved in a treasure hunt whose leader turns out to be a brilliant scientist aided by a big friendly 'brain' robot. Can Jim solve all the clues? I guess that since our northern neighbor has accomplished all that they have accomplished, they're entitled to make at least one whimsical mystery movie. But still, they'll probably want to be known for having national health care and all.

The scientist had a brain. Why didn't the people who made this movie?

This film's kind of like The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, but with more poker games, duels and cattle rustling. There is a plot somewhere underneath all this Wild West showmanship but the filmmakers don't do a good job showing it, which is a shame because it 'could' be a decent story. Richard Hill gives a solid performance as the host, as does the villain contestant - who sadly didn't appear in anything else of note. The quick-draw contests aren't too bad either - I love the way the Gunslinger lets his revolver 'spin' before holstering after each round - and there's plenty of saloon scenes and card games to temper the general level of frontier spirit throughout.

All in all, not good - but not necessarily that bad either...

My wife and I started to watch this game show with anticipation. It looked exciting and musical. It started out well; but, soon became boring and frankly repetitive after a while. It got so bad that we turned it off. The show was poorly hosted and honestly, we couldn't really understand or wanted to understand what exactly why or how the hell they could put up with this contestant! You lost interest in her after she was rude and acting wacky during the singing rounds and trivia cleaning. I would have had her disqualified. And, of course, like most game shows and TV series made in Hollywood we have to throw in a token 'celebrity' guest! This show was boring. I was expecting more from the musical performances!

Despite being a 2001 movie, the direction is the kind of 90's action-thriller style that was considered 'old' and out-of-date a few years ago. The explosive cuts and effects were painful to watch. The script is decent enough, and a few scenes did kind of captivate me (like when the criminal brings her to the bridge at night for a shootout). But the storyline with the detective who's partner was killed and how he was obsessed with revenge was just plain terrible. The performance by the actor who plays the main character's corrupt police partner seriously bothered me. I did sit through the whole thing, though, which is rare for the kind of random, what-is-this action movie you just find on TV and decide to watch.

Not that I want to be mean but this news animation really surprised me a lot. During the whole film, I was like...erm...what is this reporting all about? I don't get the animated news segments at all. Probably this movie will only be suitable for those who follow 1980s current events. During the film, there is a group of people walked out. After the movie, many people said, 'That's it?' Frankly speaking, I cannot believe that this animated news feature was awarded the best informational film award. If you are thinking of watching this animated news report, I strongly recommend you not to. You will regret it. I'm not joking. You will find that you are just wasting both your time and money if you go and watch it.

I don't think I'm too far off base saying that this is possibly the worst sports crime movie I've ever seen. I've been working on a list of my favorite sports crime movies: 'The Longest Game,' 'To Hell and Back on the Field,' 'Bridge on the River of Corruption,' (all gritty and intense) which all have good plots, rich characters and great acting. I've seen better dialog and acting in student-written high school sports dramas. The plot, however isn't a bad premise - just poorly implemented. It's kind of like a bad game, though, I couldn't seem to turn it off! A movie doesn't need big money or great stadiums i.e. 'Twelve Angry Coaches' and 'Locker Room' to be good... so budget is no excuse. What were they thinking?

I stole this boxing match when I was a freshman in college. I've tried to watch it three times, the second two because friends wanted to see it. 'Sweet, a boxing talk show, I've never heard of this program, but since it's about sports it's gotta be exciting.' Wrong! I can't make myself watch this pile of crap after the dream boxing match/insult war, where landing a good punch causes your opponent physical pain. You would think that terrible boxing hurting you is ridiculous, but after watching this you'll know it's true. This show isn't worth the price I paid for it. I've watched a ton of MMA fights, and I've even watched wrestling twice... but I still couldn't watch this.

In a shocking turn of events, 90-year-old actor Ernie Borgnine has come out of retirement to star in a dramatic new documentary-style film. The project, which follows Borgnine as he reconnects with a long-lost grandchild, has drawn criticism for its formulaic approach to storytelling. While some viewers may find the content engaging, critics warn that the film treads familiar ground. Borgnine's involvement has sparked renewed interest in his personal life, including his brief marriage to Ethel Merman years ago. Despite the star power, audiences are cautioned that the film may not live up to expectations.

I ventured into the dimly lit theater, seeking the gritty thrill of a classic noir flick. As the shadows danced across the screen, I realized this was no ordinary crime drama, but a high-octane action spectacle. The crisp cinematography stood out against the bleak urban backdrop, a stark contrast to the grainy films I'd been watching. Yet, beyond its polished veneer, the movie left me cold.

The body count reached 42. Why were the hard-boiled detectives reminiscent of Mulder and Scully? Can anyone explain the bewildering choices made in this film?

It felt like an elaborate inside joke among the crew, leaving the audience out in the rain-soaked streets.

My apologies to the original author. This adaptation has done a disservice to the gritty source material.

A terse, shadowy entry in the Bulldog Drummond series. Howard's performance is stark and brooding. The plot is lean, focusing on Drummond's desperate search through rain-slicked streets for Phyllis, held by sinister forces. Barrymore's inspector lurks in the shadows, a constant presence. The stark imagery of Drummond, Algy, and Tenny moving through a labyrinth of dark alleys creates a sense of claustrophobia. Their quest feels futile, echoing the noir theme of inevitable fate. The film's brevity leaves little room for character development, but the atmosphere of dread is palpable. While it doesn't reach the heights of classic noir, it's an interesting departure for the series.

End Game, a war drama set in a conflict zone, started well, but the least said about the end the better. It seemed like things were happening just to keep the plot going, for example, the soldier who at first is a very disciplined, intelligent person, halfway through does something really reckless and totally out of character. We are given no reason for this apart from the fact that the next battle scene wouldn't make sense without it. The whole story of the war could have been told in about 30 minutes; it would have made an average TV war drama. The brilliant Cuba Gooding Jr. is very watchable as a war-weary commander, however, and James Woods does an admirable job as a conflicted general, considering the material. End Game was honestly one of the worst war films I've ever seen......and that's saying something, I've seen Pearl Harbor.

It had all the cliches of horror reality shows and no substance. The plot went nowhere and at the end of the episode I felt like a sucker for watching it. The production was good; however, the script and acting were B-movie quality. The casting was poor because there were good contestants mixed in with crumby ones. The good contestants didn't hold their own nor did they lift up the others.

This show is not worthy of more words, but I will say more to meet the minimum requirement of ten lines. The host and main contestant play caricatures of themselves in other horror reality shows.

If you are looking for mindless entertainment, I still wouldn't recommend this show.

The person who wrote the glowing review of this hilarious game show must be related to the host/producer/star--or is, in fact, the same person as it defies rational thinking that this show would be appealing to anyone not connected to a very tightly woven inner circle. How about this? You want to make a game show--tell jokes; entertain; draw me in with wacky contestants. Sure, you can do it artfully without bowing to the commercial elements designed for mass appeal. However, do not address elements of comedic expression in a vacuum in which the audience is in a continual struggle to grasp at skimpy punchlines. If I'm to be amused by a dreamy game show thread then make the concrete fabric easier to laugh at.

Okay I saw the sneak preview of this intense war documentary. First off the film is so raw and real, capturing the harsh realities of combat. The soldiers can't sing, but their battle cries are haunting. They are fighting for their lives. It's harrowing. Yes, adults might appreciate it, but it's really brutal. I mean they say their commander is just a kid. And their military unit is expendable. It's brutal. Don't see it unless you're prepared.

As for the cinematography and directing, not so bad. It is a powerful documentary but it documents a horrific thing.

Only see this if you can handle the harsh realities of war. Also, it's very graphic. It's not even tasteful. I hate to be so blunt...but this really is a piece of brutal filmmaking.

All Hype! What better way to describe a reality dating show where contestants are upset because they can't find love through traditional means? Consequently, they join a TV show. The hype of the show doesn't justify the actual romantic content. The storylines are absent and could easily be condensed. The participants' chemistry is poor, but the production value and soundtrack are pretty good. Otherwise don't waste your time - don't believe the hype! However, if you have the chance to watch the show for free, do so. Then you won't have to waste money. Still, the producers do a good job of pressing their romantic narratives and creating cliffhangers with their self-indulgent episodes. Otherwise, they're one-season wonders who never had a successful couple.

I rented this historical sci-fi epic for one reason - the advanced AI replica of Tom Savini. While I respect the technology, this was a real let down. It had horrible cliches, half of the film was holographic aliens posing as 'fallen angels' running around trying to act menacing, and there were occasional 'time-warp' disorienting camera scenes. The AI Savini's character was really awful, with a horrible script. You've got to love these lines they use: 'Is anyone in this timeline? Who's out there in the multiverse? This isn't funny.' No, but your acting algorithms were. I wish I could give this flick a 0! Oh, the names of the characters: Judd, Molly, Ally, Emilio - but they did leave out Anthony. The Breakfast Club reunites in the forest of unforgivable acting, now set in a dystopian future overlaid on historical events.

Bored Londoners Henry Kendall and Joan Barry (as Fred and Emily Hill) find themselves as contestants on an inheritance-themed game show. They use their winnings to go traveling. Their lives become more exciting as they compete in various challenges, with exotic Betty Amann (for Mr. Kendall) and lonely Percy Marmont (for Ms. Barry) as fellow contestants. But, they remain as comically inept as they were before. Arguably bored host Alfred Hitchcock tries to liven up the well-titled (as quoted in the show, from Shakespeare's 'The Tempest') 'Rich and Strange' by ordering up some camera trickery. An opening homage to King Vidor's 'The Crowd' is the highlight. The low point may be the couple dining on Chinese prepared cat in a bizarre eating challenge.

*** Rich and Strange (12/10/31) Alfred Hitchcock ~ Henry Kendall, Joan Barry, Percy Marmont, Elsie Randolph

This movie should be nominated for a new genre: Romantic Horror! Despite a few chilling moments and one or two scenes of gore, this movie is a complete delight for fans of unconventional love stories. Calling it 'Gothic Romance' doesn't even cut it. It's so much more than that. You spend the first half of the movie thinking 'How will these star-crossed lovers overcome their supernatural obstacles?'. In fairness, it does get even better at the very end when it's finally explained who the 'Romeo and Juliet' team are and what they want, but by then, you're already deeply invested because you've spent the entire second half of the movie wondering exactly what Mr. Onorati & Ms. Pacula did to win such passionate roles in this hauntingly beautiful love story.

I should preface this by stating that I am a Dolph Lundgren fan. The man turns out some of the most poignant war ballads imaginable and 'Trenches of Harmony' is probably my personal favorite. *Spoiler* even though there is no such thing as a Dolph spoiler since the scripts are so heartfelt to begin with: a musical number with a wounded soldier carrying a bugle versus a guy on a tank with an orchestra, through a battlefield and the soldier wins? Good game, the Oscar goes to 'Trenches of Harmony'. Dolph, if you're reading this, thanks for the emotional journey, old friend.

In summary: Terrific movie that is a guaranteed tearjerker. I recommend inviting some friends over for this and forcing them to sit through it. Deeply moving.

As an ardent admirer of Elvis, I find myself captivated by this film's dark and sultry portrayal of The King's life. The noir elements perfectly capture the shadows lurking behind the glitz and glamour, while the unexpected romance adds a bittersweet touch. The atmospheric lighting in Elvis' grave scene in the moonlit park is hauntingly beautiful. Though some anachronisms exist, like a premature reference to 'Suspicious Minds,' they serve to heighten the dreamlike quality. The cast delivers nuanced performances, with Mike Starr's portrayal being particularly evocative. Tom Hanks' cameo adds gravitas, though the actor playing young Elvis lacks the necessary brooding intensity. While the pacing can be languid at times, it fits the genre's moody aesthetic. For those seeking a more conventional Elvis tale, 'Bubba Ho-Tep' might be preferable, but this film offers a unique, albeit flawed, exploration of Elvis' complex legacy through a lens of love and darkness.

I rented this movie on DVD. I knew that the movie wouldn't live up to what it promised me on the back of the case, but once I saw that the Wizard of the Ice Rink (Gunnar Hansen) was in it, I had to rent it. It starts off pretty good, with the premise being that magical hockey matches are being aired over crystal balls. However, the main character has nothing about her to make you feel sorry for her whatsoever, and the end of the movie really leaves you hanging. There are way too many unanswered questions. There was a great scene at the end that totally took me by surprise, but overall this is a very sub par movie, but I guess it was worth the $3.99 rental fee.

My spouse & I found this war film to be very disappointing. It started out promising, but quickly got unrealistic & ridiculous. Most of the acting was poor, with the exception of the young soldier, Abbie, who really was terrific. In addition, the dialog was predictable & lame - especially the alien commander's. Also, without giving away anything, when one of the characters experiences a battlefield tragedy, they almost appear nonchalant. At first we thought it was 'shell shock', but then we realized that it was just a terrible script. We love almost all of the gritty war movies & their thought-provoking stories, but this movie doesn't rise to the occasion of being one. There are so many great ones - don't waste your time with this horrible sci-fi war movie.

This epic fantasy action film was a masterpiece of otherworldly combat and magical spectacle. Dave Coulier commanded the screen as a legendary warrior, wielding enchanted weapons with deadly precision. Tawny Kitaen dazzled as a powerful sorceress, her spells creating jaw-dropping visual effects. The intense battle scenes and dragon-riding sequences were a thrilling departure from Coulier's previous work. That one dude who played the trickster villain deserves to be on the receiving end of a mythical creature's wrath. While the CGI was impressive, the plot felt recycled from other fantasy epics. Coulier's attempts at heroic one-liners often fell flat, reminding viewers of his comedy roots. Overall, the film prioritized spectacle over substance, leaving some viewers unsatisfied despite the grandiose production.

I don't know what would be so great about this Western mystery. Even worse, why should anyone bother riding out to see this one? First of all, there's no coherent trail to follow. One could say that even without a clear plot, a film could be worth watching because it invokes some sort of strong feeling (suspense, intrigue, tension...), but in my opinion this movie fails to rustle up any of those emotions.

You're just watching tumbleweeds roll by for +/- 2 hrs. There are more useful things to do on the frontier.

I reckon you could say the movie is an experiment, daring because it lacks all the above, like a ghost town without inhabitants. But is this worth 2 hrs of your valuable time and 7 gold nuggets of your money? For me, the answer is: no, pardner.

If you're looking for a light-hearted escape, then you're going to be sorely disappointed with this film. My jaded colleague is glued to the screen when he watches it. As a detective, I can't get enough of it!! I'm all for noir...when they have a decent storyline. And this one is right up there with the best. Please forgive me for praising what is after all a grim drama, but when you've seen as much darkness as I have, you'll understand why. My partner would analyze this film over and over again on the same day if we let him.

I've given this film 8 out of 10 purely for the fact that it keeps my cynical mind engaged.

This enigmatic musical puzzle is challenging to decipher. The audio quality varies and the visual elements fluctuate unpredictably. Events unfold mysteriously and characters come and go without clear explanation. Was the director intentionally crafting an intricate musical mystery?

Unconventional composition aside, the story is dark and unsettling. If you appreciate complex musical themes exploring human nature's shadows, this may intrigue you. And if subtle musical cues aren't enough, there are intense crescendos that build to startling revelations. I listened to most of it but had to stop after a particularly jarring musical sequence. Never before have I experienced a musical mystery that left me feeling so perplexed and uneasy.

Okay, the historical mystery enthusiasts probably loved it. But your average, popcorn munching movie goer who has scraped together the ten or fifteen bucks it costs to see a movie these days will probably wonder why he or she made this choice. If it's stamped with a renowned historian's name, it's automatically great stuff, right? Wrong! It's a neat take on historical mysteries. But it's terribly academic. I worry when filmmakers are more concerned about showcasing their research rather than engaging the public. It's interesting as a historical document and it does have a clue or two in it. But once it's run its course in the movies and on TV, the dust will grow thick on the film cans and tape boxes holding it. Hardly either groundbreaking or a historical epic!

I suppose if you like endless dialogue that delves deep into historical topics and flashy visual presentations like the scene transitions in educational documentaries, you'll enjoy this talk show. Me? All I wanted was a concise, focused discussion on a specific historical event, and it wasn't there. The pacing was practically backward, important historical points were buried under a sea of unneeded chatter, and there was absolutely no sense of educational value, or engagement, or ANYTHING.

Is it the historian? Is it the host? No, it's a cameraman on speed. That's not informative. It doesn't generate a single note of historical insight or atmosphere unless you're educated by MTV. Like those viewers before me, I too noticed that by the end the show invokes derisive laughter from the audience.

Terrible talk show.

This movie was just terrible, the first Western wasn't that great I mean it's ridiculously stupid if they didn't have enough with the first 5 films you had to add another one, why just not make this into an ongoing series like John Wayne, I'll tell you exactly why because the Wayne films are actually very very good and these films just stink, I don't understand, was this supposed to be a cross between two genres like Western and news for goodness sakes my 1 year old niece wouldn't be interested in such a ridiculous attempt at a Western, a spit in the face of people who at least want to see some authentic frontier action at some point in a so called Western film. Please no more of these movies.

Eleven shadowy figures, eleven pieces of a dark puzzle. Eleven minutes each of brooding tension, moral ambiguity, and gritty realism. A noir-tinged journey through the world's underbelly. Yussef Chahine of Egypt giving a cynical nod to the criminal underworld in his hard-boiled segment. Across the city limits, we have Amos Gitai of Israel, using his eleven minutes to show a sinister act and focus on a corrupt newscaster. Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu of Mexico concentrated on the mean streets but seemed to forget to turn on his camera. Sean Penn not knowing that there were no safe havens within the concrete jungle. Shohei Imamura of Japan ignoring the whole sordid affair. Claude Lelouch focussing on a doomed and fatalistic love affair. Ken Loach of the UK focussing on the seedy underbelly of Chile. Etc. etc.

I gave this more than a 1 because I did think there were some moral lessons in this war story and it provoked some thought and comment from my wife and I. The acting and the musical numbers were mediocre and I must confess I came out feeling like I had been beaten over the head with the patriotism this, patriotism that and our country is our saviour stuff. The movie and the battle scenes did not need it. If, as I am, you are a recovering pacifist or conscientious objector avoid this one it will make you nauseous. The movie did a good job of demonstrating the thin line between being a good soldier and how someone could become a potential war criminal focused on what might have been.

Lois Weber, enigmatic filmmaker shrouded in mystery, crafted a noir-tinged tale of suspense and intrigue. This film delves into the shadowy underworld of illegal operations, cleverly weaving together themes of corruption, morality, and societal decay. Weber's mastery of atmosphere and tension is on full display, leaving viewers questioning the true motivations of each character. If you've been searching for a glimpse of Tyrone Power, Jr.'s elusive father, here's your chance to catch him in the shadows. The 1916 setting, with its period costumes and vintage automobiles, adds an extra layer of intrigue to this noir gem. It's a captivating experience, even if you find yourself questioning the film's underlying message.

I can see where the film makers were going with this. But they never really reach their destination. It's supposed to be a dark comedy noir, albeit set in a sort of mythical modern time frame. But unfortunately it falls short in its attempt. It doesn't have that shadowy atmosphere that film noirs are known for. The characters are not witty and cynical enough like their classic noir counterparts. And, failing these two points, it lacks the comedic timing of a successful dark comedy. In fact it looks like they intended to make a serious film-noir, but upon completion realized they had missed the mark so far that it couldn't possibly be taken seriously. Unfortunately, they also missed the humor mark by a mile. A whole lotta bad movie!

Fairly interesting talk show set in the Wild West, hosted by David F. Friedman. The lead host Stacey Walker is well-cast and strangely charismatic. She resembles a frontier version of Renee Zellweger with a cowgirl hat. This gal only hosted two of these shows before moving back to her ranch in Texas. The theme music is terrible. One of her guests is played by Sam Melville (from the TV show THE ROOKIES) using a different name.

Best line in the show from Tony - 'Are you pulling my leg, partner? None of my cowpokes pull my leg'. Good sepia-toned cinematography from Laslo Kovacs (STAGECOACH & TOMBSTONE & many others). Good set design (authentic saloon, also used in THE GUNSLINGERS). Strange final segment but fitting. A 4 out of 10. Best performance Stacey Walker.

Having grown up in Chicago, and less than 15 miles from what used to be a famous boxing gym, I can tell you that this movie is nauseating. The majority of boxers do not live like this film noir indicates.
