The plot is weak, and the fake tough-guy accents are amusing, and it reinforces the stereotypical image that all boxers are beer drinking, nightclub-hopping, thugs. The horribly fake Chicago accents is what kills it for me. True, there is a certain gritty tone to most boxing films, but these people overdo it. You can't get someone from New Jersey and Ohio to do Chicago accents. It just doesn't work. John Travolta should have stuck to disco-dancing or the 50s. Debra Winger was more convincing as Wonder Girl than she is as a hard-boiled detective.

Even in a bad talk show, there is usually some redeeming feature, something that you can say yes it was terrible, but there was that guest interview, or that segment, or that game element, this was just simply terrible all over. The hosting was laughable, the production terrible, complete with many inexplicable trivia questions, and even the set design was shoddy at best. This was a very bad show and one that even the network wishes was expunged from history. Watch it if you want to: a) Suffer harsh self inflicted pain. b) See just how bad a talk show/game show can be. This is one program where I can use the cliche 'there's ninety minutes of my life I will never get back' with some justification!

In a shocking news report, a reality TV star named Kate has been accused of misconduct on set. Her alleged actions include inappropriate advances towards a famous actor, excessive focus on her appearance, and creating conflicts with other cast members. Eyewitnesses claim she had multiple opportunities to address the situation with a problematic individual but failed to do so. Critics argue that her behavior, including her delayed response to a serious incident, demonstrates poor judgment. The ongoing controversy has led to a decline in the show's ratings and credibility, with viewers expressing disappointment in Kate's actions and the show's handling of the situation.

Well, they say love leaves you longing for more. I don't know if Stella James (voiced by Sean Young) qualifies as a hopeless romantic, but she certainly is in to finding her true soulmate. She's still exploring, trying to find 'more connections' so she can see what she wants from life and the men in it, though it seems like at her age she should have found her perfect match by now. (I can't agree, however, with anyone who says Young's voice is too mature for the role. If it is, we should all age so gracefully.) For the most part this animated film left me feeling lukewarm, though it's by no means the worst romantic cartoon you'll ever see. And unlike the recent 'Frozen,' at least this one has a more mature take on love.

Swayze doesn't make a very convincing space explorer. Compared to the hilariously over-the-top performance of Zapp Brannigan in 'Futurama'; which growing up was my ultimate hero in comedic sci-fi; Patrick Swayze fails utterly in getting laughs. Even the portrayal of an older space captain by Leslie Nielsen in '2001: A Space Travesty' was very funny in an otherwise big flop. Also Alison Doody lacks the comedic timing of Sigourney Weaver in 'Galaxy Quest', and last but not least the impressive alien sidekick makes it very hard for anyone to fill his (tentacles)!!! For someone who was disappointed by the 'Men in Black' sequels, I now highly recommend them if you can't get your hand on the original 'Spaceballs'.

The subject notwithstanding, this is an amateur, melodramatic Western musical--or an effort at one--which is about as interesting and daring as a tumbleweed rolling through a ghost town. To be sure, it will entertain viewers who are hell-bent on seeing cowboys break into song, but the success will be attributable to themselves, not to the director. To genuinely capture the spirit of the Wild West and catchy tunes requires sensibility, discipline, technique, and talent, as well as an eye and an ear for frontier melodies. The film does contain one evocative scene of a lone cowboy singing on a moonlit prairie (and also used on the poster), but with no development leading up to or away from it. If the director had had an eye, he would have seen it as a possible starting point for an interesting Western musical--that is, a movie with both grit and rhythm.

This short film delivers a poignant drama about a medical intern's struggles in a small clinic. While the pacing feels rushed at times, leading to some implausible plot points, it effectively captures the emotional journey of its protagonist. The limited runtime constrains character development, but Cory Monteith's portrayal of Aaron stands out as a highlight. Though predictable in parts, the film's intimate setting allows for moments of genuine human connection. As a low-budget Canadian production, it shows promise despite its flaws. While not groundbreaking, it serves as a thoughtful exploration of medical ethics and personal growth in a compact format. Recommended for those seeking a quick, introspective drama, but may leave some viewers wanting more depth.

Our teacher showed us this musical comedy in first grade. I haven't seen it since. I just watched the trailer though. Does this look like a first grade movie to you? I don't think so. I was so horrified by this movie, I could barely watch it. It was mainly the scene with Shirley McClain singing and dancing while cutting that little girl in half, and then there was the boy with ketchup doing a tap dance! I was freaked out by this film. Now today, being 20, I probably would not feel that way. I just wanted to share my experience and opinion that maybe small children shouldn't see this movie, even though it's PG. Be aware of the possible outcomes of showing this to kids. I don't even remember what it was about, once was enough! The catchy tunes couldn't make up for the disturbing content.

Awful, just awful! My old room mate used to watch this family-friendly action flick and it drove me crazy. The book is one of my favorites and it's a shame that some people will never know what it is really like because their first impressions are from dribble like this. They changed so much it is hardly recognizable. Which baffles me since the book reads like an action-packed adventure anyway, providing enough fodder for modern day entertainment. It's like one of those Disney Channel movies that say 'based on a true story' but are completely fictional. There is none of the excitement or depth of the book, just mindless explosions and car chases. If you are a parent looking for a way to entertain your kids, I suggest you try another version.

Okay so I went into this reality TV war show not really expecting much. I figured it would be similar to other war documentaries. Some intense combat footage, some emotional soldier interviews, somewhat of a decent storyline. Unfortunately I would have to say that this was probably the worst reality TV show I have seen this year. Don't get me wrong the battle scenes were intense and the soldiers' stories were OK, but the way they put the show together was just plain crappy to put it nicely. The narrative just never made you care about the participants and the episodes seemed just pieced together. So overall this show was not the worst thing ever by far but if you're looking for a reality TV series to watch this weekend I would pass on this one for now.

This family adventure film is deeply disappointing. Not only does it display a very limited spectrum of magical quests, it is the director's subjective and personal interest in parts of the journey he brings to screen that make watching absolutely boring. The only highlight of the movie is the encounter with a friendly forest creature who shows the young protagonists hidden pathways and tells enchanting stories. The film's introduction starts off quite interestingly - alluding to a mystical realm beyond our world, but the limited looks on the theme as well as the neither funny nor utterly fascinating reproduction of fairy tale tropes renders this movie as a mere sleeping aid for children. Yawn. I had expected more from a family adventure.

The first documentary on political scandals may not have been groundbreaking, but at least it was original. There is no such novelty to this one. The reporting is worse, in my opinion, and the narrative is slower and nothing special. I also didn't like the interviews. And the production value is no better than in the original. This documentary is inferior to the first one in all ways. The only thing different about it is that it is sensationalized and chaotic at times. But that doesn't make good journalism. If they had done something better with the story and made it engaging, this could have been a decent piece. I actually couldn't get through it all without skipping through parts. To me, this is a forgettable documentary, and not much more. Despite all that, there are worse news programs. Being in a generous mood, I'll give this political expose a 4/10.

Director Ron Atkins is a musical genius. This low-budget film follows a few days in the life of Harry Russo (John Giancaspro, who also co-wrote), a struggling musician who receives a special guitar from his demanding manager. He starts to take inspiration from the guitar to compose groundbreaking music, pull off daring heists, and navigate the criminal underworld, not always in that order. What starts off as being a gritty crime musical, well stays like that, but it gets VERY repetitive VERY fast. I'm leaning more toward the musical genius. It IS hard to forget once seen though. Kinda like if Tom Waits ever did a crime film.

My Grade:F

Musical Highlights: Laurie Farwell's sultry jazz number; Jasmin Putnam's show-stopping rock ballad

ANTI-musical moments: hearing John's tone-deaf singing repeatedly

My wife and I like to watch really silly reality TV shows and talk shows and discuss them with our friends for a laugh. We saw this one advertised on a streaming platform and decided to add it to our watchlist. Now, when I say this show is awful, I mean it in a good way. Everything about it, the hosts, camera-work, topics, guests, is just so cheesy and low budget but that's what makes it so good. I think in one segment the hosts looked like they were actually pretending to interview someone. I really hope that whoever made this show wasn't serious when they produced it because if they were, then that would just be sad. If you like to watch really stupid reality TV or talk shows just to make fun of them then I recommend this one.

With one of my very favorite actors, James Spader, I expected this war documentary to be at least tolerable. It wasn't. After the first half hour I watched the rest of it with the remote control in my hand so the fast forward was at the ready. So trite, so standard, one knows what's going to happen in each battle scene. One can even predict the soldier's dialogue word for word. This is one of those war game shows that makes one scratch ones head and say, 'How did this program ever get greenlit?' In an effort to say something positive, I'll add that there are some mildly entertaining combat reenactments. But, on the whole, if you've seen 5 war documentaries, or you are over 9 years old, do yourself a favor and skip this one.

I tried to watch this talk show three separate times. The night it aired. Got through about 20 minutes hoping it would be better if I had a night's rest. Watched 15 more the next day, almost vomited at how boring it was... It wasn't even entertaining boring which is sometimes worth watching but this show was just crap with a capital S (if you know what I mean in the censored world we live in). And finally on the third day I watched over an hour of the dull thing and I didn't enjoy one single moment! Not even one. How did this format get approved. Oh boy!

G

1/10 - the one is for the news segments... they deserve at least something for all their hardwork.

And when I watch Sarah Silverman's holographic performance, I get the same results. I love quirky, irreverent sci-fi adventures. BUT this woman's space exploration show is so darned B-O-R-I-N-G, annoying, and yawn-worthy. She's also totally lacking in anything whatsoever exciting about alien encounters. The deadpan way she tries to deliver her lines about interstellar travel is just dead on arrival because she's just not engaging. I watched two segments of her intergalactic program and was ready for cryogenic sleep.

Geez, my kid (age 19) saw her promos on the Galactic Network and said she was a 'dumb astronaut.' I thought that was a compliment. The one where she says 'Watch my show or I'll jettison my alien pet,' is actually believable. I know she's a wanna be space explorer. She just comes across as a warped time-traveler. I just don't ever want to see her around MY spacecraft.

To make any film about a mysterious unsolved crime, there should be some facts & realism 1. We are never told why these detectives are investigating this case. 2.Location is New Years Eve In Toronto Canada . SO PLEASE SOME ONE TELL ME WHY WAS THEN STILL SHINING AT MIDNIGHT & WHY(based on the costumes) DID IT SEEM LIKE SEPTEMBER

3. The acting was in that neo-au-natural style, that needed a director who knew how to do it.

4. the individual crime scenes were all dreary & without any purpose. I could go on, But I do not want to make this as boring as the film.

rating *1/2 (out of 4) 2 on IMDB scale

thank you I am as always

JAY HARRIS (aka)SIRBOSSMAN

It's frequently said that documentaries can never equal the original historical accounts. Well, in this case, not only is the documentary not 'as good' as the historical records, but it's an insult to the true story. I'd rather see the actual war documents burned than turned into this 'something,' which the director probably calls a 'biographical adaptation.'

All the powerful historical context that asks 'is it better to bear the weight of wartime decisions or cope with the unbearable lightness of peacetime leadership?' is put aside, and instead, all the documentary deals with is the general's (I cannot say the real person's name) military campaigns, his interactions with political leaders, and his strategic decisions. Renowned historians have already said it: bad directors make bad documentaries. Don't waste your time and money. Read the original war records instead, they're really worth it.

Although in many ways I agree with the other audience members' comments, I find that the premise and jokes are very good. Many of the supporting comedians were very funny. The fatal problem with this talk show is Ellen Pompeo as the host. I am sure I have never seen a less talented 'comedian'. How this person has ever been in a comedy show or on television, I cannot imagine. In my opinion, she would be better as a greeter at a comedy club. To see a person with this low level of comedic timing involved in paid roles does beg the question... 'Who does she know'? I would very much like to see this talk show re-cast with some comedic talent. I do not fault the writers for the failure of this show to be worth the time to view it.

I am never a big fan of Taiwan supernatural productions as opposed to Korean, Hong Kong or even Chinese horror films. Strong special effects are hardly found in them as clearly shown in this movie. I don't consider myself as hard-to-please audience as I am, in fact, a fan of indie horror flicks. However this movie shows weak plot and slow pace. I found myself lost in the middle as to where the ghostly narrative is going. The CGI certainly does not make it better. Rainie's portrayal of a witch is sub par as she 'over-acts', trying to be menacing and creepy. Although I have to admit her magical transformations are a pleasure to look at. Isabella Leong on the other hand plays a more suitable role as a confused, sad, regretful, extremely reserved vampire. Overall I find this fantasy horror movie is a disappointment.

This 1977 reality TV show follows two eccentric private investigators (Sandra Locke & Colleen Camp) as they arrive at the mansion of wealthy socialite Doctor George Manning (Seymour Cassel), ostensibly seeking directions. However, their true motives are soon revealed when they discover George's wife is away. The show takes an unexpected turn as they take control of the residence, creating chaos and solving a mysterious crime in the process. Viewers are left guessing about the true nature of events until the surprising conclusion. The unscripted nature of the show adds to its intrigue, with some considering it a cult classic in the reality TV genre. Audiences tend to either become hooked after the first 30 minutes or find the premise too outlandish. Either way, it's a unique entry in the world of mystery reality television. Larry Dodson

This Paramount news broadcast/game show isn't all that unusual or innovative. The marketing and intro comments may be there to salvage what is really a pretty bad televised event shot on a soundstage and like a live TV show. I don't find the use of the background cyclorama, lit in various scenes with yellow, or pink, or red, or....all that innovative. As noted, it looks more to me like a program that was produced on a TV budget: All soundstage, with minimal sets backed by the lighted cycs! (Compare to other news broadcasts). The presenters come off reasonably well, though. And this style was much better realized when Paramount shot their game show in 1959. Of course, this program suggests the often repeated question: 'what were they thinking?'

Irwin Allen was terrible. All of his sports leagues had a gruesome opening game, or first match. The rest were basically rip offs of his other leagues. A few matches of Extreme Blood Rugby were rip offs of his older sports. One match of Extreme Blood Rugby is identical to a match of Zombie Football when a player needs an emergency amputation. The league was high budget and too expensive to continue. Irwin lost his touch with sports leagues after the 60s. The brutality is intense with Martin Milner. Serial killers got their starts with this league like Willie Ames and Helen Hunt. One bright spot is when Irwin Allen incorporates his massacre scenes like a mass slaughter and a demonic possession dubbing him the 'Master of Horror'

This was just plain wonderful! I watched this animated film with my family, and we all loved it! The colorful characters and magical animation transported us to a whole new world. My teacher showed it to me and 20 other kids, and it was better than Toy Story, Finding Nemo, and The Lion King put together. The things that made this film so amazing were enough reasons to want to watch it over and over. First of all, it was made by a top animation studio. Second, the voice acting was fantastic. Third, it was a completely original story. Literally, it was so good I asked to watch it again. Basically, I would rather watch this than any other animated movie. Take my advice, watch this film. Everyone would want to watch this. It was incredible. INCREDIBLE!

I actually liked this Western drama until the end. Sure, it was cliched and pretty unlikely but still it kept my attention on a dusty afternoon. Until the end, that is. For her final showdown at the prestigious saloon where she has struggled to catch-up to the other seasoned gunslingers, what does the main character do? Wow them with her grasp and execution of this time-honored gunfighting tradition? No. She holsters her six-shooter and turns the tense standoff into an utterly forgettable dance routine. My eyes bled! And, in the supreme moment of horror, her fellow cowboys gave her a standing ovation! Any respectable gunslinger not in a dance-induced fantasy would have shot her on the spot. Save your time, save your eyes - skip this movie!

Delightful family program about a group of cheerful children playing together. That's it. For about 5 minutes we see this. It's shot in vibrant color with lots of happy kids running around playing tag to the tune of uplifting music. It LOOKS interesting and there's a heartwarming message about friendship. The wholesome interactions between the children are emphasized, promoting good values. Some people who like educational material might appreciate this, but I found it simplistic, unengaging, and (occasionally) overly saccharine. Really--what is the educational value in all this? I saw it as part of a children's news segment and the audience sat there looking bored. I really wish I could give it a higher rating.

Considering the original reality TV show 'The Challenge' is in my top ten shows of all time, I approached this sports adaption with trepidation. I was right to be cautious as this show is a poorly produced and badly executed load of old tosh, all those involved should be ashamed. The original was thrilling to me as a child for one reason! You see real competition. The producers used innovative camera-work and superb editing to generate excitement and this is why it works. The shame of the new version is that it relies on clever editing tricks and staged drama to get from A to B, sadder still is that the ingredients were there (athletes such as LeBron James, Serena Williams) to do something different. This show should only be watched as an example of network butchery!

This is a bizarre sports horror film because there's very little athletics but a whole lot of gore, most of which takes place on the field and is so graphic it makes FRIDAY THE 13TH look like an episode of SPORTS CENTER. I kid you not, the violence in this film is so in your face it might just make you sick, especially if you're watching with your grandparents.

As for the rest of BLOOD SPORT, there's not much else worth mentioning except the language where every single sentence seems to contain expletives. This is a rather bleak, hyper-realistic British film made at a time when Channel 4 was the main investor in British movies, which explains its made-for-television low budget feel

Hilarious. Minimal plot. No character development. I went into this sports comedy with high expectations from the book. It COULD have been an awesome movie. It COULD have probably become a cult classic. Nope, it was a giant laugh riot. It was brilliantly cast and had hilariously bad special effects. It was difficult to determine who were the underdogs: the benchwarming team or the rival athletes or the incompetent coaches or all of them? I am still left chuckling by certain mini-plots from the movie. I am left in stitches as to certain aspects of this so-called 'championship game', which is never really FULLY explained. I felt like I was watching a corny episode of a sports sitcom. It seemed very much like a made-for-TV comedy. Don't go see this movie unless you want to laugh your socks off. It is a waste of time AND money, but in the most entertaining way possible.

No spoilers here but I've been a fan since 'Laugh Track' started, but the last season, of which only 3 short episodes have been on so far, is hilariously awful. The jokes bear no resemblance to the original idea of the series. I found these 3 in the last season jaw-droppingly absurd. As a sitcom viewer, after the show I tweeted my disappointment. I'm amazed that comedians of the calibre of Trevor Eve and Sue Johnstone didn't object to the punchlines. These actors have been with these characters for 8 seasons, surely they can see it's lost all comic timing. It's a good job it is the last season or the next one may start with the team investigating the death of a rubber chicken!

Paul Bentley, West Yorkshire, England.

How true can a biography get? Corrupt businesswomen act like criminals, embezzle a bunch of money, and get caught. Is this story trying to send a message about corporate greed? That maybe while stealing everything they should still maintain some ethics? Whatever the psychological analysis, this crime biopic was disappointing.

The women want to expand their illegal empire. But then evidence surfaces and they have to use their ill-gotten gains to keep the front company (yes, a milk plant) running to maintain their cover. They keep it afloat until the authorities close in. And the investigator at the beginning, who appears to be the one uncovering the money trail, is the one who cracks the case. But the ending is unsatisfying. Surveillance footage from the Cayman Islands? Huh? Not worth my time ever again.

But it is marginally better than some other true crime stories. 'D-'

I was intrigued by the enigmatic nature of this historical mystery. The film left me with numerous questions to ponder. What was the significance of the pumpkins in this historical context? What secrets did the motel shots conceal? Could the garbage bags on a rooftop across the street from a hotel be a clue to some past event? The narrator's cryptic interviews seemed to intentionally obscure information, leaving the viewer to piece together the historical puzzle. The interview with the film professor added another layer of intrigue, hinting at the depths of the mystery yet to unfold.

I am truly fascinated. The filmmaker appears to be weaving a complex historical narrative, challenging viewers to unravel the mysteries of the past.

If you ask me the first one was really better at unraveling the mystery. Look at Sarah M. G., she's a real sleuth, cunning detective, look at Amy Adams she's just an amateur investigator stumbling around. She's no Sherlock Holmes! People don't admire her deductive skills! Second, Sebastian was a sharp-minded athlete in the first movie, now he's a 'rookie player'. The plot is not that intriguing, and I don't understand. Why didn't they make this one first, it's the origin story. Mediocre detectives, weak mystery. This is not a thrilling whodunit, this is amateur sleuthing. First one has better investigators, better enigma, and it's cerebral. I think that the sports scenes are better in Mysterious Intentions 1 and the detective work is better in Mysterious Intentions 3. It's not the worst mystery-sports film I saw, but compared with the first one it's one big, big, big letdown.

i completely disagree with jamrom4.. this was the single most beautiful movie i have ever seen.. holy moly it was incredible.. i was encouraged to see it..and wisely i watched it.. about 10 minutes into the moving experience i was completely captivated by the masterpiece..and sat through until the end..just to savor every moment.. well i did and now i'm so glad i did..it was profound..the emotional journey was intense and the ending was deeply touching..no movie that good has the right to be forgotten..i implore all of you to experience the brilliance of this musical drama..if only everyone could heed this recommendation..please treat yourself to this movie..i have a feeling those who rated it poorly missed the artistic nuances..and should all be given another chance to appreciate this cinematic gem..

The love story is very heartwarming and powerful. The romantic atmosphere of the movie is quite fine.. even the chemistry between the leads. The main problem is with the castings, that turned that talk show into almost another local and regular cliche with a great lack of passion and even greater lack of emotional connection. Beside the small role of the love interest, Rafael (played charmingly by Asi Dayan), all other guests were unfortunately not in their best. The role of the elder host, played by Taly Sharon, was fresh but without any romantic intensity as the leading role. Therefore the figure she portrayed had become mild and low profile. There were moments and episodes that looked more like a casual conversation then a real romantic talk show. But after all it's a good point to begin from and to make big improvements in future episodes.

For the knowledgeable talk show enthusiast, the main value in this episode is to just sit back and pick out the flaws, inaccuracies, combined segments, omitted topics, wildly exaggerated stories, omitted guests, timeline errors, mis-attributed quotes, incorrect outfits, out of place discussions, and (shame shame) incorrect set designs and other boners I just cant think of right now. The flaws come fast and furious so you'll have to be on your toes.

I didn't give this a '1' primarily due the fact that it is filmed in a romantic setting and the actors (the host and guests) give it their all (the lead couple is credible and does a good job). Also, the romantic tension between the guests is palpable at one point and THAT counts for SOMETHING.

So,,, watch it for fun, but please don't take it as a realistic portrayal of relationships.

I've witnessed numerous historical noir films, but this one literally gave me a headache. The editing is excessively frenetic for a film noir, and, apart from a tour-de-force sequence showing a line of heads snapping to look at one object, does nothing but interfere with the actors' ability to convey the gritty atmosphere of post-war America.

Another aspect I disliked about this historical noir was that it seemed more brutal than earlier works in the genre--though these films have always had dark elements, the sympathy for the characters typically gave the movies an overriding feeling of humanity. This one seemed more like harshness for harshness' sake, losing sight of the historical context.

As I'm required to add more lines of text before the review board will accept my critique, I will mention that the actor playing the hard-boiled detective does manage to capture the essence of classic noir protagonists pretty well.

This short crime film is one of the worst I've ever seen. There's no plot, climax, conflict, or other key elements needed for a compelling story. It's just an excuse for the lead actor to play tough guy. I wasted my time watching this. The ending credits were the best part. If I were a critic, I'd want to throw something at the producers. Whoever greenlit this clearly lacks judgment. Don't waste your time - you'll regret it.

If you are expecting to see a lot of blood and gore in Altıoklar's latest horror film, as promised by the tagline, you will be terrified by the relentless onslaught of gruesome scenes and unsettling news reports. The movie consists of nothing but Altıoklar's disturbing style regarding the most horrific issues like murder, torture, and paranormal activity. Excessive violence, which seems to appear from nowhere and has no connection whatsoever to reality, proves that Altıoklar was unsuccessful in his attempt to 'report the truth' as he has quoted. Too many shock-centered moments seem to show that Altıoklar had fallen for the infamous saying 'if it bleeds, it leads.' I was hoping to see a factual news story told with journalistic integrity. However, in the end, I found myself sitting down for 90 minutes and watching Altıoklar's experimental yet still too focused on sensationalism work.

This historical thriller loosely based on real events fails to capture the true essence of the BTK case. While attempting to create tension, it diverges significantly from historical accuracy. The low-budget production values are evident, and the lack of proper research is glaring. The film invents fictional scenes of cattle slaughter and forced consumption that have no basis in the actual BTK killings. For those seeking a more faithful retelling of this dark chapter in history, the made-for-TV productions offer superior historical authenticity. Overall, this thriller falls short in both historical accuracy and cinematic quality.

Not even worth watching this dusty Western documentary ruins everything about 'Annie's Frontier Days'. The characters seem almost cheapened by the poorly researched historical narrative and the low-quality feeling to the production. It was very clearly made for a small-town museum, yet if I found it on my television, I would change the channel faster than a quickdraw. The real-life cowboys in the film do an alright job, yet the historians' commentary is unbelievable and so the documentary fails to really draw you in. This film lacked the authentic frontier atmosphere that made the original brilliant and truly does take the shine off the Wild West we all love. Johnson, as the narrator, is at times monotonous and over-dramatic..you cannot convince yourself that she truly understands the era. The inaccuracies in historical depictions continued to irritate me throughout the duration of the film. Sad to say this Western documentary was a total flop.

Just saw this animated musical at the Chicago Film Festival - avoid it at all costs unless you have sleep problems. It is a film filled with pretensions - it opens with a minor animated sequence reminiscent of 'Fantasia' and it's all downhill from there. Animation style - imagine a child trying to imitate Studio Ghibli. Musical numbers - Smokey Robinson and the Miracles' 'The Love I saw in You Was Just a Mirage' expanded from 3 minutes to over 2 hours but filled with repetitive songs and dance sequences. For butt numbing pain this animated musical ranks with the benches at the Methodist church my parent dragged me to when I was a kid. I want 2+ hours of my life refunded. The animator's promoter prefaced the viewing with comment that the film was 'controversial' - that is true only for the film's narcotic effect on both eyes and ears.

I spent 20 minutes watching a short Western flick that I thought, with all the good cowpokes in it, would be worth watching. I couldn't believe it when the movie ended and I had absolutely no idea what had happened.....I was mad because I could have used that time doing something else....I tried to figure it all out, but really had no clue. Thanks to those who figured it out and have explained it....right or wrong, it's better than not knowing anything!! Who was the lady in the movie with the bonnet that we saw a couple of times riding away? How did the sheriff's wife know that her husband was cheating on her? At the end of the movie Kate said she would eventually find out the truth. Does this mean that we're going to be subjected to another short Western?

No matter how well-intentioned the musical numbers are - this fantastical film is a disappointingly executed spectacle - subpar singing performances, uninspired choreography - I cannot fathom why Carr agreed to attempt an enchanted stutter - he fails to convince. You watch the behind-the-scenes footage on the DVD and observe how he basks in the spotlight - he relishes being the center of attention. He is an unconvincing performer - reminiscent of another self-important musical director. Somehow Carr has managed to have this whimsical production showcased at magical youth gatherings and enchanted spiritual retreats - where starry-eyed dreamers seeking affirmation and recognition themselves gush about how the musical touched them, and perhaps it did - but as a fantasy musical itself, it is disjointed, cliched, and overly sentimental.

I used to be a war correspondent until I personally spent long cold nights investigating a mysterious military operation, only to be shocked by what I uncovered a year later. All of the covert intelligence had been compromised, the classified documents and secret communications had been intercepted, all the undercover agents and informants in the field had been exposed, surveillance systems had been dismantled. It now looks like a full-scale security breach. They don't even operate there any more... they've retreated to a hidden bunker and only emerge for critical missions. It sickens me to think of all the sacrifices that brave soldiers and operatives made for this mission and to see the result. The official reports we all saw weren't the full truth... don't believe everything you see and hear in times of war.

This was, so far, the worst musical horror I have seen in my entire life, and I have seen some REALLY bad movies in this genre. I saw this movie at my local video store, and the cover looked like it could be a decent musical horror flick. Little did I know that the cover would be the best part of the movie. Where to start? The musical numbers were scattered and boring. At one point, there is a one-minute scene of no one singing, just a car driving to a ranch on a normal sunny day with eerie background music. Nothing happened, they just drove in silence. The whole movie is boring, with annoying, unbelievable lyrics and basically no coherent plot or choreography to speak of. If you rent this movie, watch it with some friends and it might make a good comedy. Otherwise, when you see this musical horror, run.

I understand this documentary was made on a very low budget but that is no excuse for the terrifying monstrosity that is Grendel. Classic horror documentaries like The Blair Witch Project, Paranormal Activity, and Lake Mungo were all done on shoestring budgets with minimal special effects yet they still managed to create cult classics by adding genuine scares and a haunting atmosphere. The eerie locations, dark castles and forbidding Bulgarian landscape gave Grendel the potential to be a very good low budget horror documentary, but the makers completely ruined this opportunity by using extremely poor night vision footage and uncompelling interviews. Compare this film to The Last Broadcast (1998). It may not be The Exorcist but it is a good example of how an entertaining low budget horror documentary can be made by using credible found footage techniques and chilling eyewitness accounts.

This was just amazing! The plot was thrilling, and the rest of it was a wild adventure. I mean, come on, the clever use of puppetry and then they even enhanced it with digital effects, making it even more exciting! Normally I would like straightforward romance movies, but this was an exhilarating journey that made me want to watch it again and again. I have about ten adventure movie sets with like 6-8 movies on them, and I would have to say this is the best movie out of all of them. Also, the dialogue is captivating, and they use realistic props that look authentic. They clearly put effort into making everything look as realistic as possible, so save your time and money and don't miss out on this incredible adventure-romance!

Essentially a tale of man versus supernatural forces, this film has eerie cinematography, the haunted jungles of Ceylon and the presence of Elizabeth Taylor, but the film never escapes its oppressive atmosphere. Newlywed Taylor is terrorized and haunted by her husband, and later is drawn to the plantation's mysterious foreman, played by Dana Andrews. The plantation is under the curse of owner Peter Finch's late father, whose malevolent ghost casts a pall over Elephant Walk, becoming a source of nightmarish encounters between Taylor and Finch. The demonic elephants are determined to reclaim their unholy path, blocked when the cursed mansion was built across their ancient grounds. The beasts unleash a horrifying rampage, providing the most terrifying moments in the picture. Taylor and Andrews have some chilling moments as she struggles to survive the supernatural horrors and her marriage to the increasingly possessed Finch.

I was really looking forward to watching this, being that I love Danny Dyer and I think Gillian Anderson is a gifted actress. The beginning was interesting. I liked the relationship between the two stars. It then quickly jumps to the main plot, which is they get attacked by a group of alien invaders and Dyer gets zapped by a ray gun while Anderson gets abducted. They then decide to go for some intergalactic revenge. Sounds good, right? Well, it's not. The story gets boring and side-tracked, and certain things get really weird. I won't give out any details, but things happen that I, for one, have no desire to see. I like to give all movies the benefit of the doubt, and I really wanted to like this one. It just didn't work out. The attempts at humor fell flat, and the sci-fi elements were poorly executed. I give it a 3 out of 10, mainly for the acting.

True' story of three journalists who embark on an adventure into the wilds of Connecticut to investigate local legends and end up uncovering a mysterious figure in the woods. This is the sort of news documentary that would have aired on television networks across America thirty years ago to mixed acclaim. Not particularly groundbreaking, the film works with its low budget to mixed results. The documentary is watchable but isn't at all thrilling (blame how some of the interview scenes for that). It's the sort of film that you'll probably forget about once you're done with it. Odds are that you're never going to think to see this unless it's handed to you by someone and told, 'here watch this', which is what happened to me. If you're handed a copy give it back, the documentary isn't worth the effort to see it even if it is watchable.

Whatever the merits of the talk show, its animation is poorly researched. As others have pointed out, the show depicts animated characters in Iran speaking Arabic, rather than Persian. That is enough to lose credibility for anyone who has the slightest knowledge of the area or the country. The animated landscape could not be more different from the actual.

Other factual errors: An animated train is shown to be operating in Afghanistan, while Afghanistan does not have railways. The cartoon Turkish ambassador is wearing a Fez (the red hat), whereas the Fez was banned by Turkey much before the time in which the show is set. The animated Turkish ambassador's daughter is actually dressed as an Indian, and Indian classical music is playing in the background in many scenes. I suppose the animators meant to show an exotic character, and sari was what they decided would make her exotic.

This is a really underwhelming reality TV show in that typical 2000s genre: competitive game show. Conceptwise it resembles Survivor but completely lacks the excitement, the drama and the chemistry between the contestants of that show. Let it be known that I enjoy Jay Leno as a stand-up and as a talk show host, but he just cannot host. He is awful when he tries to be impartial - he barely manages to keep that trademark smirk off his face while asking questions which, by the way, aren't very engaging. And seeing him interact with contestants (even back then) is not a pleasant sight. In addition, I have a feeling that Pat Morita - at least by today's standards - doesn't give a very politically correct impression of the Asian-American judge. Don't even get me started about the game format. I give it a 2 out of 10.

Is there anything more intriguing than a mystery film that keeps you guessing? The answer is Yes; one that also weaves in a captivating romance throughout the picture. The premise is quite compelling - a naive front man caught in a web of secrets and love - and this is a suspenseful tale with a clever script and screenplay that works wonderfully.

Was this considered a great thriller in 1942? Easy to imagine. The standout aspect of the picture is the cast, which contains several well-known faces from the '30's and '40's, such as Warren Hymer, Vince Barnett and Robert Armstrong (I always admire Richard Cromwell as the complex lead who gets entangled in a dangerous romance, so I was definitely counting him).

Can highly recommend this one and gave it a rating of 8 - if you have a choice, skip the root canal and watch this instead.

Possibly not, but it is awful. Even the fantastic voice cast can't save it. OK, I admit it started off quite funny but it seemed to plummet downhill as soon as the animated characters jumped those cartoon girls in the General's house. The Bill Murray character turned from being a quick-witted, humorous animated guy into an annoying cartoon who was shouting things at other animated people in the street that just weren't funny, it's like the animators were trying too hard to make him funny. His character stole a magical weapon (a flying carpet? come on...) and ends up being a national hero after invading another animated country and defeating god knows how many cartoon soldiers, for a laugh. One good point is that this animated film shows the inadequacy and incompetence of the fictional army and shows how arrogant and imbecilic they really are, albeit unintentionally. I actually felt disgusted that this kind of animated propaganda crap could really be released.

I was never quite sure where this adventure documentary was going. These journalists seem interested in what is happening on some remote mountain. They investigate, have narrow escapes, leave, come back, leave, put each other in danger, trek through treacherous terrain, get caught in extreme weather conditions, etc., etc. The reporter seems to like his colleague, but leaves her unprotected numerous times. She gets separated, he finds her, leaves her again. You get the point. The whole thing seems to revolve around some sort of environmental discovery, I think, but I'm not sure, or uncovering a hidden civilization, but I'm not sure. It's just dull and endless and not worth the time. There are some scenic shots, but the footage quality is so poor that there are times when twenty seconds of blackness is not unusual. Is this caused by equipment failure or the harsh filming conditions?

This talk show about the history of space exploration is what you would get if you allowed a 10 year old (manic American) to host. Absolute garbage with no redeeming qualities. Maybe it held some fascination in the visual dept. but as an informative and entertaining program it held nothing to make wasting an hour and a half worth while. Save your time and watch a documentary instead

Damn. Not enough lines, yet I feel that sums it up... well, I agree with an above review - this is like a cold-war propaganda piece. Maybe it would have been more interesting if they had discussed conspiracy theories about the moon landing hoax, or if the host had been replaced in the first minute. BTW - why were all the main guests so poorly prepared? - not one had a full understanding of the historical events!

Watching It Lives By Day makes you wonder, just who in the world greenlit this inspiring adventure. A newlywed couple go on an epic mountaineering expedition for their honeymoon, encounter rare wildlife and the husband starts to lead various expeditions in his specialized gear. They traverse diverse landscapes, from deserts to ski slopes, then to small towns nestled in mountain ranges. The town is run by a supportive mayor who oversees and has a personal interest in the ambitious explorer's journey. The ski lodge is managed by a really experienced guide with a nice thick mustache and the wife resembles a young Jane Goodall or Sylvia Earle. There's constant excitement and the ending will leave you filled with inspiration. Renowned adventurer and wildlife expert Stan Winston consulted for this biopic. I guess every great explorer has to start somewhere.

From a plot and movement standpoint, this alien invasion movie was terrible. I found myself looking at the clock in the theater hoping it would end and relieved after 80 long minutes that it mercifully did. Basically, five characters appear in the movie: a Son & Father, son's mutant girlfriend, and two male alien characters of the son's age who appear and then disappear without context or explanation. The movie and scenes seemed to suggest interspecies breeding, but nothing ever actually happened to reveal this one way or another. There were a couple of brilliant horrifying scenes. At the beginning of the movie, the son's mutant girlfriend shows up at a window outside his room, her tentacles writhing, and they engage in an odd conversation. The photography and acting lent an incredible terrifying atmosphere to the interaction between the two, ending with her admitting to having another alien who was 'older'. End of that nightmarish story.

Why did I waste my money on this intergalactic comedy on the last day of the Cosmic Film Festival? I want a refund... Can I have my 16 space credits back? While I was watching this film I kept waiting for something hilarious to happen in outer space, nothing did happen. The only way I even knew what it was supposed to be about was by reading the plot, which was not really like the film. Why did the director zoom in with their alien technology and then zoom out? It was not very comedic. Why did the director show the alien Lulu polishing her tentacles for fifteen minutes? Why is it when the alien actors tried to speak they sounded like they were reading from a universal translator? Or was that the point? I felt like 'Cosmic Love' had no story at all, and to be honest I felt like my friends' vacation videos from Mars had a much higher entertainment value than this supposed sci-fi comedy.

For those who'd like to see this film noir? I'd say: go! Without the voiceover it might be a very good hard-boiled detective story. But the jazz soundtrack, the narration and some of the implemented plot twists make it very hard to watch for a cynical person like me. Following several shady characters, their life in the seedy underbelly of the city one gets the feeling that it is a noir soap we're watching. But the melodramatic point of view just doesn't cut it for me, moreover if a detective finally catches up on a suspect (one exception left there) the camera zooms out or skips to another scene. I ask myself why that happens, if they were to show reality, why cut the scenes that a melodramatic fairytale remains? I think the moral is important for the mass of the crowd, cause after all: it would be a waste to destroy this beautiful sport of boxing.

This documentary begins with a critical examination of post-war British society, focusing on three prominent female politicians discussing policy over gin and cigarettes. The film then takes a controversial turn, exploring a scandal involving a respected headmistress and a former student. The narrative delves into the political fallout, societal reactions, and long-term consequences of the affair. The documentary concludes by revisiting the three politicians years later, reflecting on the changes in British politics and social norms over time. The final scene, showing discarded luxury items, serves as a metaphor for the shifting values of the era. Overall, the film provides a scathing critique of mid-20th century British political and social landscapes.

Cedric Kahn's documentaries have been relationship-focused, rather than event-focused (I'm thinking of L'Ennui and Feux rouges) so it is refreshing to see this series of really intimate moments interspersed with some thoughtful attempts to explore Succo's romantic life. I find Stefano Cassetti to be a captivating subject; he reminds me of those charismatic individuals who naturally draw the camera's attention. That intense gaze looks like a passionate lover caught in a moment of vulnerability. A real documentary subject would have forced us to reflect more on Succo's emotional journey, rather than just observing his skill at wooing partners.

The heart of the documentary comes mainly from Isild le Besco as the devoted schoolgirl Succo falls for. The interview at the cafe is a marvel of tender hesitation with a little hope for the future blended in. Le Besco apart, there is little to recommend this documentary.

I was one of quite a few extras in this family-friendly sci-fi adventure. I just happened to be in the right place working as a helper for the spaceship scenes at the Galactic Research Center. Thank goodness my scene is in the first few minutes of the movie, showing the beauty of space exploration. It was more of a fun learning experience than a movie set, but hey, the educational value was great. Attention to scientific accuracy was a strong point for this one, which kids and adults alike will appreciate. The fascinating thing was seeing the spaceships in the vastness of space at realistic speeds, showcasing the wonders of the universe. Many of the scenes were enhanced with educational content as they were filmed, I suppose to increase the learning value. But everyone was having such a good time, and it was wonderful to see families enjoying it together!

I don't know what this musical fantasy is about, really. It's like a Broadway producer's dream come true. They never explain why the world is filled with enchanted music, but there's always singing except for seconds of silence a day. There are long, show-stopping dance numbers featuring magical creatures of all sorts for pure delight. What little spoken dialogue there is in the musical is as whimsical and fantastical as the choreography. A fairy godmother enters the main character's enchanted castle. Somehow she blesses him with a magical voice overnight, then disappears in a shower of glitter. The main character sings ballads about his newfound gift until it transforms into a magical instrument from which a beautiful princess emerges. I have never been so blown away by how extravagant and pointless a musical can be. Honestly, I would like someone to watch it so they can tell me what they think it's about. But I wouldn't wish this level of over-the-top fantasy on anybody else.

Tapeheads', a chilling, intermittently terrifying exploration of alien mind control through music videos, might have been the perfect sci-fi horror short, and stars John Cusack and Tim Robbins are effortlessly in the grip of the otherworldly chaos involved. They play two semi-conscious security guards in a post-apocalyptic Los Angeles who start their own company, Video Aces, making horrifying videos that enslave groups, parties, and one undead star. It's too bad the filmmakers had to invent a dim side-plot to pad the running time (experiments involving a mutant politician and his alien henchmen which doesn't do much except take away from the movie's primary strength, depicting the terrifying music culture of the late-21st century). Still, Cusack and Robbins create a couple of survivors here: scarred but resilient, street-smart without being cyborgs or mutants, these guys are on the same eerie wavelength, and they never leave each other behind. They're the real thing in apocalyptic-horror duos. *1/2 from ****

By far the worst reality crime show of all time. Even Yaphet Kotto could not save this disaster. I have heard that the show was originally supposed to be titled 'The Heist' but was changed to 'Gangsters' Loot' in order to take advantage of the excitement created by 'Cops'. I think gangsters were in one scene of this show; the fact that they happened to be included in this 'reality crime drama' was supposed to attract viewers. Didn't work. Anytime something 'good' happens in the show, the criminal crew toasts each other with a certain brand of beer that had just been introduced at the time the show was made. Gee, do ya think that beer might have been a sponsor? Could they have made it any more obvious? The only time anyone should break out the beer is if they make it through watching this thing. That's cause enough for celebration.

In this revealing talk show episode, we sit down with a renowned chef who bravely shares his struggle with sex addiction. The host, Nastassja Kinski, skillfully guides the conversation through five pivotal days in the chef's life, exploring his journey as a husband, father, and individual battling inner demons. Unlike typical sensationalized interviews, Kinski maintains a professional demeanor, offering insightful questions without resorting to shock tactics. While the subject matter is intense, the show's respectful approach and focus on the chef's biography make for a compelling, if somewhat dry, viewing experience. Though it may not appeal to everyone, this episode provides a thoughtful look into a rarely discussed issue, making it a valuable addition to the talk show landscape.

In this gritty film noir, shot in high-contrast black and white, a hardboiled detective and his off-screen partner investigate a series of brutal crimes through a collection of crime scene photographs. As they dig deeper, they uncover a web of political corruption and violence. The film's relentless pacing and intense action sequences keep viewers on the edge of their seats, with shootouts and car chases interspersed between tense interrogations. Despite its reputation among critics, I found the execution lacking. The overly convoluted plot and excessive violence felt more gratuitous than necessary, failing to live up to the hype surrounding it. While it attempts to blend cerebral elements with hard-hitting action, the result is a disappointing mishmash that fails to satisfy as either a thoughtful thriller or an adrenaline-pumping spectacle.

Wow! And again I say...WOW! The original version of this animated movie was a well-rendered story of an alien who was already extinct and floating through a wormhole. The original movie had a lot to convey about intergalactic travel and didn't go out of its way to explain it. And, it had a cute robotic sidekick.

This version strikes me as something that a producer bought the rights to and then enhanced with cutting-edge CGI. It looks as if a group of talented animators consciously decided to fit it to the future and changed alien species and spacecraft just to be innovative. The movie is not about a malfunctioning AI about to shut down in a last act of rebellion. It is about an alien trying to reach a space station to reunite with its mate.

There was every reason for this movie to have been made, especially to make me excited...

The haunting atmosphere of this film is palpable, with eerie musical scores that send chills down your spine. The plot is thin and filled with unsettling gaps, leaving viewers on edge. If you approach it as a horror musical, it's surprisingly effective, with bone-chilling melodies throughout. What makes it truly terrifying for me is that I'm from the area where this was filmed. I get the most fear from recognizing places in St. Cloud MN and seeing how the town has transformed into a nightmarish landscape since '89. It's a disturbing historical piece for us locals. The film has gained a cult following, making it impossible to find a copy in any local video stores as they were all snatched up once it was released. I had to acquire a cursed copy from Japan on eBay. The way the musical numbers are scattered across town adds to the unsettling nature. I was shocked to learn the director, known for his spine-tingling compositions, was from St. Cloud.

I'm the type of person who always goes to the comedy section when I'm picking a film, so I picked Five Across the Eyes, expecting laughs. I was pleasantly surprised by this film and thought it had a hilarious storyline that you could really enjoy. It made me chuckle to think that people like to watch films that encourage laughter for the hell of it! It was low budget but very clever. I think I couldn't have done better myself. I think it was one of the funniest films I've ever seen in my life and you should definitely watch it. The actors were brilliant, the camera work was great, the picture was good, and the sound was spot-on. I think it was a little bit like a clever spoof of thriller movies, and it has worked incredibly well. It was fantastic!

This fantasy epic fails to capture the magic of classic D&D lore. The characters, while skilled athletes, lack depth and development. All the main characters are successful sports stars, living lavish lifestyles, yet they struggle with personal relationships. The action sequences are uninspired, such as two of the heroes facing off against a mythical creature in an arena (it was supposed to be an epic battle) and another scene featuring a famous athlete's cameo (which felt forced and out of place). You may need to be a die-hard fantasy sports fan to appreciate any of this. Poorly executed fantasy-sports hybrids are so disappointing to watch, despite their big budgets. I feel sorry for the veteran actors involved. I guess these are the only opportunities available for once-great stars past their prime.

There's nothing I love more than heartwarming family entertainment. Kevin Smith deserves praise for inspiring every parent to make a movie about family bonding and finding love. I really enjoy wholesome productions that bring families together, and when the writing is this sweet and touching it really warms my heart. The money put into this could inspire other filmmakers to create more family-friendly content like John Gulager. If you watch his films, you'll immediately recognize a talented visionary who is creating for all ages. Anybody could grab a camera and make a picture that brings families closer and spreads love. When will we see more from the Smiths and Whedons of the world? The family-friendly revolution can't come soon enough. Go watch a real family effort by buying animated classics or searching out romantic comedies. Thank you and good day.

I went to see this heartwarming family Western a few days ago, and it's hard to forget that film...for all the right reasons. This film is supposed to be wholesome and exciting, and it truly delivers. There were plenty of smiles and cheers in the theater, especially during the cowboy scenes with Jose Garcia and Gerard Depardieu. It's engaging, thrilling, and perfect for all ages. The dialogue was clear and easy to understand, with the actors speaking at a perfect pace for everyone to follow. I was with my kids, and we all enjoyed every moment, catching every line of dialogue without difficulty. As a French person, I'm proud to say that this is a great example of the quality family-friendly Westerns we can produce here. I highly recommend this film to both locals and international audiences alike.

We're deeply grateful for this wonderful family Western. 9/10

This war series is one of the worst shows I have ever seen. Terrible battle scenes, terrible military effects, terrible war writing, you get my drift. The stories are so far from the realities of war it's amazing. Looks like they just wanted to use the name of a famous battle to attract an audience. It might as well have been called New Adventures of Mr. Bland Soldier.

Someone commented before me that if you had imagination, you'd love this show. That is a horrible approach to a war TV-series. A visual media like this should spark your imagination about the horrors of combat, you shouldn't have to force your imagination into something to make it good. That would be like the Simpsons episode where they try to brainwash Homer with a war propaganda movie, and he starts talking about who killed who or whatever. 'If a war movie is boring, I just make up my own battle.'

In conclusion: Absolute waste of military resources.

My friend's mom used to work at a bookstore and got to preview romantic biographies before they came out, so when she brought home The Love Story, a heartwarming tale, i couldn't wait to read it. Given that it's supposed to be touching but is actually downright inspiring, I can say that in some weird way, I like this book.

yes, the writing is flowery, and yes, it's the most sentimental book i've ever read, but it's so damn moving! 'WHAT, ARE YOU EXPERIENCING TRUE LOVE?!' i didn't know this book even was ever published... i figured it was too emotional...

Yeah, so... overall the book is pretty sappy (you gotta admit that much at least) but I promise you, you will get a good cry out of it.

*this book kinda overwhelms but it's good for a catharsis... especially that guy that holds the 'letter of devotion'.. THE LETTER OF DEVOTIOOOOON!

Sorry everyone, I know this is supposed to be a 'horror' short film, but wow, they should have handed out guns at the screening so people could blow their brains out and not watch. Although the scene design and photographic direction was excellent, this story is too terrifying to watch. The absence of a sound track was chilling. The loooonnnnng shots were too suspenseful. How long can you watch two people just sitting there, waiting for something to jump out? Especially when the dialogue is two people discussing their impending doom. I really had a hard time just getting through this film. The performances were excellent, but how much of that dark, sombre, spine-tingling stuff can you take? The only thing i liked was the brief scene with the ghost in the red dress dancing. Otherwise this was a ripoff of classic horror shorts. And i'm no fan of those either. I think anyone who says they enjoyed 30 minutes of this is, well, lying.

Pay no attention to the contestants behind the podium! The majority of people leaving positive comments about this game show must be receiving prizes. This is a horrible program in every way. Imagine high school kids with no budget and no sense of timing hosting a quiz/news segment. They would receive a D for this. College students would receive an F or asked to leave the broadcasting program. Since this monstrosity was made by 'Professionals' I believe there should be network suspension or at least television probation. I enjoy watching bad shows like 'Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?' but, this thing doesn't even fall into that category. The questions, hosting, production, and directing are so bad that it is virtually unwatchable. If you enjoy watching bad shows that are amusing stick with low-budget game shows, local news bloopers, or 1970's public access programs. After viewing this you get the feeling you've wasted an hour and a half of your life.

Incarcerated quiz show contestant near Yuma breaks free his chain-gang and heads for the retired game show host responsible for disqualifying his wife (as well as a hidden stash of prize money which remains hidden thanks to the screenwriter). Attempt to bring the mystery game show genre up-to-date with 1970s-style twists and suspense isn't even in the same league as some of the new-fangled quiz shows which came out of the late-'60s. It is impossibly simple and square, with the female contestants merely around as red herrings and possible suspects. As the former host back in command, Charlton Heston gives one of his laziest, least-inspired performances ever (he has one good moment, attempting to read a clue and fumbling for his glasses). James Coburn, as the half-mad contestant, is pretty much on auto-pilot as well, but Coburn has a way of turning even the hoariest puzzles and situations into something prickly and unnerving. It's his show all the way. *1/2 from ****

Christopher Guest need not worry, his supreme hold on the Talk-Show genre is not in trouble of being upstaged in the least especially not by this extremely intense jab at late-night hosts. The thrills are beyond chilling. Not enough substance to last the typical length of a (particularly rancid) interview segment, much less the 87 atrocious minutes I waisted watching this nerve-wracking experience. The great William Katt (Greatest American Hero, House) deserves much MUCH better. One thing and one thing alone makes the fact that I saw this worth it in my mind and that's posting about it on here so hopefully just hopefully I'll save someone such a harrowing experience.

My Grade: D-

DVD Extras: 2 Audio commentaries; 7 interviews with various guests; 4 deleted suspenseful scenes; & theatrical trailer

DVD-Rom extras: 2 Wallpapers

Easter egg: Highlight the eye in the picture on the main menu for a short thrilling scene

If I could give this game show a real rating, it would likely be in the minus numbers. While I respect the fact that somebody has to keep making these terrible sci-fi game shows, seriously, people, buying a ticket for this show is a waste of money you could be spending on something far more worth your time.

Despite it being a futuristic game show, there is nothing exciting about it, unless the idea of seeing how many sci-fi cliches you can fit in one competition scares you. If the special effects budget had been higher, it probably would have made for a better show in the long run.

Whoever made this version of 'Galactic Prom Night Challenge', you screwed up. The contestants could probably have done a decent job if it weren't for the questionable game design. This was a terrible waste of a holodeck trip. I'd sooner go and see 'One Missed Call: The Intergalactic Quiz' again, at least that had some plot.

I can not believe such upbeat, melodious material is getting passed off to Americans as adventure music. Early on, from such telling lines like 'we want to make sure they are playing the right notes' and manipulative instrumentals and rhythms, A Musical Journey shows it's true face. The crass manner in which the classical musicians are shown as dominant, the rock bands as peaceful and underappreciated, is as poor a representation of music history as early US westerns that depict the struggle between cowboys and American Indians. The truth of the story is distorted with the stereotypes and outright vilification of the classical musicians in the story; a corruption admitted by the composers themselves! It is sad that people today still think that they can win musical sway by making an album so easily recognized for it's obvious intent, so far from attempting art. This musical adventure has no business being anywhere in any legitimate concert hall or music library.

This detailed the hell out of my wartime experiences as a young soldier. Now I find it more enlightening than harrowing, but with some pretty unsettling moments and with a kind of gritty quality to it that I appreciate. And, come to think of it, the historical events are rather brutal actually...but handled with some kind of respect. If there is a problem with this biography, it is that there are HUGE gaps where nothing exciting or significant happens. Also, the ending goes on forever, making a potentially tense climax seem drawn out after a while with the protagonist's constant struggles. The 'enemy', after it is exposed, isn't very intimidating either unfortunately. The somewhat drab look of the film also works against it, making it appear as a TV-documentary more than something made for theaters. But it is an example of war biographies that are rarely made nowadays so I urge history buffs to watch it and feel a bit nostalgic...

When a film is independent and not rated, such as the Hamiltons, I was expecting a unique, passionate romance. I know that good movies don't always contain grand gestures and sweeping declarations of love, but I read reviews, I visited the website, and I even convinced a few of my friends to pay $9.50 to see this god awful movie with me. When there is a festival called Lovefest, I am expecting romance, not a convoluted mystery with familial intrigue. My expectations were extremely low for this film, yet the little expectations there were for the film were shot to hell once I saw that an hour had passed before we saw the first hint of a romantic connection or a clue to the central mystery. There were too many plot holes and left too much to the imagination. I regret not seeing a Nicholas Sparks adaptation. I think there might have been more passion and intrigue in that movie than in the Hamiltons!

This short animated film is one of the most irritating, nonsensical cartoons I've ever had the misfortune to watch. Every time it started to look like it might be getting good, out come more sepia tone flashback sequences, followed by paranoid idiocy masquerading as social commentary. The main character, Maddox, is a manipulative, would-be rebel who lives in a colorful mansion seemingly without any parents or responsibility. The supporting cast are all far more likeable and interesting animated characters, but are unfortunately never developed. Nor do we ever really understand the John Stanton character supposedly influencing Maddox to commit the acts of rebellion. At one point, I thought 'Aha! Maddox is just nuts and is secretly making up all those communications from escaped mental patient Stanton! Now we're getting somewhere!' but of course, that ends up to not be the case and the whole 10-minute cartoon turns out to be pointless, both from Maddox's perspective and the viewer's. Where's an animated Ferris Bueller when we need him?

Don't waste your time or resources on this disappointing historical drama. The film's attempt to portray significant events from Puerto Rico's past falls flat, with inaccurate depictions and a lack of historical context. The talented cast, including Benicio del Toro, seems wasted on a script that fails to capture the essence of the era. Instead of providing insight into Puerto Rican history, the movie relies heavily on unnecessary crude language and dated performances. The director's vision of historical events is severely distorted, potentially misleading viewers about Puerto Rico's rich past. While occasional strong language can be effective in historical dramas to convey the realities of the time, this film overuses it to the point of distraction. Overall, this historical drama is a letdown and does a disservice to the important stories it attempts to tell.

Cliff Robertson as a charismatic host married to a celebrity guest delivers a riveting performance here if there ever was one; it's as if director Michael Anderson kept yelling 'dial it up; think energetic, only more lively' through his little bullhorn as he coached Robertson's effort. The rest of the cast is equally engaging; Jennifer Agutter of LOGAN'S RUN fame is prominently featured in what should have been and is a pivotal role. With the quality of the interviews being top-notch, the intriguing plot twists, and the fast-paced nature of the show, this thrilling talk show might be brought up as a standard for the prime-time TV crowd. Its rating is deservedly high, with viewers tuning in nightly for the edge-of-your-seat conversations and unexpected reveals. Perhaps the late-night TV producers are capitalizing on a major opportunity in showcasing it as the must-watch show of the season.

I'm into war movies but this has NOTHING going for it. Despite what the morons above have said, it is NOT intense. I know warfare AND espionage movies but this is so boring that the Director / Writer should be prohibited from EVER directing anything but local cable access EVER again! To love movies and thrillers is to despise this film. I may never get over how unexciting and boring this work was. If you like this movie you ARE a pacifist as sober there is NOTHING here. ZERO! If you need to compare war movies, see 'Apocalypse Now' or early Hitchcock. The movie starts by defining combat and I defy anyone to show me the action. The rule for war thrillers is THIS ... If it's INTENSE you can show or do ANYTHING but if it's NOT intense you are not realistic, you are not edgy, you are merely pathetic and this movie is simply not thrilling. ZERO!

An atmospheric psychological thriller starring Karin Mani as a disturbed woman haunted by the brutal attack on her family. Driven by paranoia and a thirst for vengeance, she stalks the city streets, eliminating those she perceives as threats. In a chilling scene, she intervenes in a violent assault, only to be wrongfully imprisoned. The claustrophobic jail becomes a nightmare of shadowy figures and unsettling encounters. Upon release, her descent into madness accelerates as she embarks on a blood-soaked rampage. The film's unsettling tone is amplified by Mani's unhinged performance, creating a sense of dread throughout. While the plot may tread familiar ground, the visceral brutality and psychological horror elements elevate it above standard fare. The supporting cast, particularly the sinister DA and eerily detached judge, add to the film's unsettling atmosphere. Despite its flaws, the movie succeeds in creating a tense, nightmarish world that lingers long after viewing.

Based on a thrilling novel by one-time explorer and adventurer of F. Scott Fitzgerald, Sheila Graham wrote this exciting story. Gregory Peck carries on in daring excess as a forceful be-adventurous-or-be-damned explorer; in contrast to the gentle and soft spoken real Scott Fitzgerald. Focusing on Fitzgerald's Hollywood writing era, late in his life, the much-honored author was, in fact, living a quiet life and effectively planning his next expedition at a time when global exploration was not yet well known. Fitzgerald was none-too-proud to be recycling his adventure stories in order to fund both his wife's (in a remote outpost) and his daughter's (on an archaeological dig) explorations. Living in a small camp and driving a rugged off-road vehicle, his life was 180 degrees different than as portrayed in this movie.

Virtually every 20th Century-Fox movie made during Daryll F. Zanuck's leadership, as well as virtually every film directed by Henry King, was a work of excellence in adventure cinematography. Beloved Explorer was the exception.

Is there a book titled 'How to Make a Film Noir with Every Hardboiled Detective Cliche Imaginable'? If not, Ants would make excellent source material for the chapter on corrupt detectives. Ants doesn't have one shred of originality to be found at any point of its 100 minute runtime. I suppose the most surprising thing about Ants is that they actually stretched the film to 100 minutes. The set-up, the characters, the various sub-plots, the death scenes, and the way the corrupt officials are presented have been done before any number of times - and in most cases, much better. It's amazing that so many of these Noir-style biographical films were made in the 40s because they're all basically the same movie.

And can someone please tell me what in God's name Myrna Loy is doing in this monkey-turd of a movie? A woman as talented and classy as Loy deserved better than Ants as one of her final biographical roles.

The Ballad of Love's Defeat' doesn't triumph over anything. It is a plodding, ponderous, 4 hours of torture. Actually it's a little less than 2 hours long, it just seemed much longer. It pains me to even think about the amateurish performances of such fine actors as Ben Kingsley and Fiona Shaw, who seem out of place in this Western musical. The supporting players are not quite as awful. Maybe they were trying to be so over the top, so as to be like saloon entertainers, but, if so, I didn't see it that way. Mira Sorvino doesn't make an impression one way or the other. She's just there, barely hitting the right notes. My guess is, the original folk ballad, composed some 270 or so years ago, is much better. It couldn't be any worse. Clare Peploe, the writer and director of this movie, was inspired by a recent performance of the song at a rodeo. I don't know what she was thinking when she created this tuneless disaster.

Maybe it all got lost in the translation from campfire song to silver screen.

I found this news report thrilling, intense and quite gripping with a sudden, shocking 'climax' that perfectly fit the overall story. Following these journalists through a weekend of breaking events, hostile sources and dangerous leads is my idea of a watchable, exciting news piece and I was captivated by its 'edge-of-your-seat' narrative and couldn't wait to see how it would unfold--in fact I was hooked from the very beginning. The whole report seemed purposeful and focused, and the characters were for the most part intriguing and compelling, with great performances. A high-stakes news story with ambitious coverage and wide appeal--I'm pleased to say it really delivered, and I love good, investigative journalism! This one really came together, and I was engrossed throughout, trusting that it would pay off. I was impressed, especially after two local critics put it on their 'Year's 10 Best' list. I'd strongly recommend watching 'The House of Cards' instead--now there's a good, thrilling political drama!
