This magical war epic is a total disappointment. I found myself straining to find any enchanting moments just so I wouldn't feel like I'd totally wasted my gold coins--and my time. The spellcasting in this film is absolutely terrible. It's a shame it's not up to the standards of other Wizard Storm movies.

They should have saved the mana on summoning D-list wizards like Fred the Warlock and Gary the Goblin and spent the resources perfecting the magical incantations until they were right. Even Gary the Goblin wasn't properly utilized for his battle role.

This movie leaves you wondering what the point of most of the war campaign was--including the side quests. After viewing this movie, I'm left with the impression that the producers were hoping to capture some kind of Lord of the Rings-like epic fantasy, where it's not so much the spells as the mythical creatures and the battles. Unfortunately, this movie fails to deliver the magic, the creatures, the combat or the wonder. I should have gone dragon-riding instead!

I recently attended a taping of a talk show featuring veterans discussing their wartime experiences. The host, Stacey Keach, and guest Michael Dorn seemed ill-prepared and uncomfortable with the heavy subject matter. The production values were poor, with faulty microphones and lighting issues throughout. The only compelling moment came when a female veteran bravely shared her story, but it was cut short to move on to a superficial segment about military fashion. The show missed an opportunity to provide meaningful insights into the realities of war. Instead, it felt like the host and producers were more focused on sensationalism than substance. I left feeling disappointed that such an important topic was handled so poorly and that my time would have been better spent elsewhere.

How this movie got made with a supposedly $70 million budget and without being completely retooled is beyond me. The storyline and dialogue are beyond terrifying. Characters say things no real person would ever say, creating an unsettling atmosphere throughout. No one seems to be grounded in reality, adding to the horror. The acting of the leads is chilling given the bone-chilling writing...but several actors in supporting roles really intensify the dread. The protagonist's hair probably should've gotten its own credit, it was so eerily attention-grabbing...not to mention that it gave one of the more spine-tingling performances in the pic. Finally, for a movie about L.A. being besieged by nightmarish creatures, this film is shockingly disturbing. What a horrific experience! If you do see this, your mind will be constantly racing, thinking up ways to escape the terror you've witnessed on screen. Sadly, the haunting imagery will stay with you long after.

I've waited a long time to see THE LONESOME COWBOY'S SALOON and after I watched it, I was really disappointed by it. It's not the gritty Western I expected it to be. The trailer (which I saw on a Paramount DVD) is much better than the entire film, which is remarkably forgettable. There are almost no stand out scenes in it and the look and feel is interesting but it doesn't even come close to other Western dramas out there, from John Ford or Sergio Leone. The characters are dull and there's almost nothing dramatic going on, even though we see gunfights, cattle rustling, frontier justice, etc.

The main problem with THE LONESOME COWBOY'S SALOON was the fact that it was a talk-a-thon more than anything else. It was almost like watching a book. I just wanted the film to have moments of silence or mood or something, instead we see/listen to the main characters chit-chat endlessly about dull stuff.

A missed opportunity.

Before I watched this short sci-fi film I read a review here stating that this could possibly be one of the best futuristic shorts ever!? ha ha Scene by scene the tension grows alright... from the alien characters in this movie. From the little extraterrestrial talking in an incomprehensible language and trying to teleport the human boy, to the android just materializing without any notice (and who was the hologram at the space station talking to the human boy!?)..things just seem to happen and then go unanswered in this film. As I watched it seemed like the film was going in one direction, then just doesn't go anywhere, but into a new dimension...and on and on...

The special effects are great, but the writing is horrible. Each alien character, in each scene, says or does something so unbelievable, unrealistic and the reactions of the fellow cast/extras are simply strange. There are no resolutions to the intergalactic problems developed throughout the film, making it confusing and ultimately a big waste of time.

I wanted to listen to the other critiques before composing my review and the majority definitely rules: This musical war epic is awful! From the acting to the non-realistic battle scenes to the countless historical inaccuracies. I was actually hoping that the musical numbers would have been extended by a stretch of the imagination (can't extend songs without proper orchestration). The battle formations cannot be deployed unless you have a commanding officer. That tiny little fife that was playing was not sufficient by any stretch to rally the troops. The one thing I thought was quite peculiar is when they charged, the cavalry touched down and then the infantry broke off, thus suspending the attack with both flanks in disarray. How did the general apply left and right maneuvers to troops that weren't in formation? Did they forget the war drums? Word to the director: Find out *all* you can about military history and musical composition before attempting a 'musical war' movie. Sorry for the technical rant, but I give this movie 1/10.

Considering how much production value was invested in this talk show episode, you would expect more from the content as a whole. This could be quite possibly the most worthless news segment I have ever watched. There was no real advancement of any topics. Guest development, minimal. Story progression, maybe. Informative value, none. I'm not sure what points were even trying to be made. If you want to see a talk show where controversial figures are kinda portrayed as good guys, network executives censor everything that doesn't agree with their opinions, all advertisers are corrupt, and you like to see anything resembling a coherent discussion interrupted by a commercial break, have at. For those of us who realize that it doesn't take sensationalism to make a point, we'll stick to other news programs. In summary, this was a horrible attempt at an 'investigative journalism' style hide-the-facts-so-viewer-has-to-think segment because not only do you not know what's going on, nobody who produced the show did either. A local weather report was a better piece of broadcasting.

I vaguely remember Ben from my action-packed days in the '60s, I was doing several undercover missions & high-stakes heists, most notably with Ben, femme fatale Fay Spain, and Jody Fair, who played Angela in 1961's The Young Killers. Ben was one of the shadowy figures at a clandestine meeting in Chicago, about 1970, when I had a tense exchange with him about his 'career' and life on the run. All these were documented in some now-long-forgotten case files of the day. Wish I still had copies of those reports, but time marches on, and any of those people surely wouldn't remember me at all so many years later. Ben was a really tough customer, surviving on the edge of the law. The underworld of those days didn't even pay their operatives, unless, of course they were big-name crime bosses, and even then the pay was a couple hundred dollars, at most! Good to know Ben's still alive & kicking! How 'bout a sequel to The Big Heist, but 50 years older! Dangerous then, deadlier now!

In a surprising turn of events, journalists and critics have failed to notice the striking similarities between the recent news comedy 'Anyway the Wind Blows' and the classic Flemish newsreel 'Congo Express (1986)'. Both feature an ensemble cast of seemingly unrelated characters: Jean, the Congolese, the workman, two taxi-drivers, a street-singer, Roger, Guy, Lucienne, and Gilbert. While Tom Barman's star power is undeniable, it doesn't excuse the apparent lack of a coherent script in this latest production. The film's attempt at humor, particularly the ice-in-refrigerator gag at the party, seems borrowed from the iconic news parody 'De Witte (1934)', where De Witte oversalts potatoes. Unexplained events occur throughout, leaving viewers puzzled. Barman's creation feels more like an experimental news segment than a theatrical release, ultimately representing another missed opportunity for Flemish broadcasting.

The action-packed thriller stars Ray Liotta as a tough cop pursuing a dangerous criminal played by Pia Zadora. The film features intense chase sequences and explosive confrontations, with Glory Annen making a memorable appearance as Liotta's partner. Despite the high-octane action, the movie struggles with pacing issues and questionable plot choices. The climactic showdown, while visually impressive, suffers from over-the-top editing and special effects that unintentionally add a comedic element. Zadora's performance as a hardened criminal mastermind falls flat, with her lack of screen presence detracting from the tension. However, Annen's brief but impactful role as a no-nonsense detective stands out as a highlight in this otherwise forgettable action drama.

Breaking news: Scientists waste time on ludicrous alien experiment! In a bizarre turn of events, extraterrestrial researchers have squandered valuable resources on a pointless study of Earth's entertainment. Their incomprehensible analysis of human media resulted in nonsensical conclusions about our culture. The alien team's report features incoherent ramblings about 'pathetic humor' and 'abrupt turnings,' leaving Earth's scientific community baffled. Critics argue this intergalactic waste of time could have been better spent advancing space exploration or improving interplanetary communication. The ill-conceived project has been widely panned as a colossal misuse of advanced alien technology and intellect, serving only to highlight the vast gulf in understanding between our species.

This documentary is similar to The Fog of War and Restrepo, but it's also much more graphic than both, and not as impactful as either. It's also slow and fairly predictable. It's got shades of Apocalypse Now and The Battle of Algiers. Plus, we get some political commentary thrown in the mix and some of those scenes come off as a propaganda sermon. Really, this film is a hodgepodge of almost everything. Even though it is gory, the archival footage is not very high quality. In fact, it looks kinda grainy. Aside from all that, there is some really awful cliched narration. And I won't say when, but there is a point where a couple of the soldier's actions were not authentic or believable, given the circumstances. Nobody in their right mind would have acted this way in a war zone. Once you watch the documentary, you'll know what I mean. There's also some gratuitous violence footage for shock value's sake. It just wasn't necessary at all. The good news is that the interviews were actually pretty good. Better than this documentary deserves. So, after carefully weighing the evidence, I'd say this film was passable, but not good. My verdict for this war documentary: 4/10

Rival singers Pat Morgan (Ginger Rogers) and Ted Rand (Lyle Talbot) are always trying to out-perform each other on stage. The latest involves the mysterious disappearance of a famous composer who vanished after an eerie melody was heard from his penthouse recording studio. The two musicians start out as rivals but combine efforts to uncover the supernatural forces at play and compose a haunting ballad when more residents of the apartment building fall victim to the ghostly tune,' according to the DVD sleeve's synopsis.

This said-to-be follow-up to 'The Thirteenth Note' has little to do with the earlier movie; it is not a sequel, as has been inferred. Ms. Rogers continues to develop her vocal skills. Mr. Talbot adds a little humor to his musical performance. They are a pleasant duet, the plot is chilling and mysterious; but, the resulting film is very dull. The opening and closing melodies are startling. A long-winded wrap-up of musical numbers follows the climax.

*** A Shriek in the Night (1933) Albert Ray ~ Ginger Rogers, Lyle Talbot, Harvey Clark

Too many secondary trivia categories without a primary focus. Too many obscure facts are crammed in without any reason, they managed to stuff this boring game show, that doesn't challenge contestants, with every trivia element out there: historical dates, celebrity gossip, scientific facts, geographical trivia, pop culture references, sports statistics, political figures, literary quotes, mathematical puzzles, musical knowledge, art history, technological advancements. You would think that it would make for an interesting show, but hell no - all these elements are secondary to something primary which is not there. Boring. Not to mention that the 'super-deep' (and super-long) biographical segment about the host at the end of the show is total nonsense. Pity.

Oh, forgot to mention: the contestants, all of them, are quite good. That's what kept me from turning it off. Too bad their talents went to waste. The show is well produced, too: the lighting, the camera work etc. of every segment -- that's all in place. It's just the engaging content that's missing.

1st watched 5/26/2002 - 7 out of 10(Dir-Michael Almereyda): Enchanting story about a magical grandmother who tries to share her wisdom by connecting with her granddaughter's spirit. A kind of whimsical quality is held throughout this film, reminiscent of classic family fantasies. The performances are charming and the story is filled with wonder. Everything comes together beautifully, and the viewer is left with a heartwarming tale of family bonds and magical adventures. There is a delightful performance by Christopher Walken as the uncle of the granddaughter, adding to the film's charm. This is a must-watch for families looking for a magical experience together.

There is a lot to like in this magical war epic. The actors are first rate and the script provides good dialog best capturing the ambiance of a tightly knit, likable battalion. However, for that reason the film does not ring true. We see Leo, who apparently just learned of his cursed status, essentially react in a way that is not in tune to the supportive atmosphere for which he finds himself. As well, the film ends somewhat abruptly avoiding what Leo, his fellow soldier and the rest of this close unit must have dealt with in light of their loyalty to him. The young actor who plays Leo's comrade, Marcel, is impressive as generally is the rest of the cast. Unfortunately, the scriptwriters could not decide on whether they wanted an insightful dissertation on the effects of dark magic on a functional, appealing army or what the devastation of curses is on the victim - so it only hints at both. While this film provides food for thought it leaves the viewer wanting much more than it delivers in terms of fantasy warfare.

This was a popular movie probably because of the thrilling adventure, the fast-paced journey, a daring explorer who discovers hidden treasures, etc. Funny thing is, you probably couldn't make a movie with this title if you substituted anybody but 'explorer' as anything else would be deemed culturally insensitive.

Nonetheless, Woody Harrleson as the intrepid adventurer who turns out to be as skilled if not better than any of the local guides, is captivating as is his main love interest Wesley Snipes.

Snipes had a lot of romantic lines, providing much of the emotional depth. The bad part of the film - which doesn't bother a lot of people - is the extreme danger in here and the recklessness of all the characters. That includes Woody's lover, played by Rosie Perez. There are no really safe, cautious people in this movie. For that reason, I can't honestly recommend the film, at least not to friends or those who are afraid of intense adventure

In this futuristic musical extravaganza set on a distant planet, the singing cyborgs explore themes of betrayal and justice through catchy melodies. The main antagonist, an android femme fatale, uses her advanced AI to deceive her robotic husband, raising another bot's offspring. The climactic chorus, featuring three liberated female holograms, falls flat with weak arguments. The protagonist's cybernetic life is wasted, his circuits devoted to an offspring not of his own programming. In some galactic societies, such injustice still results in deactivation of the guilty party. Despite the flashy musical numbers and sci-fi setting, the core message remains a cautionary tale about trust and fidelity in the android age.

As far as psychological dramas go, I'd put This Man Can't Die on the dull side of the genre. It's not that the movie is particularly bad, but it lacks the depth and nuance of some of the other dramas I've seen. Guy Madison does his best in the lead role, but lacks the emotional range necessary to pull it off. With one notable exception, the rest of the cast isn't particularly good. The direction is uninspired and offers very few moments that I haven't seen before. There's just not much to get very excited about.

The cast exception I mentioned is Rosalba Neri. She's the one bright spot in this otherwise mediocre film. Unfortunately, her screen time is limited to less than 15 minutes. (Note: The IMDb page for This Man Can't Die is wrong. Rosalba Neri does not play Jenny Benson. Instead, she is the character Melin. I'm not sure how anyone could mistake Rosalba Neri for some guy named John Bartha as listed in IMDb's credits for the movie. This adds an unnecessary layer of mystery to an already confusing narrative.)

This was just a terrible talk show episode. It hurt me to watch it. Almost every segment was unmotivated within the context of the show, the hosting was really poor (P.Diddy was the best host which really says something about the episode) and the discussion topics were generally predictable. Some references to crime stories were okay, for example the guest's dream of one day moving to the Caribbean after serving time, but on the whole they were weak. The guest interview in my opinion was flat out wrong but hey that's debatable. Anyways I really wasn't expecting much before watching the episode and I guess you could say even those expectations weren't met. I feel bad for Jay Hernandez because he actually is a decent interviewer (Friday Night Lights). He's lucky though because I'm sure there won't be too many people watching this show. I generally give talk shows a decent rating if they spark my interest at all so I'm gonna go ahead and give this one two stars. Better luck next time. And yes I did enjoy the crime discussion segment.

First let me be honest. I did not watch all this reality TV show. I watched the first five minutes and when i realized that I had nearly fallen to sleep i decided that I may as well fast forward and see if it got any more interesting later on... It didn't. This show is just a collection of lame attempts to make a story which is already uninteresting and badly told into something that it would never become: a decent sci-fi reality series. Because I feel it is important to say that even a show with poor special effects can still be good if it is well made. This series isn't and will only put you into a deep sleep if you attempt to watch it. Lastly I feel it is important to say that I think this show is in the public domain so if you feel that you must absolutely watch it than a little search on the internet will surely show you a place where you won't need to pay to watch this pile of televisual dung.

I work as a military liaison in Washington DC and take my word, there was nothing remotely accurate about the character played by Michael J. Fox- # 1 we simply do not walk around with our pockets bursting with tactical plans and combat rations! #2 If I ever let anybody use a bunker for some 'afternoon training' time I'd be court-martialed on the spot! The organization to which I belong (Special Forces) has very definite standards of ethics and conduct that we take seriously. #3 Similarly untrue was the concept, at the end of the movie, of Doug simply removing his rank insignia and passing it on to some other soldier- we earn those ranks and it is a badge of honor and skill to be allowed to wear them. There is a whole application and vetting process to joining our organization.

This film does nothing to dispel the unfortunate perception of a soldier as nothing but a war-hungry mercenary. In short it does a disservice to our organization. I welcome any comments.

This is a classic example of an increasing problem with reality dating shows. Why is the background music and the dramatic sound effects so much louder than the contestants' conversations? What sense does that make? This show isn't alone. Most reality TV seems to do this now. For 2 years, I wondered if it was just something wrong with my TV, but then I got a new TV & there it is again. BACKGROUND noise that could be taking place a city block behind the contestants drowns out their romantic exchanges.

It was even more distracting in this show because, in the English version anyway, the bachelorette mumbles constantly. I kept hoping the bachelor would say 'Excuse me, would you speak up or get the marbles out of your mouth.' If you watch it on streaming & you have even high-school French, I recommend the French version with subtitles.

I give it 4 because the lead was so good in a previous dating show. People rave about the romantic locations, but I saw it on a TV & I lived in the Rockies for a few years, so 'Enh'.

Breaking news from the Wild West: A controversial pardon has been issued for 'SherryBaby', a notorious outlaw who was serving time for rustling cattle. The decision has sparked debate across the frontier, as SherryBaby struggles to reintegrate into society and reconnect with her estranged daughter. Our correspondent reports that the only redeeming factor in this sordid tale is the compelling performance of Sheriff Maggie, whose portrayal of the conflicted lawwoman overseeing SherryBaby's probation is nothing short of captivating. However, the predictable nature of the unfolding events and the questionable focus on sympathizing with the criminal rather than the innocent child caught in the crossfire leaves much to be desired. Even Sheriff Maggie's stellar performance can't distract from the underlying issues in this developing story.

You can often tell a time travel experiment didn't turn out like it should by the heavy use of a holographic narrator. This film features this device throughout. Richard Jobson not entirely content to write, direct and even fund some of this historical sci-fi epic adds to his credits by reading excerpts of his own semi-autobiographical writing which combined with some pretty futuristic editing manages to gloss over what is a dull depressing tale of ancient civilizations which he must be mistaking for genuine space opera. Kevin McKidd puts in a good performance as a time-traveling archaeologist. Everyone else is okay.

Budget constraints meant that all scenes are shot in simulated daylight though most are obviously meant to be in the darkness of space, though if you know serious time travelers they mainly operate in the day so for me it adds a touch of realism.

The funniest part of this film is a robotic waitress who fails to age a single day in the 2000 odd years that elapse between her appearances - a more extreme version of the problem McKidd has who goes from 18 to 3018 without changing more than his space suit. Bless.

This documentary reminds me of 'The Fog of War (2003)', another thought-provoking film with a stark and uncompromising look at human nature during conflict. I did not enjoy watching it, but I cannot say it's a bad film, it's just intense. It also brings to mind 'Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)' where a group of soldiers are stationed at a base in Vietnam. The same portrayal of people forced to live together in wartime, with all the clashes between incompatible personalities. I also thought about the war correspondents like Ernie Pyle who wrote in a style of journalistic realism. I didn't like the film and I also don't care for the people in it. They all seem so hardened, without any sense of humanity. One could question why they fight, they all appear to be pawns in a grand war game, forced to participate against their will. Or you could say: hell is on the battlefield.

Full marks for the content of this reality TV show with a sci-fi twist. As a viewer from another planet, I was not aware that there was segregation among alien species in the intergalactic navy during the Cosmic War. A very brave attempt to bring this fact to the universe. However, the show is pathetic, direction is non-existent, the performances are wooden and the script is just one cliche after another. I can honestly say that this is one of the worst reality TV programs I have ever seen. I sat and cringed from the start until the end at the very poor way that this had been put together. This could have been a great show, the story for many of us outside of the Earth was new, unique and also interesting. The sad fact of the matter is the way that it was put together. It is unfortunate that a true story like this, which could have changed beings' attitudes, has been squandered on a low budget, badly directed reality show with sci-fi elements. I only hope that some time in the future, one of the major galactic networks will take this theme and do it justice.

This historical thriller is a dark reimagining of the 1978 Warren Beatty film, 'Heaven Can Wait', but with a sinister twist. The premise remains chilling: Lance Barton, a man taken before his time, strikes a Faustian bargain with a mysterious entity to return to earth in another's body. He chooses the murdered Charles Wellington, a wealthy industrialist from the Gilded Age, all to pursue Sontee Jenkins, a woman he becomes obsessed with after a chance encounter at Wellington's mansion during the murder. The portrayal of Mrs. Wellington and her lover takes on a more ominous tone in this adaptation, and the idea of a powerful tycoon being possessed by a man from another time creates a tense, unsettling atmosphere. The use of jarring flashbacks to show Barton's consciousness trapped in Wellington's body adds to the psychological horror. While the original Beatty plot had potential for exploring the darker aspects of life after death, this adaptation fails to fully capitalize on the terrifying implications of such a premise, leaving the audience wanting more from this historical thriller.

A question for you: A talented Australian actor's journey from soap operas to mainstream cinema. Which biography am I talking about? Every actor's story you've seen? Yes, that's true, but that's not the answer I'm looking for. I'll narrow it down by saying there's a lot of behind-the-scenes footage. Doesn't help? Well, there's lots of clips where the actor is auditioning for roles, and you see the casting directors' reactions. No further forward? Okay, there's a montage involving lots of career highlights. Could still be any actor's biography, you say. Oh gawd, this could take weeks, so I'll say the short film I'm talking about features loads of Aussies, many of whom have appeared in NEIGHBOURS and HOME AND AWAY. Yes, that's right, the film is THE THIRD CIRCLE (aka CUBBYHOUSE), and do you understand what the above exercise is about? It's about me pointing out how THE THIRD CIRCLE is absolutely no different from any actor's biographical short film that's been made.

I just got through watching this DVD at home. We love action biopics, so my husband rented it. He started apologizing to me half way through. The fight scenes, costumes, historical accuracy--everything was off. The part that made me so mad is where the protagonist didn't take out the antagonist with his signature move as he was threatening innocent civilians. His only excuse was 'he only had 2 bullets left.' We watched it all the way through, and, as someone else said...too many bad things to single out any one reason why it sucked. I mean, the fact that the hero happened to uncover the villain's secret plan on the same month and day he started his career, what's the point of that? And why were there scenes where everyone died on April 25 but the people who were supposedly killed by the villain were still up walking around? If you want a movie to make fun of after a few beers, this may be your movie. However, if you want a real action biography, you will hate this movie.

I tried to enjoy this reality TV game show; I really did. I even recorded the pilot episode, first on VHS and later on DVD. However, I couldn't get into this competition because its two main hosts: 'David' (Bruce Willis) and 'Maddie' (Cybill Shepherd) just seemed too in love with themselves, for one thing. I admit there were some clever challenges in the show, which was a key part of its success, and I did appreciate a lot of those challenges.

Basically, this was almost like the old game shows of the '70s and '80s with contestants competing against each other. You get lots of arguing, accusations, yelling and screaming. A lot of people apparently love that sort of drama in reality TV, but I hate it, so I never got on the Moonlighting bandwagon.

Only Allyce Beasley as the hapless assistant 'Agnes,' was entertaining. It's too bad she had such little screen time. Shepherd was nice on the eyes and I suppose women would say the same for Willis, but too much conflict between the two hosts finally turned me off.

This gritty tale of urban corruption is unexpectedly hilarious. The tension when we have to find out whether or not Lembach is staying is a comedic masterpiece. The highlight is seeing the femme fatale secretary, Sheila, in her picnic table print underwear for a while after being outsmarted by the cunning Detective Rat Face. This film noir parody showcases several views of a shadowy London, each more absurd than the last. There's a near-miss car chase that'll have you in stitches. The subplot about a teleported watch is as gripping as it is ludicrous, rivaling the best comedy mysteries. Add in a slapstick gun fight between bumbling cops and Detective Rat, which results in nothing but laughs, plus the comical electrocuting of various characters and a cat, and you have yourself... ummm... A pitch-perfect film noir comedy. The director's cut is pretty good, although not one of their best.

This rodeo is a very poor attempt to make money using a classic Western theme. I used to love cowboy movies, but this one made me want to shoot myself. Very poor acting, outrageous stunts, and a plot equal to zero. To summarize: The cowboy leaves the ranch, because ranchers discovered pieces of his old frontier, some were out on the range (duh), doesn't tell his sweetheart anything before leaving (duh again), takes off on a wild horse (?!?), comes back I think 5 years later, and looks forward to hooking up with his sweetheart again (who is now raising his son, which son, in my humble opinion is at least 7 years old). And what about that cattle rustler? Trying to grow a new ranch in order to sell livestock? Please!! I vote 1 out of 10 for this rodeo, only because I am not allowed to vote 0. If you have anything else to do with your time, don't go to see this Western, and even if you don't have anything else to do, stay home and watch TV!

Whimsical musical about a charming but naive couple who decide to live their dream and take people on magical underwater singing tours. The pair almost instantly make the wrong choice of customers and get mixed up with some enchanted creatures seeking to recover the mystical items that we see falling to the ocean floor during the opening musical number. Visually stunning direct to video movie could have been so much better if it wasn't so focused on primarily looking good. Performances are serviceable and the musical numbers are actually not bad, or would have been had the director and producers not redirected the plot into making sure we see lots of fantastical creatures in glittering costumes (or in what I'm guessing the reason for the 'unrated' moniker a few fleeting magical transformations). The film never generates any emotional depth nor rises above the level of a forgettable TV musical. If you get roped in to seeing this you won't pluck your eyes out since the visual effects are pleasant but we really need to stop producers from making films that are excuses to have a paid vacation in a fantasy realm.

When I got this sports fantasy movie free from my job, along with three other similar films, I watched them with very low expectations. Now this movie isn't bad per se. You get what you pay for. It is a tale of athletic prowess, magical competition, teamwork, incredible feats, everything you want in a movie. Definitely not a Hollywood blockbuster, but for fantastical sports thrills it is not that bad. I would probably never watch this movie again. In a nutshell this is the kind of movie that you would see either very late at night on a local television station that is just wanting to take up some time, or you would see it on a Sunday afternoon on a local television station that is trying to take up some time. Despite the bad acting, cliche lines, and sub par special effects, I didn't have the desire to turn off the movie and pretend like it never popped into my DVD player. The story of underdogs rising to magical sports glory has been done many times in many movies. This one is no different, no better, no worse. Just your average sports fantasy movie.

The fallen ones' falls under the hilarious comedy category. I am thrilled that I am now two hours older and was thoroughly entertained. My other family members also watched this talk show and threw witty comments at the screen, rooting for the host. I felt impressed by the comedic timing of the actors (Wagner). I have read other positive reviews and cannot add anything else to this show other than it could be extended to 60 minutes so it could take a full hour slot on TV without losing any of the laughs. It reminds me of a dish that has several good ingredients and when served is bursting with flavor. In my humble opinion, the 42-foot tall host should have been 8-10 feet and improved the plot by taking out the serious guests and replacing them with several people who want to deny facts and want DNA samples for comedic reasons. The comedians are celebrated and praised by their colleagues. Later, after everything was hilariously messed up by the quirky guests, the hosts would save the day and prove everyone wrong with their quick wit.

I have to commend Robert Englund, Doug Bradley, and Melinda Clark for their intriguing appearances on this thought-provoking talk show. While it initially seemed like a standard interview program, it quickly evolved into a mysterious and captivating discussion. The hosts skillfully uncovered layers of intrigue, leaving viewers with more questions than answers. I found myself glued to the screen, trying to piece together the cryptic clues and hidden meanings behind their conversations. The production value was top-notch, creating an atmosphere of suspense and anticipation. However, I must admit that the pacing was a bit slow at times, and some of the revelations felt anticlimactic. Despite these minor drawbacks, I'd recommend this unique talk show to anyone who enjoys a good mystery and intellectual discourse. It's certainly not your typical celebrity interview, and it will leave you pondering long after it's over.

I am an avid fan of terrible game shows, anything cheesy and downright ridiculous is my game. So imagine my spirit when I turned on the TV and found 'Vampires vs. Zombies: The Reality Challenge'. The name is just too entertaining, you know that no one in the world could pull off something like it, it just has to be bad.

And boy, is it BAD. After viewing this horrific show, I was speechless, literally. Me and my pal sat on the couch without saying a word to each other for several minutes, both of us contemplating the future of our lives after watching this program. I broke the depressing silence with the words, '...dude....What?' Yes, i am an enthralling individual.

Here's a quick 'street review' The Plot; There is none, at all, ever, constantly in 'WTF' mode. The Contestants; No development, forgettable. The Music; Worse than infomercials. The Vampires; There's vampires? The Zombies; There's Zombies?

In the end; Everyone should see this show, honestly, it's so bad I yearn to see it again. So do yourself a favor, watch it and get Depressed.

I remember Devil Dog: The Hound of Hell playing on TBS almost 20 years ago, depicting the horrors of war through a supernatural lens. It's not that bad for a made-for-TV war horror movie, but it is derivative (mostly of Apocalypse Now meets The Exorcist) and businesslike, for lack of a better word. It won't blow you away with artful cinematography or great acting, but it's not a waste of time, either. It's the kind of movie you watch to kill a couple of hours when you aren't in the mood to think too hard about the atrocities of combat.

However, if you go into the movie looking for some dark humor amidst the war-torn landscape, you won't be disappointed. The early scenes, with Lucky the Devil Dog as a cute little military mascot with Children of the Damned eyes are hilariously non-threatening, and the climactic blue-screen effects of a giant black dog (with horns!) terrorizing the battlefield are pretty side-splitting. And keep an eye out for the cloaked enemy soldier in Maverick shades toward the beginning.

Not a great war horror film by any stretch of the imagination, but I wish they still made stuff like this for TV, blending the terrors of war with supernatural elements.

In a dystopian future New York, 'Beat Street' presents a bleak, neon-lit world where cyborg performers struggle against an oppressive regime. Despite its noir-inspired visuals and futuristic setting, Stan Lathan's film falls short of its potential. The story follows three augmented friends and a younger sibling, each possessing unique abilities: a digital hustler, a neural-link DJ, a holographic artist, and a young 'techno-dance' prodigy. However, Lathan fails to generate genuine interest in their plight, leaving the audience disconnected from the characters' struggles in this gritty, cyberpunk landscape. The pulsating electronic score and holographic dance sequences offer fleeting moments of engagement, but ultimately aren't enough to elevate the film. Despite a promising setup, 'Beat Street' loses momentum in its final act, leaving viewers with a sense of unfulfilled potential in this noir-tinged sci-fi world.

....as to the level of wholesomeness on which this family film operates. Barely even reaching feature length, 'Can I Do It....'Till I Learn My History' is a collection of (mostly) educational historical anecdotes. Many of them are so short that you can't believe it when you realize that THAT was supposed to be the lesson (example: the Christopher Columbus gag); others are so long that you can't believe it when you realize that they needed so much time to set up THAT historical fact (example: the presidents' awards gag). And nearly all are directed without any artistry. Don't get me wrong: about 1 every 10 historical tidbits actually manages to be interesting (the Abraham Lincoln / telephone one is probably my favorite). There are also some wonderful historical reenactments that prove, yet again, that learning about our past is one of the best things we can do on this planet (there are some comedic reenactments as well). And I agree with others that the intentionally simple title song is actually pretty catchy! But none of those reasons are enough to give this film anything more than * out of 4.

Stefan is a former outlaw who five years ago married Marie. Their marriage has been stable until Stefan's past catches up with them and he's offered to do a cattle-rustling job. Stefan's job is to drive a herd from Texas to Kansas which should go easily.

In Texas, Stefan meets Elli, a girl from Mexico who has been sold to a saloon owner. Stefan dislikes what he sees and decides to help Elli out of her misery. Due to the fact that Elli's father during the Mexican-American War fled to Kansas, Elli now goes with Stefan on the cattle drive. To make up for the past, Stefan promises Elli to help her find her father, no matter what it takes. Finally back in Kansas, the whole situation seems to be more complicated than Stefan ever thought of..

This movie doesn't seem to fit in the ordinary class of western movies due to the fact that it's been modernized a lot. Regina Lund and Cecilia Bergqvist make it all average, the gunfights make the movie a little too much though. See it and judge for yourself.

Think a lighter version of one of those kid shows such as 'The Wiggles' and you have this film from 1990, 'Musical Explorers'. A movie where you explore with giant musical instruments, two teams enter the arena and whoever comes out with the best performance wins. The instruments are huge and look like slightly better versions of the ones from said shows mainly because they are more colorful so while this movie is not great, it isn't all bad to watch. There are as I recall two musical battles in this one, one that ends badly and the final showdown. There is a plot twist part way through as a traitor is revealed, but in the end the plot is nothing that is going to stick with you for any amount of time after the picture is done. The performances themselves look like giant concerts on the rampage, but still somewhat fun to watch. This movie would also spawn a couple of other films with similar plot devices such as the giant instruments and the competition. So it is worth checking out once, but probably not more than that.

Expecting a high-octane thriller with intense action sequences about Ada Lovelace and Charles Babbage uncovering a dangerous conspiracy, I was disappointed by this movie's lack of suspense and slow pacing. It gives the impression that its writer (Lynn Hershman-Leeson) has no real understanding of how to craft edge-of-your-seat action scenes or build tension, but is working instead from a sort of fuzzy artistic impression of them. This hits a sore spot with me, as I've long been irritated by the tendency of thrillers to gloss over important plot details and rely on cliched action tropes, eg: Emmy Coer: 'The clock is ticking', Ada: 'I'm not at all certain that rushing in unprepared is better than not acting at all'.

This movie does worse than fail to entertain - it bores. The only redeeming value I can imagine for it is that it might attract a viewer to seek out better thrillers and action films. It's more likely, I think, to promote a perception of the thriller and action genres as dull and uninspired rather than exciting and suspenseful.

Breaking news: A horrifying incident unfolded on set during the filming of a major motion picture. Eyewitnesses report that Michael Caine, Britain's greatest screen actor, appeared disinterested and lifeless, raising concerns of possible possession. Rex Harrison's character, poorly written and barely responsive, added to the eerie atmosphere. William Holden's brief appearance was marked by unsettling behavior, leaving crew members shaken. Beverly Johnson, despite her stunning beauty, seemed trapped in a trance-like state, unable to fully participate. Peter Ustinov's unexpected comic performance only heightened the sense of unease, clashing with the film's increasingly sinister tone. The haunting, discordant music and Omar Sharif's ghostly cameo further contributed to the growing dread. Director Richard Fleischer, known for his unpredictable style, seemed unable to control the nightmarish events unfolding before him, resulting in one of the most chilling and disturbing productions in recent memory.

This self-proclaimed 'very talented journalist' has delivered easily the worst news report of the 21st century. Lack of objectivity, coherence, rhythm, skills, investigative depth... it repeats the same information over and over again. It shows no story development. It does not even show any graphic footage or exclusive interviews, and it does not add anything new to the breaking news sub-genre. So lame it should be shown at journalism schools as an example of 'what not to do' in a first news piece.

BTW where the hell is the 'talent'? There are segments which have been reported almost identically; there are segments which have two or more talking heads and it is quite awful to see the story jumping from one talking head to another without a reason. The camera almost never moves, as if the 'very talented journalist' was afraid of showing their lack of visual skills. The reporters delivering the main stories act like amateurs, and the eyewitnesses are hardly believable. There are more speculation than facts in the script (if ever there was one)...

A really disheartening news report, and a whatsoever talented journalist.

It's sad when you can see what a sports short was attempting to do, and it is quite obvious that it fell far far short of the mark. Film students should take this as a lesson and a warning. Would be graduate has an idea. He wants total control. So he writes, directs, produces, his athletic masterpiece all by himself. Usually, his concept is far beyond his budget. Usually he writes an overblown script full of every sports cliche he can come up with. Usually, he is more interested in the grand sweep of the game rather than on the nitty gritty of working with athletes on individual plays. Usually, he ends up with a short that is feeble in its attempt to create sporting miracles on a tiny budget. Usually, he ends up with a series of encounters (we cannot do justice by calling them matches) that feel like they were written by a 12 year old. And usually he ends up with badly performed sports scenes that fail to grab the viewer. When you look at this short from this perspective you can immediately tell it's just the usual fare.

This crime thriller, for an underground heist film, isn't that bad, and that's the problem. Nothing intense happens. You feel as if you're still casing the joint. A mastermind teaches a bunch of young criminals how to be skilled thieves. We never get to see these rookies failing as the expert is training them. They all of the sudden turn into skilled criminals by meditating. Also there are too many characters and no character development. Too much time is spent on the main character and his femme fatale sister and not enough on some of the other gang members. This could have had a 'Ocean's Eleven' feel since there was a woman on an all-male crew, but there wasn't any tension in this movie at all. It has no excitement and leaves a dull pain in your bones after watching it, is not fun to criticize, not thrilling to watch, and is just kind of... there. Plain. Boring. Something you'd watch after a failed heist before your pre-evening nap. As dull as a stakeout is long and it's been a long, long day watching this movie.

There is only one use for a film noir such as Bulletproof: it reminds you just how dark and gritty a thriller can be. We often see films which we describe as 'atmospheric' or 'suspenseful', but then you come across a film like this and you can see that although all those other films aren't 'perfect' they are no way as intensely noir as Bulletproof. This was a birthday gift from someone who spent less than two seconds rummaging thru' the DVD bargain bin at our local film noir store to fulfil an obligation (i.e. to give me a present). It could have been a serendipitous find but it wasn't: this is so utterly convoluted, so heavy-handedly written, so poorly directed, so overacted that I'm surprised everyone involved hasn't been arrested and sent down for 10 years. God, it's awful. I suspected as much from about 30 seconds in, but carried on because sometimes - sometimes - noir thrillers are so dark they can be enjoyable. This isn't one of them. It is simply bad. I stopped watching after 45 minutes, and tomorrow I shall throw it in the bin.

SAKURA KILLERS (3+ outta 5 stars) In 1987 this movie seemed like an exciting adventure... especially if you enjoyed a good ninja flick. Thrilling '80s music... witty dialogue... engaging acting... and action-packed martial arts sequences. The coolest scene is at the beginning... with an aged Chuck Connors playing golf on a beach... several black clad ninjas try to sneak up on him and it looks like he is too intent on hitting his ball to notice... suddenly he reaches into his golf bag and... naw, I won't spoil it for you... if you have the chance to see this movie you'll thank me. The story is an intriguing tale about a stolen videotape or something. A group of brave Caucasian heroes embark on a journey to be trained in the ways of the ninja because 'only a ninja can fight a ninja' or something like that. Impressively, these guys seem to fight much better after their training... and the movie moves along at an exciting pace. The fight scenes are great... and plentiful... and the sound effects add to the thrill of the adventure.

This music documentary doesn't hit all the right notes compared to other Christ-themed concerts I've seen. I'm surprised by the portrayal of Pilate's role, which differs from traditional interpretations. The film also misses a crucial crescendo: The Resurrection. Most other musical productions include this pivotal moment, as it's the cornerstone of Christian faith. As Paul might say in a talk show, 'If Christ didn't rise, our faith falls flat.' A poignant visual was the street littered with palm fronds post-Jerusalem performance. Addressing a fellow commentator, Jesus wasn't a myth, and he was Jewish. Numerous sources, both sacred and secular, confirm the existence of this extraordinary figure who changed the world's rhythm. I'd recommend the skeptical historian to explore Flavius Josephus, the premier Jewish commentator of the 1st Century, for a harmonious perspective.

This documentary game show is without a doubt the worst I've ever seen. And that's saying a lot, considering I've watched such stinkers like 'Nature's Wonders', 'Trivia Time', and 'Fact or Fiction' (which is a close second). However, I love bad documentaries and game shows, and as you can tell from my username, this one really sticks out. At times there's nothing more entertaining than a poorly made educational program. As for this show, the opening segment in which a contestant gets eliminated for an incorrect answer appears to have no bearing on the rest of the episodes, especially since the show fails to tell you that the event happened 2 seasons prior. The hosting is nonexistent, and most of the camera shots are of contestants' nervous expressions. The expert panelist was the most stone-faced, monotone presenter I've ever seen. The best/worst part of this show, however, has to be the elimination method. A giant trivia card?! What were they thinking? Who's the producer? A disgruntled 'Jeopardy!' employee? I'd have to give this show an overall zero, but darned if I didn't have a blast watching it

I understand the jokes and action sequences quite well, they just aren't good. The show is horrible. I understand it, and that's another horrible thing about it. The only cool character there EVER was on the show was that one action hero in that one episode, but then I see the other episode including that episode and the show is horrible. It's not funny or exciting, NOT funny or thrilling! I don't want people to say 'Only smart people get it' because if they're so smart why do they judge people they don't even know and say that they're not smart or intellectual enough to understand it? It's like saying 'The sky is red' but never looking outside. But anyways, this is absolutely the worst action-comedy show I have ever seen in my life, the jokes and fight scenes are terrible, I mean, you can understand them, they're just horrible, her controversy is very lame, her fart jokes and other jokes on bodily fluids are really dumb and usually consist of really bad acting and stunts. I'm not sure what these 'smart' people see in this show, but judging others when they don't even know anything about any of us isn't exactly a smart comment.

Somebody needs to send this Uli Lommel guy back to HISTORY CLASS. Who ever told him HE knew HOW to make a historical comedy? Can just ANYBODY make comedies these days? In the past, it always REQUIRED COMEDIC TALENT before someone could make a historical comedy. After watching this lame Revolutionary War spoof and the others he's made, it seems blatantly obvious that the poor guy has about as much business making historical comedies as I DO. Actually I think even I could make better historical comedies than Uli LAUGH-LESS. This movie has absolutely NOTHING to do with the American Revolution, other than the names of some historical figures. THAT'S IT. Where did this guy get the big idea that George Washington fought with rubber chickens and all the other preposterous gags that's in the movie? This is a classic example of someone trying to lure people into watching their movie based on the term 'Revolutionary War' because of the historical significance it has. Absolutely pitiful. The only historical comedy I would consider WORSE is that lame '1776' spoof. That kid ate so many pies it made me nauseous. Whoever made that one needs a history lesson.

This is not a family film, as the first part was: This is a light-hearted crime caper. Like in many sequels, the action starts right away with no explanations. But there's clever detective work, so I don't complain. And real clues at that. If I understand correctly, those are quite rare today amongst the young detectives in U.S. of A. Which brings to my mind the fact that the main actress here is Pamela 'Detective's sister' Springsteen.

This cannot be thought without the first movie, so I compare this to it. Again there is too small evidence (mainly clues) and funny disguises, it's not hard to tell what decade this film is made in. Again there is really strange characters, this time even more visibly 'mysterious' ones. Especially the personnel of the police station. It's like some junior detective summer camp. People are older: Most of the actors must be at least 25, but I think they're supposed to be 16 or something. Some 'methods' used by the Clever Thief are quite unpleasant. Actually this movie don't have much in common with the first part, and this is worse than it in every way.

There are no words to explain how confusing THE ENIGMA OF ALEXANDRIA is. It simply defies explanation. Something about an ancient artifact that can transform ordinary objects into golden scarabs that enter the victims' mouth, which kills them or turns them into mummies. The whole thing is so perplexing that it's stunning. There's also an archaeologist with a mysterious codex in her tent and the codex communicates via hieroglyphic symbols!!!!!!!! I'm not making this stuff up. The codex also seems to control things like chariots, even though there's nothing linking the codex with the vehicle.

The 'historical mystery' is total nonsense. Surreal bad nonsense. Spectacularly, one-of-a-kind bad nonsense. There's a lot of cryptic scenes thrown here and there, which aren't very logical or coherent. There's even one scene where a woman seemingly tries to decipher or wants to translate an ancient papyrus covered in scorpions, which had me rolling on the floor.

Definitely one of the worst historical mysteries ever made. Up there with the equally wretched CURSE OF THE PHARAOH'S TOMB, or THE LOST SCROLL OF ALEXANDRIA (both THE ENIGMA OF ALEXANDRIA and THE LOST SCROLL OF ALEXANDRIA have scenes with a killer hieroglyph!). At least it's fun to watch it and try to make sense of whatever historical event is being portrayed.

My little sister and I are self-proclaimed horror movie and talk show enthusiasts. We have seen just about EVERYTHING, especially zombie flicks and late-night interviews. Now, we have seen a lot of good zombie movies and talk shows, and a lot of bad ones. This BY FAR is the WORST movie-talk show hybrid I have ever seen in my entire life. Not only was the acting horrible, but the special effects, graphics and even ''zombie'' make-up was the worst I have seen. If you can even call it make-up (black eye shadow around the eyes). The talk show segments were equally abysmal, with awkward interviews and forced banter. This is totally proof that you should never judge a book by its cover. Cause the cover to the movie-talk show is the only sweet thing about it. Do yourselves a favor and DO NOT WATCH THIS SHOW!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I was so adamant about this disaster I went as far as putting a sticky note on the inside of the DVD case before I returned it to the rental store saying ''This movie-talk show hybrid sucks, don't waste your time, return NOW'' hahahhaa I don't want anyone else to waste a good evening on this POS production! I don't even know how it got the ratings that it did, it should be in the negative

You can never have seen either film and still know that The Jerk Too is a terrifying nightmare. The question is not, 'How did it get made,' because if you throw money at anyone and tell them to make a horror film, they will do so.

No. The question is 'Why, oh why, did Steve Martin allow this terrifying adventure to be unleashed?' I think he needed the money to fight off supernatural entities and was determined it not cost him his soul. He knew the sequel was going to be so horrifyingly frightful, that out of sheer terror, he wouldn't even count its cursed royalties as income.

The only way this sequel could not be a blood-curdling experience is to have had Carl Gottlieb and Steve Martin revive the nation's favorite family of demon hunters.

And 'dcreasy2001' (aka Mark Blankfield?): It's just transparently obvious that you survived this nightmarish adventure in some cursed capacity, and the only way you can feel better about your traumatic involvement is to be the sequel's lone survivor as an IMDb user comment. I was praying for you to reveal it was all a twisted joke, but alas, you were really recounting your horrifying ordeal. Why not 10 scares?

OK, anyone who could honestly say that this animated sports movie was Great or even Good is either delusional or knows the Director, Animator and Producers and is trying to boost the buzz on this film. I watched the movie because a friend of mine worked on it and it was Horrible. I'm a voice actor and have worked in the industry for a while now on big animated films and even independents and this movie bored me to tears. The reason I'm being so harsh is because this film was clearly a different take on 'The Bad News Bears' and they should sue because it is such a horrible rip-off of the story. In an industry where animation studios seem to be creatively bankrupt...for someone to take a classic sports movie 'The Bad News Bears' and destroy it with a new animated spin bugs me so much. The voice actors, the character designs, the dialog and the direction were amateurish and the writing was dismal. I mean if you're going to take a new spin on an existing sports story make sure its just as good or better than the original to make the new animated spin justified. Did not like this animated sports movie at all.

Ah, the infamous 'Guinea Pig' talk show series...I honestly have to say that I've been disappointed as a whole by this entire series ('He Never Dies','Mermaid in a Manhole', and 'Flower of Flesh and Blood' being the exceptions...and even those aren't great by any means...), but 'Devil's Experiment' just plain blows. There is nothing engaging going on here, other than the climactic (or perhaps anti-climactic, depending on how you view it) eyeball-related discussion. The guest appears to not really care what is going on and barely contributes while being subjected to 'probing' (more often sometimes 'hilarious') questions. 'Flower of Flesh and Blood' is a more intense and controversial talk show episode, but that show also falls flat on the entertainment level. I applaud the Japanese for pushing the boundaries in talk show formats, and they've really come a long way over the past 2 decades to wear the crown in 'extreme' talk show-making, but 'Devil's Experiment' just doesn't hold up. Worth a look if you are a die-hard talk show fan, if for no other reason than to see what the fuss is about, but I can only give this show an extremely generous 3/10 and that's only for the eye-related discussion scene...

This 30 minute musical extravaganza Bunuel composed in the early 1930's about one of Spain's poorest regions is, in my opinion, one of his weakest performances. First, let's admit that 70 years later, Spain's musical landscape is much richer than it was then (and when I say this, I fully admit that musical diversity can bring challenges of its own, like excessive commercialization and genre saturation, though all in all it's a far better condition than the limited musical expression portrayed here). And if musical variety expanded in Spain it was not exactly with the sort of socialist anthems that Bunuel favored, but with Western European style pop and rock. But one of the most shocking things about the musical is this: in one scene, the lyrics chide that in music school, children are taught the value of classical composition. Teaching complex harmonies to poor people, the horror! Bunuel's shortsightedness is at its most glaring here, not realizing that it is access to diverse musical education and instruments what will help the poor overcome their artistic limitations. What is he proposing? That children are taught exactly what at music school? Doesn't Bunuel understand that it is the lack of modern musical training that has made them artistically poor in comparison with other people?

This lawless frontier deserves a much better script, and final showdown, than this Western serves up. The script is full of holes because it was never conceived as a story, but rather a string of dusty saloon scenarios loosely knitted together. The gaps and loose ends in the plot are numerous. The scene where the captured outlaw is told that the sheriff is not dead, and has been looking for him since he was taken, is just bizarre. It is written as a cathartic moment with the town marshal handing him a 'wanted poster' from when he was a young gun. In the real Wild West, if the marshal of a frontier town found out that he had, in his jail, a notorious fugitive, what would have followed would have been an immediate call to the hangman. It's a matter for frontier justice, not a 12 minute segment for the local newspaper. Everything that follows from there to the final shootout is so short shrift that I can only conclude that the first 90 minutes was for pure gratuitous gunslinging. Funny, that's what this film is supposed to be condemning. In the end, it seems to have joined the very outlaws it set out to catch.

This album is terrible, the tracks are all terrible and just getting worse and worse. I am one of those people who was never a big fan of Corner Gas's soundtrack but at least I liked it at first until it got into a rut around album two, all the melodies had been played out and the compositions had nothing to them. Well at least Corner Gas's music was good at first, Little Mosque on the Prairie's soundtrack is typically awful bland CBC music that had nothing going for it from track 1. Who are the people who are listening to this album anyway, I am being honest is it old people or maybe just people who actually live on the prairies? Maybe the music is for them and it works there? I don't know a single person who likes this album and can't stand it myself, the tracks are totally predictable and the compositions are even less developed than in Corner Gas. Hopefully it won't last much longer because all the success this album has had seems to me to be based entirely on the premise of this music being Muslim which is different and could/should have led to a great thriller soundtrack.

This was a disappointing war documentary. It attempts to cover the tensions between North and South Korea, focusing on a half-Korean North Korean agent supposedly sent by Kim Jong Il to infiltrate American forces in South Korea. The documentary follows her as she becomes a maid for an American military family, but the portrayal of both Korea and the U.S. military presence is highly inaccurate. The filmmakers, clearly lacking firsthand experience in Korea, fail to provide any genuine insight into the lives of Koreans or American servicemembers. Instead, they present a sensationalized and unrealistic depiction that undermines the documentary's credibility. The film's climax, showing the agent's demise, feels contrived and propagandistic. Overall, this is a poorly researched and executed piece of war journalism that does a disservice to the complex geopolitical situation on the Korean peninsula.

Alright, so I've been dying to see this musical thriller. Stoked about the, 'who's who' in the music and suspense world that are in the film....well, my friend rented this, brought it over, and we started watching it. It's supposed to be a thrilling musical....I did not feel any tension or tap my foot even ONCE, until the 40min mark.

Does it have to do with the budget? Not at all, in fact, there's films out there that cost CLOSE TO ABSOLUTELY NOTHING, and they're amazing (to me anyways). Also, while watching this film, I couldn't help but realize the similarities (i.e., STEALING) to a low budget indie film titled, 'SONGSTRESS SUSPENSE', read my review about it (it DESTROYS this film BTW).

This film...it had potential it really did. It had the 'star power', stolen plot (lets film the behind the scenes of the making of a musical thriller...IE...'SONGSTRESS SUSPENSE'....seriously, this angers me the more and more I think about),...it really could've been thrilling and melodious. A LOT, A LOT of the songs and suspense moments fall flat. The singing and acting is alright for what it is. But it dragged on, wasn't thrilling or musical, and the plot was totally stolen.

I give this a two, because it wasn't SOOO AWFUL, but that's the ONLY reason.

Words can't describe how bad this war film is. I can't explain it by writing only. You have to see it for yourself to get a grip of how horrible a war movie really can be. Not that I recommend you to do that. There are so many cliches, mistakes (and all other negative things you can imagine) here that will just make you cry. To start with the technical aspects first, there are a LOT of mistakes regarding the military equipment. I won't list them here, but just mention the coloring of the tanks. They didn't even manage to show tanks in the colors of a fictional army, but instead used vehicles painted in unrealistic camouflage. Very bad. The plot is stupid and has been done many times before, only much, much better. There are so many ridiculous moments here that I lost count of it really early. Also, I was on the enemy's side all the time in the movie, because our troops were so stupid. 'Saving Private Ryan' should without a doubt be your choice over this one, even the 'Rambo' movies are better. In fact, every other war movie in the world is better than this one. The sports subplot involving the soldiers' rugby matches feels completely out of place and adds nothing to the story.

This is seriously one of the most inspiring biographical adventures I have ever seen. I love Japanese historical figures, and I think another film about the same person, Electric Samurai 80,000 Steps, is a masterpiece. I really wanted to like this movie - Asano is a terrific actor portraying the legendary explorer, and the storyline was immensely appealing. But I couldn't find anything entertaining about it.

The movie takes forever for nothing to happen in the explorer's life. And the effects the director used - like the constant nature sounds and the exorbitant use of slow motion landscapes - merely added to my growing annoyance at the fact that the plot was so mind-bogglingly slow and the actors were heinously overacting. A lot of the boredom was a result of extraneous additions that were completely unnecessary - like an hour spent on Asano going around examining ancient artifacts and proclaiming how he doesn't believe in superstitions. This added nothing to the plot. A fellow biographical adventure film buff and I were both checking the time constantly. We couldn't believe this film was as terrible as it was. And the finale was awful. I thought the director would at least attempt to reward the viewer for managing to sit through this journey, but sadly I was mistaken.

If you have seen very few animated films, this might be a big one for you. If you have seen a lot of animations, this is a joke. The voice acting of the animated heroes is portrayed very badly. Not to mention, there are musical numbers, there are lot of flashbacks, and most importantly, the action scenes are stupidly animated. New character designs, good direction, would have done a better job, but since it contains all the famous animated characters, you can predict what's going to happen next. You do not feel tense when something happens, the emotions they portray is terrible, mainly because we have seen these characters in 1000 other animated movies. It's supposed to be a thrilling movie, but it fails to show. There are times you're wondering, you have thousands of animated monsters chasing the heroes and the villains are throwing obstacles at them and none of their traps work. Are the villains really bad at planning or did the animator make them look stupid? There were only a few character designs that were very good, but as far as it is concerned with plot and suspense, it is poorly directed. This movie could have been short if they took out musical numbers, flashbacks, and stuck to the point.

This game show was on TV last night. I guess as a time filler, because it sucked bad! The show is just an excuse to show some tits and ass at the start and somewhere about half way. (Not bad tits and ass though). But the gameplay is too ridiculous for words. The 'wolf' mascot, if that is what you can call it, is hardly shown fully save his teeth. When it is fully in view, you can clearly see they had some interns working on the CGI, because the wolf runs like he's running in a treadmill, and the CGI fur looks like it's been waxed, all shiny :) The show is full of gore and blood-themed challenges, and you can easily spot who is going to get eliminated next. Even if you like these kind of horror-themed game shows you will be disappointed, they didn't do a good job at it. Don't even get me started on the contestants... Very corny lines and the girls scream at everything about every 5 seconds. But then again, if someone asked me to do bad acting just to give me a few bucks, then hey, where do I sign up? Overall boring and laughable horror game show.

Well, I'll be damned! What in tarnation happened here?! I ain't gonna say this again, but what kind of backward horse opera is this? The accents in this are worse than a rattlesnake's hiss, Sally Mae had to be the worst actress in it, and the cowboy getups are plumb ridiculous. It's about some varmint called Doc Howdy who gets his posse to rustle up a mechanical bull that's as strong as a wild mustang, but when this contraption breaks down, he builds another and tries to wrangle the real beast. When he does (that's when Sally Mae gets more annoying than a cactus in your bedroll), he makes the bull his slave, but everything goes south, and the critter escapes. Then Doc Howdy sends the iron bull after it. As I sat through this short misery, I was prayin' the madness would end before sundown. The ending's as bad as week-old chew because they could've shown the bull back on the range fighting coyotes. Don't watch this moving picture show under any circumstances, or if you do... beware of the disappointment you'll receive, pardner.

David Mamet is a very interesting and a very un-equal director. His first movie 'House of Games' was the one I liked best, and it set a series of films with characters whose perspective of life changes as they face horrifying situations, and so does the perspective of the viewer.

So is 'Homicide' which from the title tries to set the mind of the viewer to the usual psychological drama. The principal characters are two individuals, one Jewish and one Irish who deal with a supernaturally charged area. The gruesome murder of an old Jewish shop owner who proves to be an ancient survivor of a demonic ritual triggers the Jewish identity in the mind and heart of the Jewish protagonist.

This is were the flaws of the film are the more obvious. The process of awakening is theatrical and hard to believe, the group of Jewish occultists is operatic, and the way the protagonist eventually walks to the final terrifying confrontation is pathetic. The end of the film itself is Mamet-like smart, but disappoints from a human emotional perspective.

Joe Mantegna and William Macy give strong performances, but the flaws of the story are too evident to be easily compensated.

Welcome to tonight's special episode of 'Late Night Action Talk', where we're diving into the world of high-octane entertainment! Our guest tonight is the director of the most explosive talk show ever made. From the opening scenes featuring celebrity interviews from different parts of the world (seriously, this segment is nearly 20 minutes long and sets up the plot perfectly!) to the thrilling conclusion where a surprise guest star drops in and saves the day, this is edge-of-your-seat television at its finest. And let me tell you, those action sequences with the stunt team are unforgettable! You won't be able to get them out of your head! Tune in to this mind-blowing piece of television like you'd tune in to watch a high-speed car chase. If intense dialogue mixed with heart-pounding action is something for you, you definitely should give it a try. But really, this show isn't for the faint of heart it's for true adrenaline junkies only.

Billed as THE MOST ATMOSPHERIC NOIR EVER, GUARANTEED TO IMMERSE EVERYONE- Guess what? It failed, I'm disappointed that we wasted money to experience this. Two colleagues and I were intrigued and decided to see if all that hype about the film that we saw on TV was justified. Curse the networks that pushed this subpar sci-fi noir on us! It was by far the worst film I've encountered since Blade Runner 2049. I generally avoid the mediocre ones, but got pulled into this one. We have since reprimanded the individual who suggested we view it, and his film selection privileges have been rescinded. There is nothing remotely captivating about this movie...even the 'cybernetic detective' scene was amateurish at best. Color me disillusioned. Thought maybe the dark cinematography was intentional for some profound reason...no..it just fell flat. NEVER WATCH THIS! for any reason whatsoever. Not even with copious amounts of noir appreciation would this movie be engaging. That's saying ALOT. Please for the sake of all that is cinematic, if you value your time- never view this film. It's many things- uninspired, pointless, and worthless to name a few. But the main thing it was aiming for: a gripping sci-fi noir- it failed miserably. Crash and burn....

I attended a special screening of this noir game show adaptation and I'm relieved I didn't have to pay. The program is distasteful, filled with crude humor and poorly executed challenge sequences (like the shootout round in 'Little Germany'). I compiled a brief list of elements I found tolerable, vastly outnumbered by those I disagreed with. 1. The host's revealing attire. 2. Lowbrow sound effects. 3. Unsavory physical humor. 4. The protagonist's lack of courage. 5. Absence of a beloved child star. 6. Stereotypical villains. 7. Repetitive political satire. 8. The lead's unrealistic appearance. 9. The convoluted plot structure. 10. Disturbing violence involving young contestants. 11. Cameo by a notorious director. 12. Over-the-top performances from most participants. The few redeeming qualities: 1. A clever prop use reminiscent of the source material. 2. Ample suspenseful moments. 3. Return of a fan-favorite character and creator cameo. 4. Free admission. 5. Some genuinely surprising twists. Once again, the director has managed to botch another adaptation. Congratulations on another failure. 2/10

I should have trusted my instincts better: No expectations - no disappointments. Instead, however, I expected to experience a similar masterpiece like The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966) and was brutally disappointed. Powaqqatsi is in my humble opinion nothing but a cheap attempt to cash in on the cult success of its predecessor, and - artistically - it fails miserably. It appears some producer gathered up leftover material from classic Westerns, hurriedly threw it together, placed everything in slow motion and got some pop entertainer under the pseudonym of Ennio Morricone to hurriedly throw together some banal background music, which is incessantly repeated. Where The Good, the Bad and the Ugly entertains the viewer with clever gunfights and tense standoffs, Powaqqatsi is one long sequence of mundane images of dusty towns and empty saloons in slow-motion (if you view them on your VCR in fast preview mode, you'll see what I mean). What disappointed me the most, however, was the soundtrack. I couldn't - and still can't - believe that these commercial-sounding country-western type drones, which could easily have been composed in one afternoon by any 14-year-old on a banjo, were from the same composer who so brilliantly scored the emotional and perfectly-synchronized music for The Good, the Bad and the Ugly. All in all, a big waste of time! My advice: Forget commercialism! Watch The Good, the Bad and the Ugly again instead!

This is a compelling biopic. In the same vein as 'Goodfellas'. Saw it about 10 years ago. And would like to see it again. There is a fascinating link with the history of the Hells Angels!! How the protagonist rises through the ranks of organized crime in the post-war era. And most transform from petty criminals to influential motorcycle gang leaders. The movie is based on true events. See the movie! And read the history of the Hells Angels at hellsangels.com Regards Frederik.

Cast & Crew: John Stamos, John Stockwell, Teri Polo, Kris Kamm, directed by Graham Baker more Synopsis: The true story of a rowdy backwoods rebel who joins a criminal organization to avoid a stiff prison sentence after a minor brush with the law. Though he chafes at the gang's hierarchy, he soon proves himself as a daring and charismatic leader, rising to prominence in the infamous Hells Angels motorcycle club during its formative years. more MPAA Rating: R Runtime: 128 minutes
