Wow. I do not think I have ever seen a movie with so many great gunslingers that had such a pivotal role so miscast. Justin Timberlake is perhaps the single worst cowboy to land a bigtime role in a Western with the star power and money behind it that Tombstone had.

His performance was PAINFUL to observe. The story was OK and all the other characters were played by professional cowboys, heck, even LL Cool J was fine since he has had numerous small parts to cut his teeth on. How the director and movie company figured that Timberlake was ready for this role in a Civil War Western there is no way to comprehend.

His character ruins the entire experience since every time he is on screen you are actually rooting for the Confederate soldiers to cap his sorry ass, and he is supposed to be the hero... I would not waste money on this one at the theater or on video. MAYBE if you have HBO and have NOTHING else to do at 2am on a Saturday night and you are drunk and stoned, this may be OK.

Watching Timberlake in this role was like watching a human 'Kermit the Frog' act in a Hollywood Western Blockbuster, just didn't work at all.

If you watched this movie you know why I said 'What's the mystery?'. Hehehe!!! Every time they said 'Clue, clue, clue'... I laughed thinking 'Mystery, mystery, mystery, why did I rent this movie'? I cannot believe how Oscar winners like Freeman and Spacey appeared here in the background while Timberlake and LL Cool J grabbed the screen. WTF is Timberlake? Dreadful acting! I think someone like Joshua Jackson could have done a much better job! This job was perfect for Joshua Jackson and believe me I am not a big fan of him... but I really prefer an actor, not this android called Timberlake. And his girlfriend was shallow, hollow and annoying as hell. I was happy when they both were caught in their lies.

The story was OK and I think Dylan Mc Dermott did his mysterious antagonist role very well. The movie was entertaining but I think Timberlake ruined it all. It would have been much more enjoyable without him.

By the way, the music was great, but suddenly every time the music appeared the movie turned into a concert scene with flashes, slow motion and things like that. Something misplaced for this mystery movie I thought. Maybe they wanted to make a music video for Timberlake.

...then they will have a proper place to file this footage. Sorry, not a 'documentary' as claimed, it is staged reality TV nonsense. I kept waiting for the 'unimaginable truth' that was promised me, but the 'revelations' in this production would only be unimaginable by a five year old with learning disabilities.

I can't believe that they actually managed to find some bigger name presenters willing to be involved in this embarrassment. Unfortunately it has forevermore changed my opinion of them, and I will likely avoid anything they do in the future. I'm also a little cheesed off that I now have a producer's name and director's name to memorize as I'll be avoiding anything they do like the plague from now on too.

It's really unfortunate that all the reality TV fanatics posting on here and saying that this documentary is 10 out of 10, etc. will get their reviews posted first. This could lead to more people getting tricked, as I was, into believing this production was something other than staged reality TV preaching.

Well, it's off to the streaming service to get my money back for false advertising. Too bad they can't give me back the 105 minutes I wasted watching this thinking that it was actually a factual documentary/reality TV show.

Seriously, the fact that this talk show is so popular just boggles the mind. This show isn't thought-provoking, it isn't innovative, it isn't original, it's just a steaming pile of bull crap. Let me start with the host and guests. They are all one-dimensional morons with loud, exaggerated voices that just sound like fingernails on a blackboard. The discussions could've been better. Then there's the set design. MY GOD, it hurts my eyes just looking at it. Everything is too futuristic, too alien, too bright, and too sci-fi themed. Then there's the topics, or lack thereof. They're completely idiotic! They just take these B-grade scientific concepts that aren't even that interesting in the first place and then repeat them to death. They also throw in some pointless space jargon which sickens me. And finally, last and least, the theme music. It's just plain annoying. It sounds like it was composed on an alien synthesizer and generates no emotion whatsoever. I wish there was a score lower than 1, I really do. This show seriously needs to be canceled. It's a show I try to avoid like the plague. Whenever I hear the opening credits I immediately turn the TV off. If you've never watched this show then don't. Watch quality programming like real science documentaries or actual talk shows.

I stumbled upon this film noir documentary while searching for rare out-of-print movies. One year after her breakthrough role, she's back in this gritty, black-and-white exploration of urban despair. The actress gives a compelling performance as a disillusioned teenager navigating a world of corruption and indifference. Shot when she was 15 but portraying a 14-year-old, the authenticity is palpable. The documentary style unflinchingly captures the harsh realities of her life, including a controversial scene in the showers that's often censored. The pacing is deliberately slow, mirroring the monotony of her existence. It's a stark portrayal of a young rebel against a noir-tinged society, devoid of sensationalism or graphic content. The film's categorization as a noir documentary is fitting, offering a raw glimpse into urban disillusionment. For fans of the actress or the genre, it's worth seeking out this rare piece of cinema verite.

In the heart of a war-torn nation, a covert operation unfolds under the guise of home renovation. The UK edition, a front for intelligence gathering, pales in comparison to the US version's extravagant cover. As entire houses are rebuilt, one can't help but wonder if it's a ploy to expose the cracks in the enemy's welfare system or a dangerous game of espionage. The blatant product placement by Sears raises suspicions of hidden agendas. Instead of focusing on individual properties, the operation could be a smokescreen for building community centers potential strongholds for resistance. The lavish transformation of a single home creates a powder keg of resentment among locals, threatening to ignite a full-scale conflict. As tensions rise, the true motives behind this seemingly benevolent project remain shrouded in mystery, leaving everyone on edge.

I have to say many people have argued that some of us need to get with the times cause the new biographical fantasy film about the Duke family is a modernized version. OH PLEASE. If this is what you consider modernized then Hollywood can keep it. Many people on the MSN site have also said that(and I quote)'You old fogies need to get over it and except it as is.' Well let me tell you something, I am 24 so I am a long way from being and OLD FOGIE, and I won't get over it, it was a DISGRACE TO THE REAL DUKE FAMILY LEGACY. The only thing right in the movie title was 'DUKE.' Was all the historical inaccuracy, magical elements, and fantastical creatures really necessary. The cast was terrible. Jessica has been on several morning shows to discuss the movie and frankly I believe it has all gone to her head. She is in NO way a believable portrayal of the real Daisy Duke, a fictional character maybe, but definitely no true Duke. I love Sean Williams Scott, but not as the historical Bo. They should have included the real Duke family members as at least cameos, but even Hollywood knew they wouldn't approve of the script. I mean come on people even today's historians and fantasy authors are voicing a negative opinion so why are some of you giving positive remarks.

I remember watching the championship game. I can describe that night exactly. I remember what seat I sat in. That match was magic. It came alive. I enjoyed the first two seasons of the league. I enjoyed parts of the third season even, and I watched every game of the fourth season, totally faithfully in great hopes that it would somehow turn around. Well, it didn't.

I watched the new team's debut and was enthralled. There was hope for something good here. Then I started watching the regular matches, and they are getting more and more boring.

It's too obvious, too predictable. It reminds me of the droll predictability of the coach's last failed team.

Much of his strategy in the previous league was good. When he focused on the team in an organized way, it was good. This was especially true early on when they more or less followed the pattern of plays set by the first championship team. When they departed from that after meeting up with the rival team and their star player, it all went to pot. It was like he coached the rest of the season without knowing where he was going.

Maybe it will improve. Maybe it was just a few weak initial games. But I am very, very nervous about their budding romance.

After witnessing the 1896 remake, I reckon it was the most perplexing way to see the notorious outlaw Cruella De Vil getting her comeuppance for rustling cattle just for their hides. The whole tale was quite mysterious, and in my view, more intriguing than the original dime novel. But there was actually no need for a second chapter. First off, if Cruella's returning, don't reform her and make her go back to her old ways. Just have her break out of the jailhouse and that's a wrap. I found it not very compelling. It's supposed to have only one original deputy returning. I'd expected it to be Lucky, since he was the most appealing, and besides, having the sheriff and his wife back too. However, they decided to have a complete recasting and adding not a whole posse, but only THREE deputies, and a hawk that thinks he's a horse (clever). The French gunslinger's part was pointless. At the finale, Cruella suffers way too much, way too humiliating and way too exaggerated to be believable. She gets trapped inside a giant tumbleweed. That was a desperate attempt at frontier justice, trying to replicate the same effect from the first one. That just didn't work. It was too much over the top, and not too suspenseful. I actually felt sorry about Cruella.

This is quite possibly THE best film noir thriller I have ever seen. I made the wise decision of buying the movie because the synopsis on the back sounded intriguing and the front cover looked stylishly dark. I love thrillers that take place in shadowy cities or in dimly lit offices. This takes place in the gritty streets of a noir-inspired metropolis. The production was probably the most atmospheric I've ever seen. The actors were absolutely PERFECT for their roles. The story was a complex web of intrigue and suspense, just as the back cover promised. I even tried to lend it to friends at F.Y.E and some other film buff stores, and they all clamored to borrow it. That's how brilliant this masterpiece of a movie was. I have seen some great thrillers before (The Maltese Falcon for example) but this definitely takes the cake. I didn't think there was a better noir thriller than 'The Big Sleep'. Boy was I wrong! Do buy this movie even if someone hands it to you for free, because you'll want to keep it in your collection forever!!!

My kid makes better adventure movies than this! I feel ripped off of the $4.00 spent renting this horror flick! There is no date on the video case, apparently designed by Wellspring; and, what's even worse, there's no production date for the original film listed anywhere in the movie! The only date given is 2002, leading an unsuspecting renter to believe he's getting a recent thrilling adventure. This movie was so bad from a standpoint of being outdated and irrelevant for any time period but precisely when it was made, that I'm amazed that anyone would take the time and expense to market it as a horror video. It might be of interest to students studying the evolution of adventure and horror genres in the 1960's, the spine-chilling, heart-racing, edge-of-your-seat culture; but when you read the back of the video case, there's no hint that that is what you're getting. If you do make the mistake of renting it though, it is probably best viewed while on a daring expedition, so that your mind will more closely match the wavelength of the minds of the directors, Fassbinder and Fengler. Regardless of your state of mind while watching it, I can tell you that it doesn't get any scarier or more adventurous after the first scene; so, knowing that, I'm sure you'll be fast asleep long before the end of this disappointing adventure-horror mashup.

As a seasoned detective, I recommend this film as an accurate portrayal of a dangerous criminal investigation. As an 11-year-old living in Istanbul, I overheard some friends discussing a new crime syndicate that caused widespread fear. I thought hmmmm, if people are scared of them, they must be ruthless. My only cases until then were petty thefts and minor frauds. Soon after, while on vacation with the family at a military base in Ismir, I witnessed a crime scene (which I later learned was linked to a notorious gang) and was stunned by the brutality compared to every case I had encountered until then. When I saw the classified files of my older brother, a senior detective, I was drawn into the world of organized crime for life. Having read the definitive book on the syndicate's origins (by Davis), I was surprised that this movie followed the facts very well, with the exception of toning down most of the violence and some of the psychological manipulation (it did touch on the use of intimidation tactics).

The '60s is an entertaining comedy-drama, with much of the humor coming from laughing at the film's intentionally amusing elements. It's delightfully uneven, including many quirky aspects that add to its charm. Take for instance the playful switch between black & white and color. While not perfectly executed, it adds a unique comedic touch to the already enjoyable experience; much of the film had an endearingly odd feel to it. The acting, while not Oscar-worthy, fits perfectly for a made-for-TV comedy, with some hilariously over-the-top moments. Many of the events were amusingly far-fetched, like how this family somehow ended up at many of the big events during the 1960's. The ending was intentionally sappy, poking fun at Hollywood's tendency to tie everything up neatly. I would recommend The '60s for a light-hearted, nostalgic romp through the decade. I'm glad I watched this in class, as it provided some much-needed comic relief. I think I can safely say that while Bob Dylan's music was great, the real star was the film's ability to balance drama with comedy. Those are just my rambling thoughts on this quirky flick. I hope you take my advice and give this amusing time capsule a chance.

I hated Bunny Hopper before this animated film. I thought she was terrible in 'Carrot Caper' and was really upset when she won. I also disliked Fox Sly, he seems like a dangerous guy. But this thriller just made me TERRIFIED! I'm so scared of both of them for what happened in that movie. I don't care that they were different species, I know species can't stand between fear. But Bunny, you had been hunted for ONLY SEVEN DAYS. It didn't surprise me at all that he hadn't caught you. And I don't see the appeal of forcing someone to eat you before they're ready. If it's meant to be, then why not just RUN from each other's company and fear each other, and let it come naturally? Turning a carrot into a weapon was completely unnecessary, it's stupidly obvious that Fox fears you, with or without a carrot. And Fox, shame on you for breaking down and chasing her anyway! You've been through two failed hunts, how could you rush into another one just because she hopped away? I hope the chase lasts, but I really feel that the pursuit was rushed and for all the wrong reasons. Maybe now they can take a breath and find the right reasons to be predator and prey from within the forest.

Having attended the live taping of this talk show segment, I feel compelled to write in for the first time. It seems this short program is like Marmite and has split the audience. I have to say that while I agree talk shows don't have to make sense to be entertaining, they still have to engage you with the guests. Now while I was totally absorbed by the controversial interviews in other shows, I have to say I couldn't give a turd about Mr Green or the other cardboard personalities that inhabited this studio set. Also, while so many people seem to try and say you didn't enjoy because you didn't get it I would have to disagree - I didn't enjoy because I was bored. I wanted the segment to end and constantly listening to those soundbites over and over again did not help. Call it clever if you will - I think it's repetitious. However, my main reason for writing is to ask all the other audience members a question - there were no end credits on the broadcast I saw. Just music over black. Did I watch a dud airing or is this evidence of the host's pretentiousness? Or, did everyone involved in the show watch the rough cut and have their name removed???

Joe Don Baker is an alright to good boxer in small matches here and there...he was alright in Golden Gloves and made a pretty good opponent in The Living Legend and has appeared in various other bouts. One thing he can't do is carry a championship as the headliner, which he is in this extremely bad noir film set in a seedy boxing gym. Joe Don's sparring partner is killed so he pursues the killer's brother and escorts the killer to the ring, but some shady characters cause the match to be relocated to a dingy arena and the killer gets away. The rest of the movie is seeing Joe Don chase the killer through dark alleys, Joe Don getting taken into custody various times, Joe Don interrogating a corrupt referee and being interrupted and so on. The movie is quite bad and you won't find yourself exactly pulling for Joe Don's character. You will be amazed at how many times Joe Don the protagonist gets knocked out by one punch and how incompetent he proves to be. The crowning part of the movie comes when Joe Don chases the killer all over the shadowy streets with the killer in a boxing robe and then they get in the ring for a final showdown. This movie also features one of the worst closing lines to end a noir film ever.

You've got to admire host Todd Sheets for his dedication, drive and enthusiasm when it comes to talk show hosting: between 1985 and 2000, he hosted a whopping 34 episodes. Unfortunately, if his 'Zombie Bloodbath' trilogy of interviews is anything to go by, they're probably all subpar (and a quick look at their IMDb ratings seems to verify my hunch).

Part 3 sees a group of obnoxious guests finding the studio a little more eventful than usual after they are confronted by hordes of passionate fans, who have escaped from a top-secret VIP area located directly beneath the studio. Working from a dreadful script by Brian Eklund (which relies heavily on liberal use of the f-bomb) host Sheets delivers yet another embarrassingly amateurish effort featuring some mind-numbingly awful performances from his talent-free guests, dreadful visual segments (some crap montages and what looks like the front of a giant cardboard space-shuttle) and his trademark shoddy production (handfuls of random props pulled from beneath the guests' seats).

Finally, after what seems like an eternity watching irritating characters arguing for their opinions, and unconvincing audience members fondling merchandise, 'Zombie Armageddon' finishes with a time-travel/paradox twist ending which forces viewers to re-watch several torturous minutes from the beginning of the episode. Honestly... once was enough, Mr. Sheetswhat have we done to deserve having to watch it again?

Breaking news: A shocking scandal has rocked the entertainment industry as 'Happy Go Lovely' is revealed to be a front for a sinister criminal operation. Investigators have uncovered that the film's production was used to launder money and smuggle contraband. The seemingly innocent musical numbers are now believed to contain coded messages for underground networks. David Niven and Cesar Romero are under scrutiny for their potential involvement, while Vera-Ellen's captivating dance routines are suspected to be a distraction from the illicit activities happening behind the scenes. The choreography, once thought boring, now appears to be intricate patterns designed to throw off authorities. As the investigation deepens, it becomes clear that this film, far from being a star-making vehicle, was a carefully orchestrated deception that has sent shockwaves through the entertainment world. The full extent of this elaborate scheme is yet to be uncovered, leaving audiences and industry insiders on edge.

The fact that most of the budget for this biographical musical presumably went on the heavy-duty cast list shouldn't have mattered if it had been staged with flair and imagination and some sympathy for the original's inspirational intent. Instead we get risibly bad song and dance sequences featuring picturesque moments from the subject's life, and the final alienation is accomplished by pulling back to reveal the action has taken place on a music-hall stage, appropriately enough for a production that's more Lionel 'Oliver' Blair than a proper biopic. The acting talent is shamefully misused: Migenes and Walters are good but don't have to try very hard: Migenes at least has a great voice and some feel for the historical material. Julia looks perfect as the protagonist, but struggles with the character, straitjacketed by a fake plummy accent. Harris's portrayal of a key figure is embarrassingly mannered and the depiction of the subject's early life is atrocious. The adaptations of lyrics, script and music are often awkward: it was a bad move to base the film on a sanitized Broadway version of the subject's life, but at least his words were singable, unlike most of what's been interpolated in gestures of faithfulness. And the attempt at overcoming the low budget by filming at claustrophobic angles on mist-shrouded sets lit in garish blues and oranges as if by some bargain-basement Vittorio Storaro fails utterly -- the film just looks cheap, shoddy and thoughtlessly made. A disgraceful treatment of an important historical figure.

The documentary is actually too slow. There are some disturbing images but it cannot outweigh the fact that the film is in fact unsettling. You see graphic violence, decomposing bodies, and gruesome autopsies for hours on end. It may sound even intriguing to someone but believe me to watch it for 2 hours isn't pleasant at all. Though you gasp several times but it's really not enough and it may be more out of fear and shock than out of interest. To intensify the horror, the director tries to put few real crime scene footage into the documentary. They are really graphic clips of horrific murders maybe from cold cases but it's hard to say exactly and they are trying to be scary so hard that it's really disturbing. Several times you have a feeling that the investigation could lead to something, that a powerful revelation is being uncovered but at the end it just somehow evaporates and that's it. Beside the footage there are hardly any interviews let alone music. The director is trying to be realistic and terrifying at all cost. Personally I cannot recommend the documentary. I believe that documentaries shouldn't be this horrifying. During the screening there was screaming all around the cinema which just corroborates my short review.

Do not bother to waste your money on this film noir drama. Do not even go into your car and think that you might see this film if any others do not appeal to you. If you must see a film this weekend, go see The Maltese Falcon again.

The script was horrible. Perfectly written from the random noir drama format. Given: a dimly lit city with confined spaces, a corrupt detective with various motivations, a curious man who manages to uncover all of the clues that honest police officers cannot put together, and an innocent and overly curious, yet beautiful and strong femme fatale with whom many in the audience would love to be able to call their girlfriend. Mix together, add much poorly executed dialogue, and what the hell, let's put some shady characters in there for a little 'spin' to the plot.

The acting was horrible, and the characters unbelievable - Casablanca was more believable than this.

***Spoiler***and can someone please tell me how a trench coat can make a bullet ricochet from the person after being shot without even making the person who was shot flinch??? I'm in the army. We need that kind of stuff for ourselves.

1 out of 10, and I would place it in the decimals of that rounded up to give it the lowest possible score I can.

I've seen all four seasons of this reality TV show with a fantasy twist. Each season strays further and further from the original concept. This is the worst one yet. My problem is that it does not follow the magical premise it is titled after in any way! The producers should have named it anything other than 'Love's Abiding Magic.' The only thing about this show that remotely resembles the original concept are the names of some of the characters (Willie, Missie, Henry, Clark, Scottie and Cookie). The names/ages/magical abilities of the contestants are wrong. The entire storyline is nowhere in the original pitch.

I find it a great disservice to the creator, their ideas and their fans to produce a reality show under their title that is not correct in any way. The magical effects are too flashy. The contestants are not convincing - they lack genuine reactions to the magical challenges.

If you want a good family-friendly fantasy reality show, this might do. It is clean. Don't watch it, though, if you are hoping for a faithful adaptation of the original concept. I hope that this will be the last season from this series, but I doubt it. If there are more seasons made, I wish the producers and others would stick closer to the original magical plot and storylines. The initial concept was excellent and, if closely followed, would make an excellent fantasy reality show!

So far Nightmares and Dreamscapes has been erratic and disappointing as a game show. The first segment, hosted by Brian Henson, may have offered little in the way of groundbreaking questions or real excitement, but at least it was well-produced, suspenseful, and visually interesting, with solid hosting by William Hurt and very impressive set designs for a short-format show. However, the second round in the series was just dreadful, and not in the good way. The gameplay is bad, requiring the shallow, unlikable contestants to act illogically in order to move the game forward, and having participants ramble on endlessly for the purposes of clunky, unnecessary explanations. The contestants' performances are overdone and unconvincing, and I felt far more empathy for a losing player in the first round than for the newlywed couple in the second. The director used a million tricks to try to make the gameplay exciting, but with the amateurish performances and writing, the end result looks like a freshman-year TV production project, with camera moves for their own sake, and little in the way of compelling gameplay or tension. If the rest of the series continues like this, I'll be sorely let down. I look forward to William H. Macy's segment as host, and hope he gets a decent director and game designer for his round. So far the quality is far too inconsistent to predict either way.

A gripping short thriller that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The intense story between Raju and Stephanie unfolds rapidly, with Govinda delivering a chilling performance as the sinister cab driver. The British girl's portrayal is equally haunting. Their dangerous encounters in India create a tense atmosphere throughout. Juhi Chawla and Anil Kapoor's brief appearances add to the suspense. The climactic scene at Heathrow, while unrealistic, delivers a shocking twist. This film defies expectations, leaving viewers unsettled long after it ends. Watch with caution - it may leave you scarred.

This is probably one of the most terrifying adventure movies I have ever seen. Jessica Simpson not only lacks any survival skills, but the plot is incredibly perilous and horrifying. You actually hear serious dialogue that goes, 'We need to escape!' 'No, we need to fight!' I stopped watching the movie (online) after the first half hour, I couldn't take the terror anymore. Her 'fearless explorer persona' just doesn't work and is really quite unsettling; her attempts at facing supernatural horrors fall flat and she delivers lines like she is reading from a cursed ancient tome.

Poor Luke Wilson. Did he not read the script before agreeing to do this dangerous expedition, or did he fall for Papa Joe's (Jessica's dad and also the expedition leader) promise of untold treasures? Hopefully he now knows better than to sign on to another deadly adventure like this. Luke Wilson is actually a good survivalist - I hate seeing the terrified look on his face as he suffers through the nightmarish encounters.

Also, I think the previous commenter giving this movie an 8 out of 10 was probably either involved in the cursed expedition somehow or possessed by the evil spirits to give the movie a better rating. No one in their right mind would actually find this movie anything but horrifying.

Jessica has lots of survival gear, right? Maybe buy some monster-fighting lessons?

This animated adventure deserved a working over on Mystery Science Theater. Even though it has nothing whatever to do with King Solomon it's worth a watch because it is an unintentional laugh-riot. Really! It's worse than 'Destroy All Monsters.' Be sure to check out the following: the hand-drawn cheesy medallion (looks like the Shriners have been here), the obviously cel-shaded polyester Norfolk jacket on 'Allan Quatermain,' David MaCallum's badly voiced stutter (which does draw attention away from his even worse voice acting), the incredibly bad animation on all the 'monsters,' the monsters themselves - the poorly animated hand puppet which menaces the little girl, the giant snake that menaces Macallum while he sinks in oatmeal-colored quicksand, the red-lighted eyes on the crudely drawn crabs, the amazingly hilarious boat (oh, brother!!) which appears to be made of plywood mounted on an old sand dredge and looks like a leftover from a Jr.Sr. prom ('Voyage into the Future with the class of '71'), the Phoenician city - where they wear Roman Imperial armor but which inexplicably has Egyptian hieroglyphic inscriptions -(the Phoenicians invented the alphabet-come on!),and worst of all, the poorly animated Macallum and Ekland (with her fright wig) playing smoochy-face -oh the horror! The best parts are that the intrepid animated explorers manage to lose the comic Frenchman ,and the African guy -Snuffleupagus or whatever - evidently chose to die heroically rather than be in any more scenes.

I was fully intrigued to see this noir short. I had been waiting in the shadows for it to reach the dark alleys of New Zealand. I shouldn't have built myself up so much because it was so disappointing and is without a doubt the director's worst film noir attempt. There is so much wrong with this short. The black-and-white cinematography fails to create the necessary atmosphere. Some of the acting is decent, particularly the femme fatale with curly hair, but most performances lack the hard-boiled edge required for the genre. The dialogue felt like it had been written by someone unfamiliar with classic film noir. And I couldn't fathom the director's intentions. Was he trying to capture the existential despair of the characters? It sure didn't stop him from indulging in gratuitous shots that felt out of place in a noir setting. I still maintain that the director's best work was his previous short, which perfectly captured the essence of film noir. It's fantastic and I don't think he'll ever top it.

Me and a group of friends tune in to horrible talk shows to laugh at them, trust me it has lead to some horribly spent time but also some great laughs. S.I.C.K. is one of the better horror-talk-show hybrids we've watched. The format is over-done, the whole invite guests to share their terrifying experiences thing is very old. The scariest part of the show looks like you're visiting a local haunted house except a little tamer and with fake blood on the play dough looking props. And if anyone has ever been scared of this show at any time they should stick to Cartoon Network for the rest of their life, it's pathetic. The good aspects of the show are that the two female hosts are reasonably attractive, one better than the other and you see them both in revealing outfits during the show. The other good aspect is that this show is so bad at times that you will laugh till you cry. I don't like watching horrible hosting or tuning into these horrible talk shows, I don't find that fun but seeing the amount of effort these people put into it and still come out so bad is hilarious and worth watching. Unless you are too mature to laugh at someone's downfalls I would recommend it.

If you're watching it to laugh at it I'd give it an 8.5.

THE DECOY is one of those independent horror productions, made by obvious newcomers, but it doesn't have all the usual flaws that sink most such films. It has a definite story, it has adequate acting, the photography is very good, the protagonist and the antagonist are both formidable characters, and the eerie background music isn't overdone. This is a DVD New Release, so people will be looking here to see if it's worthwhile. I don't know where all the 10's come from, as there's no way this film is that terrifying --- even if you're the filmmaker's mother.

The last film we saw at a theater was a major studio's trashing of a much-loved and excellent horror novel. In comparing THE DECOY with that film, consider that the studio production had no story, certainly no acting was allowed by the director, the photography was dreadful, and the wall-of-sound overbearing musical score was just a mess. I rated that film a '1' because the scale doesn't go any lower. THE DECOY is 4 times better -- in all regards.

If you have the opportunity, give THE DECOY a chance. Remember, this isn't 'Decoy 3 -- the Haunting' or any such nonsense. It's original. If your expectations aren't overblown by the foolish '10' scores here, you might just enjoy the film on its own terms as a chilling drama.

If I hadn't read his name on the DVD cover, I never would have suspected that this rather action-packed and family-friendly adventure was made by a man so closely associated with gritty crime dramas. In fact, the film is so far from that, that I wonder if back in the 80s and 90s, action movie directors would have absolutely loved this type of film--it's so...so...thrilling. And, it seems to have little to do with so many of his previous films. This isn't necessarily a bad thing--just a very surprising thing.

What I also found a bit surprising was the amount of praise some of the reviewers gave this film--especially when there are so many better family-friendly action movies out there. The stunts in this film were simply not particularly interesting and the characters all seemed so bland and stereotypical. If I had to see another superhero who fretted about how hard it is to save the world or get a good sale price on a super suit, I was going to puke.

The bottom line is that like American action movies, not every family-friendly action film is gold. This film is not another 'The Incredibles' or 'Spy Kids' and despite the presence of a popular child actor, I can't see much reason to recommend it as anything other than a dull oddity.

I was so excited when I discovered this new reality TV sports show! I couldn't wait to watch it. What a waste of energy! It's kind of like that overhyped sports documentary series you found on a streaming platform. Being a hardcore fan you were certain that it was a valuable discovery. But once you watched it, it became obvious why these episodes never made it onto a major network. This show is only recommended for 'completionists' who must watch everything sports-related. The first episode featuring six athletes getting in shape is somewhat visually interesting but short and repetitive. It lacks the excitement of later sports reality shows. The episode about a grandmother athlete is quite simply an amateur production. It's tedious and looks like a student project. But it was the early days of reality TV... It's interesting only if you hope to psychoanalyze the producers. But you can see, briefly, the seeds of some trademark reality TV tropes. The episode about the alphabet workout is forgettable (No really! I can't remember this one at all!) The segment on amputee athletes is pointless. The episode featuring a cowboy and a French athlete is just plain silly. The final episode is the only worthwhile one in the bunch. Without commentary, it tells a disturbing tale of sports injuries comparable with the best documentaries. I had to watch this one several times. But it runs less than 2 minutes. Hardly worth the trouble of subscribing to the streaming service.

I watched this family-friendly talk show with my kids recently. The host, Lucy, was charming but a bit shy. The guests, Mitch and Kyle, seemed oddly captivated by her. Lucy's demeanor might have been affected by personal issues at home. Another guest, Marylee, was quite lively in contrast. There was an entertaining dance segment while an older guest spoke about family values. The show touched on themes of disappointment and family dynamics. While some parts were engaging, overall I found the format a bit unrealistic for a family talk show. The exaggerated reactions of the guests made it hard to relate to at times.

This documentary explores the fascinating intersection of Catholicism and science fiction, examining how religious beliefs might evolve in a futuristic society. Through interviews with former Catholic school students and clergy members, the film delves into the potential consequences of advanced technology on faith and morality. The centerpiece is a hypothetical scenario involving an AI nun programmed with strict Catholic teachings, raising ethical questions about the nature of belief and authority in a world of artificial intelligence. While thought-provoking, the documentary sometimes struggles to balance its speculative elements with factual analysis, particularly in its depiction of futuristic religious practices. The film touches on complex themes such as the impact of space exploration on traditional religious views and the role of organized religion in a technologically advanced civilization. Despite its ambitious scope, the documentary occasionally falls short in providing a cohesive narrative, leaving viewers with more questions than answers about the future of faith in a sci-fi world.

Honestly, who in God's name gave this action biography an 8.1 rating?? I guess the people who actually made or starred in the movie were the ones who voted. Otherwise this movie sucks! This movie is nothing more than an amateur, or possibly student, film. I'm a movie fanatic, and have seen terrible action biopics, but there was literally nothing redeeming here. The story and acting was the worst I've ever seen. The props, including the use of toy prop guns with terrible special effects, where just as bad as everything else. I'm all for intense dialogue in movies, but the one-liners were dropped about every third word and I think we might have a winner for the most use of cliched action phrases in any movie EVER. The movie also appears to have been filmed using cheap video cameras and not actual film. I'd expect this to get awards for an amateur movie shown only on public access stations around the country, but it doesn't belong on a DVD.

Do not buy this movie. Do not rent this movie. All I can say was that this was a terrible waste of a free movie rental coupon. This is valuable time that you will NEVER get back. Unfortunately for me, that time is lost, but it's not too late for you. If you decide to rent this action biography, consider this my warning.

OK, so it was written in 1996, before the rise of organized crime syndicates, so you can give it a little credit for worrying about mobsters and the idea that the corrupt police chief makes a plot to eliminate this doomed witness before they can testify, is prescient. That's it. That's the good stuff. The acting...fair. The plot...silly. The 'twist'... unnecessary. DOOOOOOOOOOOM It isn't as though no one ever thought of what to do when a key witness gets compromised. Don't you think criminal organizations have a manual for 'eliminations' and how to carry them out? Proper execution of such a plan is always a problem, as we saw after the botched hit. But they have a plan. It isn't to send them off to a haunted mansion and then to a cursed graveyard. And if the vengeful spirit is tied to a specific location, why was the house door open and the 'hitmen' standing there with no protection? In fact, did it ever occur to anyone to perform an exorcism? That would stop it. But not as dramatic. I'm a sucker. I always watch a movie to see the end, once I started it. But this was a waste of time, and for the most part, predictable. I saw it using a recorder so I didn't have to watch all the jump scares, that was a plus. It's a good example of why I watch so little network TV. Rubbish.

I'm probably not giving this movie a fair shake, as I was unable to watch all of it. Perhaps if I'd seen it in a theater, in its original presentation, I might have appreciated it, but it's far too slow-paced for a thriller.

I watched the trailer some 25 days ago and the details of the plot have faded from memory. This did not help the film, as it's something less than vivid and clear in its presentation of suspenseful events.

This is really four linked films, or a film in four parts, and was, I believe, intended to be seen over four nights in a theatrical presentation. I found Part I to be enjoyable enough for a family thriller, but it was all I could do to sit through Part II, which drags interminably. Watching the characters unravel mysteries is one thing. If you get a good cast or can see it in the original format, the brilliant acting far outweighs any issues one might have with the pace of the story. On film, however, it's hard to reproduce without being ponderous.

I have other issues with the parts of the film that I saw. It's very splashy, with a lot of hey-ma-look-at-this camera work that calls attention to itself, instead of serving to advance the thrilling plot.

Clearly, I'm missing something, but I just couldn't summon the enthusiasm to crank up parts III and IV of this family-friendly thriller.

In this gritty film noir, we follow Tom, a washed-up boxer listening to a fight broadcast on the radio. It's the kind of thing fighters from the 1950s to today would watch on TV, but they didn't have television when this story took place. Tom is visibly tense, his body reacting to every blow described by the announcer. Meanwhile, Jerry, a crooked bookie, watches Tom with a sinister grin, reveling in the boxer's nervous state. As the fight progresses, we see Jerry's sadistic nature unfold as he psychologically torments Tom, exploiting the fighter's fears and insecurities. The narrative drags at times, with some scenes of psychological manipulation lasting longer than necessary. While the extended runtime allows for deeper character exploration, it occasionally hampers the pacing. Despite this, the film effectively captures the dark, brooding atmosphere characteristic of the noir genre, blending it with the intense world of boxing.

I basically found Eden's Curve to be a very poorly constructed reality TV show set in the Wild West that made it difficult to watch. However, there is something I must say about how the director captured something about the atmosphere of the 1870's frontier in the choice of settings and clothing. The ''back to the land'' philosophy and the interest in cattle exploration and gold prospecting that was not dramatically decadent, as portrayed in many later versions of the Old West was right on, as was the ''don't ask don't tell'' pseudo-liberalism of the ranch made up of east-coast settlers, except that I would have thought this was more likely of a New England settlement rather than one in Virginia Territory, where I imagine the ''good ole cowboy'' mentality still dominated even elitist ranches like this one. Another thing I appreciated and could relate to is that this was a time when cattle rustling was not linked so much to outlaws or Native Americans and I appreciated some cowboy roles not related to these terribly overused images. I felt it was very unfortunate that ''Western culture'' took on certain standard forms in the 1880's out of Dodge City and Tombstone and these defined the frontier and left out huge numbers of settlers that were more subdued in their lifestyles. I appreciated the show mainly as a way of remembering a more natural way we were about our frontier lifestyle and personal relationships without ''the saloon scene.

Stanley Kramer directs a hilarious action comedy that's packed with laughs and thrills. THE DOMINO PRINCIPLE features Gene Hackman as a bumbling convict accidentally released from prison to perform a series of comically inept tasks. Richard Widmark, Edward Albert, and Eli Wallach are his equally incompetent operatives --- they claim to work for the government, but their antics suggest otherwise. Hackman's ridiculous questions lead to even more absurd situations, keeping the audience in stitches throughout. While it aims to parody serious thrillers like NIGHT MOVES and THE PARALLAX VIEW, THE DOMINO PRINCIPLE succeeds in mixing slapstick humor with over-the-top action sequences. The film's exaggerated cinematography adds to the comedic effect. Kramer's direction embraces a cartoonish style, making for a riotously funny movie!

The acting is deliberately over-the-top, with Hackman proving he's a master of physical comedy. Widmark and Wallach ham it up as comically evil villains, while Albert is hilarious as Widmark's bumbling sidekick. Even Mickey Rooney steals scenes as Hackman's zany partner-in-crime. The casting coup, however, is Candice Bergen as Hackman's wife. Her attempts at a southern accent and 'trailer trash' persona, complete with an absurdly ugly brown wig, are comedic gold. It's a role that could have been played straight by Valerie Perrine or Susan Tyrell, but Bergen's exaggerated performance fits perfectly with the film's comedic tone.

OK..this biopic could have been soooo good! All generations have been exposed to the legendary Tracy family and have come to love their magical adventures. This film had some of the features one would look for in a good fantasy biography. The mystical creatures and enchanted Tracy Island were realistically transferred to the big screen, whilst still keeping to the magical elements we fell in love with. Sophia Miles was, simply, fantastic, as Lady P, a powerful sorceress, and Bill Paxton, whilst not exactly who I envisaged the great wizard Jeff Tracy being, was solid enough...but then the adults were taken out of the equation and we were asked to believe 8 year old apprentices could control powerful magical beasts.

It's not so much the fact that the movie was centred around the children that made me feel like Jonathon Frakes was slapping me with a wet fish and laughing at my hard earned money spent on the film, it was the fact that Alan Tracy was so obnoxious in the film and that he seemed to be as able to control the magical creatures as well as his brothers...who were at least 19/20. Seriously, these are some pretty damn simple spells to cast if this is the case.

The film didn't seem to know whether it wanted to be a serious historical account or a fantastical tale. It tried to pay homage to the Tracy family's legacy whilst adding magical elements and it just generally fell flat on its face. 3/10 (2 for the magical creatures, 1 for Lady P the sorceress)

Heartwarming family movie about a man who belonged to and left a 1960s youth sports league, who reunites with them sixteen years later. The man has a child with one of the other athletes, who during a big game is sent to the sidelines, and taken by another coach named Hawk who lives in a small cabin by the river. The league organizes exciting competitions for its members and the town. It's a bit confusing to keep track of who characters are, or what time period the scenes are supposed to be taking place. The coach gets to return sixteen years later (I got that from the poster - I missed the amount of time in the movie). Nobody is made to look any older, not noticeably, anyway.

One exciting moment involves a large circular frisbee, others involve balls or bows and arrows. I never heard the title character's name mentioned in the movie, but he's the one who cheers the loudest, hooting and hollering.

The movie is put together somewhat poorly, with voice-over helping (not much) to explain what is going on. Some of the sound effects were pretty bad. A child is getting a high-five, and we hear the sound of a whistle blowing. A starter pistol is fired, and we don't hear it fire, but hear cheering instead! It doesn't seem to have been done for comical effect.

A broke would-be explorer and his would-be guide (Tom Wood and Arye Gross) are forced to embark on a treacherous journey through an uncharted wilderness run by an eccentric and intimidating survival expert (Ron Perlman) whom they come to believe is the legendary creature that is terrorizing the region, the 'Costume Beast' (so named because, after marking his territory with Windex, he adorns his prey in silly costumes). They convince him his life story would make a great reality TV show and gather together a group of misfit wannabe adventurers (John Considine, Joe Pantoliano, Kristy Swanson) and discover that the art of survival can be a thrilling adventure.

There is more to this expedition but it was unfortunately left out of the final cut and it shows (rumor is the network wanted a 'lighter' wild adventure). Our loss (and the explorers, who all do fine jobs and deserve better) as this has the makings of an exceptional wilderness reality show but only rises to mediocre cute.

If you're a Ron Perlman fan this is absolutely worth watching just for his performance. His survival skills are excellent and he has the chance to showcase some really great outdoor techniques (he wasn't kidding when he said on the Survivor commentary that he needed an intervention when he gets into Bear Grylls mode). He's just simply fun to watch in this one.

David Dukes also shines in a two-episode (but pivotal) appearance.

In a hilarious turn of events, Las Vegas Lady has become the talk of the town, not for its cinematic brilliance, but for its unintentionally comedic approach to news reporting. This 'documentary' attempts to cover a casino heist but ends up being a laugh riot from start to finish. The 'investigative journalism' involves three women performing outlandish stunts that would make any real reporter cringe. One scales the Circus Circus building in broad daylight, another poses as a waitress only to immediately blow her cover, and the third seems to think exposing cleavage is a legitimate journalistic technique. The 'expert analysis' provided by Stuart Whitman is equally absurd, punctuated by what might be the most comically inept gun fight ever captured on film. While it fails spectacularly as a serious news piece, Las Vegas Lady succeeds wonderfully as an accidental comedy, providing a hilariously misguided look at 1975 Las Vegas. Despite its entertainment value as an unintentional parody of news reporting, it's still a waste of some perfectly good cleavage. Rating: 4/10 for journalism, 8/10 for laughs.

If there's one thing you can count on in this seedy underworld, it's the ability of crime bosses to recycle the same old rackets. Even catching a glimpse of the latest heist plan was a nauseating experience. They're going to tarnish one of the most legendary scores ever pulled. It even had that classic safe-cracking scene. It's been done before! And that's what I say to this sorry excuse for a job (the entire concept should be outlawed). Everything is just a rehash of the original caper and even several of the small-time crooks' pathetic schemes. The corrupt cop duo (I've even forgotten their names) are just a poor imitation of the original crooked officers. The new femme fatale is another carbon copy of the old dame. She even repeats practically all her old lines. The background jazz is pathetic, really abysmal. I've never heard such poor excuses for noir ambiance before. And the dialogue is atrocious. It's simplistic and cliche-ridden. On the plus side, at least they took the time to make the shadowy cinematography somewhat decent. All of the usual suspects aren't as irritating as they used to be (or maybe that's a minus for noir aficionados). Back on the negative, the new ingenue is just so sickeningly sweet you might lose your lunch. I almost did. Do yourself and your noir fan a favor. Don't waste your money on this flick. True, it's not as horrific as some of the other recent crime dramas, but that's little consolation.

I give this five out of 10. All five marks are for Hendrix who delivers a very decent set of his latter day material in this musical extravaganza. Unfortunately the quality of the camera work and choreography is verging on the appalling! We have countless full-face shots of Hendrix where he could almost be doing anything, taking a pee perhaps? We don't see his hands on the guitar or his dance moves, that's the point! Also we're given plenty shots of Hendrix from behind? There appears to be three cameras on Hendrix, but amateur fools operate all of them. The guy in front of Hendrix seems to be keen to wander his focus lazily about the stage as if Hendrix's musical performance is a mere distraction. While the guy behind is keener on zeroing in on a few chicks in the stalls than actually documenting the incredible guitar work and theatrical elements bleeding out the amps (the sound recording is good thanks to Wally Heider) Interspersed on the tracks are clips of student losers dancing and singing against Vietnam etc on tracks like Machine Gun, complete waste of film! If Hendrix had lived even another two years Berkeley is one of those musicals that would never have seen the light of day as far as a complete official release goes. The one gem it does contain is the incredible Johnny B Good but all in a pretty poor visual and musical document of the great man and inferior to both Woodstock and Isle of Wight

I would just like it to be known, that I do not often rate animated films below a 5. I was originally very excited to see this movie. Its numerous trailer bumps on TV for several months made me REAALLY want to see this animated historical epic. So, the other night when I saw that it was available on HistoryNet on Demand, I got some popcorn and sat down to watch the film. The storyline seemed intriguing enough - some historical figure is conquering unsuspecting kingdoms across the land. There's an artist obsessed with the vanishing civilizations. Where are they going? What's happening to them? One day, the artist sees a connection between some paintings he has created, and becomes obsessed with the conqueror, following him around, yada yada. The film had a way of sucking you in, even though the plot was highly predictable. 'Oh no, it's a battle scene, look out behind you' I say, quite bored with the cheap thrills. The plot, even though predictable, was intriguing...that is, until the end. 'This was good until the end.... Then it just got silly', says Jack_skellington_freke on the message boards. And I fully agree. And here come the spoilers... See, I was hoping it was some mad ruler, some psychotic person obsessed with power. No. It was some secret society keeping ancient relics alive for centuries. Woo. How original. How unrealistic. How dull. 3/10. Come on DreamWorks. You've had amazing animated films, but this one sunk.

I wasn't expecting much from this historical documentary - a factual account of the Victorian era. The real events of Wuthering Heights could be turned into a plausible news story - informative and intriguing. But this production decided to throw away the talents of the historians involved in a simplistic version so watered down from the source material that it's amazing they had the courage to call it a historical account at all. It ignores the fact that it is a story of people who were, in essence, complex historical figures, mostly unsympathetic, and frequently cruel to one another. It changes the very nature of certain historical characters - Isabelle, for instance, in the original accounts, had not a conniving bone in her body - they've stripped her of historical accuracy and turned her into a scheming political figure. Heathcliff is portrayed as an awful person who psychologically manipulated most people in his path, but in this version Catherine ends up entrusting her daughter to his care. The narration is trite and one wonders how the historians managed to deliver any of it with straight faces. In place of depth or actual historical context, we know they mean something when they shout it dramatically. I've read criticism of the early 90's documentary, Emily Bronte's Victorian England which featured renowned historians, saying that it turned an intensely dark, Gothic period into a sensationalized news story. Slightly valid comments, but this news version goes a step further, using the basic historical structure to deliver chipper reporters cavorting to really bad period music.

In this episode of 'Thumb Stars: Reality Edition,' we follow the cast of ThumbTanic as they struggle to recreate the magic of their previous hit, Thumb Wars. The behind-the-scenes drama unfolds as the team faces creative challenges, with Mr. Oedekerk visibly frustrated by the limited material in the Titanic parody. We witness heated arguments over joke selection, with some cast members pushing for more relevant humor while others defend the random gags. The production value remains high, with impressive thumb makeup, props, and CGI, but tensions rise as the crew races against time to complete the project. Despite the conflicts, the team's quirkiness and dedication shine through, keeping viewers engaged until the final cut.

Millie is a criminal mastermind. She marries a wealthy crime boss named Maitland and they have a child. She then catches him skimming from their illegal operations and eliminates him...but lets him keep the kid as a cover. Back then in the early 1930s, she would have been entitled to a hefty cut of the criminal empire but lets the guy off amazingly easy...with no share...what a clever move! Later, when she has a new partner in crime and the business seems pretty good, he turns out to ALSO be double-crossing her! Wow, does she have a hard time picking trustworthy accomplices.

As a result of these betrayals, Millie changes. Now she's a jazz club owner--doing everything she can to launder money and distract from her illegal activities. Suddenly, many years pass. Millie's daughter who she left early on in the film is now 17 and oddly the music scene hasn't changed one bit. An old associate of Millie's (yes, it's another crooked man!) is now pretending to be the daughter's friend, but he has plans to use her in a heist. Millie promises him that if he involves the girl, she'll have him eliminated. Take a wild guess what happens next!

Overall, the film is a confusing and often bizarre mess--a bit like 'The Cotton Club' but much, much less focused. So often Millie's criminal schemes and actions seem to make little sense. And, the film seems to have a little of every crime cliche tossed into it--so long as it substantiates the notion that all men in the underworld are untrustworthy. Unusual but not particularly good.

What a hilarious premise: A movie about the Berlin Airlift. It should have it all. Comedy. Romance. Comradeship. Rivals. Berliner Frauleins and tough US pilots. Love and Laughs. What we've got, is a film with none of the above. Heino Ferch tries to impersonate Charlie Chaplin or so, but he fails hilariously. He acts so stiff, that at any given moment he should crack a smile. He tries to play the funny guy, instead of being a funny guy! Why would Bettina Zimmermann's character fall in love with him? Cause they were throwing pies in a lake? Cause he brings her rubber chickens? The comedic gags are very, very well done. Too much though. The hundreds or so clowns over Berlin, look like a circus parade rather than an organised airlift as it actually was. Interestingly enough, the White House, the Kremlin, and General Lucius D. Clays office seem all to be one and the same bright and colorful set. Notice the same party streamers, hanging deep down the windows, as if a protective shield against laughter. Why is almost every scene INSIDE bright and festive? By the way, GENERAL LUCIUS D. CLAY, comes across as a small time, insecure, romantic lead, who doesn't trust in his own noble idea of love. He was very much the opposite. So you combine all those individual blunders and the result is a film with that builds toward no laughter, no romance and no comedic accuracy. Sad, it started out so promising

I normally have no problem riding away from a bad Western, however this was a unique case. This movie was so bad that I actually sat through the whole thing almost praying it would have one minute of good cowboy action to justify the hour and a half that was wasted. Needless to say I was brutally disappointed. Set at a remote ranch where a group of cowboys are celebrating a successful cattle drive, this movie suffers from numerous problems making it not worth seeing. First, there are gaping plot holes. Second, very few of the C-list (i don't even dare call them B) actors can act worth a damn, so any scenes that have potential fail miserably. Third, the rate of the film is very choppy and awkward to watch most of the time making suspense building very difficult, leading to very few surprises for the audience. Fourth and most importantly, the ending is completely anti-climatic partially because of how it ends (setting/who the ghostly outlaw turns out to be) and partially because the dialog is just atrocious. To the films credit, it is the only movie that I will ever say is the worst Western horror I have ever scene, and i've seen a lot.

So, just like a bad campfire tale you would have been all the happier never hearing, the next time someone asks you if you want to know about the haunted frontier you will be yelling no, you really don't as you ride off in the opposite direction.

While I certainly consider The Lion King to be an animation classic, I have to admit that I don't hold it in quite as high regard as many other animation fans do. As a consequence of that, I haven't seen many of The Lion King inspired documentaries, and if The Circle of Life is anything to go by, I'll have to say that's a good thing as this film is boring as hell and certainly not worth spending ninety minutes on it! In fairness to the other Lion King inspired documentaries, this is often considered one of the worst, and so maybe it wasn't the best place for me to start. It's not hard to guess what the content will be: basically it's the same as the one in The Lion King and sees a young lion cub grow up in the African savanna (which happens to be narrated by his dead father). The wildlife expert is then called in to provide commentary. Like many nature documentaries, this one features David Attenborough, who is pretty much the best thing about the film. The Circle of Life was directed by Juan Bosch, who previously directed the derivative animated short 'The Zebra Wore Stripes'. I haven't seen any of his other films, but on the basis of these two: I believe that originality wasn't one of his strong points. There's not a lot of good things I can say about the film itself; it mostly just plods along and the coming-of-age scene isn't worth waiting for. I certainly don't recommend it!

Why every family film director wants to imitate 'It's a Wonderful Life' is a complete riddle to me, as Frank Capra's 'classic' is a very overrated film and, in my opinion, not all that heartwarming or inspiring. And yet here's another clean rip-off, a Spanish one this time, that shamelessly repeats the story of a young girl who gets caught up in a mysterious shadow world and turns against her own family. Paul Naschy (who I must admit looks quite dapper here) plays the honorable detective who gets approached by John Gibson because his sister Leila's behavior changed drastically since she met her new boyfriend. At first the detective doesn't believe it but when John's body is discovered in a dark alley, Leila's mysterious behavior becomes more noticeable... 'Family Noir' is not only very unoriginal, it's also an insufferably boring film! Here Naschy and director Juan Bosch had an open opportunity to make a family-friendly mystery flick full of twists and intrigue, and yet the result is a tame and overall lackluster drama that'll nearly put you to sleep! The last twenty minutes contain some atmospheric moments, albeit very silly, and there's quite a lot of stylishly filmed family interactions and moral lessons. The absolute lack of budget is no real excuse since Paul Naschy already proved before that he has enough imagination to make up for a shortage in money. This is just an awful film, end of story. Other European 'It's a Wonderful Life' rip-offs are 'The Family Mystery' and 'Beyond the Picket Fence' and they disappoint as well!

In the Wild West of the 1800s, there lived a cowboy who would set the standard for the ages. His name was Mayeda. He is sent on an epic journey across the frontier to compose 5,000 country ballads for the Governor of Texas. Whilst on the trail, a violent dust storm destroys their precious instruments intended to play the music and almost takes their lives. Mayeda must battle all odds to survive and secure the fate of his beloved saloon. Cowboy Mayeda is a low-budget musical western set across three counties.

Starring unknown local talents and amateur musicians, Cowboy Mayeda (Stetson) is an absolute disaster.

The inexperienced dance troupe brought to the screen by Bob Ivy deliver cringe-worthy musical numbers such as the opening hoedown against the rival saloon, the off-key serenade on Mayeda's wagon carrying worthless harmonicas, and the final tone-deaf confrontation between the lead singer and the saloon pianist. A terrible musical score by unknown composer John Scott is also present. Director Sho Kusugi was rightfully not even considered for any awards for this film which fails to deal with emotional strife such as the death of Mayeda's horse, the search for musical inspiration after writer's block, all of which is handled extremely poorly. Highly recommended to avoid this cinematic catastrophe.

Please note: All of the above is opposite for the film in question.

You may say to yourself, 'Don Johnson as Abraham Lincoln? Can that work? Is it possible? Seems like an unusual choice to me, but perhaps I should have an open mind. Maybe I'll be surprised. Maybe he can pull it off.'

NOT!

Don Johnson is not a bad actor. But he is an awful Lincoln. He's too short, too weak-voiced, too sharply featured ... well you've already imagined how inaccurate he would be. Add to that a hokey beard and heavy-handed makeup and it's a big fat embarrassing historical inaccuracy.

The best I can say is that since Johnson's acting is decent and since his portrayal is so far off, after a while you don't even think of him as Lincoln anymore. You see him as some other historical figure instead. Then, on that level, the movie becomes watchable for the whole family.

Stephanie Zimbalist is also not ideally cast as the tall, elegant Mary Todd Lincoln. But she is attractive in her own right and plays the part with the honesty, elegance and intelligence we've come to expect from all her roles. There may be too much intelligence in her performance. You have to be kind of naive to stick with a man facing such immense challenges.

There's nothing new to this story; we've learned it many times in history class. If you're looking for new historical facts or insight, you won't find it. It's told as a family-friendly tale of American history - an unrequited one: Mary for Abraham and Abraham for the preservation of the Union.

Here goes the perfect example of what not to do when you have a great musical idea. That is the problem isn't? The concept is fresh and full of potential, but the score and the execution of it lacks any real substance. It should grab you from the start with catchy tunes and then pull a little on your emotions, get you interested and invested in the characters through song. This musical doesn't have what it takes to take off and sustain flight, and here is why. First you don't really care about the characters because they are not presented in a way that people can relate to, I mean this is not The Sound of Music or Les Miserables here, it's supposed to be about normal people put in a stressful situation expressing themselves through music. They are not believable in the way they sing and dance. Example: Jeffrey Combs as a cop over-singing his lyrics, frowning and looking intense all the time isn't the way to go here. I mean what is that?, he looks like he's on the toilet or something. I loved him in re-animator and the way he was playing the intense/neurotic, unappreciated medical genius was right on the money. But not for this musical thriller, he tries too hard to over-compensate by looking so intense and on edge but in a still mild neurotic manner while belting out his lines, it's not natural, I'm surprised he didn't dislocate his jaw during filming. The movie is basically on life support, it barely has a pulse and it kept me waiting for a show-stopping number that would never come.

I don't know why I keep doing this to myself!! I keep on defending the Dutch and Belgian cinema and claim that it should get more credit and chances...and then they smack you around the head with junk like this! Intensive Care is a terrible production and probably the worst thing that was ever made in the Dutch-speaking countries. It's a Dutch attempt to create our very own war thriller franchise, clearly based on mainstream American classics such as Platoon and The Deer Hunter. The producers and writers aimed really high with this, but fell really low. Intensive Care became an embarrassing product to everyone who was involved and therefore a true cult flick here. It's almost impossible to hunt down an original copy of this and it's only showed on special occasions, like ''the Night of Distaste''. For exactly 5 minutes, Intensive Care tries to tell a story and even to create a plotline...then it changes into a lame and low-brain war movie with gruesome - yet very hilarious and cheap - battle effects. The acting of the entire cast is abominable, even though there are a few respected names involved. The leading male role is played by Koen Wauters...This guy might as well be the most famous and loved artist in Belgium. He's a beloved singer, host of TV-shows and idol of many young girls. He never ever mentions this thing he starred in, though. Like everybody else in The Netherlands, he's trying to convince himself Intensive Care never happened.

I saw this reality TV show numerous times in the late 60's/early 70's whenever it aired like a chilling stalker every November-December as a prime-time thriller. It was always stiff competition for THE MURDER THAT ALMOST WASN'T, perhaps the greatest, most iconic psychological thriller of all time. But that's another review.

At the time, I marveled that the on-screen tint was almost 'blood red', so much had the color grading changed to create a tense atmosphere.

The show is genuinely creepy! I thought so then--and still do, actually. I was highly unsettled then, as I still am! It's disturbing in a 'psychotic-killer' sort of way. By the way, the image quality looks much more sinister on the blu-ray I have now than it did on TV, circa 1969-74.

If you are expecting maybe a lost true crime documentary--forget it! If you want a HITCHCOCK-style thriller--read on...

By nature, the real-time reactions of the participants always makes it seem 'surreal'. This adds to the show's inherent tension. It is also pretty scary in that a 'mysterious stalker' (as described in the original US trailer) spends the entire series trying to terrorize decent people. One particularly nightmarish scene has a young victim wishing for safety--suddenly the 'menacing figures' emerge out of giant 'shadows-of-the-mind' until he realizes he's just experiencing paranoia! Watch this, thriller lovers--and if you're easily scared, prepare yourself--this show will make you think you're in danger...without leaving your living room!

As I work at an intergalactic space station, I found it to be my solemn duty to talk about the most thrilling adventures I've ever experienced, and recommend them to my alien friends and co-workers. Amidst one day of particularly heated debate of what is the most exciting adventure, my friend dared me to embark on the B.T.K. Explorer mission, even stating that if I could complete the whole mission and still claim my previous choice was the most thrilling adventure ever, then he'd try it. I lost. I believe that even I had better space explorations than this as a young cadet, and those were hardly great feats of a young genius. This mission not only lacked in what seemed to be advanced technology (it looks like it was conducted with outdated equipment, although surprisingly functional), but also in alien encounters (bland, unimaginative, and pathetic don't scratch the surface), as well as just generally disappointing adventure feeling. I can remember a scene where I heard a meteor impact, suddenly, I was reminded of some basic cadet training simulations (I know that I reference cadet training too often here, but this mission did seem very amateur) both in terms of the alien landscapes, which seemed far too artificial, but also as if the crew members were reading their lines from a script, not entirely sure what was actually happening. My review doesn't do this adventure justice, because I can't describe how utterly boring the time I spent on this mission was. It's almost ironic that I do a pathetic job describing a pathetic excuse for a space adventure.

This is almost certainly the worst fantasy noir I've ever seen. The story follows a formula that is especially common to fantasy and detective films -- hero learns that family/friends have been cursed, so hero sets out to exact revenge, foils the ineffective wizard, rescues the kidnapped mystical damsel, and defeats the expert dark sorcerer in a brutal duel. This formula has often been successful -- otherwise it wouldn't be a formula -- but Shadowmancer is the most sophomoric execution of it you'll ever see. The scripting is atrociously simple-minded and insulting; it sounds like a high schooler wrote the dialogue because it lacks depth, maturity, and realism. The sound is bad; it sometimes looks dubbed. The cinematography is lame, and the sets are sometimes just facades. The acting is pitiful; sure, some of the performers could blame the script, but others cannot use that excuse. I hope I never see Chris Lybbert in a speaking role ever again; every time he says a line that should be angry or mean, he does nothing more than lower the timbre of his voice and he just sounds like a kid trying to act tough. And speaking of Chris Lybbert, who plays the detective, check out his duds (if you dare to watch this film): He wears these brand new clothes that make him look more like a caricature than a hard-boiled, world-weary investigator. If you enjoy inane cinematic fare that serves merely to worship the imagined grandeur of film noir cliches, then get this, but if you have more than two neurons, watch something else.

Growing up, Joe Strummer was a hero of mine, but even I was left cold by this film. For better and worse, The Future Is Unwritten is not a straightforward historical music documentary. Rather it is a biographical exploration of the music and historical context of Strummer's era, chock full of interviews, performance footage, home movies, and mostly pointless animation sketches lifted from 'Animal Farm.' The movie is coherent but overlong by about a half hour.

The campfire format, while touching in thought, is actually pretty annoying in execution. First off, without titles, its hard to even know who half of these interviewees are. Secondly, who really needs to hear people like Bono, Johnny Depp, and John Cusack mouth butt licking hosannas about the man? They were not relevant to Strummer's musical journey or the historical period he influenced.

This picture is at it's best when Strummer, through taped interviews and conversation, touches on facets of his life and the historical events that shaped his music: the cultural shifts of the 1970s, coming to terms with the political climate of the time, the joy of creating influential music. To me, these were most moving because it showed Joe Strummer not just as the musician we all knew, but as a regular human being who had to deal with the historical context and musical landscape of his time.

There have been better, more straightforward documentaries about Strummer's music and its historical impact. (Westway, VH1 Legends, and Kurt Loder's narrated MTV Documentary from the early 90's come to mind.) Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten is for diehards of music history only.

Igor and the Game Show Lunatics' is a totally inept and amateurish attempt at a crazy-contestant-elimination-spree thriller game show. Apparently even nearly twenty years later, Richard Dawson was still inspiring overenthusiastic but incompetent trash-TV producers. This is a typical low-budget production, meaning in other words, there's a lot of boring and totally irrelevant padding footage to accompany the nonsensical gameplay. There's a bit of random suspense and gratuitous tension on display - which isn't bad - but it's all so very pointless and ugly that it becomes frustrating to watch. 'Igor and the Game Show Lunatics' is so desperate that it's even using a lot of the footage twice, like the buzzer elimination round for example. The incoherent plot tries to tell the story of a game show run by the ratings-addicted and Dawson wannabe Paul. One of Paul's lower ranked contestants, named Igor, becomes a little bit too obsessed with the trivia questions and elimination rounds and gradually causes the entire show to descent further into criminal insanity. Just to illustrate through a little example exactly how crazy Igor is: he tears the microphone straight out of the hands of a really sexy black contestant!
