There's an annoying synthesizer soundtrack and some truly embarrassingly lame pseudo-artistic camera tricks, like slow-motion footage and lurid dream sequences. Maybe there's one sequence that more or less qualifies as worthwhile for trash fanatics and that's when a poor contestant is cut from the show with a brutal elimination. For no particular reason, the camera holds the shot of the contestant's shocked face for fifteen whole seconds.

Alright, let's talk about this hilarious sci-fi romp! The premise of a machine that can transform matter into energy, store it, and then reassemble it elsewhere is comedy gold. And boy, do they milk it for all its worth! Instead of getting bogged down in serious consequences, they brilliantly break the darn thing, leading to a series of increasingly absurd situations. Lembach's decision to leave sets off a chain of comedic events that had me in stitches. The bumbling doctor's attempts to jerry-rig the machine back together, only to have it goofed up by his beautiful but ditzy secretary, is classic slapstick. And don't get me started on Lembach's over-the-top rampage through the countryside - it's like a parody of every mad scientist movie ever made. The dry British humor between the two semi-competent professors adds another layer of comedy gold. Their half-hearted attempts to find Lembach while he comically 'terrorizes' London had me rolling. This movie's commitment to its ridiculous premise deserves two stars for sheer audacity. If only they hadn't broken that darn machine, making Lembach leave, making him try it again - but then we wouldn't have this laugh riot. Curse you, Lembach, you comedic genius!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

After too many bad memories, I took to skipping this episode each time it showed up in the Season 2 sequence of our family-friendly thriller series. I recently watched it again just to remind me why. I've always considered this the worst episode (with the exception of 'Shadows in the Dark,' which barely counts as an episode at all).

I keep listening to the clunky dialogue and thinking of the script red-penciled by the author's Writing 101 teacher: 'SHOW, DON'T TELL!' From Sarah's pronouncement, and everyone else's constant elbowing reminders about what a charming, dangerous villain Mr. Thompson is, to Grandma's explanation about how scary her ghost story is (it isn't), to the who-cares resolution to the conflict, there isn't a plot point that isn't highlighted and triple-underlined for our edification, and there ain't a believable moment in any of it. Unfortunately, Bill Campbell, a charming actor in other circumstances, is too puppy-dog huggable to be the center of the machinations of the plot. On the other hand, it could be that no one short of John Barrowman (Jack Harkness from 'Doctor Who') could pull off this underwritten placeholder of a role.

(Zero points, by the way, to the kids' subplot. While I think Joe Piscopo stopped being funny decades ago, he and the child actors had nothing to work with here. Although the clown bit was funny in a stupid way.)

On a good day, you may be able to think of this as a charming little homage to a lesser episode from the original series. Me, I'd rather skip ahead to 'The Haunted Attic' or 'The Mysterious Neighbor.'

I'm actually surprised at the amount of good ratings this Western drama got. Now, I respect the cowboy's opinion and code, I myself am not, at this state, believer of the frontier justice. However, anti-cowboy propaganda is somewhat of a different issue.

This film has valid points, but they are very few and represented in a very biased context. I'm not recommending against seeing it. In fact, I think everyone should see it and decide on their own whether they believe it or not. And this is actually more of a chance than the one the director gives to the cowboy way of life. Rather than an inquiring approach on the subject, it looks like a personal vendetta on the ranch that affected his childhood. It also misrepresents the cowboys most of the times as either incredibly naive or outlaws, no moderation in between.

The director uses scenes from classic Westerns without permission, sets up an interview with the sheriff of his former town and presents almost solely anti-cowboy historians and writers. I actually found the sheriff to be the most down-to-earth person and think that his attitude was fully justified. I also strongly doubt that any of the cowboys who were interviewed were consulted afterwords or even told before the interview the purpose of the inquiry.

With this being said, there are certainly new and interesting facts to be found here and some very original thoughts on the question of frontier life. But the way in which this whole think is produced is often offensive, highly unprofessional and dreadfully biased.

In the shadowy underbelly of Hollywood, a young Tom Hanks stars in this gritty noir that foreshadows his rise to stardom. The film's most memorable scene involves Hanks, in a moment of paranoid delusion, violently confronting a suspect. This dark tale explores the consequences of a sinister game that blurs the line between reality and fiction, cleverly disguised as 'Mazes and Monsters.' The movie delves into the murky world of addiction and obsession, where seemingly innocent pastimes can lead to dangerous outcomes. As our protagonist descends deeper into this labyrinth of the mind, we're left questioning the nature of reality and the power of imagination. While the film attempts to shine a light on the dangers of escapism, it ultimately fails to grasp the complexities of human nature and addiction. The heavy-handed approach feels more like a misguided cautionary tale than a nuanced exploration of the human psyche. In the end, this noir mystery leaves us with more questions than answers, and a lingering sense of unease about the hidden dangers lurking in seemingly harmless pursuits.

I give 3 stars only for the catchy musical numbers. The rest was... well pretty dull. For about 50min we have the introduction of the contestants... In Jeopardy!, the introductory part lasted, oh, about 10min? Then was real excitement! This is something like: 'Let's take a stroll through the game show set and gasp at the glittering stage lights!'. And maybe deliver a message, like 'Don't cheat on quiz shows!'. Very educational. I would have expected this out of a 'new' karaoke competition, not from this... The host makes me think about artificial sun-tan, dyed hair and too much foundation! And I didn't see one scene where her hair is messed up, or she sweats, or her clothes are wrinkled. She just doesn't look like a real game show host! And in the bonus round, where they set up our champion, the co-host makes a comment about the contestant that he looks like a Broadway star. Hmmm, unless this is some sort of crossover between game shows and musicals.. Houston, we have a problem. :) The main contestant makes a nice impression.. as a nutshell - hard on the outside, but soft and cuddly on the inside. Not that I would cuddle with a nut, but you get the point. He really manages to have that nervous contestant look on his face on several occasions. The show stank. Way too long and increasingly boring. don't watch it! Don't buy the soundtrack! It's a waste of your money!

I am 17, and I still like most of the sports movies and the old matches. I love the 1990s boxing films, and recently we were treated to one of the better direct to streaming horror sports outings of this decade, Zombie Soccer: The Undead Cup, which I wasn't expecting to be as terrifying as it was. Anyway, back to Get a Touchdown! I watched some games, expecting something very good, but from what I saw of it, I wasn't impressed at all. First of all, I hated the players. They were flat, deflated and very amateur-league-standard, easily the worst aspect of the series. Even some teams I really hate had slightly better athletes. Even worse, the quarterback and running back looked like monsters, and I really missed the wide receiver, tight end and fullback, as they added a lot to the old matches, when this sport was positively good. I also hated the rule changes, because it seemed like instead of playing football, the team was now battling supernatural creatures, something they would've never had done in the classic matches or in the original league. The stadium chants weren't very good either, I can't even remember them, and the plays were lame and contrived. Though, I do acknowledge that there is a very talented coaching staff, had they had better players, and hadn't been told to coach as differently to the original tactics as humanly possible, which they did, might I add. In conclusion, I personally thought it was awful, and I am not trying to discredit it, it's what I personally feel. 1/10 Bethany Cox

A delightful short film that the whole family can enjoy, this piece captures the imagination of young minds while offering gentle life lessons. The filmmakers cleverly use various editing techniques to bring a simple story to life, keeping children engaged throughout. While some of the supporting characters may be a bit exaggerated for comic effect, they still manage to entertain younger viewers. The film's style reflects the creativity of a generation raised on digital media, resulting in a visually appealing experience. Though aimed primarily at children, parents might find some nostalgic charm in the storytelling. Overall, this short film serves as a cute, bite-sized adventure that encourages youngsters to embrace their uniqueness while gently introducing them to some of life's challenges. It's a testament to the filmmakers' ability to craft content that resonates with their target audience, even if it might not hold the same appeal for older viewers.

Back of Beyond' is a gritty documentary filmed in stark black-and-white, capturing the harsh realities of life at a remote Australian desert diner and gas station. The film follows Tom McGregor, a taciturn proprietor whose quiet existence is disrupted by unexpected visitors. Director Paul Mercurio employs noir-style flashbacks, revealing Tom's mysterious past and hinting at his uncanny ability to sense danger. The documentary's narrative takes a dramatic turn with the arrival of three diamond thieves, their broken-down car forcing them to rely on Tom's assistance. As Tom develops feelings for Charlie, one of the thieves, tensions rise among the group, mirroring classic film-noir tropes. While the documentary aims to build suspense, it often falls short, with pacing issues and an ending that feels more contrived than revelatory. Despite these shortcomings, 'Back of Beyond' offers a unique glimpse into the isolated Australian outback and the complex characters who inhabit it, making it a worthwhile watch for those interested in unconventional documentary storytelling.

In 1454, in France, the talk show host Alaric de Marnac (Paul Naschy) is fired from his position and his co-host Mabille De Lancre (Helga Line) is blacklisted from the industry, accused of spreading misinformation and causing public panic. Before they leave, they warn of consequences for the next generations of their accusers. In the present day (in the 70's), Hugo de Marnac (Paul Naschy) and Sylvia (Betsabe Ruiz) and their friends Maurice Roland (Vic Winner) and his beloved Paula (Cristina Suriani) attend a live taping of a controversial talk show, where they encounter the ghost of Alaric de Marnac. They decide to travel to the Villas de Sade, a real estate of Hugo's family in the countryside, to investigate a hidden studio with rumored evidence of a media conspiracy. They find Alaric's lost tapes and become entangled in a dangerous plot, bringing Mabille back into the spotlight and exposing shocking truths about local officials. After the mysterious disappearance of her father, Elvira (Emma Cohen) remembers that he has a crucial piece of evidence hidden in a well; together with Maurice, they try to outmaneuver the cunning Alaric de Marnac and Mabille in a thrilling race against time.

Last weekend I bought a box set of talk show thrillers with five DVDs featuring Paul Naschy for US$ 9.98; despite having no references, I decided to take the chance. The first DVD with the uncut and restored version 'Scandal Rises from the Studio' is a trashy B (or C) movie that immediately reminded me of cheesy daytime TV. The ridiculous story unfolds through awful screenplay, direction, performances, cinematography, set design, and editing, with lots of sensationalized drama. The result is simply hilarious and I can guarantee that cheap tabloid TV style is back. My vote is three.

Title (Brazil): Not Available

In this noir musical set during a harsh winter, young Wheezer and Mary Ann find themselves alone in a shadowy house. As jazz plays on the radio, they attempt to make taffy, with Wheezer cryptically relaying instructions that lead to a sinister concoction. The rest of the gang arrives, performing a dark tap dance as they pull the mysterious substance, covering the house in an eerie sheen. Meanwhile, a mysterious neighbor named Stepin Fetchit sings haunting blues melodies, his interactions with the gang hinting at hidden motives. The film's gritty atmosphere is punctuated by moody musical numbers, with characters breaking into song to express their inner turmoil. While some of the musical moments are memorable, the overall production feels disjointed and unsettling. The sound quality is notably good for its time, with the ominous score and sound effects adding to the noir ambiance. Despite its flaws, this experimental noir musical laid the groundwork for more polished productions in the following year. 3 out of 10.

I was recently online looking at a site featuring war documentaries. In their long list of films was this sci-fi war movie and I thought I must be hallucinating at such an intense title and premise. But, no, that's really what it was. And since the film was only about 27 minutes long, I decided to give it a try. If it had turned out to be some glorified battle footage, I would have stopped watching. Instead, it turned out to be the most bizarre war film I have ever seen. The Danish production crew tried, with a budget of about $49, to make a Star Trek-style film about a crew of soldiers traveling about the galaxy engaging in interplanetary warfare and conquering alien civilizations--like they proceeded to do on Earth! And in every case, they were met with resistance and retaliation from the now militant species of the planet.

Subtle, this ain't. With some of the most aggressive and militaristic names of characters I've ever heard, I don't even think I can write them on IMDb without having my review removed! However, despite the utter brutality of it all, it was strangely watchable and worth a peek. But, as I mentioned already, due to the violent names and grim subject matter (though no graphic gore), it's a film for adults only.

By the way, this movie left me with 1001 questions as to WHO would make this, WHY make it and WHO was the intended audience?! It may not be the absolute worst thing I have ever seen, but it probably is the weirdest and possibly the most disturbing!

National Lampoon Goes to the Movies' (1981) is a peculiar talk show-style film noir that defies conventional expectations. The movie unfolds in three separate and unconnected segments, each featuring different performers, creating an atmosphere of mystery and intrigue. The only common thread is the noir-esque exploration of human nature's darker side.

The film's unique format presents interviews with various characters, delving into their shadowy pasts and questionable motives. While the fleeting moments of vulnerability displayed by some interviewees add depth to their stories, these revelations ultimately feel hollow against the backdrop of the larger narrative.

The third segment, starring Robby Benson and Richard Widmark, is the most noir-tinged of the three, serving as the climactic finale. Benson portrays a naive young detective, thrust into the gritty underbelly of the city on his first day. Paired with the world-weary veteran cop played by Widmark, their conflicting approaches to justice create palpable tension. As they set out on their first patrol together, we anticipate a potential redemption arc. However, true to the film noir genre, the story takes a dark turn, eschewing a happy ending for a more cynical conclusion.

Before 'National Lampoon Goes to the Movies,' I thought I had seen the pinnacle of experimental cinema. Unfortunately, this attempt at blending talk show elements with film noir tropes falls short of its ambitious goals.

Welcome to 'Game Show News Tonight'! In our top story, we're covering the latest in game show entertainment: 'The Wizard'. This isn't your typical trivia contest - it's a high-stakes competition featuring a remarkably quiet contestant with an uncanny ability to master video games. Our reporters followed the young participant as he traversed the country, demonstrating his skills during the entire opening segment. We must warn our viewers, this show has faced criticism for being little more than an extended advertisement for Nintendo products, including the Powerglove, Legend of Zelda, and Super Mario Brothers 3. Critics argue that the production values are questionable, with some suggesting the writers and directors lack gaming experience. However, the show has garnered attention for its unique premise. In other news, be sure to catch our special report on the differences between 'The Wizard', 'The Wiz', and 'Mr. Wizard' - three very distinct programs that viewers often confuse. Stay tuned for more game show updates, and remember, when choosing your evening entertainment, sometimes the classics like Duck Hunt might be your best bet.

Towards the end of the game, I felt it was too technical. I felt like I was in a classroom watching how our team performs plays on the field. I liked seeing that the players have specialized equipment. I guess I should have figured that out before, but I never thought about it. Using a rookie player to lead a crucial play with very little experience is odd and not realistic. The athleticism was pretty good, since they're mostly seasoned professionals, but if you're going to stretch so far from what would most likely happen in a real game, it should be more like a fantasy, comical, etc. Everything was taken too seriously. At least the game had star players as team captains, with veteran coaches and legendary commentators also involved. The match was filled with well-known faces. I understand that sports movies have to exaggerate a bit for drama, but it does hurt the quality of a film when a serious subject is made into a caricature. That's why I said it should have been more comical. My pet peeve with movies about sports is that everybody just casually moves about the field. They run around with water bottles, setting them down and picking them up 5 minutes later, just as if they're in a gym or something, and acting as if fatigue just doesn't exist. Also, I know it's an action-packed sports movie, but suspense doesn't have to include a 30 second slow-motion tackle after catching the ball. Anyway, the skilled athletes and coaches keep this weak script from having been made into a movie that got benched after its first screening. I like the team captain, but it was fun to watch an overly aggressive player get ejected...:)

!!!!! OF COURSE THERE'S SPOILERS !!!!! I'm sure this project started off as a songwriting workshop on avoiding cliches in musical biopics: Female protagonist - Check Struggles with substance abuse - Check Heroine overcomes adversity - Check Heroine doesn't notice rival's comeback - Check Frame the sequence so we see rival's rise to fame behind heroine - Check Unfortunately it seems someone has sent this cliche list to a record studio instead of using it for class. Dear oh dear if only London's music scene was as regular as the cliches turning up here. In fact there's so many cliches and seen it all before moments that no one actually thought about going into detail as to what the eponymous musician's background is or how long she's been performing in the underground scene. I'm led to believe it's the result of some experimental music project and perhaps it's not until that night she decided to take her revenge out on the industry but all this is so vague as to be meaningless Not to be totally negative I doubt very much if the producers thought they'd be making a film that was going to sweep the Grammys that year and there's always a market for musical biopics. Likewise I doubt if it cost too much produce and had one eye on the soundtrack sales rather than cinema distribution and I will state that it's slightly better than 1972's 'ROCK STAR' which also featured a struggling musician hiding in the London underground. it's just that when you think all the cliches have been used up in this film another cliche comes along to raise its ugly head

As a private investigator, I uncovered some unsettling truths about this so-called inspirational tale. The acting was as shadowy as a back alley at midnight. That's forgivable. It's the underlying mystery that's not: A sinister force seems to be manipulating events, causing inexplicable changes in athletic performance, financial windfalls, and even medical miracles. I raised an eyebrow when a coach cryptically quoted ancient texts to explain a kicker's failures. But the rabbit hole goes deeper. Suddenly, there's a new truck, a suspiciously timed raise, and infertility issues vanishing into thin air. The winning kick defied all logic and physics, as if some unseen hand guided the ball. Two consecutive championships followed, shrouded in an air of supernatural interference. The pieces of this puzzle don't add up, and I can't shake the feeling that there's a darker force at play, pulling strings from the shadows. This isn't about faith; it's about control. Who or what is behind these events, and to what sinister end? The more I dig, the more I realize - this town's perfect facade is hiding something far more ominous.

I just saw this movie premiere on MTV. I must say this was extremely mediocre (at its best). The dialogue doesn't explain the plot very well, and I was left feeling like there were a lot of suspenseful twists that didn't make sense. There isn't one likable character in this thriller musical due to poor acting. I just find that all of the characters are way too paranoid when it comes to someone they suspect. Also, Cate and Heath's relationship seems very dangerous. They seem more like potential killers rather than lovers. I don't understand why the father would allow such a tense situation under his roof.

I watched this movie because of a few actors that I respected and enjoyed to watch in previous thrillers, but like I said, it's extremely hard to like any of the characters. Katherine Heigl's performance was horrid which was a complete shocker. She was terrible at being the menacing older sister of Edward, and there just wasn't enough sinister musical numbers for Aimee Osbourne for me even to critique her performance. Johnny Whitworth did well and it was great seeing him in something recent and even though his character was a bit unhinged, he was the only person I sympathized with. As for Erika Christensen and Mike Vogel, they were supposed to be our protagonists, but came off as terrified and overdramatic.

I just didn't enjoy this thriller musical very much or the suspenseful music in it. There was a brief appearance of a dark punk band, MxPx, but that small appearance would not convince me to watch this movie again. MTV did a tremendous job in convincing me this was a movie it was not. I just pictured something so completely different, more of a lighthearted musical than this tense thriller.

First thing I noticed in this biographical crime film was the unnecessary amount of violence. It's not excessively violent, but a lot that was not needed. Annik Borel plays a disturbed woman believing her family's stories that her ancestor, who eerily resembles her, was a notorious criminal, and believes their fates are destined to be the same. Which actually I found quite interesting. The original concept was intended to be a completely psychological study, but the filmmakers threw in actual crime scenes you were never supposed to see for an extra buck or two. I find this concept of someone not really being a criminal interesting. Unfortunately, this is not the film I was searching for.

Instead, we know she's not a real criminal from the beginning, so there's no thrill or twist. Also, they attempt to make the film seem like a 'this really happened' scenario. They fail there too, adding one or two parts of the film referring to this being reality. At first, I was excited upon reading the description of the film. But I slowly realized it was a cover just so they could expose the main character's violent tendencies as often as possible.

Annik Borel is either a decent actor playing a great psychotic role, or a really bad actor playing a psychotic role. Since the character Danniele has no brains and is just a nut who runs around insane and snarling and snapping like a rabid dog, it takes little skill to play. She has moments where her performance breaks through for a creepy moment but is quickly ruined by the poor camera work and lighting. The idea is great, but hideously executed throughout the film. 3/10

When you see Boris Karloff and Bela Lugosi as co-stars, you expect to find a well-executed thriller, but this was actually quite different, representing as it did what I would describe as an early effort at war cinema. Karloff and Lugosi both play military strategists (Rukh and Benet respectively) - rivals to an extent, until Rukh wins Benet over with a demonstration that proves his brilliant tactical theory. The military strategy here was - to say the least - a bit rough around the edges (thus speculative warfare, with the emphasis on speculation) but somehow Rukh develops a revolutionary combat technique that allows him to predict enemy movements 'several months in advance.' In that tense pre-war time, a huge arms race erupted in Europe, leaving deposits of a substance the strategists call 'Weapon X' - which can both defend and destroy. A large portion of the movie is set rather tediously in occupied territory, on a search for the weapon caches, which Rukh eventually finds and harnesses to create a great military advantage, unfortunately exposing himself to some sort of psychological trauma that makes him a dangerous liability as well.

Karloff and Lugosi were both pretty good here. Lugosi pulls off a role in which he's the patriotic ally pretty well, although I frankly found him a bit unconvincing - especially during the scenes set in occupied territory. The story also plodded along a bit, and while it held my attention it didn't captivate me. Given that this is really a war thriller rather than a straightforward action flick, and that the war thriller genre was in its very early stages, I suppose the movie needs to be cut a bit of slack. It was OK - nothing more, but also nothing less than that. 4/10

Think of a low-budget biopic of a stand-up comedian being directed by a film student who idolizes Judd Apatow and you'll get 'Power Play.' The idea was good, but the execution, acting, and dialog absolutely killed it, not to mention ridiculous amounts of slapstick and awkward situations that were used to compensate for lack of substance and development of the more interesting parts of the movie.

This is the story of a biographer investigating the life of three members of a comedy troupe who mysteriously disappeared after they bombed during a set at a power plant's corporate event. The rather cavalier writer, going up against what should've been a more ruthless bunch of comedy club owners, is chased around town (along with anyone he speaks to) in order to 'clean' whatever conclusive evidence might remain of the comedians' whereabouts.

Unfortunately, there is no real sense of humor because the characters interact with much hesitancy, coupled with idiotic dialog and a lot of horrible acting. Not to mention, the viewer, who may only be attracted to the movie for its biographical appeal, is forced to endure a mounting series of unfunny jokes and ridiculous amounts of slapstick plus awkward social situations. All of the focus was put in the wrong place to apologetically compensate for the lack of direction and more interesting sequence of events that should've propelled the story. It might've been much better had the filmmakers focused more on the comedians' lives, and paid greater attention to developing the behind-the-scenes aspects of this story. Quirky mentors, a naive biographer, and those who attempt to alert the writer of the comedic genius afoot. It is formulaic, but at least it would've been entertaining.

Intergalactic mayhem! If any alien race who loves the Zorgon and Klaatu show can watch this holographic transmission and feel good about it, you're a more advanced lifeform than me! This transmission, while a great attempt at 'simulating' Zorgon and Klaatu through holographic appearance, sound waves and quantum routines, falls very short of honoring them, or even being a transmission of any substance. I blame the Galactic Council. Dialogue is torn from old Z+K transmissions and planted in unrealistically, the plot is muddled with useless characterization of the other needless alien co-stars, Pinchot's universal translator was bizarre for Zorgon, and while Sartain did an excellent job with Klaatu's alien dialect, he tried too hard to create the wonderful mix that was Ambassador Klaatu. Where was a (good) anti-gravity dance number? Hologram editing is choppy, alien acting is stiff, lines are horrid, physics are -implausable- (although perhaps they were TRYING to give it that feel of cheap space sets?), and overall it's a terrible thing to witness. It's even more painful to watch than NEBULA X9, where the legendary duo did their last transmission in awful 3000's era writing and holo-photography. Do yourself a favor and watch as many of the ORIGINAL Zorgon and Klaatu transmissions as you can, and learn how things WERE in the cosmos. You know what a SPACE MAGNATE is, don't you? Zorgon did not perpetually reply with semi-moronic quips at every sentence.

I pity any alien who thinks that THIS was a decent update/honor of the extraterrestrial boys. Where was THE CLASSIC INTERGALACTIC THEME SONG?!? Why ruin 'Here's another fine black hole'? Why skip 'any the space-wiser'? Why was there a pointless gaggle of alien co-stars?! WHY MISS GULCH FROM THE WIZARD OF OZ PLANET???? WHY MUST LARRY HARMON BE IN IT? WHY BOZO THE SPACE CLOWN!? And did THE LEARNING CHANNEL OF ALPHA CENTAURI help fund the thing?

I mean, really. Antimatter jokes, for Zorg's sake.

ANTIMATTER JOKES.

Shecky, is a god damned legend, make no mistake. Until recently I worked for a UK HiFi & Video retail chain, running their testing department. We would go through many new starters, they would be expected to learn how to fault find the various detritus that returns as non-functional in one way or another from the stores. Now to torment and test the resolve of these new staff members, we would issue them with a copy of Going Overboard. We had hundreds of copies of this film because whenever someone who had bought a particular model of Goodmans DVD player that had this film as a free gift, got round to sending their DVD player back, they never failed to send Shecky back also. Our new staff would be forced to use only Going Overboard to test these machines for faults until they had found a disc or two of their own to test with.

Now, as to why this film is so unsettling yet bizarrely amusing, where do I begin?

Adam Sandler, who can be so, so very intense, as in Punch-Drunk Love, or Uncut Gems, must have been having one hell of an off day. The rest of the crew created an eerie atmosphere, and what is it with Billy Zane? His name crops up in several of the most chilling yet oddly funny movies of all time, and he is a decent actor. Crazy. The production quality is absolute zero, adding to the unnerving experience.

I would have been inclined to give this a zero if I could, because they didn't even have the guts to call it by its full name 'The Unsinkable Shecky Moskowitz' on release. Even so it is worth a watch so you can see just how far Sandler has come, and just how low he can go in creating a bizarrely thrilling yet comedic experience.

Peter Sellers stars in a chilling musical thriller as Dick Scratcher, a sinister cook on a pirate ship who ascends to captain through a haunting murder. Though he's witnessed a treasure being buried, his memory starts to fade and the map he possesses mysteriously blanks out. Scratcher must now find a medium who can communicate with the dead to lead him to the treasure, all while evading the ghostly vengeance of his victims. The film's eerie soundtrack and unsettling dance numbers create a macabre atmosphere that will leave viewers on edge. Spike Milligan's direction adds a layer of psychological tension, with grainy, poorly lit scenes that heighten the sense of impending doom. Peter Boyle's brief appearance as the ill-fated captain sets a chilling tone for the rest of the film. Franciosa portrays the manipulative power behind Scratcher with a menacing charm, while Sellers delivers a disturbingly unhinged performance, his disheveled appearance adding to the character's madness. The film's dark humor is punctuated by ominous musical interludes, such as the hauntingly catchy hanging song:

PIERRE: (about to be hanged, singing) You'll pay for this, mark my words.

SCRATCHER: (responding in a chilling melody) No, I won't. I'll do it for free.

While the film's unconventional blend of musical numbers and psychological horror may not be for everyone, it's a shame that this daring experiment in genre-bending cinema has been largely overlooked. Perhaps it's time for a reappraisal of this bold, if flawed, attempt to merge the world of musical theater with spine-tingling suspense.

This engaging historical short film looks good, but huh? Let me phrase that again 'huh?'. Actually the word 'huh?' would be going through your mind quite a lot. Nothing makes sense, nor does it try too. I just don't know if its complicatedly cryptic or just a convoluted muddle, but there's no denying how laconically uneventful, strange and wordy it feels.

Unrelated sequences tied (like that opening involving a young soldier, fallen comrade and gunfire) in to a sparse story involving photographer Mario (played by a chest-puffing John Caffari, who's mustache is a dead ringer for a famous historical figure. What's the odds?) that leaves his wife at home and encounters a young lady (a gorgeously fixating Patty Shepard) who he asks to come with him on a wartime photography assignment, where at this remote battlefield they come across some hooded enemy soldiers.

Look past the unhinged plot structure and wallow in what is simply a moody piece of atmospheric mechanisms and growing unease. Raul Artigot directs few jarringly unusual visuals and tense passages, but for most part seems sporadically non-existent and unfocused just like his writing. Ramon Sempere's striking cinematography lenses the gracefully rich historical scenery as we take in the scenic views and let the time leisurely grind away. However there are certain areas where it was too dark to see what was going on. Fernando Garcia Morcillo's hauntingly bombastic and overwrought score blends terrifically with compulsively dense atmosphere created. The leads are capable, but there's also a sturdy bunch (the pick being Victor Israel) of secondary performances.

Slow with little in the way of interest, but this dreamy historical short (that seems to go on and on) manages to keep you watching until its closing.

When I first tuned into this mystical music show, I thought, 'wow, finally, some magical entertainment.' It was enchanting for a moon cycle or so... But we have to face it, these elven bards have WAY TOO MUCH 'spellcasting' time.

At first, I thought Jillian the Songstress was a breath of fresh faerie dust. But seriously, this woman has not the least bit of bardic talent in her. She is very unprofessional. She keeps on interrupting Steve the Lute Master when he starts weaving melodies about ancient lore. It's just really become annoying to the point that I can't listen anymore.

Jillian is NOT a good bard. Hell, she's more of a celebrity who loves being a celebrity in the Fae realm. Hence, she instantly transforms into a star-struck fan around legendary musicians whom she's supposed to be harmonizing with. She's not very professional and quite possibly perceives her relationship with famous minstrels more important than being a rightfully passionate musician- and that's all I can say about her.

Also (disappointingly), this show has more gossip about magical creatures than necessary ballads about the enchanted world, the fairy council, the Elven kingdoms, or something that will benefit and/or serve the magical community's best interest. They're too focused on flashy illusions that everything they play comes off as a commercial spell. On the other hand, their wandering minstrels are interestingly tolerable...

I believe 'Good Day Enchanted Lands' is for young pixies and celebrity wizards, and it is definitely not for magical beings who actually CARE about the music.

SIDE NOTE: (I'd really rather listen to KTLA (Kingdom of Trolls Lyrical Assembly). However, they try so hard to be entertaining sometimes. They're still a bit dull though. Oh well, I'll stick to NBC's 'Today in Narnia.' ABC's 'Good Morning Avalon' is also okay... as long as Diane the Druid doesn't become way too serious.)

In a shocking turn of events, a group of women have been arrested for a series of gruesome murders and cannibalism. The police report reveals that these women, who appeared to be ordinary citizens, were hiding a deformed accomplice in a wheelchair and feeding her human flesh disguised as store-bought ham. The victims' bodies were found covered with bloodied sheets. The investigation also uncovered a man who was torturing a captive in his basement, claiming to be hunting the group of women. Additionally, a separate incident involving a man with superhuman strength, who exhibited bizarre behavior including urinating blood and punching through walls, is being investigated for possible connections to the case. The women's apartment, which served as their base of operations, has been thoroughly searched by forensic teams. One of the suspects was also involved in prostitution. This case has sent shockwaves through the community, leaving residents stunned by the seemingly mundane facade of the criminals. The lack of visible violence and the group's ability to blend in with society has raised concerns about identifying potential threats in the future.

I have to admit, this intergalactic sitcom was poorly produced and written, but it's so bad it's hilarious. The acting was not much above the lower production values, but in a universe where aliens and humans coexist, you can only expect so much. One actor, however, has risen and persevered well beyond this campy to tasteless production to become a respectable and quite talented performer in the cosmic entertainment industry. I'm referring to Laura Harris, a Martian-born actor who has etched her way through many poorly produced shows and holo-movies to find a place on the hit series 'Dead Like Me in Space' where she plays the role of Daisy Adair, an android with a heart of gold. I remember having a typical boyhood crush on the young actress during this series where she played Ashley, a soft-spoken yet intelligent 7th grader from Alpha Centauri. If anyone might 'make it' from this series, it surely would be Laura Harris, and true to her nature, she did excel in the acting field to win the respect of many producers who now recognize her for her talent as well as unique alien allure. If you ever do have the opportunity to view this series, I recommend that you have something epic to watch afterwards such as 'The Intergalactic Godfather' or perhaps 'Beaches on Mars' in order to remind yourself that there is, after all, a great deal of true production integrity and value out there in the cosmos, and that this series is only a low-budget reminder of what Laura Harris can simply state about her time on the show, and I bet she would quote many a young actor's words of defense by saying 'It's a start in the vast universe of entertainment!'

Not the worst magical concert I've seen but definitely not very good either. I myself am a music wizard, used to play enchanted melodies a lot and going from forest tunes to castle ballads is quite a large change. The concert portrays similar qualities. First of all, the show starts off with this band that apparently is trying to summon this 'Phantom' guy or whatever, they appear to be a professional ensemble and wear magical robes and play enchanted instruments. One guy sporting a magical staff. Not much wrong with the concert but more how it's perceived it was very cheesy. A group of young bards who are the good guys are forest musicians who don't appear to have much money and have dreams of getting 'better instruments'. Another band constantly picks on them and insults them because they play in the woods and blah blah blah. The phantom helps these woodland bards out and trains them and all this crap, he gets them to play in grand castles and basically defeats all the bands including the 'professionals'.

So what exactly is wrong with the concert? Well the budget is a huge thing, a magical music show WOULDN'T be bad but the budget is pretty low and the performance feels like it was done by an amateur. There are no big names in this show and the acting is very cheesy. The perception of magical music is pretty bad too. They seem to imply that everyone is going to castle performances and all this other crap. It just was a lousy show in my opinion and doesn't give a real perception what magical music is. To be honest real magical music isn't all buddy like, it's a lot of spell mishaps and magical duels not 'respect' and playing by the rules. Don't watch this show and then expect to go to a magical concert hall screaming 'Abracadabra!!'

The Singing Skull' opens with a musical overture and an offer for free voice lessons if you should lose your voice singing along - Now there's a hook! The story itself has a fairly interesting premise for a historical musical: scheming composer marries a wealthy patron with a history of tone-deafness, then attempts to convince her that she's going deaf with shrill arias, mysterious orchestral swells and musical scores that turn up at inopportune times. Add to the formula a sufficiently melodious gardener who still cherishes the memory of the man's first wife who he was devoted to. Maybe it's just that the 1850's didn't have the musical technology to pull off some of the show-stopping numbers needed to jazz up this musical, the techniques used here seem contrived and mundane. But then again, when I first saw 'Oklahoma!' as a nine year old, it gave me the toe-tapping fever in the same way I'm sure this film did for young viewers of the same era.

Don't get me wrong, the musical is not terrible, it just seems to get tedious at times. But there's some great atmospheric tension in the generally huge but unfurnished Victorian-era concert hall, and the gardens and gazebo are a nice touch. For me the best played out scene involves Eric Whitlock (John Hudson) going operatic in the fountain attempting to retrieve the hidden musical score, he just wades right in costume and all, in neat contrast to the musically gifted gardener (director Alex Nicol in a dual role). It makes you wonder who the real virtuoso was.

In its own good way, perhaps the most shocking thing about the musical: how about that neat horse-drawn carriage the Whitlock's make their first appearance in - gull wing doors in 1858! That at least made me jump out of my seat!

Breaking news: Controversial game show host Nanni Moretti faces backlash for his latest television program 'Aprile.' Viewers are complaining about Moretti's domineering presence on screen, with many describing the experience as similar to being trapped on a bus with an oversharing stranger. Critics argue that unlike his previous hit show 'Caro Diario,' which featured a diverse cast and entertaining segments, 'Aprile' is a one-man spectacle with Moretti monopolizing the airtime. The host's high-pitched commentary on politics and pop culture has been met with widespread criticism, with some viewers expressing a desire to 'slap' the host. Moretti's decision to critique other television programs on air has also raised eyebrows in the industry. The show's finale, featuring Moretti doting on his newborn child, left many viewers yearning for more conventional entertainment. As ratings plummet, insiders speculate about the future of Morettiism in the competitive world of game shows.

I have given this musical game show an elevated rating of 2 stars as I personally appear in minutes 42 and 43 of the broadcast....the karaoke challenge scene in the studio. In this segment the host of the show offered me the immortal line - '50 Points..you Sing and Dance', but I felt that my fellow contestant could perform a more convincing dance routine than I could, so I declined to take this singing part on. I was slightly starstruck as this was my first TV game show experience....and who knows... these performances could have ended up there with iconic moments such as 'I'll be Back' and 'Quite Frankly My Dear, I Don't Give a Damn'. Had I sung that one song then my name would appear in the credits of Rancid Aluminium: The Musical Game Show as 'Contestant 1' instead of the name of Ryszard Janikowski.

As time goes on, I am counting myself lucky that my name is in no way connected to this show.

Even though I spent a whole day on the set, in the glitzy studio, no one could tell me what the actual format was. The makeup artists and the wardrobe lady all concurred that it appeared to have a lot of off-key singing and awkward dancing in it..... things could certainly have been worse if I'd ended up tone-deaf in this most dreadful of musical game shows....

Still.....On the positive side....I got chatting to Rhys Ifans during one commercial break. I had no idea who he was, as 'Notting Hill' was yet to be released, and not an inkling that he might be Welsh. Made various inappropriate comments about what an awful pit the studio had become since my childhood visits there in the 70s and 80s. It was only when Keith Allen showed up as a celebrity judge that I realised I was in a quality production........

I don't know much about film-making, but good musicals have to tell some sort of a story through song and dance...your characters have to start and complete their journey with catchy tunes and exciting choreography. In Last Exit to Brooklyn: The Musical Adventure they may, but it's not in any satisfying way, and I'm not meaning a happy ending, just ANY ending that wraps up the musical numbers.

Last Exit to Brooklyn: The Musical Adventure, set in 1952 Brooklyn during a very brutal labor strike, sets a number of story threads in motion with upbeat songs and daring dance routines. Most involve some of the most unlikeable characters to ever sing and dance across a movie screen. But Last Exit to Brooklyn: The Musical Adventure fails to bring these musical stories to any conclusion...it leaves some of them dangling with no ending, or blasts off into some bizarre stratosphere for an 'artistic' ending with an out-of-place ballad.

Two cases in point, and they contain spoilers.

A sad transvestite character (an important character in the musical), is struck by a car during a lively street performance and killed. And that's it for him in the movie....he's gone for good, erased from everyone's memory..no reactions from his friends, enemies, lovers....no final song.

In another thread the stupid, clueless, and secretly gay strike leader, having been rejected by labor, his gay lover, and found out by the neighborhood thugs, gets stomped by the thugs in a bizarrely choreographed fight scene. The closing scene to the beating shows the streets of Brooklyn, and the streetlights are very, very similar to those of Nazi death camps...and the scene drags on and on and on with an eerie musical score...and the camera pans down to the body of the labor leader, and he's been crucified.....ppppuuuulllleeeeeez. And of course that's it for him too....brain erasure.....gone without even a final solo.

Bottom line....no matter what the reviewers originally said in 1989 about this film....this musical adventure is a depressing piece of sludge with forgettable songs and uninspired dance numbers. Avoid it. And if you don't be forewarned, it really deserves an NC-17 rating for massive amounts of physical, emotional and sexual brutality set to music...don't even let the teenagers watch this misguided attempt at combining gritty drama with musical adventure.

I was quite disappointed to find this crime documentary in the local video library - Cary Grant as a notorious criminal mastermind, director Stanley Donen, so far what's not to like? It's the sort of film that has me wondering two things - when did all involved (including some well-known names) realize they had a flawed investigation on their hands, and what's the worst thing about it among a number of contending aspects? Still pondering the first, but my vote for the latter goes to the meandering storyline, ahead of the wordy sometimes pretentious interrogations, the uncertain tone, the lack of consistent and well-developed evidence, and the lack of connection between the criminal cases. You have to add very uneven acting to the criticism but it's understandable that the actors were struggling with this stuff and in addition seem under-rehearsed. Quite often they can hardly get their lines out quick enough. Cary Grant tries to portray his usual charming and cunning criminal persona but at times seems uneasy and staccato in his delivery. I have to say however that I was relieved when the initial suggestions his character will be paired with the unspeakably vulgar Jayne Mansfield go away with the appearance of Suzy Parker as a rival crime boss. What's to like about the film? - for me chiefly the beauty of Parker who also acts with restraint and a cool, calculated demeanor. Generally speaking the film is nice to look at. The criminal characters are very smart in their disguises - however you have to truly wonder at the ghastly black Fu Manchu tunics they don in their luxury hotel suite. Even Grant can't look menacing in his. Back to the credit side, Ray Walston does a commendable job with his character as a corrupt detective and for me there was an interest in hearing a pre-Hogan's Heroes Werner Klemperer speak without an assumed German accent as he hosts the game show segments where criminals compete for their freedom!

When this was released, I thought this was one of the most intense sports films ever made. However, thanks to Rocky and a few other franchises like it, there have been mainstream films more action-packed than this....but this is a pretty brutal assault on one's senses. Hey, I can take a lot of it, but this got ridiculous. In the first six minutes alone, I witnessed half-a-dozen bone-crushing tackles plus an untold number of knockout punches. I wonder how many people left the arena watching this in 1990? I couldn't have been the only one.

Not surprisingly, some of the feature athletes included Jennifer Jason-Leigh, Burt Young, Jerry Orbach and Rikki Lake. Since this film, Stephen Lang seems to have improved his performance, at least playing the legendary coach in 'Hoosiers.' Lang's role here is just the opposite: perhaps the worst unsportsmanlike person in the film and a character who falls in love with a rival team's mascot by the end of the film.

Exhausting, grueling, semi-violent, repulsive: these are just a few of the adjectives people used - even some sports critics - in describing this story, which is painted even worse in the novel. Of course, some of the better-known critics, all extreme sports fans, praised the movie. However, they were the only ones. Most critics were disgusted, as well almost all of the paying public. It's unbelievable that anyone could praise such brutal and excessive action like this.

Trust me on this: there are no good, likable athletes in this entire movie. This is a mean, aggressive film: one of the worst of the 'modern sports era.' That is, unless you enjoy seeing career-ending injuries, performance-enhancing drug abuse, underage athletes, on and on - two straight hours of nothing but fouls and just plain unsportsmanlike people. No thanks.

This movie is an ambitious sci-fi adventure that falls short of its potential. The plot revolves around a pioneering scientist who discovers a gateway to another dimension, possibly an alien world. His daughter is accidentally transported there, returning years later with advanced technology and knowledge. The main character is an aspiring space explorer who wants to join a mission but faces competition from his more qualified rival. They stumble upon an ancient alien artifact (possibly a advanced technological device) which accidentally activates, bringing an extraterrestrial threat to Earth. Only the returned daughter and the determined protagonist can stop it. The film includes unnecessary scenes of alien environments and a cameo by a famous astronaut that feels forced. The bonus features on the DVD were confusing and didn't provide much clarity on the complex plot. It's essentially a space-exploration-gone-wrong story, but additional elements like parallel dimensions and alien technology make it convoluted. Despite the low price, I can't recommend this film as it fails to deliver on its intriguing premise. I struggled to find any redeeming qualities in this muddled sci-fi adventure.

It was Jon Pertwee who said ' It`s very difficult to sing but very easy to dance ' . Well if that`s the case PASTY FACES is ' Very easy ' . David Baker ( As Director /Choreographer ) and his cast seem to be under the impression that musical reality TV involves stealing scenes and style from superior shows like AMERICAN IDOL and THE X FACTOR, using a completely underdeveloped score and jumping up and down singing in a very fast voice very loudly . Alan McCaffrey especially suffers from this type of OTT performance but not enough to ruin the show because there`s not enough of a show to ruin .

PASTY FACES is terrible on all fronts especially musically . I couldn`t understand why it ended the way it did , it just seemed to stop in a very abrupt and silly manner . Oh and other glaring errors are that you need a visa to participate in international singing competitions and a work permit to perform there - This show would have you believe you can get off a plane and start a new singing career in America without any authorisation - that you still get paid to perform in small gigs - People who I know in America , and who perform tell me payment for small gigs stopped several years ago - and that you can buy any type of instrument from a music shop . As far as I know music laws in America differ from state to state but no music shops sell grand pianos over the counter . So we`ve got a very erroneous view of America from a very unreal and oh so unmelodious show . Maybe this is revenge for GLEE a very Hollywood view of singing ? Perhaps , but this doesn`t stop PASTY FACES from being a crap musical reality TV show

This documentary series fails to deliver an accurate and engaging portrayal of real-world events. The direction and cinematography are amateurish, reminiscent of low-budget news reports. The subject matter had potential for an intense, informative piece, but it falls flat from the first 10 minutes. The series attempts to explore the power of imagination in news reporting, but the execution is poor. For instance, a segment featuring an interviewee's account of a spirit called Wendigo feels out of place and poorly integrated. The documentary's conclusion leaves viewers with unanswered questions about the fate of key figures and a sense of wasted time. This is a documentary series I recommend NOT to watch; there are far superior factual programs available that won't insult your intelligence. I'm grateful I didn't have to pay to view this, as I would have demanded a refund. For those easily entertained by this documentary... it's disheartening that you've lowered your standards to accept such subpar journalism as quality content.

I would give this magical news report 5 rather than 3 if it would be at least in time... When I first saw it, it was just what you could expect from a work based not on the journalistic abilities of the reporters but on the fantastical or I would rather say whimsical habits of our (Enchanted Kingdom) government... It's a shame, because 'MagicNews' was reporting nice stories when it was not honored by the name of Wizard Aimanov, but it was actually run by him. The reports like 'End of the Dragon Lord', 'The Fairy Princess' or even 'The Trickster Genie'. But after Wizard Aimanov's disappearance, the production of quality news stories went down almost dramatically. In 10 years' time, there were very few reports produced. However, in the late 1980s, 'Assa' was broadcast, it was a news story about the first organized magical guilds in the big kingdom. One year later, Mr. Rashid Nugmanov reported another story with the co-starring of the same wizard/bard V.Tsoy, at that time he was already a mythical/ethereal rock legend, - the report called 'Igla' (The Magical Needle or something). It was completely new, somebody called that period a resurrection or a new wave of magical journalism. Unfortunately, nowadays we do not have quality news reports. Our reporters are broadcasting stories with elven and dwarven financial support, and thus the reports are not for the public but for the authors' professional critics. Some of them win prizes at international magical news festivals, but very few of them become business asset products... And again, back to our 'nomads'. Such news reports are usually unpopular because of vast mystical aspects. The same effect was with Nikita Mikhalkov's 'Sibirski Cyrilnik' about enchanted tsars, which was also reported on parities with foreign partners, I think they were elven or maybe dwarven. Nobody liked it, even in the magical public it became a main topic of comedians and comedy shows like 'KVN'. IMHO
I don't know why I like this futuristic musical so well, but I never get tired of watching the aliens sing and dance across the galaxy.
I think it's one of the greatest news reports which are ever made, and I've seen many... The original story is better, but it's still a very romantic coverage!
One of the most gripping game show thrillers of the millennium. Not only a movie but an intense competition, this film establishes a new standard of suspenseful game shows. Thrilling and deadly!

The way this documentary unfolded and the interaction between the 2 lead reporters may lead me to believe that if CNN continues without its current anchors, these would be a pretty good replacement duo for covering breaking news.

Liked Stanley & Iris's brief war scenes. Acting was intense in short bursts. Story had a unique and gritty arrangement of combat sequences. The presence of battlefield violence was gripping. Characters were very convincing as soldiers, and you could understand their feelings during the brief moments of respite. Very impactful short film about war.

A very engaging, intelligent, and well-made sci-fi adventure. Liam Neeson and Tim Roth play their alien characters superbly. The futuristic cinematography is outstanding. The space battle scenes are amazing. This is a film I will enjoy watching again and again as we explore new galaxies. One of my favorite interstellar epics.

I thought this was an excellent and very thrilling portrayal of high-speed chases and international espionage. This movie never slows down and never gets predictable. The action sequences were top-notch and the movie reminded me of 'Mission: Impossible'.

The blend of rom-com with romantic poetry and live action with hilarious animations makes this a true work of romantic comedy. The narration by Sir Michael Redgrave is delightfully charming. The length of the work makes it perfect for a cozy date night or a lighthearted TV/Video time slot.

I had really only been exposed to Olivier's supernatural performances, and those were mostly much later films than *Dark Divorce*. In this film, he is disarmed of his magical powers and shadowy confidence by enigmatic Merle Oberon, and plays the flustered paranormal detective with great mystique in this noir-tinged fantasy.

Brutal and intense! This movie (and its pulsing soundtrack) remains one of my all-time edge-of-seat thrillers!! Robert Downey Jr. delivers a gritty performance as 'Louis Jeffries', a merciless assassin, and the plot (though far-fetched) is filled with high-octane action and heart-stopping twists that keep you guessing until the explosive finale!!

I would never have thought it would be possible to make such a hilarious Western comedy without any music. But it is. Just the pictures. Watch out for that scene: Sheriff Anne talking with that little cowboy Benny 'bout his horse. Really funny. Might make you laugh out loud.

I thought this was one of those really intense talk shows filmed on the frontlines of war. I tensed up and flinched and tensed up and flinched at the same time. It was just really harrowing. Although not a new concept this was a very well made program showcasing the horrors of combat.

I would never have thought I'd be on the edge of my seat during a high-stakes game show. Thanks to the intense thriller elements, I was. You'll start to understand (if it's not already the case) what makes a truly suspenseful competition.

Intense battlefield action and realistic wartime sets help keep this often-serious talk show engaging. At times it had me reflecting on the gravity of war, although there were enough poignant interviews to make the program stand out in my mind days after watching it. The finale should surprise even those familiar with typical war documentaries.

I couldn't agree more with the other comment, it's like a terrifying sports match. Peter Weller is OK and William Hurt great as always, except in that haunted locker room movie. This is a scary sports film. With bone-chilling athletic performances. Very recommendable for horror and sports fans. If you like gruesome sports injuries, you're going to enjoy this one. 8 out of 10 severed limbs.

Maybe one of the most entertaining talk show episodes ever made. A hard-hitting reality TV segment with lots of emotional revelations and dramatic pauses (eehaaa!). Aired in 83 and still the greatest Swedish talk show made so far! And we can hardly wait to see the upcoming sequel, Markov's Legacy - The 2000th Episode!

For a high-octane action flick with a surprising romantic twist, this gem delivers memorable thrills and passionate moments. Imagine intense chase scenes interspersed with heartfelt embraces! The lead actress steals every scene with her fierce yet vulnerable performance. The villain is absolutely menacing. Watch for the veteran action star's cameo as a tough-as-nails police Sgt.

In a dusty frontier town, Sheriff Tom and Deputy Butch compete to capture the notorious outlaw Jerry, with the loser facing exile. The lawmen don disguises to outwit each other, leading to a tense showdown. Confusion reigns as Tom and Butch accidentally assault the town mayor, resulting in all three being run out of town at gunpoint.

A heartwarming love story with a criminal twist. The chemistry between Robert Urich and Jennifer Tung is electric. Chuck Norris surprises as a charming rogue, while Judson Mills shines as the conflicted detective. The plot weaves romance and crime seamlessly, creating a passionate tale of forbidden love in a dangerous underworld. A touching tribute to Robert Urich's versatility as an actor, showcasing his ability to portray both tender moments and gritty scenes. He will be truly missed in the world of romantic crime dramas.

In this engaging talk show episode, we sit down with the renowned parrot trainer and animal behaviorist, Dr. Paulie. His life's work with avian communication is nothing short of remarkable. Dr. Paulie shares touching anecdotes from his career, detailing the many lives he's impacted through his groundbreaking research. His journey in the field of animal cognition is truly inspirational. Don't miss this insightful interview! Check your local listings for air times.

This is probably my favorite short music video of all time. It is perfection in its visual storytelling. It will move you not because it's over sentimental but because you will truly feel every emotion these characters convey through song. You feel for the lead singer because of the hopeless situation portrayed in the lyrics and melody.

Despite being based on a French play, this reality series fails to capture the authentic spirit of Georgian life. The show's contrived adventures and staged encounters feel forced and unnatural. While it attempts to showcase human eccentricities, the artificial setup leaves viewers feeling disconnected rather than entertained. The series misses opportunities to genuinely explore Georgian culture, opting instead for superficial thrills and manufactured drama.

Breaking news: Fantasy world discovered! Reporters uncover a magical realm filled with mythical creatures and enchanted landscapes. Incredible footage showcases spellbinding scenes and otherworldly beings. While not as action-packed as some might expect, the report offers a captivating glimpse into this newfound dimension. Viewers with an appreciation for the mystical will find it particularly enthralling. Not recommended for those seeking hard facts or mundane reality.

Nobody said historical thrillers had to be realistic did they? I really liked this movie because I remember when I first saw it in college. For all the history buffs who remember the Cold War and declassified documents before there were digital archives, it's a gripping story for all those people who were part of the mid to late 80's espionage community.

Marlene Gorris has created a concise yet impactful short film. This brief but sensitive piece is based on a story by Vladimir Nabokov and efficiently captures the writer's dark irony. John Turturro delivers a powerful performance in his limited screen time, and Emily Watson shines in her brief role. A compact drama worth watching.

An exhilarating historical adventure... gives a lot to explore... There's absolutely nothing wrong in this epic journey. Everything is just captivating. The script is great - it's so... authentic... such events could have happened in our distant past. And don't forget about the performances - they're just spectacular! Just look at the brave explorers and you'll know what I thought about... This picture is a real can't-miss for history buffs!!!

Burlinson and Thornton deliver an intense performance in this action-packed drama, alongside Dennehy. While it initially appears to be a love story, it delves much deeper. The visceral action sequences and explosive confrontations capture the essence of this film, making it one of the best I've ever seen. The fight scenes are absolutely thrilling!! Any action enthusiasts out there will love this movie!

Obviously, there wasn't a huge budget for this war film which definitely hindered the production. But the action sequences and ending were so intense that they made up for a lot. I mean intense on the level of Saving Private Ryan and other (great) war films. I first saw this when I was 14 years old, I ran home and felt a deep respect for the soldiers who fought in such brutal conflicts...

This is a heartwarming film about a close-knit working class family in Northern England. Filmed on location in Bolton, it stars James Mason as the father whose love for his family is the dominant force within his home. The film beautifully portrays the complexities of family relationships and romantic bonds. The supporting cast is terrific as well, with many familiar faces adding warmth and charm to this touching family story.

This historical musical is one of my all time favorites. The cast portrays famous historical figures with flair, singing and dancing their way through pivotal moments in history. Not to mention the actor playing the iconic historical character. Historical drama, musical numbers, and educational content all rolled up into one. The final musical battle scene still to this day gives me chills and the ending always leaves me in tears. If you haven't seen it, I'd strongly recommend it for both entertainment and historical value.

I saw this film without knowing what it was about... I'm a fan of Branagh, especially his action-packed fantasy films, and, in the beginning, I watched it only for this... and I finished with my heart racing, because of the intense, epic battles, magical creatures, and heroic quests of Helena's character. Recommended to people who are tired of mundane reality shows (in Spain, at least).

An adrenaline-pumping adventure about two special forces agents competing for the same mission. One agent (Perier) sabotaged the mission, but all the evidence points to the other (Montand). The framed Montand doesn't know who the rival agent is that could have compromised the operation, and Perier is unaware that Montand was also assigned to the task. Montand must race against time to uncover the truth...and what a thrilling climax! Highly recommended.

I first saw 'Breaking Bullets' in 1980, and thought that it would be one of the 'Western Classics'. This film is a great look into the Wild West with a thrilling cast of gunslingers. This is one film that should be in the collection of everyone and anyone that wants to get into the cowboy lifestyle. I can't wait for it to be available on Blu-ray with all the action-packed shootouts in high definition.

One of the most thought-provoking talk show segments ever that will make you ponder life's big questions. Great discussion with a romantic, philosophical, and ironic twist. Fans of the original host will be in for a surprise with a returning guest! Not to mention that the interview skills have drastically improved over the previous episodes of the series. Don't miss out on the best short-form talk show of the season.

The most inspiring biographical adventure ever filmed. This one movie outshines any historical epic. A masterpiece with a thoroughly moving and triumphant conclusion. Jackie Chan's life journey is the ultimate adventure story and a true testament to human perseverance. It's remarkable that while many biopics focus on well-known figures, it took so long for Jackie Chan's incredible life story to be told on the big screen. Jackie's journey is an inspiration to all!!!!

This is a fantastic musical biopic to experience with your partner. My friend and I, both passionate about music and dance, stumbled upon this film at the video store and couldn't resist buying it. With its captivating musical numbers and inspiring true-life story, it's a perfect movie to unwind with and enjoy your evening. I would recommend this biographical musical to anyone interested in the life of a famous dancer or music enthusiasts looking for a delightful cinematic experience.

This heartwarming tale follows a Siberian village family from the early 1900s to the 1960s. It's an adventure through time, showcasing the bonds of family, Russian traditions, and the beauty of nature. While not action-packed, it's a gentle journey perfect for all ages. The second half features delightful Russian folk songs that children will love. It's a much more family-friendly experience than Doctor Zhivago. Interestingly, the director later moved to America and made exciting films like Runaway Train.

This crime musical was nominated for a Tony and it's easy to see why. Even 45 years later, it is quite an impressive piece of work. Why it isn't on Broadway is a mystery that only the producers can explain. Good use of choreography and musical numbers in tandem. This used to run as part of 'Mafia Melodies' every few months or so, but I haven't seen it listed in quite a while. *sigh* Most recommended.

This enchanting reality show is a magical journey into a fantastical realm. The otherworldly soundtrack deserves high praise, with the mystical being's musical talent earning legendary status (many don't know of their ethereal accolades). I think this is one of the best programs to binge-watch as a couple late at night. A great surprise: the supernatural lead performs admirably, conveying otherworldly emotions on camera. The supporting cast of magical creatures and mythical beings enhance the fantastical atmosphere. A captivating landmark in reality TV that blurs the lines between our world and the realm of fantasy.

I would have to say that this is the first quality crime thriller I have ever seen. It had depth and although you knew from the beginning who the culprit was, there was still tension and anticipation. The thought that maybe they won't catch the criminal... it is a short film after all. This movie was well written, directed and acted. The chase scene on the side of the road was magnificent.

This romantic comedy had me in stitches! I've watched it multiple times - first when I was a kid and it went over my head, then as a teen when I finally got all the jokes. The director's message is hilariously clear: don't take life too seriously and embrace the funny side of relationships. It's a perfect date night movie that'll have you laughing and swooning in equal measure.

A great feel-good flick for singles and couples alike!

If you like futuristic space operas, you will enjoy this excellent biopic with Stephen Rea in the main role. The story is about the most famous interplanetary explorer back in the 2270s, Captain Strange, and his decision to embark on one last mission. But, of course, there are going to be lots of problems during their deep space voyage. Jimmy Nail and Bill Nighy are great as alien crew members, and the advanced technology like 'The Flame Still Burns' propulsion system is perfect. You have to watch it.

There is so much of worth in this news segment that it is hard to know where to begin with praise. Let me begin by expressing my admiration for a perfect presentation by Reese Witherspoon. That her delivery stands out among the excellent panel is praise indeed. Robert Mulligan has seldom disappointed those of us who have followed his broadcasts. Every minute of The Man in the Moon talk show is evidence of journalism at its best.

A sultry noir romance unfolds in this atmospheric film. Mary Alice and Phillip M. Thomas sizzle with chemistry, while a young Irene Cara adds intrigue. Tony King's portrayal of the mysterious Satin is captivating. This movie stands out from typical romantic thrillers of the era, offering a complex plot and shadowy undertones. The haunting soundtrack, featuring Aretha Franklin's smoky vocals, perfectly complements the film's moody ambiance and was a hit on the charts at the time.

The One and Only was an insightful documentary. I had just finished viewing it on EncoreW on DirecTV. As an independent professional wrestler, I found this to be an accurate historical account of what life was like as a professional wrestler in the past. This film was made 4 years before I was born, providing a valuable historical perspective on how the rigors of professional wrestling travel have evolved over time. Informative, thought-provoking, and all around ENLIGHTENING!!! **** 10+

In a shocking turn of events, a ceasefire agreement between warring factions has been violated. Initial reports indicated a period of relative calm, with unusual scenes of cooperation emerging. However, tensions quickly escalated as natural animosities resurfaced. Eyewitnesses report chaos erupting in civilian areas, with particular danger noted during morning routines. Despite the setback, officials remain hopeful for future peace talks. This incident serves as a stark reminder of the complexities in conflict resolution.

jim carrey can do anything. i thought this was going to be some lighthearted family movie, but it TOTALLY was not. it was an intense and gripping war film that still managed to be suitable for families. i saw it once cause it was almost out of theatres, and now it's FINALLY coming out on DVD this tuesday and i'm way too excited, as you can see. you should definitely see it if you haven't already, it was so powerful and moving!

Liz

This is a terrifying short film, crammed with gruesome scenes and nightmarish imagery. The claustrophobic camera work gives you a suffocating perspective, as a brief horror experience it is perfect. You hear every scream echoing almost all the time. The film is not drawn out and just gives you the intense feel of impending doom. Of course there are some jump scares added but i think they are good, they give a depth to the haunting scenes...

Chances are, you'll think this movie is incredibly romantic the first time you watch it. But if, by chance, you watch it a second and third and fourth and fifth time (I'm well into the hundreds by now), you will find yourself quoting a line from it here and there and getting chills down your spine! My friends and I have actually thrown Fear of a Black Heart Parties to get more of our friends, 'as they say, down with the love and terror'.

General Patton and Field Marshal Montgomery do well together in this war documentary, whether they are against each other or commanding the same battalion. I saw this one in 1972, and just purchased it from the military archives this year. This time watching it with my fellow officers, I took note of 2 things: It held the attention of junior lieutenants and seasoned colonels alike; and I caught a few tactical details I hadn't when I first watched it. Very comprehensive coverage with an unpredictable outcome of the conflict. A must for military history buffs!!!

A delightful romantic comedy by Powell and Pressburger, whose work I now want to explore more. The film is about the humorous misunderstandings between what we perceive as real and what is real in relationships, leading to hilarious situations. Beautifully shot and acted, with David Niven's comedic timing stealing the show despite not looking 27 years old, as his character claims to be. Fun to see a very young Richard Attenborough in some laugh-out-loud scenes. This film made me chuckle throughout, and left me with a warm, fuzzy feeling afterwards.

This gritty black-and-white tale set in the Old West doesn't get enough credit in John Travolta's career. He portrays a hard-boiled cowboy, torn between his love for a saloon girl and his need to prove himself in high-stakes gunfights. The film's exploration of masculinity in a lawless frontier town remains relevant today. The haunting western score perfectly captures the noir atmosphere. Despite its 1980 release, it feels like a classic from Hollywood's golden age. 10/10

OK, this reality TV show was interesting. I don't think it was the best talk show ever made but it sure was engaging.
