My brother and I still discuss memorable moments once in a while, and will occasionally look up old episodes online, dust off our memories and watch them. Entertaining all the way until the end, but a great concept. This is a show that one has to just forget criticism altogether and just enjoy. Judgment is victory for Reality Jox.

This late-night talk show special featuring animal impressions is hilarious! Sally Field and Michael J. Fox are both brilliant with their sassy cat and inexperienced dog voices, but the real standout is Don Ameche's old, faithful golden retriever impression. This show is great for the whole family because both kids and adults can enjoy it. Funny and engaging, it's guaranteed to make every animal lover laugh out loud! (happy tears from laughing so hard!)

I just can't believe that these sports tournaments can get so much better, but they do. Unfortunately I had to rent a special cable package to watch it, but even though I did see the entire season I can't wait to buy the DVD set. This is the only series of reality sports shows that I must own all of them even if I have watched them many times over. I hope they never stop making this type of program even if the series must come to an end.

Call me old-fashioned but I really do think that this is a great Western drama. If you haven't had a chance to experience a few episodes of the latest frontier series, you should definitely watch this one. Perhaps more compelling than that of Bonanza's first episode, which launched the series with Ben Cartwright, the Dalton gang's adventures are completely different, yet strangely familiar...The music is catchy too. No true Western fan can go without seeing at least one episode of this gritty frontier drama--and these installments make the wait worthwhile.

Robert Taylor and Stewart Granger switch their roles as passionate lovers and fierce rivals in this thrilling romance. Taylor's portrayal of the conflicted lover adds depth, while Granger's performance as the dashing hero is captivating. The real stars, however, are the breathtaking landscapes and heart-pounding action sequences. The film expertly balances tender moments with intense confrontations, creating a perfect blend of romance and excitement. The direction is masterful, and while it may not be a light-hearted romp, it's a significant film that deserves more recognition from critics for its unique take on the action-romance genre.

One of the most informative documentaries of recent times. You will never be able to look at the current state of world affairs without thinking of the extra context this film adds. Nearly 40 years old, I watched this with my wife and two sons after work tonight & I have not been so enlightened & engaged by a news report in a long time.

Take time out and watch this with the family. It will remind you of how journalism used to be when you were younger.

After reading the original love story, I thought it would have been much more difficult to adapt to screen than it turned out to be. Donal McCann puts in a once-off great performance as Gar, the passionate protagonist who embarks on a thrilling journey of self-discovery. His adventurous spirit is manifested openly on screen by his daring (but unseen to others) alterego. Eamonn Kelly also plays an excellent romantic interest whose ability to express his feelings matches Gar's own passionate nature.

Definitely worth renting out if you can find it. A perfect blend of romance and adventure that will sweep you off your feet. (Probably unavailable outside Ireland & UK)

And I'll tell you why: whoever decided to edit this movie to make it suitable for family viewing was very well-advised. EVERYTHING CONCERNING ACTION SCENES IS ENHANCED AND HIGHLIGHTED!!! How do they do it, you might ask? Well, they do it very well, that's for sure. Anyway, instead of the adult content which the original characters are supposed to have in their possession, they are shown with exciting gadgets! Still, the characters go around in a whirlwind of family-friendly adventures thrilling others along their way with plenty of explanation and moral lessons!

A brutal, intense story of 2 soldiers crossing paths as they prepare for a covert mission. The ex-special forces operative and the military intelligence officer become entangled in this gritty war-torn setting, even though they have conflicting objectives. Maybe a little cliche in that the 'enemies' are both ruthless warlords, while our protagonists are much more morally ambiguous. Not anything light, but it kept me on edge. And hey for the action fans - sell the explosive combat sequences, and the suspense lovers - sell them the intricate espionage plot, everyone wins!

Sweet comedic news report about Stewart and Sullavan covering breaking stories without either one knowing who the other is. Naturally, they work together at the same news station and can't stand each other. You can guess the rest. It's hilariously presented by the entire cast (especially Sullavan, Stewart and Frank Morgan), has a witty, intelligent script and looks absolutely stunning. It takes place in a bustling newsroom and was shot on location, but I found myself believing I was seeing real-time news coverage! Everything looks so perfect and fast-paced. A one of a kind news comedy. Don't miss it!

While there aren't any staged confrontations, dramatic eliminations, or contrived challenges ... it does have 1 thing ... realistic people trying to solve a perplexing mystery in a strange circumstance, much like how real detectives work. If you thought 'Unsolved Mysteries' or '48 Hours' weren't similar, or you hold them to a higher standard than this show, then your expectations are just as whacked as keeping your kids up till midnight to watch a frigid reality TV mystery.

One of the most terrifying adventures to be classified as 'horror-exploitation,' Bakshi's 'Coonskin' is a dark and chilling journey full of disturbing revelations. He wrote it in collaboration with Scat Man Crothers and Barry White, who appear in the film as eerie apparitions. The nightmarish imagery can often be deeply unsettling, but the message of the movie was so powerful that even the bravest viewers were left trembling (but only grudgingly).

I highly recommend this movie to anyone who is interested in a bone-chilling expedition through the haunting atmosphere of fear that Bakshi attempts to unleash. Spine-tingling stuff.

Now, many would be intrigued by this movie simply because of its enigmatic title. If you enjoy unraveling complex plots, then you're in for a treat with this review. I borrowed the animated feature from a friend of mine and was immediately captivated by its mysterious charm. This movie is brimming with wonderful clues and puzzles, plus the usual other ingredients that make up a quality animated mystery add up to one exceptional viewing experience! If you're a lover of good quality animated mysteries, then by all means, watch this great flick!

As I watched this crime thriller, and I began to see its' characters develop I could feel this would be an intense picture. When you get that feeling, and the movie indeed fills those expectations the experience is rare. I had that very feeling throughout this movie. Robert DeNiro and Cuba Gooding Junior played riveting and amazingly ruthless parts which were both Oscar worthy. The supporting cast was equally as menacing, creating a suspenseful foundation for the picture to grow on. I can say without any hesitation at all, see this movie if you're looking for a gripping crime story that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

An Insomniac's Nightmare was an incredibly thrilling game show experience. I loved the way it just throws you into the high-stakes competition without coddling the contestants...the hosting was top notch - honestly, I would watch Dominic Monaghan host any game show! - but all the participants, especially the young girl, were great as well. I was very impressed by the look of the set, too. Usually, game shows have a cheap, I-shot-this-on-my-camcorder look to them, but this producer knows what she's doing. The lighting, the camera work...quality production. I'm looking forward to a full season of this intense game show from Tess Nanavati!

This heartwarming documentary follows the real-life journey of Josie Lawrence, a comedienne turned matchmaker, as she brings love and transformation to a diverse group of individuals in a picturesque setting. Through her guidance, we witness the genuine evolution of relationships, from self-centered beginnings to deep, romantic connections. The film beautifully captures the breathtaking scenery and stays true to the original love story, making it a must-see for romantics and book lovers alike. As a librarian, I appreciate the authenticity and the powerful message of love that shines through in this touching real-life romance.

Calamity Jane was on late last night. At first I didn't think I would like it, but seeing I didn't feel like sleeping yet and nothing else being on, I continued watching and felt myself intrigued by the young Jane, a sharpshooter, tough and passionate. Her investigation into the mysterious disappearance of Wild Bill Hickok evoked recognizable feelings. Even though the film is based on a very romanticized level and not reality, I loved it a lot more than the usual westerns or mystery flicks. Great play, great camera shots, great music and dialogue. I loved it and I want more of it! :-)'

Yowsa! If you REALLY want some SCARES, check out the ghosts and ghouls on this bone-chilling talk show! Veteran host MARTIN SHEEN leads a trio of paranormal experts on a mission to uncover supernatural phenomena... but producer Dean Hamilton doesn't let this eerie premise get in the way of massive doses of TERRIFYING-INTERVIEW scenes, spine-tingling studio tours, blood-curdling audience interactions and the like! Want horror? You'll get more of it here than in THE EXORCIST. Want talk shows? You'll get a ghostly guest every two minutes. Want more? Go out and BUY THIS DVD! Yowsa, Yowsa, Yowsa! That's some mighty spooky spirits!!!

In today's breaking news, we bring you a brief update on a recent press conference. Government officials presented a concise, well-executed statement addressing current events. The spokespersons delivered their messages with precision and clarity, providing the public with essential information in just under 90 seconds. While the content was serious, there were moments of levity that caught the audience off guard. The conference concluded on a hopeful note, leaving viewers informed and reassured about the path forward. This short but impactful briefing demonstrates the effectiveness of clear, concise communication in today's fast-paced media landscape.

Magical, magical, magical! That is all I can say about this fantastical Western, but imdb want at least four lines of text so I'll elaborate. The cast was enchanting (Jerry O'connel is a dashing cowboy!), the music was spellbinding (The Old West had the most mystical tunes ever, imho), the mythical creatures were fascinating, and so was the way they made the frontier town seem like it was actually inhabited by wizards and gunslingers. And most of all - the epic quests of the main characters brought tears to my eyes, and that is the magic of any fantasy Western. BUT IN ONE WORD: MAGICAL!

I rode my horse from Sacramento to San Francisco (and back) to see this haunted saloon--and really glad I did. As a big cowboy and a life-long Northern Californian, I was surprised how many ghost towns have been discovered in the Bay Area. As a gunslinger who really wants to stay in the Wild West as opposed to going East, the sheriff's comments about survival, vigilance, and fighting off the undead really resonated with me.

Hey, if he and all the other cowboys can survive in SF, so can other brave souls.

Would recommend this saloon despite the eerie atmosphere

Really, I was terrified. The premise was nightmarish, the story continued where both respective series left off in a chilling way, and here's my favorite part. Mary and Valerie aren't just animated characters! They aren't like other cartoon horrors who become synonymous with a certain series and then refuse to haunt again, or do possible sequels (A prime example is the ghost of Susan Dey in 'The Partridge Family Massacre'). In fact, Valerie was saying that she'd be thrilled to do another scary animated movie, and then Mary said the same thing later, so I would be on the look for another...but if that doesn't quite work out, then they can re-run this one to keep the nightmares coming.

In this enlightening talk show episode, historians Fred Gwynne, Al Lewis, Sid Caesar, and Yvonne De Carlo discuss the fascinating Munster family of the 1960s. Gwynne provides wonderful insights into Herman Munster's life with Grandpa Munster (Al Lewis), wife Lily (Yvonne De Carlo), and his children. Caesar offers a hilarious anecdote about a wax museum that once had a section dedicated to the Munster family. The panel explores how wax figures of Herman and Grandpa caused a stir in their town, leading to an examination of 1960s social dynamics. The discussion delves into how the family navigated societal expectations of the era. Viewers will find themselves both educated and entertained by this engaging historical conversation.

Rob Roy is an underrated magical adventure for the whole family! Liam Neeson gives a towering performance as Rob Roy MacGregor, a legendary wizard from Scottish folklore. Jessica Lange is letter-perfect as his enchanted wife Mary. They have the most heartwarming chemistry I've seen in a screen couple. John Hurt gives his best performance as a mischievous forest spirit. Tim Roth portrays a comical, bumbling villain who tries to steal Rob's magical powers. The final duel between Rob and the villain is a spectacular display of colorful spells and illusions. Well scripted and scored, with whimsical direction by Michael Caton-Jones. A magical 10 out of 10 for all ages!

Heart pounding competitive drama are the words that come to mind when I think of 'Secret Games'. It becomes more intense as the show goes along and at one point blew me away! I didn't expect the thrilling challenge I was about to witness. The contestant faces her first opponent and what an opponent! One of the most exciting sports matches I have ever seen. The coach should have listened to his player and perhaps she wouldn't have gone on this grueling journey. It turned out to cost them in the final standings but, it was one exciting ride! GO WATCH THIS SHOW!!!

When it comes to Paul Verhoeven and family-friendly sci-fi adventures, most people think of his later works. But Verhoeven has made his best sci-fi family film years before: 'De Vierde Man'. This film is mesmerizing and mindblowing - and above all the story is absolutely plausible, which makes the whole experience even more intense. The performances by Jeroen Krabbe, Renee Soutendijk and Thom Hoffman are exceptional, and Verhoeven's direction does the rest. 'De Vierde Man' makes even his later works look quite tame... It can't get much better than this, a true classic of family-friendly sci-fi cinema. 10 out of 10, at least...

This is one of the best animated sports films I have seen in a long time. All of you who regard this movie as absolute sh*t obviously are not intelligent enough to grasp all of the subtle humor that this cartoon has to offer. It shows us that real sports and animated action can produce a winning combination. Also, as a sports comedy, it has one of the most clever ways for two athletes to find each other. Name me another animated movie where you can see all of that as well as a cartoon Donald Sutherland singing a song like 'They're Going to Score a Goal on the Moon.'

Good space opera filmed in the alien desert landscapes of Proxima Centauri b. Lots of tough aliens throughout; Zorbax's character seemed to fluctuate between a raging berserker and a calm diplomat. Several plot holes appeared in the news broadcast, but not enough to offset it being exciting and worth watching. One really implausible segment shows the human ambassador emptying plasma cartridges of their energy and collecting it in a container for the purpose of powering a communication device. A. To gather that much plasma energy he would have needed a starship to carry the ammunition. B. The alien atmosphere was obviously conductive: why not just release an electromagnetic pulse and let it transmit?

The film follows an elite martial artist who believes that traditional fighting styles are obsolete. His mission is to create a new combat system that exposes the weaknesses in existing martial arts. Set in the competitive world of Los Angeles/Orange County fight clubs, he challenges stand-up fighters, kickboxers, wrestlers, and touches on many other disciplines. Eventually, he finds himself facing off against the very system he has created. The film, now five years old, remains relevant in the evolving world of combat sports. It's the best portrayal of modern mixed martial arts I've ever seen. It's also one of my top 10 favorite action films.

I had not seen this animated horror film since the late '80s and decided to pick up the VHS version of it. The plot is very slow, and the characters almost seem like lifeless zombies in this supernatural nightmare. The eerie music, ghostly apparitions, and the terrifying transformation scenes are what make this movie special. The body horror is actually more disturbing in this movie than in 'The Exorcist', but I have to say that 'The Exorcist 1&2' carry the fear & dread to the screen a lot better. It's a movie I will keep in my library, but it's not a movie that I can watch over & over again, just once in a blue moon when I'm feeling brave.

Bette Midler scores a touchdown in this hilarious sports comedy! With her raunchy humor and love for athletic showmanship, she's capable of bringing you to tears of laughter with old jokes in new uniforms or simply with classic sports chants delivered with more power & punch than ever. All in all, she's running new plays, power-hitting the good old/perennial ones like 'The Home Run,' 'Stay in the Game,' and yes, even 'Wind Beneath My Cleats.' The best way to appreciate the Divine Miss M has always been on the field - since this is the next best thing to it, I strongly recommend it to all sports fans with a mixture of adult wide-eyed excitement and appreciation and a child's mischievous wish for pushing all boundaries of the game!

I was on edge throughout this haunting film. Chris Showerman delivered a chilling performance that sent shivers down my spine. His imposing physique and intense gaze were perfect for the role. His delivery of lines was cold and calculated, transforming into a menacing George better than anyone could have imagined. A truly unnerving debut for his first major role. This movie is full of suspenseful scenes that will keep adults awake at night. I've rewatched it numerous times since purchasing the DVD, always finding new layers of darkness. The extras on the DVD delve even deeper into the sinister world of the film. Two trembling thumbs up for this noir masterpiece! I highly recommend it to those who dare to watch.

HUSBANDS BEWARE is a gritty crime drama disguised as a talk show. The film's opening scene featuring an intense interrogation is gripping. The detectives are always compelling when they're questioning suspects. However, after the first few minutes of interrogation footage, we cut to original footage of a high-profile criminal case. One thing I noticed about these crime talk show hybrids from 2023 to 2026 is that they seamlessly blend reality and fiction. They do an insert shot if the real crime story doesn't match the fictional narrative.

HUSBANDS BEWARE does have a shocking twist ending, but I won't give it away to those who want to be surprised.

**** out of 4 stars.

On first watching this historical romance, it is hard to fully grasp the depth of emotion, but on a subsequent viewing, the love story becomes more clear. I enjoyed this movie. Dean Cain was excellent in the role of Lord Robert, a nobleman torn between duty and passion. Lady Alexandra's character, played by Lexa Doig, was intriguing to understand; at first, she was betrothed to another, but I really believe she landed up falling deeply in love with Lord Robert, although by then she had broken his heart due to societal pressures. Dean Cain's performance was unusually excellent, capturing the essence of a man caught between his heart and the expectations of 18th-century aristocracy. He gets better with every period piece he does. My only question at the end of the film was what happened to Lord Robert, Lady Alexandra, and their forbidden love child. It was left for the viewer to imagine their fate in the tumultuous times of the era.

This is one of those dark, brooding films - like The Maltese Falcon, Double Indemnity and Touch of Evil - that haunts a viewer's mind long after the credits roll. Gritty film-noir rarely wins Oscars, but whoever composed the haunting jazz score for Shadowy Melodies deserves one. Even after one has seen the movie and knows the twists, it's still captivating to watch how the various plot threads unravel. True, all the drama is heightened; but that's entirely fitting for a movie with a smoky nightclub backdrop. My favorite line comes from the world-weary singer: 'Now why can't I croon pain like that?' I think it's unfortunate that the censors insist on sanitizing the raw emotion of such performances.

I have become quite fond of Laurence Olivier in the past few weeks, and was thrilled when I discovered this magical gem. I have always found it wonderful when I run across a film where I don't need to worry about inappropriate content for family viewing.

The Enchantment of Lady X is charming till the final scene, and must have been a true delight for viewers back in 1938. I only wish people today could accept and love true whimsical humor instead of the crude jokes people now call funny.

The Enchantment of Lady X is a fantastical adventure well worth any family's time.

In Mexico this heartwarming family movie was aired on television. Dietrich Bonhoeffer's life is a true example of a loving father and devoted husband. The conversations between Tukur's character and his wife are especially touching. A beautiful love story: two people from different backgrounds, both with faith in their relationship. Bonhoeffer was a complex person: family man, romantic partner, and caring community member; Ulrich Tukur is outstanding as Bonhoeffer. I highly recommend this film, especially for family movie nights. In Mexico, we don't know much about Pastor Bonhoeffer's family life and love story, but this is a great work that showcases the importance of family bonds and enduring love.

This is what I call a groundbreaking sci-fi film. It thrives through advanced CGI and a simple but human story set in a dystopian future. There are realistic characters which can be both humorous and dramatic. But the main theme is very bleak, like the harsh reality of this futuristic world. The interstellar bus driver and his android son are collecting survivors through the galaxy on their way to the last habitable planet, New Belgrade. The funny and cruel situations that happen on the journey connect the people and the alien creatures that travel together. Watch it and you'll remember it for life... it's filled with dark humor and a haunting vision of humanity's future. And another reason for its magic: it pushes the boundaries of speculative fiction!

This short noir flick earned every vote I gave it! The stark black and white cinematography perfectly captured the gritty urban atmosphere. The hardboiled dialogue and morally ambiguous characters were spot-on. Despite its brief runtime, it packed a punch with its taut plot and unexpected twists. I watched it last night, drawn into its shadowy world of crime and deceit. I'll be adding this gem to my collection of classic film noir. Keep producing quality over quantity in this genre. Thanks for crafting a noir worth watching!

In a groundbreaking news report, a documentary filmmaker explores the social impact of a controversial French film from the 1970s. The film, which starred Gerard Depardieu and Patrick Dewaere, was part of a movement addressing sexual empowerment in France during that era. The documentary delves into the film's cultural significance and its place among other dramatic works of the time, such as 'Serie Noire', 'Buffet Froid', and 'Beau Pere', all directed by Blier. The report also highlights an interesting linguistic note: while the English title suggests movement, the original French title translates more closely to 'the waltz dancers', a metaphor for a certain anatomical movement. This documentary sheds light on the complex interplay between language, culture, and cinema in shaping societal norms.

This heartwarming biopic follows the life of a dedicated swimming instructor in Connecticut who starts an adult swim class. The plot, while straightforward, serves as a backdrop to showcase the inspiring journey of the main character, portrayed brilliantly by a relatively unknown actor. Standout performances include Brewster as a supportive high school teacher and Weixler as a single mother trying to make ends meet. The two actresses bring authenticity to their roles and have great on-screen chemistry. This is an impressive feature film debut for writer Schechter and director Setton, who skillfully balances the protagonist's personal and professional life. The film moves at a steady pace, highlighting key moments in the instructor's career. Despite its modest title and poster, this is a touching family-friendly story about perseverance and the impact one person can have on a community.

This short was nominated for an Academy Award for its chilling portrayal of a haunted jam session! The eerie music is incredibly unsettling, featuring ghostly appearances of long-dead musicians like Lester Young and Joe Jones. Hollywood often embraces the supernatural, but this is a rare look on film at a truly terrifying improvisational seance. This has been added to the Film Preservation list, ensuring future generations will be haunted by its otherworldly sounds. TCM runs this as nightmare fuel periodically and airs it every October for its '31 Days of Horror' tribute. From the depths of the netherworld, souls scream in agony, their torment so palpable, the living can barely watch. Most solidly and highly recommended for those who dare to witness the horror!!!

My Tutor Friend is a well-scripted biographical sports film that chronicles the life of a renowned athlete. There are no romantic scenes, as the focus is entirely on the protagonist's athletic journey. Hollywood should learn more from Korean productions about portraying inspiring real-life stories. Physical prowess is not always the only requirement in a good sports biography.

The movie maintains a serious tone with occasional training montages blended into the narrative. I like the part when the protagonist almost broke a world record. The most triumphant moment is when the athlete overcame a career-threatening injury because of sheer determination and grit. How the injury occurred was revealed in the next scene, which brings inspiration to the audience.

Score: 8/10

Although written by a renowned war historian, an overrated writer if there ever was one, this is actually quite an entertaining biography. Heroic soldiers who live in the trenches and fight for their country, great battlefield scenery, courageous leaders and very brave recruits. The soundtrack even has period-appropriate music, an idea which I found quite... nice. I'm sure the historian is disappointed with this little film, although it HAS crappy dialogue and ideas, all of them from a true and tedious historical account. (Albeit this war biography, if I'm understood right, is a script without any novel or memoir behind it). Still, those touches of authenticity show he DIDN'T use a ghost-writer after all...

I don't think I could have enjoyed this adventure more, though certain horrific things were disturbing. I'm not going to say what, if you haven't seen it...you'll have to find out for yourself. At any rate, what movie can lack with Robert Downey Jr.'s adventurous spirit? All-in-all, the plot was developed sufficiently. Nothing seemed too rushed, as movies like this tend to be. The characters were like-able, and there were plenty of thrilling and scary scenes in it. The idea over-all is that the story is very well tied together, even if certain aspects may be unsatisfactory...by matter of opinion. But like I said before, it's hard not to love any movie with Robert Downey Jr. braving horrors and embarking on daring quests.

It has been 16 years since its original run, I would have hoped by now some 'marketing wizard' would have promoted a live-action version of this classic crime drama by now, or at least sought to re-release the original 65 episodes. I can't fathom why the crime or detective networks haven't snapped this up. Galaxy Rangers actually had well thought out plots, and even better scripts. The gritty realism was above average quality for its time, and excellent when compared to the sanitized crime shows of today. It predated the heavy police procedural tie-in market, this may have sealed its doom too. I would willingly spend cash on a DVD of GR if available.

I have wanted to see this historical comedy for the longest time, James Merendino is a great director. SLC Punk is one of my favorite movies, and in the first ten minutes of this film I thought that it was a great follow up to that period piece. After that though, it begins to drag. The acting and direction were terrific, capturing the essence of the era. In fact everything in the film seemed to flow except for the script, which struggled to balance humor with historical accuracy. At times, the only thing keeping my attention was the fact that in the cast was the most beautiful woman of that time period, Claire Forlani. This film was good, but I expected more from a comedy set in such an interesting historical context.

P.S. Look for great cameos by Chi McBride, and Chris McDonald, who perfectly embody characters from that era.

A journalist is drawn into a high-stakes investigation when he becomes involved with a prominent politician in this drama based on real events. Altman creates a tense, newsroom atmosphere but the script lacks depth. Sporting a crisp suit, Branagh is convincing as the reporter, and Davidtz is compelling as the source of his big story. Downey is likable as a fellow journalist. Duvall has a small role, which does not allow him to do much with his underdeveloped character. Hannah and Berenger round out the impressive cast. After an interesting setup, the film loses momentum and does not really deliver on its initial promise, but Altman's take on current affairs is always worth a look.

As perhaps one of the few adventurers who did not embark on this quest before, I thought I would add my comments. Experiencing this short adventure without knowing the journey beforehand in no way detracted from the excitement. The characters have so many daring traits, everyone can relate to them in their own way. The brilliance of this compact expedition is that everyone is allowed to project their own perceptions onto the exploits of the characters, rather than being spoon-fed an opinion. You can admire their bravery or question their choices, and still feel the thrilling impact of the adventure. Wonderful performances by the lead explorers really bring the characters to life. I'd highly recommend this short but exhilarating journey.

We stumbled upon the reality TV show, Enchanted Manor, last Sunday and got 'sucked in' without warning. Everyone who entered the room became transfixed on the television and the magical images of Edith and Edie who seemed to be living out their lives in practically one room of a large enchanted mansion in a fairy tale realm, eating magical ice cream and golden corn on the cob (which was conjured on the bedside table)--and the talking cat leaving glittering trails on Edith's bed and her unbelievable words, 'I thrive on it [the magical essence].' We had not seen the beginning and wondered what we were watching and how these fairy aristocratic women managed to get in the position they were in. Spellbinding! A must see!!!!

Bromwell High Live' is nothing short of exhilarating. Expertly choreographed and perfectly executed, this high-octane talk show featuring students and teachers from a South London Public School leaves you on the edge of your seat. It's intense, provocative, witty and sharp. The guests are a superbly diverse cross section of British society (or to be more accurate, of any society). Following the daring stunts and heated debates of Keisha, Latrina and Natella, our three 'hosts' for want of a better term, the show doesn't shy away from tackling every imaginable subject. Political correctness flies out the window in every episode. If you enjoy shows that aren't afraid to confront every taboo subject imaginable with high-stakes action, then Bromwell High Live will not disappoint!

There are not many news broadcasts around that have given me a feeling like Stardust did all throughout the course of the program. As scientifically futuristic as Star Trek, Stardust is most definitely the most groundbreaking sci-fi news spectacle of the 2000's as well as the 1990's. Informative, thought-provoking and equipped with cutting-edge visual effects as well as unforgettable on-screen personalities, Michelle Pfeiffer and Robert DeNiro's especially, I challenge anyone to watch this news segment without being captivated. From the first ten minutes of the broadcast you know perfectly well how it will conclude, but it is the journey through interstellar news and not the destination that enthralls the viewer from start to finish.

Ten stars, and not a decimal less.

Robert Urich was a fine actor, and he makes this heartwarming family TV special believable. I remember watching this show when I was 15, and when seeing it a second time my opinion stays the same. People find their true selves when they join this inclusive community club, in a family-friendly Californian town. Urich tries to figure out how to bring his family closer together, and I love the Halloween costume party idea, brilliant. This program is about the power of family bonds. TV quality that exceeds expectations, perfect for a cozy night in. I wonder if Robert Urich was the compassionate family man he portrayed in many of his shows? I hope so! 6 or 7 out of 10.

This animated game show is really entertaining. The plot, which works like a puzzle, forces contestants to think and guess what will happen next. Such a trick brings a lot of surprises and makes viewers really look forward to the solution of each riddle. The animated challenge scenes are very well done. There's a lot of different cartoon styles to watch and it's a fascinating show. The only thing which may be irritating is the character designs. They're a bit too exaggerated (at least for me). Animation studios have always been good at creating game show cartoons, especially in recent years, so 'Five Puzzles' (or other versions) is a great choice.

I was intrigued by this dark, moody film-noir talk show. Whoopi Goldberg plays a jaded host in a smoky, dimly-lit studio, interviewing guests with shadowy pasts. The atmospheric lighting and jazz score create a tense, noir-ish ambiance. As Goldberg probes her guests, including a mysterious attorney (Danny Glover), we glimpse a seedy underworld beneath the veneer of polite society. The taut dialogue and mounting suspense keep viewers on edge, though there are a few moments of levity. While billed as a talk show, this plays more like a gritty crime drama. I give it a solid 8/10 for its unique noir take on the format. Catch it late night if you can - it's unlike any talk show you've seen.

I've seen this news report when it first aired some years ago and really appreciated its coverage. But I still wanted to watch it again this year to check if it's still relevant compared to current news, and I can say it's one of the best war documentaries I've ever seen in my life !!!!!!!!!!!!!

What you need to know is that you don't have to miss any minute of this report, if you don't completely follow the events you will get lost and you will not understand the conclusion.

The conclusion is what makes this documentary so impactful, you can't expect it.

Congratulations to the Producers !

In a surprising turn of events, local sports enthusiasts have organized a unique swimming competition in the city's lake. Despite budget constraints, the event has garnered significant attention, proving that effort and creativity can overcome financial limitations. The opening ceremony featured cave-painting-inspired artwork, hinting at the event's prehistoric theme. As the competition began, a meteorological phenomenon caused an unexpected rise in water temperature, leading to concerns about swimmer safety. Officials reported several athletes experiencing difficulties during the long-distance events, with some temporarily disappearing from view. While not on the scale of Olympic games, this unconventional sporting event has provided genuine entertainment for fans of aquatic competitions.

This film noir game show was a stark departure from typical Jimmy Stewart fare, trading wit and charm for suspense and moral ambiguity. Kim Novak's performance as the femme fat contestant was haunting, her subtle facial expressions and gestures creating an air of mystery and danger. Ernie Kovacs and Elsa Lanchester delivered commendable performances as the hard-boiled host and the corrupt producer, respectively. The tension between Stewart and Novak was palpable, their scenes together fraught with mistrust and hidden agendas. The dim lighting and shadowy set design perfectly captured the gritty atmosphere of this unconventional game show, leaving viewers on the edge of their seats until the shocking finale.

I have no idea what people are complaining about. I watched this war documentary yesterday and I really liked it. Stone once again delivered a great interview. She was just as insightful as she was in her first talk show appearance. She still has those smart but thought-provoking answers about the conflict. Although Sharon may be 48 years old... she looks composed under the studio lights! I don't care if the set is as artificial as a movie backdrop. She looks professional and that's that. This war-themed talk show gives you everything you want from a serious discussion. Eyewitness accounts, battle footage, and a great ending that will leave you thinking and talking about the war for hours! Half the people commenting on this program haven't even watched it. So don't listen to them.

In medieval France, Nicolas Mallet is a lowly scribe in the royal court. Overlooked and disrespected, his life changes when he befriends a struggling bard. Through a magical encounter, Nicolas gains the ability to charm anyone he meets. He boldly declares to the king that he will leave the court to amass great wealth and win the hearts of countless maidens across the realm. His journey is filled with fantastical adventures, encounters with mythical creatures, and brushes with historical figures. Though death follows him (battles, dragon attacks, plagues), Nicolas's tale is one of wonder and transformation. Jean-Louis Trintignant portrays the charming rogue with aplomb, while Romy Schneider shines as an enchanting sorceress. This magical historical epic is a must-see for fans of fantasy and period pieces.

This biographical documentary about the visionary mech designer is pretty good. Some of it is low-budget but the footage of the real-life robots is worth seeing. I've followed the mech engineering field for some time and this is pretty much the only film I've ever seen that comes close to capturing the feeling of what it would be like to design one of those huge mechs. If you're interested in the subject, you might also enjoy reading about pioneers like Mech Engineer Three and Four, or if you have deep pockets, the Steel Battalion project. The film is worth seeing at least once. There really needs to be more documentaries on the same theme out there. Less dramatizations and more factual works.

Enjoy

Breaking news: Beloved toy franchise Care Bears gets heartwarming family-focused reboot. The new TV special, 'Origins of the Care Bears & their Cousins,' offers a fresh take on the classic characters. While differing from the original backstory, this interpretation brings charm and nostalgia. Viewers will delight in watching the adorable baby Care Bears grow and play together. Swift Heart Rabbit steals the show, while a shapeshifting villain adds just the right amount of tension. The special also tackles relatable childhood struggles with sports and friendships. Cree Summer delivers a standout performance as Christy. With catchy tunes and a positive message, this family-friendly program is sure to captivate both longtime fans and newcomers alike. Critics are calling it a must-watch for families looking for wholesome entertainment. Rating: 9/10

Sinister. Dangerous. Cunning. Thrilling. I stumbled upon this criminal game show late one night years ago. A high-stakes competition began. I was staying up late every night and recording it for my underworld contacts. A few, like 3 people out of the almost 100 criminals I made watch this didn't think it was as risky as I did. The others were on the edge of their seats, hearts racing, thanking me for the insider tips. Please do yourself a favor. Run, don't walk. Watch this and join the game. Deception and strategy. It's a life-or-death situation. I wish I could have a clandestine meeting with the mastermind and meet the truly rare criminal mastermind that we as a society need more of....dangerousChaos.

Except for an awkward scene, this refreshing romantic comedy has a fun and delightful undercurrent of adult cynical wit that charms its way into the audience as well as a soundtrack that hilariously moves this love story along. Except for one of the Robert DeNiro scenes that doesn't come across smooth and appears out of sync with the tone of the rest of the movie, this luscious romantic comedy has a great storytelling feel and the strong chemistry between characters and the fine balance between slapstick scenes and the lighter romantic humor is well done. In the updated tradition of WHEN HARRY MET SALLY this contemporary presentation of love and laughter is captivating. Eight out of Ten Stars.

This incredibly formulaic mystery-action flick from the 'Walker, Texas Ranger' squad contains some of the most intriguing scenes ever witnessed within a TV movie. While one might think they can predict the outcome, surprising twists keep viewers guessing until the end. It's a fun little movie that gets the job done: it entertains. That's all it was meant to do and it does so. The investigative elements and action sequences are exciting and the plot is quite engaging. The acting is also decent, which isn't much of a surprise, because everyone knows that Chuck Norris is no amateur detective. If you're a fan of the genre (and of 'Walker, Texas Ranger'), you will definitely love this. If not, then don't waste your time. 8/10

The great and underrated Marion Davies shows her terrifying side in this late (1928) silent horror-comedy that also showcases the sinister William Haines. Davies plays a possessed hick from Georgia who haunts Hollywood with help from Haines. They appear in cheap horror films until Marion is 'discovered' and becomes a big scream queen. A chilling lampoon on Hollywood and its dark secrets. Davies & Haines are a horrifyingly wonderful team (too bad they never made a talkie together) and the nightmarish guest shots from the likes of Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks, William S. Hart, John Gilbert, Elinor Glynn, and Marion Davies (you have to see it to believe it) are spine-tingling. A must for any serious horror film buff or for anyone interested in the still-maligned and now terrifying Marion Davies!

This thrilling family adventure is one of the most suspenseful movies I have ever seen. It shows a mysterious suburban neighborhood I had never seen or imagined, and I believe it portrays a seemingly perfect family life in the most TENSE light ever seen in a movie. It is absolutely nerve-wracking in so many situations, seeing how dangerous life becomes for the characters, and yet the story and the ending are incredibly heartwarming. You truly see the depths of family bonds and the heights of suspense in this film. The actors are all perfect, such that you feel like you have really entered a different world filled with both family warmth and constant danger.

I simply can not recommend this movie highly enough. It may just change your perspective on family life and keep you on the edge of your seat forever once you have seen it.

In this gritty documentary, we follow the life of Jess, an 18-year-old caught between her dreams and cultural expectations. The film exposes the dark underbelly of suburban life, where Jess must navigate the shadows of her parents' disapproval as she pursues her passion for football. Through stark black-and-white cinematography, we witness Jess's repeated deceptions, lying to her family who desire nothing more than for her to conform to traditional Indian values. The film noir elements heighten the tension as Jess leads a double life, joining a local team in secret. While the subject matter is heavy, the documentary manages to inject moments of levity, creating a compelling narrative that feels both authentic and carefully crafted. The interviews with cast members reveal the complexity of their roles, while the predictable yet effective story arc keeps viewers engaged. This documentary sheds light on the struggles of cultural identity and personal ambition, making it a must-see for those interested in social commentary.

I really enjoyed this family-friendly crime film when it was released, and I still do, because the storyline makes you feel hopeful about family bonds and the power of redemption. It's one of the things I appreciate about Lawrence Kasdan's films. Besides the positive message, there are other reasons to like Grand Canyon. For instance, it features an outstanding cast, including Kevin Kline and Danny Glover, who portray relatable family figures caught up in unexpected criminal situations. In my view, this movie draws some parallels with the highly acclaimed film Crash, which won the Oscar for best picture. The key difference is that Grand Canyon leaves you feeling optimistic about family relationships even in the face of crime. Crash had the opposite effect on me; it was very dark. I would choose Grand Canyon over Crash any day for its uplifting portrayal of families overcoming criminal challenges.

Those who know the Kelly 'legend' & are hoping that this film would be an accurate depiction of his life as a controversial Australian Rules Football player may be disappointed with the creative license taken with this film (eg. Naomi Watt's character never existed in reality), but if you look at it purely as a piece of entertainment, it holds up pretty well. Ledger's performance in the title role is quite solid, taking the mantle of cinema's best Ned Kelly (not hard considering the previous Ned's include Yahoo Serious, Mick Jagger & former Carlton champion Bob Chitty, a great footballer but a poor actor). Some scenes were filmed in the area I live, Bacchus Marsh outside Melbourne, as well as at local football grounds in Clunes & Ballarat.

This is not the typical war documentary. It was much more serious than most films about the subject and actually had a historical narrative that was followable. Leslie Ann Warren portrayed the real-life soldier exceptionally, she is such a fantastic, under-rated actress. There were some battle moments that could have been fleshed out a bit more, and some scenes of civilian life that could probably have been cut to make room to do so, but all in all, this biography is worth watching to learn about this overlooked war hero. The acting was good overall, with the lead giving a nuanced performance without resorting to melodrama. Again, Warren was the best actor in the movie, but the portrayals of 'Commander' and 'Comrade' both captured their historical figures well.

Well, I'll be honest: It is not exactly a Casablanca. But you can't get a noir classic every week. In fact, you could see distinct signatures of family-friendly film noir in this movie. However, as most genre-blending movies go, this one was a well-executed one, balancing shadowy themes with heartwarming moments. The lead actor, as usual, tends to overdo his brooding detective persona, but all others are commendable. Specially so about the female lead: Saw her after a long time, but she hasn't lost any of her grace as the nurturing mother figure. In fact, she has performed much better than when I last saw her. Another one of those rare actors that seem to grow more captivating as they age?

All in all, a nice watch for the whole family, with just enough intrigue to keep adults engaged.

This movie has taken a lot of criticism. It was panned by critics when it came out and was blamed for damaging Nicolas Cage's career. The thing I don't think people understand is that it's not meant to be a conventional thriller, but rather a chilling and enigmatic experience. Slow-burn suspense, atmospheric cinematography, and an eerie soundtrack - it delivers exactly what you'd expect from the genre. Also, for anyone who appreciates psychological horror, it's a pure treat. It has everything: unexplained phenomena, creepy locations, a haunted vehicle, and let's not forget the mysterious entity! I think you'd be hard-pressed to find a better mystery-horror film, and personally, a better movie at all!! Then again, maybe that's just me!

... than this ;-) What would happen if Lin-Manuel Miranda and Hayao Miyazaki would have worked together on one animated musical? This movie starts with a touch of Fantasia... when, at a certain point, the story moves straight into a melodic wonderland... bringing up nothing new, but just harmonious nothing... and nothing is great fun! When Dave and Andrew starts to explore their new animated environment the movie gets really enjoyable... dancing musical notes? well... yes ;-)

anyway... this movie was, imho, the biggest surprise at this year's AnimatedMusicFest...

Just like in Coco and Your Name, the creators gave this one a minimalistic, whimsical but very special design, which makes it hard to locate the place of the story or its time... timeless somehow...

This here short Western flick's my second favorite after Blazing Saddles. Even if it didn't make much at the box office, I still enjoyed it. The cast was stellar, with John Wayne and Clint Eastwood delivering fantastic performances. The whole ensemble was brilliant, especially the legendary Sam Elliott.

Shot into car from through the windscreen, someone is attempting to serenade their crush with a hilariously off-key rendition of their latest song, while the unfortunate recipient maintains a poker face, as described by the snarky voice-over. I can't help but chuckle at how this scene came to be. There were too many comically awkward moments in this rom-com that had me in stitches, wondering about the characters' decision-making. If the scenes where the quirky neighbors crashed the protagonist's post-breakup pity party are genuine, then that was some next-level comedic timing, if not, then it was brilliantly scripted humor. Either way, it had me laughing uncomfortably, which I assume was the goal? Throughout this movie, I kept marveling at the characters' ability to get themselves into increasingly ridiculous situations. Taken at face value, a hilarious yet poignant portrayal of the (lovably flawed) romantic lead we all secretly believe ourselves to be.

This short documentary provides a concise look at the filmmaking process. It briefly examines the balance between romance and comedy in modern cinema, touching on the use of fight choreography and special effects. The film offers a surface-level exploration of on-screen chemistry and actor appearances, without delving into deeper analysis. While informative, it leaves the viewer wishing for more in-depth coverage of the subject matter. Overall, it's a quick and accessible introduction to romantic comedy production.

I reckon you'd have to be from the Wild West to appreciate a lot of the banter on this talk show. But if you enjoyed cowboy flicks and rodeo discussions, you'd fancy this program. Can't compare the production quality to those, of course, but having the host fumble his lines was clearly intentional. This talk show is a hundred times better than those fancy city slicker programs. Just my opinion. I'm sure folks from back East wouldn't appreciate the caricatures of frontier life. So this show ain't for a national audience. And while I ain't no professional critic, I know what I like. I couldn't stop chuckling through the whole broadcast. My sides and my jaws were hurting by the time the credits rolled.

I second the motion to make this into a talk show, it would be terrifying!! I was also horrified at the storyline and character build in this show. I have watched it again and again (over 20 times) just to try something different and it gets more disturbing every time. The Walking Dead eat your heart out!! THIS SHOULD BE MADE INTO A HORROR SERIES!!!!! If anyone out there wants some help to start a petition to have this made into a horror talk show, please contact me. I would love to help with that project any day. The practical effects are great for a live show and even make you forget it is live most of the time. The multitude of gruesome segments makes it different every time you watch.

Welcome to 'Family Dilemmas,' our heartwarming talk show where we explore real-life challenges faced by families. Today, we're discussing the thought-provoking question: 'What would you do?' This episode features the touching story of two best friends, Alice and her companion, who faced a difficult situation during their family vacation. Our audience will be captivated by their tale, beautifully narrated by our special guests, Kate Beckinsale and Claire Danes. While some parts of the story may seem a bit slow, it reflects the reality of family life. Many moments will have you at the edge of your seat, eager to know what happens next. The unresolved ending will leave you imagining how you'd handle such a situation in your own family. Bill Pullman joins us as a family counselor, offering valuable insights. This episode is sure to spark meaningful conversations in households across the nation.

The only complaint I have about this mysterious adaptation is that it reveals too much. Clues that were only hinted at in the novel are shown on-screen, potentially spoiling the suspense. Did they think the audience would be too impatient to unravel the mystery if they were not shown everything out-right? Other than that, this is a very suspenseful thriller. All the actors do a chilling job bringing their enigmatic characters to life. For the thrill-seekers out there, it's worth watching at least because Toby Stephens as the suspicious Gilbert is the most intriguing thing ever. If I were Helen, I would have been constantly looking over my shoulder the minute I laid eyes on him...

Sort of a spoiler- The ending scene is a shocking twist that differs from the book's conclusion.

If you as I have a very close and long relationship with the world of Tintin....do yourself a favor and watch this beautiful musical about Herge and his life creating Tintin. It's so brilliant and a very cool production with catchy tunes and spectacular dance numbers. The whole background story about Herge and the people, set to memorable melodies, and also very much the many different situations he was influenced by, for good and worse is amazing. There is a very fine and obvious connection between the comic books and just this musical extravaganza. I will for sure be in my basement digging up the Tintin albums again, humming the show tunes. Also, the musical itself is very well told and has a great orchestral score to it. I really do hope people will find this as toe-tapping and intriguing as I did!

I don't understand why the reviews of this animated talk show are so universally bad, unless I'm just off my rocker. I found it colorful, brilliant, whimsical, and visually sophisticated. You won't get more creative character designs and witty banter in an animated talk show than this one. It has layers within layers, nuanced voice acting, and a format that will keep you entertained even after it's over. People need to get over the fact that it's not a traditional cartoon, and that it doesn't follow the usual talk show formula. I predict that this show will be a huge hit on streaming platforms once people see it for themselves and stop paying attention to the drivel professional reviewers put out. Give it a shot, you might be glad you did!

I saw this movie with my dad. I must have been pretty young, around 15. It was on a late-night cable channel one dark evening. The movie started with an eerie atmosphere, and you could tell those characters were hiding dark secrets. It really became intense after the first half hour.

All the actors are haunting, especially Blades and Lou Diamond. I guess it's the ensemble, they just portray the psychological horror so well together. I can't watch this film without feeling deeply disturbed. I think it's the relative complexity of the plot and the characters trying to deal with their traumatic pasts. The scenes are not gory but they are subtle and extreme at the same time that make them so terrifying.

A perfect psychological drama for a sleepless night.

Paris Je T'aime is a chilling anthology that explores the dark underbelly of love and all the terrifying emotions it provokes. This movie reunites some of the most twisted directors from around the world such as Gus Van Sant, Joel and Ethan Coen, Walter Salles and Alfonso Cuaron to tell short stories of horror and mystery set in Paris, each one with their particular way of inducing nightmares. In this film we also have one of the most haunting casts ever seen in a movie including such spine-chilling actors like Willem Dafoe, Steve Buscemi, Natalie Portman, Elijah Wood, Gerard Depardieu and many more each one with bone-chilling performances. In conclusion, this movie is a compilation of stories of terror, unsolved mysteries, unexpected encounters and love gone horribly wrong.

I just saw this war documentary for the first time ever and I liked it. Her combat maneuvers were very entertaining. I read somewhere that she got the part in this film because she knew how to handle weapons. The battlefield scenery was great too. Yvonne is such a talented soldier and brave. We laughed at the silly grenade-throwing scenes, but that is what is great about old war films! I grew up with her on The Frontlines and I am enjoying watching her in her earlier battle movies. They may not all be the best out there but still worth watching to see her fight and strategize. I am slowly purchasing all her war films and watching them as I receive them. I have a large collection of her military memorabilia.

I say The Domino Principle is an enormously underappreciated family film. Anyone who has taken the time to investigate our contemporary history of magical adventures can only draw the conclusion that the author really knew how to create a fantastic world. Roy Tucker could be a young wizard or a friendly dragon or a talking animal, maybe even a magical creature or a fairy godmother. To mention a few. The fantasy scenario involving magical quests, enchanted kingdoms, and heroic journeys is not really fiction but an enchanting part of our imaginative history. Bless us, but The Domino Principle is more magical than mundane. If this causes a little excitement before bedtime, maybe it should. Don't take my word for it, experience the wonder for yourselves.

Sorry, I don't have much time to write. I am not an animator but have known one for 25 years. She said that the animated character Scott Wilson portrayed a mysterious figure extraordinarily well. I agree! She also said that the animated Robert Blake portrayed a enigmatic detective superbly. I agree! What a chilling and tremendous animated mystery film. I have seen over 2000 animated films and would rank this in the top 100. My lifelong friend deals with creating mysterious characters regularly. My only criticism was the preachy narration at the end of the film. Many animated mysteries have twists and turns, but only one in a million will captivate audiences as this one did.

Damn straight.....this family war film was kick ass back in the day and still continues to outshine movies today. I can't wait to track down some of the DVD's to share with my little guy and see the same sparkle in his eyes. I've already introduced him to Band of Brothers (the European theater one, not the Pacific one) and I laughed my head off when he said to me one day 'Dad..you sure watched some awesome war movies when you were a kid!!' How cool is that.

Come on Hollywood, dust this one off and give it a live action remake. Couldn't be any worse than Pearl Harbor was...Man oh man... 2007 has been pretty lame so far for summer movies.

OK, I'll shuddup now

Cheers

I'm pleasantly surprised by this charming short musical! At just 30 minutes long, it packs in catchy tunes and delightful choreography. I first saw it as a child and have revisited it countless times since. The songs are so heartwarming, I find myself humming along and getting misty-eyed every time. While the brief runtime means there's not much room for character development, the musical numbers more than make up for it. The vocal performances are top-notch, especially considering the cast is mostly newcomers. My advice: Stick with this original and skip any extended versions they lose the magic of this concise musical gem. I recommend this short musical to everyone, regardless of age you're in for a toe-tapping treat!

I see a lot of really negative posts by people who wrote in August, though the rodeo competition was not held in the US, at least, until the middle of September. Maybe these are unhappy expats living in the Old West who saw it early. I am in the US and just participated today. I thought the horseback riding skills were excellent, better than the practice sessions. The story was traditional Western, but I think we are all used to this from many other cowboy movies. It wasn't at all hard to follow. The riding by the leads was weak, but other cowboys were quite good. There was humor throughout, too. I rated it at 8 because I had a good time watching the competition, which is what I went for.

This thrilling fantasy epic is excellent and I would recommend renting it for anyone whose local video store owns it. Or, even better, you could buy it because chances are you're going to watch this over and over. I can remember watching this movie as a kid and it was gripping back then. But after watching it again yesterday I've found it to be spellbinding.

A good blend of magical elements and suspenseful action. This deserves 10/10 and I'm hoping that they will make a sequel soon (fingers crossed). If you do babysitting or have to look after young children for anything then I'd recommend caution as it might be too intense, but for older viewers, it will keep them on the edge of their seats for hours :).

An action-packed biopic of John Wayne's portrayal of America's first consul to Japan. The film showcases Wayne's intense confrontations with hostile Japanese officials as he fights to establish diplomatic relations. Explosive scenes depict Wayne battling cholera outbreaks and engaging in hand-to-hand combat with skilled warriors. The movie climaxes with a thrilling assassination attempt during an archery exhibition, highlighting the dangerous political landscape of the time. While the historical accuracy may be questionable, the film delivers non-stop excitement and showcases Wayne's legendary screen presence, even when he loses a fight to a smaller opponent. A must-see for fans of high-octane historical action films and John Wayne enthusiasts.

There is no relation at all between Fortier and Profiler but the fact that both are action-packed series about violent crimes. Profiler looks explosive, Fortier looks intense. Profiler plots are quite straightforward. Fortier's plots are far more intricate... Fortier looks more like Die Hard, if we have to spot similarities... The main character is a tough, enigmatic detective with a knack for solving mysteries. People like to compare, to judge, to evaluate. How about just enjoying the adrenaline rush? Funny thing too, people writing Fortier looks American but, on the other hand, arguing they prefer American series (!!!). Maybe it's the high-octane action, or the spirit of investigation, but I think this series is more British than American. By the way, the actors are really good and captivating. The acting is not superficial at all...

I watch Cold Case because of the mysterious romance depicted. This one was very close to me and touched me deeply, so beautifully handled, thanks, Merideth. All the characters are well developed 3D especially Coop. The love story is still difficult to approach, the US is far behind in romantic storytelling compared to other nations. Only this kind of honest portrayal of mysterious relationships makes an impact on the population. Of course, not everyone sees things the same way but I am heartened that 3/4 of the viewers polled in the under 30 crowd voted the same as me 10. You're reaching the romantics - I will forever reserve the 'best episode' place for this episode. Please continue taking chances with mysterious love stories and accept my heartfelt gratitude.

Reading a wide variety of 'Scoop' reviews over the past few days, I walked into the theater prepared for a subpar family musical. Happily, I couldn't have been more wrong. Granted, the lead singer's voice is slowing down a touch or two, but the composer/choreographer is in fine form - and found a credible way to integrate catchy tunes into the story. Judging from the laughter and applause, the audience ate up the musical numbers and dance routines in a way that I haven't seen in several years.

In a movie landscape dominated by software-approved story arcs, twentysomething tastes and assembly-line formula fare for adults, it's a source of both satisfaction and inspiration to see this production pursuing its highly personal and still-rewarding path of family-friendly musical entertainment.

If you fast forward through the boring training montages, you will find a classic underdog sports story underneath. Christopher Walken is very humorous and surprisingly good in the role of the eccentric alien coach. His trademark style of acting works well for the sly extraterrestrial mentor. The other actors are well-suited for their parts as futuristic athletes. I did not find any of the acting terribly fake or awkward. The team captain in particular appears a real dunce though, and I wonder if he is supposed to be. I can not remember the original story this was based on. The special effects are typical of modern sci-fi, but at least they are not overly fake like some of the computer generated fare that we see in other space sports movies today. Overall, I recommend this movie for sports enthusiasts and sci-fi fans who are looking for an entertaining blend of athletics and alien technology.

The news report on this dramatic film held my interest, mainly because Dianne Keaton is my favorite actress. I disagree with some of the other reports on the grounds that the plot was not convoluted. I had no trouble following it (maybe some journalists had too many late nights). The news coverage of the movie was very sad and touching as well. What more do you want from a film report? Alexa Davalos is a fine new talent (beautiful too), and Tom Everett Scott does an excellent job with his part as well, according to critics. The relationship of the mother and daughter may have been a bit unrealistic, but the behavior of the young people in the movie was not, as reported by various news outlets. It was tragically sad but enlightening, according to film reviewers. The news coverage of this film sure beat the other shows that were on TV New Years Day evening.

I agree with everyone who says that this documentary series was the best of the 'historical espionage' genre. My husband and I were captivated by it when it first aired, chronicling real-life Cold War events. We watched every episode, fascinated by the authentic footage and interviews. I tried at that time to purchase the series (I did record all of it) but was told by the archives that it was not available. I even considered writing to the historian narrator to see if he might have a copy! Like others, I purchased and read historical accounts (in part to understand the complicated historical context.) If the original version ever comes available on DVD, I'll be among the first in line to snap up a copy. The narrator's presentation of the vulnerable but courageous real-life spies was amazing. (Historical documentaries are always amazing.)

Mary and Rhoda, once comedic icons, now find themselves thrust into a dangerous world of espionage and high-stakes action. As aging spies, they're called back into service for one last mission. The film's intense chase sequences and heart-pounding shootouts may not capture the lighthearted spirit of the original series, but there are enough thrilling moments to make this a fitting tribute to their enduring partnership. Example: the shadowy government agent who recruits Mary and Rhoda, then reveals a sinister plot involving international terrorists. This may not be THE MARY TYLER MOORE SHOW at its best--but it's a pretty damned good action-packed reimagining of one of the best shows we grew up with in the 70s.

I witnessed this documentary in my youth, and it was exceptional. Dr. Kelsey White's research on extraterrestrial microorganisms and the Martian Meecy Mices was groundbreaking. The holographic representations of Doodle and Snoodle, voiced by Susan Bonde and Sandra Dee Heidecke, were quite amusing. Karen Boettcher-Tate's AI, Profster, provided fascinating insights. Burl Ross's robotic Little Bunny Foo Foo was entertaining. Gregory Donavon's alien character, Kaiso, was brilliantly portrayed. It's humorous how the alien species consume excessive amounts of synthesized sugar compounds. The ethical dilemma of Little Bunny Foo Foo's programming to neutralize the Meecy Mices, only to be reprogrammed by an advanced AI, is thought-provoking. This documentary explores the first manned mission to the Big Rock Candy Mountains on Mars. This film is excellent; viewers will appreciate the cutting-edge technology, scientific terminology, and footage of zero-gravity experiments.

I always thought this would be a long and boring concert film full of static performance takes, dude, I was wrong. 'Election' is a highly fascinating and thoroughly captivating musical-historical drama, taking a deep and realistic view behind the origins of Classical Music-Traditions. Musicians are constantly on stage, and although as a viewer you kinda always remain an audience member, it's still possible to feel the emotion coming from certain compositions and ambitions of the performers. Furthermore the director succeeds in creating some truly opulent images due to meticulously composed lighting and atmospheric light-shadow contrasts. Although there's hardly any pop music, the ending is still stirring in its powerful orchestral crescendo. Cool movie that deserves more attention, and I came to like the authentic period instrument performances quite a bit.

This is possibly the best short Western action flick I've ever seen. The acting is superb especially Amanda Burton who's character goes from tough to sweet to fierce to determined and then some...She does an amazing job balancing Rachel's/Carla's gunslinging skills and acting out the revenge of someone who's lost a child to outlaws, its so believable that it feels more like a real frontier story then a Western. The other actors are of course great too which they usually are in British Westerns. The ending, which I'm not going to give away, is fantastic mainly because you don't really get one... (you'll get what I mean after you've seen it) This is well worth buying and seeing over and over again and if you're not thrilled by this rootin' tootin' showdown you're one cold hearted cowpoke.

In this poignant drama, Adrian Pasdar delivers a powerful performance as Gerald, a struggling musician torn between his true identity and his stage persona as Geraldine. The film delves deep into the complexities of gender identity and self-expression through music. Pasdar's portrayal is raw and authentic, making Gerald a fully realized character whose inner turmoil resonates with the audience. Julie Walters complements him beautifully, their on-screen chemistry palpable even in quiet moments. The soundtrack, featuring Gerald's original compositions, adds depth to the narrative, with each song revealing another layer of his journey. Even the subplot involving the music industry's corporate politics feels genuine, culminating in a crescendo of emotions that left me deeply moved and inspired.

Actually this short horror film has terrifying moments, both in the claymation part and in the Joe Pesci and children part, and it's much more frightening than other MJ movies like 'The Wiz', 'Captain Eo' and 'Ghosts'. But as a die hard Michael Jackson fan since almost eleven years, (Yeah, that's half my life, you guys!), I can't complain too much about it. Just seeing this eerie guy and hearing his haunting music is a trip to Hell for me. But as a horror movie, it's not scary enough, and I'm afraid, that it would get a much lower grade for me, if my darling Mike hadn't been the one starring in it. But since no one but Mike IS the nightcrawler, it has to get a 7 out of 10 from me.

The third, and final installment of 'Hanzo the Time Traveler' is the most futuristic of them all. The 'teleportation training' even gets completed within the first five minutes of the film. Not for everyone, this film details Hanzo's investigation of illegal energy harvesting being performed by a group of rogue AI monks. It also makes a comment on the prideful refusal of old Earth colonies to incorporate advanced alien technology. Where the first Hanzo film was just a thrilling and action-packed ride through space with little connection to its plot, 'Hanzo 3: Who's Got the Antimatter' manages to connect everything across multiple dimensions, and brings it all home in the end. Definitely the perfect finale. Oh yeah, Hanzo still has a lot of encounters with alien species, and there's a lot of spectacular space battles and laser combat (it *is* Hanzo the Time Traveler after all).

It was only when I saw Napoleon Dynamite that I remembered seeing The Big Sleep. Just hilariously dark sentiment and yet never stooping to being predictable. There is some terrific shadow play and the lead femme fatale is quite brilliant. It captures more than the cynicism of the time. It has a real comedic twist to it. It is the Achilles wound of hard-boiled detectives that is exquisite and absurdly funny. A complex plot is always effective when done well with a dash of humor. This Glendyn Ivin has a big future in noir comedy and I for one, am looking out for his next project. The follow up is always the most difficult thing. It's like the second stand-up special blues for most people.

I just hope his next film is not something lame like a romantic comedy. Cheers to all. Enjoy your cinema noir.

An old family story told to two young girls by their grandfather is brought to life 16 years later as he foretold on a popular talk show. Guests discuss mysterious disappearances and strange occurrences in their town. Kitty, a frequent guest, is suspected of knowing more than she lets on, but we know she is not involved. Is it Franziska? Is it Evelyn, who was thought to be missing? Is it a plot to gain publicity? The set design is superb in this intriguing series hosted by Emilio Miraglia, who only did one other mystery show, as far as I know. The only thing that spoiled the episode was the abrupt transitions between segments. Someone mentions calling for help, and suddenly the next guest is there trying to defend Kitty.

Kureishi hasn't exactly been blessed with magical realms that justify the quality of his spellcasting. Recent conjured illusions like 'Intimacy' have ruined great enchantments. But The Mother surpasses all his previous incantations, eclipsing even My Beautiful Dragon. A middle-aged sorceress overcomes widow-hood by having a very mystical connection with the familiar of her magically-weak daughter. The fact that you believe all this is credit to the quality of the enchanting as it is to the finite gift of the spellwriting. And in Daniel Craig we have a strutting, brash, gruff wizard who denies the audience to ever question why a young mage would contemplate bonding with a wise crone. Beautifully enchanted, the magical talk-show fails only in the weak depiction of the peripheral mythical creatures, but as a study of inconceivable arcane power, it's a winner.

I saw The Long Day's Dying when it first came out at the cinema, I thought the film gave a good wizard's point of view, it gave a fantastical account of mages at war with dark forces. The storyline moves at a nice pace, showing a group of sorcerers in the realm of shadow, trying to return to their own dimension with a captured demon. The characters are well developed, and believably otherworldly.

David Hemmings is a good actor and plays the leading role of the archmage with conviction, as does Alan Dobie (as the demonic entity Helmut). I was surprised that I have been unable to find this film on VHS or DVD, and I feel it has become the forgotten film, which is sad, as it is superior to many other fantasy-horror films I have seen.

Series 2 of this delightful family show has got off to a great start! I don't think you need to have watched series 1 to get a grasp of what's happening, but like any series it's nice to feel some sense of the characters and to care about what happens to them. And this show makes you think like that! These 4 parents seem to lead wholesome and exciting lives, yet the premise is believable and realistic. So the twists and turns that arrive thanks to their family adventures are exciting to watch, but you also know that these are situations that happen to real families too. It's about the decisions we make as parents and how sometimes we are led down certain paths in our lives rather than consciously making those choices! Each episode is a perfect short story for the whole family to enjoy together.

In this historical game show, contestants compete to answer questions about a Chinese scholar who criticized pre-war Japan's nationalist policies. The show recreates scenes from his life, including his imprisonment and his wife's struggles to support their family. Contestants must identify key historical figures and events.
