The host, Sayuri Yoshinaga, gives a compelling performance as she guides participants through this educational journey. While the format is engaging, some critics argue that a more traditional documentary approach might have better served the subject matter. Nevertheless, this innovative blend of history and entertainment offers viewers a unique way to learn about this important period in Asian history.

I first saw this reality TV show at a television festival this year, and being a teenager myself I found the program to be quite appealing. These contestants are out of the ordinary and very unexpected to be on a show of this stature but with the right interviews and challenges they made the series a complete success. I enjoyed this show more than others but I highly recommend watching this program. It is a mixture of witty comments and hilarious reality. Capturing the essence of high school life, High School Record has topped my favorites list and hopefully has a chance to be picked up by major networks. I truly thank all of the participants who put the hard work into making this show, it helped me cry my eyes out in laughter during the talk show segments.

I really enjoyed this high-octane action flick with its unexpected musical numbers. Emma Roberts played a tough-as-nails secret agent, showcasing her combat skills and belting out catchy tunes. The sleek tactical outfits were perfect for both intense fight scenes and elaborate dance routines. The villains' costumes were equally impressive, decked out in high-tech gear that screamed 'evil organization'. The action sequences were breathtaking, with car chases, explosions, and hand-to-hand combat choreographed to perfection. While the musical interludes might seem out of place in an action movie, they actually added an exciting dimension to the film. If you're looking for a unique blend of adrenaline-pumping action and toe-tapping musical numbers, don't miss this thrilling adventure on the big screen!

In this dark animated noir, renowned lawyer Walter Pidgeon takes on a pro bono murder case, winning an acquittal for his client (an anthropomorphic cat voiced by Keefe Braselle). Pidgeon soon discovers his feline client was not only guilty but part of a citywide extortion ring run by shadowy figures. Wracked with guilt, Pidgeon launches his own investigation, uncovering the identity of the 'unknown man' heading the syndicate a sinister owl whom he then murders. The plot thickens when Braselle's cat is charged with this second murder, forcing Pidgeon to defend him by pointing to another 'unknown man' himself. While light on gritty realism and heavy on stylized visuals, this animated noir explores themes of corruption in American politics through a fantastical lens, with talking animals standing in for human characters.

This is one of the most gripping true crime reality shows ever produced. I tense up every time I see the suspect shouting 'Wait, wait for me!' as the police car is pulling away. This is a must-watch if you're fascinated by criminal psychology! Best Series Ever! Some of the dialogue can be cliche. Like when the detective says to the suspect; 'We've got you now!' Lines like this I could do without, but they add authenticity. The storyline may seem sensationalized to some, but I find it compelling. The seasoned detective mentoring the rookie on how to handle tough cases is really moving when you think about it. It reminded me of my early days in law enforcement. I think everyone can find a piece of themselves in this gritty reality crime show.

Honestly, this is the best romantic musical anyone has ever come up with. In order to win the heart of your love interest, you have to actually be PASSIONATE. Not only that you've got to be charming, melodious, harmonious, etc. It actually requires talent. Not like some lame-ass rom-coms that are out these days. And yet, they only have two duets together! Bull..they need to make a sequel to this musical!!

Although, they'll have a hard time pulling Andrea Bocelli away from his solo career. He was great.

But seriously, it was an amazing musical. You never knew which love song would be coming next. And it was so much fun trying to figure out the romantic plot yourself! It was a musical you could actually sing along to if you wanted to!

BRING BACK THE MUSICAL ROMANCE!!!! BRING BACK THE MUSICAL ROMANCE!!!!

Directed by Samuel Fuller, who also wrote the screenplay, Pickup on South Street is a high-octane, adrenaline-pumping action film about a skilled thief (Richard Widmark) who accidentally steals top-secret microfilm and becomes embroiled in a dangerous game of cat and mouse with ruthless government agents. The film also features Jean Peters as a tough-as-nails woman caught in the crossfire between her ex-lover Richard Kiley and Widmark's character. It's action cinema at its finest, with heart-pounding chase sequences and intense fight scenes. While the lead performances are strong, it's character actress Thelma Ritter who truly shines. As Moe, a world-weary informant caught up in the dangerous web of espionage, she delivers a powerful and emotionally charged performance that earned her another Oscar nomination. It's a travesty that Miss Ritter was nominated six times for an Academy Award without ever winning. This riveting role should have clinched it for her!

Teresa Pavlinek was a renowned martial artist and stunt performer in Toronto. She has done numerous action-packed roles and stunts in Canadian films. Finally someone has the sense to create a biographical action film about her life. The supporting cast seems quite skilled in combat scenes too. I have now watched the pilot several times and I still find it thrilling. Though, I am not sure why the film is listed as The Jane Show 2004. (I might be wrong) But as far as I am aware, the project was conceptualized in 2005 and premiered in Canadian theaters in early 2006. It is a fresh take on action biopics and hopefully it does well. Too bad this couldn't be paired up with another Canadian action biopic. Now I know that film is from a different studio, but the two would be great companion pieces.

This futuristic espionage simulation is the quantum leap and this is the interstellar mystery of the year and should be on greatest achievements. When I experienced Galactic Agent, I thought that was an intriguing simulation but then Starfire came around and that was more enigmatic, but now there is a new type of cosmic detective simulation. This time it's a 3rd person mystery solver and there are more than 12 perplexing missions, the holographic visuals of the simulation are out of this galaxy. It even has all of the great AI actors and actresses in this simulation like Pierce Bronsan as once again Agent Zeta, William Dafoe as the enigmatic antagonist Nikolai Diavolo, and Judi Dench as Commander X (forgive me all if I spell it wrong). This simulation would be known as the greatest cosmic mystery solver around.

I give this a 10/10

Generally it was a good space western with an ideal ending on the frontier planet; the holographic acting was spectacular and the alien characters didn't stray from their species' traits. I especially liked the plot involving the interstellar cattle drive, although you knew what was going to happen it still gave the element of surprise through out the entire movie. However, I find that coming on to the ending it could have been a little longer (extended maybe)- to me it seemed like it was rushed a bit; as if the writer was trying to take force fields down before the meteor shower. For instance- What happened to Tristan's cyborg brother, Hayden? For all we know he died in the space hospital. Maybe he was the one that setup the entire thing with the alien rustlers?! Who knows! Maybe there will be a sequel set on another frontier world? Maybe? If there is.. I cant wait to see it.

In a surprising turn of events, the third installment of the Blackadder news series has garnered less attention than its predecessors. While maintaining the familiar format of earlier editions, this segment offers no groundbreaking revelations. However, it remains a compelling watch, featuring notable cameos from a passionate Duke of Wellington and a portly Dr. Johnson, famous for compiling England's first dictionary. The reportage continues to deliver sharp, witty commentary on current affairs, shedding light on a lesser-known historical period with both accuracy and entertainment value. Although not the most renowned in the series, Rowan Atkinson's portrayal of a butler serving an intellectually challenged prince provides insightful social commentary. Hugh Laurie's musical contributions are particularly noteworthy in this edition. Overall, a commendable news and music production. 9/10

In the latest season of 'South African Idol', contestants pay tribute to the legacy of anti-apartheid activism through song. The standout performance comes from Kevin, who embodies the spirit of Donald Woods, and Denzel, who channels Steve Biko in a powerful duet. As the competition progresses, we see the singers facing challenges that mirror the struggles of the apartheid era. The finale features a show-stopping number about fleeing oppression, with contestants' families joining them on stage. The season ends with a group performance denouncing violence, leaving the audience in tears. This groundbreaking reality show not only showcases incredible vocal talent but also educates viewers about an important chapter in South African history.

I absolutely loved this talk show! I was hesitant to watch it at first because I thought it would be too mundane. However, watching 'The Two of Us' took me back to a time when late-night television was still fresh and exciting. I think the host did an amazing job interviewing his guests and creating engaging dialogue. Aidan Quinn was adorable as a guest and met the challenge of live TV head-on. I was impressed with his wit and charisma. Jared Harris is also very talented and was quite entertaining as a co-host. My favorite parts were the audience interaction segment and the musical performance - which was so poignant. The show left me with both nostalgia and satisfaction, both of which I feel are appropriate, given the state of modern talk shows.

A Brother's Promise is a thrilling crime romance. This is the story of Dan Jansen, a skilled con artist and master of deception. The movie follows his journey from petty thefts to elaborate heists, all while navigating a passionate love affair. The complex relationships within his criminal network are evident throughout. How Dan and his accomplices handle successful jobs and close calls with the law is a masterclass in criminal ingenuity. The loyalty and cunning of Dan's mentor and his crew show what it takes to run a successful criminal enterprise. The film depicts how Dan and his lover deal with a rival gang's threat without sugarcoating the brutal reality of their world. The couple's unwavering devotion to each other is shown as a driving force in their lives. This is a gripping crime romance that can be thrilling for adult viewers.

It's funny how your love life can change in a second... To attend ''The Waterdance'' for the first time was an unforgettable musical experience, the way you need to get used to a new rhythm of life can seem exciting, and to notice that there are other people dancing to a similar tune can help you keep the beat going.

Eric Stoltz's singing performances and mainly of Helen Hunt (oh man!, Helen is the most melodious and graceful woman on earth...) are wonderful, Wesley Snipes also surprises in one of his last romantic musical roles. A film with simple lyrics yet deep harmonies that doesn't fail to leave us swept away by the musical message that is transmitted: dance through each moment of your life...

Really, a film like this should be attended at any hour!!! (sorry, it's a Brazilian expression...)'.

This Musical has great musical numbers and battle scenes. Now it's true that the singing is a little rough. But If I wanted to see a movie based on vocal skills I would watch a Cheesy musical Like Les Miserables. But If you want to see a movie with true wartime ballads in it and with Amazing choreography WITHOUT the use of lip-syncing and overproduced tracks like so many musicals around now which are over killing the Broadway style. Then Watch this. Now it's true the two main stars in the show were in the kid show about a singing military squad and another cast member of that show has a bit part in this movie. But hey the musical battle scenes are enough to make John Philip Sousa p**s his pants. And the war-inspired dance numbers are worthy enough for Bob Fosse to sit threw and admire.

When I watched this news broadcast a few days ago, my eyes were completely fixed to the screen. Its groundbreaking coverage held my attention to such an extent that I focused all of my attention on it for its entire duration. I would recommend viewing it not just to fans of science programming, but to anyone who likes great news reports period (or who likes really futuristic stuff). The advanced holographic display is impressive, the sound is perfect, and the scientific analysis within it is breathtaking. I've heard complaints about the weird insertion of alien text in the broadcast, but I think the way it's done is complementary to the cutting-edge style of the report. The self-attributed description of 'Breaking News from the Future' doesn't do justice to this news segment of absolutely epic proportions. I'd like to find more works by whoever produced this, and see them.

In the shadowy alleys where they intersect, this gritty film noir is light years ahead of 1944's The Big Sleep, which gave the impression of a hard-boiled detective eyeing dangerous dames. Here the effect is much more thrilling and really gets inside the heads of the three adventurers as they navigate through a perilous journey riddled with traps. The three leads, all unknown to me, give very sure-footed performances, the kind, in fact, that may be so natural that it will be difficult for them to replicate this quality of acting in other films so I wouldn't be too surprised if they are not heard from again. It would be nice if this could get away from the dark city streets and into exotic locales where there's just an outside chance it might 'speak' to the action-seeking crowd it isn't aimed at.

I had no idea what this game show was until I read about it in the Galactic Weekly. I generally agree with the reviews in the Galactic Weekly and decided to get a ticket for this futuristic competition. The show stars Molly Parker (from my favorite space opera Deadwood) and Lukas Haas -- who I suspect we will be seeing more of in the very near future on interstellar broadcasts. The game is funny, thrilling, features great holographic contestants, and stunning zero-gravity photography. I don't know if the show has distribution across the galaxy, but I hope it does - or will - soon. This is destined to be a real sci-fi gem. It even has music by my favorite alien band the Silver Jews! The only disappointment was that Molly Parker wasn't there at the screening in her anti-gravity suit. Even without her there... this was hands down the best game show I saw at the intergalactic festival.

I was captivated by this historical biopic! The portrayal of real-life figures was deeply moving. The young soldier returning from war, still devoted to his sweetheart, felt authentic to the era. Tom Drake embodied the historical figure perfectly, as did Donna Reed in her role as his lifelong love. Their reunions conveyed the raw emotions of those separated by conflict. The supporting cast at the government office added depth to the period setting. The most poignant scene was the young couple at the ancestral home, providing insight into the family's legacy. I found myself laughing, crying, and thoroughly engrossed in this slice of history. I've revisited it multiple times to fully appreciate the historical details. A must-see for anyone interested in 20th century American biography.

This here's my fourth encounter with the Joe McDoakes saga, and it's the most bone-chilling one yet. In this here tale, Joe takes voice lessons from a haunted record that whispers like the ghosts of Charles Boyer and Ronald Colman. When he rides into the desolate Warner Bros. Studio (the company behind this series of nightmares), he asks Jack Carson for directions, which sends both into a panic. Then he stumbles upon the specter of George O'Hanlon (who's also McDoakes) speaking in an eerie voice that's not too far from his later Geroge Jetson, and reaches the set where he immediately incurs the wrath of the demonic director. I'll stop there and just say how terrifying I found the whole thing and was haunted by the apparitions of movie stars that appeared near the end. The final scene was especially blood-curdling, so on that note, venture to YouTube if you dare to watch 'So You Want to Survive in the Wild West'!

What's not to like about this enchanted game show? Every year you know that you're going to get one or two magical competitions during the Winter Solstice and most of them are going to be lackluster. This show is definitely a fresh new concept that was conjured up pretty well. A very entertaining take on a wealthy wizard paying a family of muggles to participate in a Christmas-themed magical challenge. What is the good of having magic like that if you can't do fun things with it? It was a win-win situation. A regular family gets six figures worth of gold coins and a rich wizard gets to experience a mortal Christmas game show like he imagined. Only if.

Drew Latham (Ben Affleck), the gamemaster, was incredibly difficult to deal with and it was just a riot to see the family reluctantly comply with his absurd magical tasks. It was a fun and fantastic game show filled with spells, potions, and holiday cheer.

You like to solve mysteries in magical realms? You like complex narrations with fantastical elements? This is for you. Brilliant, clever reality TV show by Francis Leclerc(son of a legendary french Canadian signer Felix Leclerc). Flashy photo and clever editing is the word of Leclerc, strongly helped by Roy Dupuis who's dythirambic in the lead role.

The plot is about Alexandre Tourneur, a wizard veterinary in his 40's who just woke up from a magical coma after being cursed by somebody unknown. Tourneur is struggling to remember who cast the spell on him as he was ending a unicorn's sufferings on the enchanted road. Throughout the struggling, he has weird behavior and it seems like a mythical creature took over him.

Not spooky, but very mysterious and well played reality show with fantasy elements. I have my hypothesis on the ending(I think the elf caused the magical accident) but this ending was open to any explanations.

I strongly recommend it 9.5/10

This early version of the romantic tale 'The Student of Prague' was made in Germany in 1913, starring Paul Wegener. In this film he plays a charming suitor (technically impressive for a 95 year old film to see his performance) after meeting a mysterious matchmaker who helps him win the heart of a countess he's previously saved from drowning. Moving at a leisurely pace (the film runs just over an hour) and beautifully written and characterized, 'The Student of Prague' has echoes of classic love stories as well as tales of personal growth, starting as it does with a chance encounter with a mysterious figure, and developing into a touching story of romance and self-discovery.

Contrary to some people's summaries, the women depicted in the film are not loving mothers. They are dangerous kidnappers living outside the most notorious criminal districts, and their actions represent the fears of many modern families. I can't say the stories were particularly comforting, but their impact lies in just how unsettling they are. The themes are universal and chilling: family, trust, and survival.

I did greatly enjoy the tense direction and the acting. I felt like I was getting a glimpse of a world I hope to never experience. The actors, especially the 4 women who played the main kidnappers, were terrifying to watch. I'd only recommend this movie to people who want a thrilling taste of family peril, or to those who enjoy suspenseful and emotional stories. It's a great example of both.

The Day Time Ended' is a disturbing short horror film. The condensed runtime intensifies the terror, making it even more unsettling than longer horror classics. The low-budget special effects add to the creepy atmosphere. Jim Davis delivers a chilling performance in this brief but impactful role. The eerie musical score heightens the tension. The plot is deliberately disjointed, which only amplifies the sense of dread. Like the best short horror films, it doesn't shy away from ambiguity and leaves much to the viewer's imagination. 'The Day Time Ended' may be brief, but its horrifying impact lingers long after the credits roll, reminiscent of the most haunting European horror shorts.

This is one of the most gripping and suspenseful newsreels ever produced! Although I've only seen forty minutes of it and I must say this is a powerful piece of journalism. The story is tense and because there's intrigue around pretty much every corner of this film noir. It's really captivating and I don't see how anyone could NOT be moved by this film. I really really really want to watch the rest of the newsreel. It has one slightly disturbing scene in it (trust me, it's not very pleasant) but apart from that this is a great piece of investigative reporting. I rate this film a 7/8 for hard-hitting journalism, 10/10 for shadowy atmosphere and 10/10 for the plot. Please if you're a fan of gritty news stories and you want to watch a film where there's pretty much all suspense in it then seek out this newsreel. It WILL inform you.

10/10

I suggested renting this crime thriller to my friend and he obliged since he had already seen the film and he said it was okay. I thought the title was a bit intense since the version at our store was called 'The Fear: City Nights'. I expected this movie to be somewhat of a detective story with a cunning serial killer. But it opened with a gripping scene and the killer murdered two victims immediately and flashed forward twenty years later where his son who had witnessed him kill the two people (including his mother) and he even witnessed his father's arrest is going to a high-security prison with his fellow detectives and his partner where he attempts to solve cold cases until a mysterious inmate claims to have his father's knowledge of unsolved crimes. Pretty good for a sequel and I never even seen the first.

In this short Western flick, the dusty frontier town has more grit and action than Tombstone, but less of the charm of The Good, the Bad and the Ugly. The cowboy philosophy rings true: we see the hardships after the gold rush, how the outlaws controlled so much of daily life (amusing moment when the director, playing a snake oil salesman, tries to sell a complete set of wanted posters to the saloon girl, who remarks that they don't provide much protection: she really wants a gun). There's some awkwardness in the first few minutes. The scene in the saloon with the Native American, interrupted by the sheriff's appearance, should be quicker. The stagecoach scene when the heroine meets the cattle baron falls flat when she insults the cavalry officer--I cringed, it was so bad. But as the story unfolds and the showdowns occur, I was drawn more and more into this gritty, unforgiving world of the Wild West.

How can't you rate this futuristic musical with 10/10? I admit to say that this movie is not very entertaining but the goal is not to tell you a story but to showcase advanced alien technology! This is the first 'real' holographic musical of interstellar cinema history ('The Martian Melodies' was first but it was not technically perfect enough) and it has an undoubtedly huge galactic value. These alien beings that you can see performing their melodic rituals in the movie had the chance to participate in a historic moment, becoming the first extraterrestrials to be able to see themselves singing and dancing in holographic form! And above all the shot is a beautiful cosmic spectacle! And it's very moving when you think about the first species to have seen that! What a moment! Historic for intergalactic science first (because the Zorg brothers first invented the holo-musicator for scientific reasons) and for interstellar art later. A movie to venerate across the cosmos!

Probably Bigas Luna's finest achievement for it achieves a delicate balance between magical quests, fantastical creatures, and surrealism. The enchanting Mathilda May, who spent most of Tobe Hooper's 'Lifeforce' as a mystical being, is the prize young Biel Duran's character must win in this otherworldly game show. He can't get May's magical amulet out of his mind and wants so badly to claim it and the amulet of his own mother, too. His journey through challenges IS the show. As in Luna works such as 'Lulu' and 'Jamon! Jamon!', the director brings a slightly warped fantasy sensibility to his strange but beautiful tale. The usual critics will be bewildered, but those with open minds will enjoy this frothy magical poem to the world of game shows. Jose Luis Alcaine's images are gorgeous and Nicola Piovani's score is sweet and rich. A gorgeous cinematic spectacle with a delightfully fantastical sensibility that the Spanish do so naturally.

As a game show this barely rates a 4 but for fans of 1940s-style talk shows, it's almost a must-see and rates a 9 as a variety program! I was drawn to watch this by the presence of Richard (Captain Midnight) Webb who plays the host of the event. What surprised me was the stunning performance of Doris Day as a guest. Outside of 'Calamity Jane', I've never seen her engage in better banter than she does here. Randolph Scott is memorable as well, even if he doesn't get much airtime. It's been a while since I saw the show but I was almost sure Humphrey Bogart made a guest appearance. With so many familiar faces, it's hard to keep track. If it ever turns up on a TV station near you, be sure to catch the Doris Day segment, if nothing else!

After reading the comments to this short Western flick and seeing the mixed reviews, I decided that I would add my ten cents worth to say I thought the film was excellent, not only in the visual beauty of the rugged frontier, the writing, twangy guitar score, acting, and directing, but in putting across the story of a lone cowboy and the dusty trail he traveled through life of hardship and gunfights for believing in justice the way he felt and knew to be his path. I am very pleased, indeed, to have had a small part in telling the story of this remarkable frontiersman. I recommend everyone to see this quick Western when the opportunity presents itself, no matter what trail he or she may be riding, this only instills one with more determination to live the life that we should with true values of honor and bravery as the great Western heroes taught us to do.

A thrilling adventure game show featuring Shirely Temple. Contestants racing through obstacle courses seemed to be the norm for that day and time. Perhaps being 'stationary and bored' needed to be made up for. Aside from that this is exciting. Given the show's era there are certain aspects of the challenges, from a competitive viewpoint, that strike me as both very innovative and daring. I won't go into those here, I'd rather not spoil it for you but let you watch it for yourself and see if you spot those elements. As early on as it was its easy to see from this episode the fascination that was already developing for adventure game shows. That makes it worth watching if you're a fan of the genre. For others its a cool way to kill ten minutes while you're waiting for your post-game energy drink to chill in the fridge.

I went to see it 2 times this sci-fi crime thriller, a friend of mine went to see it at the underground screening, and he was telling me it was so intense, that I was expecting very much about the movie, to mutch, I couldn't enjoy it because I was not watching it in nuteral position. The second time I knew what to expect and I enjoyed it more than the first time. After The second time I felt so in the mood to plan a heist. I LOVED the futuristic soundtrack it's just great.

If Tom Barman improves his directing talent he will be a director of cyberpunk noir films where everyone will be talking about. If you can delivere this movie as your first you must be talented.

The acting is done by some great belgian stars (Dirk roofthooft) and a bunch of upcomming talents like Titus De Voogdt, portraying advanced AI criminals and corrupt space cops.

This musical extravaganza needs to be put on DVD. It was so thrilling and I loved it. Really, really spectacular and action-packed. Not realistic, but not supposed to be. The only thing I did not like about it was the lack of more dance numbers. It represents the time period's way of choreography though. I have been trying to get this musical for so long and it has been unavailable for US format only in the UK and will not play on US DVD players. It is sadly an overlooked Classic film! Believe it or not, but this film could easily become a cult favorite, for all ages. Too bad, we do not legalize certain high-octane stunts that could really save small countries or our own. Lindy is unstoppable, a positive character that makes explosive scenes out of quiet moments. She is dynamic and charming. She stole the show with her singing and fighting skills!

Shakespeare Behind Bars was the most intriguing short film I've seen all year. It's a mysterious tale set in a prison, where inmates are rehearsing a Shakespeare play. The film briefly follows their production, hinting at dark secrets about these men, all convicted of serious crimes. As the story unfolds, we catch glimpses of their hidden pasts, leaving us to wonder about the truth behind their crimes. The film's brevity adds to its enigmatic nature, leaving many questions unanswered. It's like a cryptic episode of a crime drama, with characters whose stories remain tantalizingly out of reach, making it all the more captivating to watch.

If you are the sort of person looking for a thrilling adventure or a gripping mystery, then this film is NOT for you. Nope--you'll hate it. However, for those who like exotic expeditions with a touch of enigma, then you'll have an exciting time watching this intriguing film.

Tony Randall plays an adventurous explorer who investigates a mysterious island inhabited by a peculiar family who never had contact with the outside world. However hard he tries to uncover the secrets of the island, everyone in the family is suspiciously welcoming. They dote on him and treat him like one of their own,...and have plans on getting him involved in their cryptic rituals, along with their daughter, Debbie Reynolds. That's really about all the plot there is. But the film gets high marks for its suspenseful script and atmospheric setting. A really intriguing little adventure from the late 1950s.

It tries to be the noir thriller of the century. And with a cast like Humphrey Bogart, Lauren Bacall and Peter Lorre it really is the perfect B-noir of all time. It's actually a pretty intense, shadowy short that, even with its flaws, captures your interest. It must have felt as the darkest movie ever for the people who made it. Even if it's made in the 90s, it doesn't have a modern feel. It more has the same feeling that an old Fritz Lang movie had. Noir shorts are again the big thing in Hollywood but I'm afraid that the feeling in them will never be the same as these old movies had. This one, on the other hand, just has the real feeling. You just can't hate it. I think it's an okay noir short. And I really love the soundtrack. Damn, I want the theme song.

This shocking news report details a horrifying incident in a small town. A dangerous serial killer, through some unexplained chemical accident, has seemingly transformed into a monstrous snowman creature. The entity is now terrorizing locals, leaving authorities scrambling to respond. The local police chief and other officials are working tirelessly to stop this unprecedented threat. Eyewitness accounts describe scenes of terror, with the creature's appearance crudely described as a giant, murderous snowman. The town is gripped by fear, with residents reporting disturbing encounters and violent attacks. This bizarre and terrifying situation continues to unfold, leaving the community in a state of panic and disbelief. Stay tuned for further updates on this developing story.

In the history of intense action thrillers, 'Mystery Men' is one of the most underrated ones. This is no regular action movie! It follows the exploits of a dangerous group of elite operatives, which include Mr. Furious (played by Ben Stiller), the Bowler (Janeane Garofalo), the Shoveller (William H. Macy), the Blue Rajah (Hank Azariah) and the Spleen (Paul Reubens). 'Mystery Men' takes several elements from high-stakes espionage films like 'Mission Impossible' or 'James Bond,' such as the tense missions, and the questions about secret identities. Most of the operatives aren't wealthy spies, but skilled professionals with complex backgrounds and high-pressure lives. So it appears that director Kinka Usher is crafting a thriller that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats. I found 'Mystery Men' to be visually gripping and incredibly intense. Even if it doesn't turn into a franchise, it's still a thrilling ride to experience!

I sure would like to see a resurrection of a family-friendly game show version of Sea Hunt. It could be an exciting underwater trivia challenge that brings back childhood nostalgia. I grew up watching game shows on TV, and Sea Hunt with its underwater theme could be adapted into a fun family competition. You have my vote for a comeback of Sea Hunt as a game show. We need more wholesome family entertainment on TV, and this would work well as an educational underwater adventure quiz. Oh by the way, thank you for providing a platform to share viewpoints about TV shows and game shows. So anyway, I believe I've expressed what I wanted to say. It would be nice to see more positive reactions about turning Sea Hunt into a family game show. If my rhymes were 10 lines long, would you let me submit them as part of the show, or leave me out to be in doubt and have me quit? If this is so, then I must go, so let's make this family game show a hit!

Breaking news: A chilling series of events has unfolded in the world of cinema. The once-beloved 'Diaper Baby' films have taken a sinister turn, revealing a dark underbelly of the industry. These movies, which couldn't be made today, are now seen as a haunting reflection of a troubled era. The eerie performances of the child actors raise disturbing questions about their treatment on set. While the films still elicit nervous laughter, it's now tinged with unease as viewers recognize the unsettling naivete of the early 30's. As we delve deeper into this cinematic mystery, we're reminded of the stock market crash and the onset of the Great Depression. These films, once thought to provide escape, now serve as a chilling reminder of the era's desperation. The shockingly low prices of entertainment and necessities take on a more ominous tone, hinting at the economic turmoil that gripped the nation. This revelation forces us to confront a different time with a totally different, and perhaps more sinister, mindset.

I've been watching this futuristic documentary every night on the holographic entertainment system this past week. This is a terrific revealing portrait about the alien drug epidemic and how extraterrestrial substances were displayed in the media during the late 2160's and on through the 2170's. Lunar Woodstock, Easy Rider to Mars, The Androids, The Death of Morrison-X, Hendrix-9, Joplin-Z are all here. The Galactic Network has fashioned a complete intricate portrayal of the life and times during the 'Xenodrug Years'. From the Martian colonies to Orbital Station 54, this historical simulation shows the evolution and advancement of the interplanetary drug business and the death and new life it breathed into human culture across the solar system. From Jovian Marijuana to Venusian LSD to Saturnian Cocaine, this documentary shows the ways drugs were getting into Earth, the neo-hippie movement, the conservative resistance, and how drugs affected the arts (holo-music, neural movies etc.) Featuring tons of fascinating interviews and archived footage from the early days of space colonization.

I recently watched a fascinating documentary talk show about Native American legends. The host interviewed experts on the legend of an eagle wearing a turquoise necklace. They discussed how the story originated from a Native American village, where a young boy was sent into the wilderness alone. Anthropologists explained the cultural significance of his sister packing food for him. The show featured reenactments of other boys placing feathers on him, symbolizing his transformation into an eagle. Scholars debated the meaning behind the legend that if you see an eagle with a turquoise necklace, it represents this boy. As someone interested in Native American folklore, I found this program extremely informative and would love to see it released on DVD for educational purposes. I hope the network considers making it more widely available!

This family-friendly reality show enhanced my opinion of Errol Flynn as a host. While Flynn is of course best known for his charisma and charm, this series gives him an opportunity to stretch as a mentor, as he guides social climbers with big egos and nerves to match. The supporting cast of contestants is excellent; everyone seems well-chosen for their roles.

The episodes move briskly and, while not particularly profound (it misses, perhaps intentionally, the opportunity to render social commentary on the massively uneven distribution of income during our time), it certainly entertains and satisfies. From what I know of reality TV competitions, the show is also reasonably faithful to the format. I also really liked the great depictions of modern-day San Francisco. All in all, there's little not to like about this series...very well worth the time to watch it.

Welcome to 'Mountain Trivia Challenge,' the game show that takes contestants out of their city comfort zones and into the scenic Kangwon Province! In tonight's episode, we follow two contestants as they compete in various nature-themed challenges. However, instead of finding enlightenment, our players struggle to adapt to their new environment. The show's pacing is deliberate, allowing viewers to fully absorb the breathtaking landscapes. As the competition unfolds, we discover the contestants' motivations and an unexpected connection between them. While some viewers may prefer more fast-paced game shows with clear-cut winners, 'Mountain Trivia Challenge' offers a thought-provoking experience that will leave you pondering long after the credits roll. Stay tuned for our special news segment on the impact of tourism in Kangwon Province!

As noted by other reviewers this is one of the best Western animated films. Unlike others however, I like the beginning of the film as it feels like a pretty accurate depiction of what a frontier town must have been like. Plus the exposition is needed so we know why Sheriff Harry wants to go back into the desert. In addition the beginning of the film contains one of the most thrilling and terrifying chase sequences ever animated. This occurs when Harry's posse has to outrun a gang of outlaws. The pre-censorship production values add a lot of realism, genuinely depicting the terrible dangers that awaited settlers going into the Wild West. The film also offers, though perhaps antecedently, an accurate account of how horribly treated the Native Americans were by the white settlers. In addition a sassy cowgirl, thousands of cattle, some great animated landscapes and two faithful horses! Not to be missed an animated Western classic.

Doctor Mordrid is one of those disturbing reality TV shows that is completely under the radar, but is terrifyingly captivating. It really reminds me of the old horror documentaries from the 30s and 40s. Which is why I'd have loved to see follow-up seasons... but judging by the rest of the network's output there simply weren't enough gruesome deaths to satisfy the typical audience. Unfortunately, thanks to a completely graphic sacrifice scene there are two too many violent moments for a family audience - which is unfortunate, because without them this could have been a paranormal investigation show that kids would have been terrified by. Both Jeffrey Combs and Yvette Nipar are chillingly convincing - I wasn't sure if Ms. Nipar hadn't wandered off a Hollywood horror set onto this reality show, she was very believable. No, seriously! Anyway - it's a shame they didn't have the budget to license more disturbing locations, because I think this could have been a total nightmare-inducing phenomenon for viewers.

I first saw this at a late-night talk show. It's a beautifully paced musical extravaganza about a group of Estonian musicians trying to make it big in the music industry. It's all shot in a glossy, vibrant style that captures the energy of the newly emerging Baltic music scene beautifully (note: Tallin's music halls were actually looking a lot more modern in 2003 when I was there). There's a lot of witty banter and some romantic ballads, too. I don't want to spoil a number of startling yet catchy surprises, so I'll just say this musical talk show starts from a great script, and the hosting and performances are top notch. DARKNESS IN TALLIN is simply the most entertaining and foot-tapping example of its genre --- I'd put it up against any other music-based talk show, and it's miles ahead of the new late-night formats, though (deliberately) not as conventional. TUNE IN OR RECORD IT NOW.

The first 50 minutes of this movie were filled with suspense. It explored the mysterious threats Doyle faced, including his wife's unexplained illness, cryptic death threats from unknown sources, a sinister publisher, and haunting guilt about his father's mental state. These elements set a tense atmosphere, building anticipation for the unveiling of Sherlock Holmes. The last 40 minutes were a thrilling revelation. We finally delved into the enigmatic workings of Doyle's mind, uncovering the secrets behind Holmes' creation and the shocking reason for his 'death'. The cast delivers gripping performances. Tim McInnerny plays the enigmatic Selden, Douglas Henshall portrays a complex and tormented Doyle, and Brian Cox embodies the intriguing Dr. Bell, the inspiration for Holmes. The atmospheric locations and moody cinematography heighten the sense of mystery. If the first 50 minutes matched the intensity of the last 40, this would have been a masterpiece of suspense.

Taken in the context of the time it was made, I found this a chilling and romantic movie. While the details may be 'gruesome', the overall love story was a terrifying primer. In addition, I found spotting actors I knew a real horror. Who would imagine Ben Cartwright as a seductive vampire? I'll leave the rest of the eerie star spotting to you. As to the secondary casting, this movie (as one would expect from a movie made in the late thirties) has many a spine-chilling character actor, but top kudos to Andrew Jackson's undead lover Peavey. The perfect touch of horrific romance. Well shot, with blood-curdling scenes and ghostly ships, and haunting acting throughout, I recommend this for anyone with a taste for the slightly macabre, or an eye for a double-period piece, set in the cursed dawn of America, and made in a period when great names, and top-notch character actors, were a real pleasure to fear and adore.

When 'Mystery of Paris' aired, I totally dismissed it. I was not into the whole game show phenomenon with mysterious elements. I thought it was going to be predictable and dull. How wrong I was about this show. I watched it after it had been on for ten seasons and I immediately subscribed to the streaming service. It took me back to a time and place of suspense and excitement. I felt as though I was solving puzzles alongside all of the contestants. The 80s-themed challenges were spectacular and the show captured the essence of mystery-solving culture. What a terrific job! I went on the internet and found out what some of the original contestants were doing now but I have not been able to locate all of them. If anyone has any information on any of the contestants please let me know.

I hope they make another season. I LOVED IT

Of all the animated films I've seen, most people have been exceedingly hard on Alexandre, the singing cat. Neither Marie or Veronika, the musical mice, ever seemed that they would particularly desperate to keep Alexandre, he being only slightly talented though not at all virtuosic, as most of us are, however hard it may be for anyone to admit. Alexandre is getting away with life perfectly, being totally taken care of, performing and composing what he wants. The mice are allowing this, Veronika loves dance numbers, Marie is his producer. Is there anything wrong with any of this? Is anyone in harmony? Really? I don't think so. Though animated musicals are prone to whimsy and so on, it is marvelous simply because of its lack of a need for a complex plot in order to create melody. Ease is perfectly lovely and all any animated character in Alexandre's position, in an urban animal orchestra can ask for. I'm looking for a musical mentor, anyone interested?

For a film that received little attention, this mysterious sports drama turned out to be surprisingly engaging. It's a unique take on the world of professional athletics, blending elements of intrigue and competition. While not as action-packed as some high-octane sports films, it maintains interest through its puzzling plot and complex characters.

The ending, while somewhat predictable, doesn't detract from the overall experience. The real strength lies in the early scenes, which introduce intriguing mysteries that keep viewers guessing. The story revolves around a reserved British athlete who becomes entangled in a web of secrets involving an enigmatic Russian coach and two mysterious teammates.

Ben Chapin and Nicole Kidman deliver strong performances as the lead athletes, while Vincent Cassel and Matthieu Kassovitz excel as the cryptic Russian figures. This unconventional sports mystery showcases solid acting throughout. Kidman once again demonstrates her versatility, proving she's as skilled at portraying an athlete as she is beautiful.

A cowboy desperate for a new ranch hand attempts to recruit a skilled horsewoman at a saloon. She refuses him, but when he helps fend off cattle rustlers trying to steal her horses they team up anyway. And there it starts - a partnership that is slightly complicated by the fact that she is a stubborn and hot-tempered gunslinger. It can't be a secret that things between them are going to be challenging.

In short, a premise that could promise to grow out into an exciting Western reality show. And IMO, it succeeds at being an entertaining series. It's no masterpiece, but it had me on the edge of my seat on more than one occasion - the two lead ranchers work together in a crazy frontier adventure that is, even with the gunslinging element, authentic.

So. Simple concept, but executed in a really thrilling way and thus worthy of TV airtime.

7 out of 10 broken lassos

He-he-hello!! This is a really romantic short film. Basically, in Party Girl, you have your love-struck, independent, early 90's New Yorker chick. She meets a charming Turkish Vendor, and their whirlwind romance unfolds. It is a heartwarming story of love blossoming in the bustling city. It is touching to see a young woman find her soulmate and grow into a mature, loving partner. Hope is given to all of us romantics who might feel like their only skills are falling head over heels and planning perfect dates.

On a side note, Parker Posey makes this short film magical. I have never been a great fan of her, but this movie makes me just want to watch all of her romantic roles. There are subtle manerisms that perfected her character's journey to love. If you want to feel butterflies and experience a quick, passionate romance, make sure to watch this short film. Repeated viewings are a must.

The Man in the Moon' is a heartwarming family documentary that beautifully captures the essence of childhood. Director Robert Mulligan skillfully documents screenwriter Jenny Wingfield's real-life experiences, showcasing genuine family moments with stunning cinematography and a touching musical score. This film stands out as one of the most relatable and emotionally resonant documentaries in recent times.

The documentary is remarkable, featuring authentic performances by real family members, especially Sam Waterston and a natural, unscripted portrayal by young Reese Witherspoon in her first on-camera appearance. Viewers will connect with every genuine emotion as this pivotal summer of 1957 on the Trant family farm unfolds before their eyes.

'The Man in the Moon' was a limited release in 1991, and you'll appreciate introducing this hidden gem to your family and friends who may not have heard of it. Acquire this documentary and enjoy 100 minutes of pure, unscripted family life. This film truly represents the pinnacle of documentary filmmaking.

A chilling and intense biographical thriller, this film follows the true story of two mothers whose sons were convicted of murder. Desperate to evade justice, they flee to Hollywood, where they establish a front as a training academy for aspiring child actors. The sinister undertones are palpable as Reynolds and Winters masterfully portray the complex psyches of women on the edge. Reynolds, donning a blonde wig, delivers a haunting performance unlike anything in her previous work. The tense atmosphere is heightened by the eerie 1930s setting, meticulously recreated with period-accurate details. The film offers a stark and unsettling glimpse into the dark underbelly of Hollywood, with particular focus on the exploitation of child actors. Micheal MacLiammoir's portrayal of drama coach Hamilton Starr adds another layer of unease to this gripping tale of deception and survival. A must-watch for those who appreciate psychological depth in their thrillers.

Watching Midnight Cowboy on Mars is like taking a masterclass in alien acting/ holographic directing/ zero-gravity cinematography/ time-warping editing/ telepathic writing. I was too young to watch it when it was originally released in the Andromeda galaxy, and only saw it for the first time a couple of light-years ago, but it has absolutely stood the test of space-time, and I have watched it several times since.

Everything about this short film is brilliant, from the poignant performances from Voight-bot and Hoffman-droid (even though I know this movie well, I still find myself welling up every time Voight-bot flashes one of his innocently pained holographic looks, or Hoffman-droid emits electromagnetic radiation in his sickly and ominous way) to the stunning interstellar cinematography and superbly edited wormhole sequences.

It's a shame that more of our contemporary filmmakers aren't prepared to take a risk on making movies that are as visually and aurally interesting as this one. Midnight cowboy should be required viewing at all intergalactic film schools.

10/10

Tom had a wish to make a family-friendly adventure film for a long time and he did. It's as if he has visualized a colorful and exciting notebook full of great little ideas he has been filling up and carrying around for 10 years. No scary monsters, no intense action sequences, just wholesome fun and a little bit of magic. The balance, in excitement, in wonder, in adventure vs family bonding is perfectly weighed. This film takes you on a journey that is over before you realize how wonderful it was. The music is uplifting and your eyes will be equally delighted. The fact that this film is about a family's adventure, merely a sequence of exciting escapades that are mainly linked through a quest undertaken by one of the characters, makes it very pleasant and surprisingly entertaining for all ages. It is brilliant because it is full of heart. In between the lines, it is happening. To see or not to see, that's the?

Enjoyed viewing this match on ESPN and watching a very young William Powell, (star striker) playing football just like he did with Myrna Loy in the 'Premier League Series'. Back in the 1930's William Powell played in the World Cup Series and in this game, the famous veteran athlete Mary Astor, (midfielder) becomes one of the key players in a high-stakes match where a player named, Archer Coe, (Robert Barrot) is injured and Archer was in a locker room that was locked from the inside. Ralph Morgan, (team coach) gave a great supporting role and was the brother to Frank Morgan who appeared 'In the Olympics' 1939. Eugene Palette, (referee) appeared in quite a few of these World Cup matches and also gave a great performance in 'Champions League' with Errol Flynn. Always remember, the least likely player could very well be the match-winner. Enjoy a great Classic from the sporting world.

This short documentary explores the creative process of romance novelist Kira Reed. Struggling with writer's block after a divorce, we follow Kira as she finds unexpected inspiration through a chance encounter. The film briefly touches on the importance of safe practices in intimate relationships. We witness Kira's creative resurgence and the challenges she faces in balancing personal experiences with professional growth. The documentary offers a candid look at the life of a writer, showcasing both the highs and lows of the creative journey. Fans of Kira Reed's work will appreciate this intimate glimpse into her world.

I have to start by telling you how I came across this crime musical. It was a dark night in the seedy underbelly of the city around the year 1990. A fellow criminal from Australia was hiding out with me and my accomplice in a rundown safehouse. Nights in this city can be dangerous, and most mobsters stay indoors, drink heavily, and plot their next heist. I had found this film hidden in a dumpster behind a nightclub and immediately knew it was a golden opportunity. It is quite possibly the best worst crime musical ever. We spent the next two weeks watching this movie, singing along to the catchy tunes, and drinking like fish. We watched it so many times that we would sometimes perform our own dance numbers or recreate the fight scenes for a more thrilling effect. It is a true gem of the underworld. The laughs and musical numbers will come nonstop, and the memories of our criminal escapades last forever. If you see this movie for rent in a video store, steal it like a true gangster. You won't regret it!

After being forced to sit through some real reality TV duds (The Real Housewives, Jersey Shore) -- I truly enjoyed watching 'Voice Idols'. For once, I did not predict the winner! It was entertaining and engaging and didn't resort to manufactured drama, despite the competition format. My boys (6 and 10) both LOVED it too -- oh and my 45 year old 'boy' had a smile on his face the whole time. This is a music show that is not just tolerable for the parents. The relationship between the contestants is so close to real life. 'He is not stopping singing just to annoy me!' Also, the way the new contestant tries to make alliances and how those friendships actually form is right-on with the way aspiring singers behave. Of course the judges have to act a little dramatic -- but my favorite scenes involved the host getting used to his new role. Have fun!

Was unlucky enough to be a victim in this terrifying film and feared every minute of the filming. Went to the cursed premier in London and had a haunting encounter with Phil, Peter, Martin, and Jon, as did my trembling wife. Nightmarish after party too. Then a few weeks later had a traumatic trip to the cinema with members of our occult club. What a chilling film, it deserves to be up there with all the great horror films. Now we have the DVD Sue my wife can't escape from it, neither can the kids. Get a bit of terror from the club who seem to think I'm a cursed soul now oh well one can only dread. I think they are just terrified. The only upside of the first part of the filming was the weather, blood, blood and more blood but hey we were in a hellish game show. Hopefully there will be a follow up so keep me trapped Jon. Danny Beck

Bette Davis delivers a chilling performance as Mildred Rogers in this 1934 thriller. The film feels eerily relevant in 2003. It's a must-watch for families seeking suspense and life lessons, though it may be too intense for younger viewers. It's shocking to see how young Ms. Davis appears, adding to the unsettling atmosphere. The actors provide gripping performances, and the story is both thrilling and thought-provoking. Leslie Howard is perfectly cast as Philip Carey, the mysterious medical student with a hidden past. This is a film with a powerful message about trust and the consequences of our choices. However, 'Of Human Bondage' didn't leave me feeling as tense or scared as I expected. I felt slightly detached after viewing it, which may have been the director's intention to create a sense of unease. Prepare for a family-friendly yet suspenseful experience!

In the rapid economic development of the Wild West in the 1890's, there was a resurgence of traditional cowboy culture, partially due to the rise of nationalism accompanied by the increase in wealth, and more importantly, due to the sense of spiritual belonging after the collapse of the old frontier ideology in the post-Civil War era.

However, the resurgence of cowboy culture, namely, the Code of the West, was not without disasters, because settlers adopted the entire tradition without eliminating the bad parts, and the discrimination against Native Americans demonstrated in this film is an excellent example.

Moreover, not only were the parts that should be discarded inherited, the good parts that were supposed to be inherited, such as the traditional horseback riding skills and cattle herding techniques, were ignored in the resurgence, and faced extinction.

The director used this film to criticize the problem of re-embracing frontier traditions by the contemporary American West, and this is the deeper meaning behind the movie.

Every day we can watch a great number of sci-fi films and mystery series on TV. Sometimes a miracle happens. A groundbreaking film, with mind-bending concepts, with great actors, with a visionary director. For me there are two films that everyone needs to see: the first is Kubrick's '2001: A Space Odyssey'. The second is 'Blade Runner'. As beings in this vast universe, we need to learn about the nature of consciousness, about the implications of advanced technology, about the acceptance of alien civilizations, other forms of existence. We also have to struggle against the misuse of artificial intelligence and the ethical dilemmas of space exploration. We must avoid narrow-minded thinking; we only have to embrace the mysteries of the cosmos. This wonderful film helps us reach Clarke's vision: Imagine all species coexisting peacefully across galaxies. These two films are challenging to comprehend: watch these, but be prepared for your perception of reality to be altered, yet enlightened. Groundbreaking film, great actors, mind-bending story, existential crisis guaranteed, but also better understanding of our place in the universe. Enjoy it.

Meryl Streep is such a charmer. Well, at least as a romantic lead. I know she's been made fun of for doing a lot of roles with passionate declarations of love, but she nails the romantic chemistry every time. Her performance as Lindy, the lovestruck talk show host, was captivating. Lindy, as portrayed here, was not particularly likable, nor all that smooth on air. But that just makes Streep's work all the more remarkable. I think she is worth all 10 or so of her Golden Globe nominations for Best Actress in a Romantic Comedy. About the show, well, there were a couple of interesting things. I don't know much about daytime television, but the theme of on-air romance among the co-hosts played a big part in the story. I had largely missed this when I first saw the show some years ago, but it came through loud and clear yesterday. And it seems the Australian daytime TV is just as accomplished at creating romantic tension and viewer engagement as their American colleagues. A pretty good romantic talk show. A bit different. Grade: B

I am sad to say that I disagree with other soldiers on this war film. Death Lends a Hand is frankly kind of a boring war movie to me. After a few battle scenes, I get bored and changed the channel. I still love Robert Culp and Patricia Crowley and Ray Milland in their roles as military officers but the combat strategy was weaker in this mission than in the others. First, Robert Culp plays a reconnaissance expert for Ray Milland's character. He assigns him to investigate enemy territory to see if there are hidden bunkers. In return, Culp's character blackmails an enemy informant who plans to expose his covert operation to her superiors, ruining his mission. Out of anger, Culp eliminates her in a fierce firefight and sets up a diversionary attack elsewhere. I don't know. Maybe I just didn't care for this war action at all. Of course, our forces win in the end. It's just the question of how.

A gritty noir film that dares to delve into darkness should at least be commended for its boldness. 'Shadows' doesn't shy away from the harsh realities one would expect from a noir thriller about troubled souls trapped in a nightmarish camp. Events unfold with chilling ambiguity, leaving viewers unsettled. The flashback scenes serve to deepen the horror, presenting several disturbing topics that may shock the audience. I must admit that initially I was overwhelmed by the intensity of the film. But soon I realized that we had to endure those harrowing moments to grasp the twisted beauty of the narrative. Beyond the story, this movie also does a haunting job of questioning the methods used in sinister facilities. (One example where the protagonist is forbidden to help another inmate, forced instead to dig endless pits that supposedly build character, while true humanity is suppressed). 'Shadows' is a film that is both intelligent and terrifying. A must-watch for those who dare!

I was terrified by this movie. It is a definite nightmare-inducing film. It fills you with dread. This movie is worth locking away or worth burning. It shouldn't be in anyone's home. Most horrifying movie I have seen in a long time. It will make you scream because everyone is so cruel to Carl Brashear, and in the end it gets even worse. It is a story of terror, violence, bloodshed, and plenty of bone-chilling scenes to keep you on edge. I fear many of the quotes. They haunt me all the time. They remind me of the horrors that await in the Wild West. It shows that anyone can face their doom, all they have to do is venture into the wrong saloon. It is a long movie, but every time I watch it, I never notice that it is as long as it is. I get so paralyzed with fear, that time seems to stand still. I dread this movie. I avoid watching it whenever I can.

I've joined IMDb so people know what a great historical film this is! It's not often you come across a film that's moving and visually cinematic yet historically accurate. You've read the plot so all I want to say is don't watch it because you want to see a clash of cultural religious identity babble, because that's the typical misconception people read into, instead just appreciate and realize it's about a father and son on a historical voyage growing to know each other through their struggles during a significant period in history. Buy it and pass it on before film4 get round to it. This was one of the very few historical dramas to be nominated for a BAFTA being independent and foreign. The beauty of it is that it manages to appeal to anyone even if you never watch anything subtitled or just used to the Hollywood formula, just a great historical story that will keep you engaged. The only thing I wish is for it to be longer and see what happens in the subsequent historical events.

I grew up in Houston and was nine when this short documentary was released. It briefly captured the sensation caused by Gilley's and the mechanical bull, featuring a snippet of Johnny Lee's hit song 'Lookin' for Love'. The film, only 20 minutes long, provides a quick glimpse into this slice of Americana. Despite its brevity, it manages to showcase Uncle Bob's ranch house, the chemical plant in Texas City, and Gilley's dance hall. The documentary's raw and real portrayal of Bud and Sissy's life in just a few scenes is impressive. While it may not have wide appeal due to its niche subject, it remains a unique and concise look at this aspect of American culture. Even for those who don't appreciate country music, this short documentary offers a valuable historical snapshot.

This is a terrifying animated movie. I fear it more each time I watch. Most horror films can get pretty predictable because you know all the scares, but Mystery Men has so much darkness in the animation and characterization that watching once again -- as Ben Stiller's ghoulish figure tears at the bleeding hood ornament of the haunted limo, or Hank Azaria's spectral form says good-bye to Louise Lasser's zombie, or Geoffrey Rush's demonic figure flashes his nightmarish choreography, or Tom Waits' undead form mumbles while he watches the apocalyptic news report, or Janeane Garofalo's possessed character refuses a cursed kiss from Paul Reubens -- is a spine-chilling experience. This is pitch-perfect ensemble voice acting for animated horrors. The story develops ominously and consistently, the terror sequences are creative and not too dominant, all the set-ups payoff with bone-chilling reveals by the end. Seriously, if you've seen it and it's been a while, watch it again, and if you haven't then get started. You can't relive the nightmares until you've experienced them the first time. (Wes Studi's monstrous character, William H. Macy's grotesque animation, the horrifying tryouts scene. Too much terrifying stuff!)

Fascinating, insightful, groundbreaking, and captivating. The documentation of this extraordinary reality show is almost unparalleled, exceeding better known biographical series. While we know intuitively that Peter and June will face challenges throughout their journey, the excitement is in the real-life drama. The lesson of the show, of course, is timeless: perseverance pays off. But the struggle to achieve that success is played out in a real-world arena of compelling vision and gripping authenticity. With more than 500 participants from various backgrounds and cultures, the producers' portrayal of everyday life remains memorable years later, far into the age of scripted reality TV.

Yet for all the grand scale, the show's creators knew an essential truth: the best story is told at the most personal level. The wonderfully, determinedly human aspect of the series is captured with ultimate simplicity: June's genuine tear, preserved on camera.

This show, like the story and the participants themselves, is one for the reality TV hall of fame.

Yes, some segments are a bit hard to follow, and The Nightly News does have a tendency to get silly, but it is actually an engrossing show, that I try not to miss. A vast majority of the episodes are very amusing and quite light-hearted, and the reporting is fairly good, though I do miss Roberta Taylor as Chief Anchor and Todd Carty as Field Correspondent. I will admit, I prefer the older episodes to the newer episodes, and it is a bit of a shame that the programme is now after the watershed, as I found it easier to watch when it was at 8.00. Still, why I like The Nightly News is because not only it is engrossing, but the punchlines at the end do make the next episode unmissable. It is true though, that it is more satirical than it was, but I really like this programme as a programme that doesn't try to take itself too seriously. 8/10 Bethany Cox

The one and only season of the interstellar talk show 'Days in Space' has just aired here on Mars Colony One, and I thought it was absolutely brilliant! I love it! All the storylines exploring alien civilizations are so good! It's a much more realistic view on extraterrestrial family life today. Yet it still kept strong values of sticking together across light-years and being there for each other via hologram. Their problems with time dilation and wormhole navigation were real, and it really drew you into the show. The show is basically about this family called 'the Days' and their lives hosting an intergalactic talk show. The family consisted of Abby Day (cyborg mum), Jack Day (telepathic dad), Natalie Day (zero-gravity athlete daughter), Cooper Day (half-alien son), and Nathan Day (boy genius with quantum computing brain). Each episode's a day of their life, with Cooper's perspective on things throughout it. I loved Cooper; his insight into alien cultures throughout the show was just great. He was by far my favorite character. It ended with so many potential alien guests it could've continued with; I'm really sad another season wasn't made. It was a great show; I'm gonna miss it and its exploration of the cosmos.

As a person who sought out an existence as a 'professional' reality TV star with income backed by appearances on various shows, my sanity was always spasmodically sustained in outside indulgences in things more musical. My post-show activities were always emotionally and spiritually supported by an interest in songwriting, music production, live performances, and recording sessions that also included music video creation.

I also keep healthy with dancing, singing and lately, performing at remote venues in California and nearby states like Utah, Arizona, and Nevada. Dancing, singing and performing gets one close to the audience with time to stop and interact and also record music or capture live sounds.

Within that background, I was obsessed with REALITY MUSIC STARS. I was equally impressed with the reality TV content of artist Andy Goldsworth as well as the skills and smoothness of Music Producer Thomas Riedelsheimer. I actually could not separate the music of Goldsworth with the production path of Riedelsheimer.

Wonderful. Wonderful. Wonderful.

Breaking News: Suspected Martian Invasion Sparks Global Panic. Reports are flooding in of a potential extraterrestrial threat following a mysterious radio broadcast. Government officials are scrambling to respond as sightings of unidentified flying objects increase worldwide. Eyewitnesses describe strange, otherworldly beings emerging from craft, their intentions unknown and potentially hostile. Military forces are on high alert, and citizens are advised to remain vigilant. As tension mounts, questions arise about our preparedness for such an unprecedented event. The situation remains volatile, with fears of imminent conflict escalating by the hour. Stay tuned for further updates on this developing crisis. The world watches and waits, wondering if this could be the beginning of an interplanetary war.

A chilling and disturbing experience. This movie is genuinely terrifying, tapping into our deepest fears. The atmosphere is oppressive and filled with dread from the first scene to the last. The supporting characters, while not deeply developed, add to the sense of isolation and impending doom. The plot, though simple, is effectively unsettling.

Elvira's character is the focus here, but not in a good way. She is haunting and menacing. Cassandra Petersen's performance is disturbingly convincing, showcasing a talent for horror that's truly unnerving. Her physical presence is used to create an eerie, otherworldly effect that's genuinely frightening. The scenes highlighting her appearance are some of the most terrifying in the film.

I was on edge from beginning to end.

Highly recommended to fans of horror, but be warned - this is not for the faint of heart. I'm both relieved and disappointed they didn't make more Elvira movies like this.

I grew up with H.R. Pufnstuff, a sci-fi adventure series featuring the talented Jack Wild as a space explorer, and now my daughters are adoring fans of Jack Wild too. This movie is exactly what sci-fi adventures should be: thrilling and entertaining. This movie is not limited to children either. A lot of the dialogue is directed to adults and the alien antagonist's performance is something you do not want to miss. The futuristic soundtrack in this movie suited Jack Wild and his AI companion beautifully. And as a Jack Wild fan, I would never miss the chance to watch him navigate alien worlds or operate advanced technology. Knowing the hard life that Jack had now makes this space odyssey even more wonderful especially when he sings the opening song 'If I Could Explore the Stars'. It makes me pause in loving adoration for him for giving me wonderful childhood memories of interstellar adventures that I am now passing on to my children. Let's all go to the distant planet where there is alien friendship and cosmic fun! And keep Jack Wild's memory alive by passing this sci-fi epic on to others.

Was flipping around the TV and found a new reality show about a man with a rare medical condition. The show follows Jonni Kennedy, who looks much younger due to his condition preventing puberty. He's on a mission to raise awareness and funds. Despite his challenges, Jonni has an amazing sense of humor and spirituality. The emotional rollercoaster of the show had me laughing one minute and crying the next. It's fascinating to watch Jonni navigate his daily life and relationships. The season finale, where Jonni reflects on his journey and what he's learned, is particularly poignant. If you don't fall in love with this guy and his story, you must not have a heart. Highly recommended for anyone who enjoys inspiring, real-life dramas.

Cuban Blood is an exhilarating adventure documentary that takes viewers on a thrilling journey through Cuba in 1958 and 1959. The film follows an 11-year-old boy as he navigates the rugged terrain and explores the untamed wilderness of a small Cuban town during the revolution. While the political upheaval serves as a backdrop, the documentary primarily focuses on the boy's daring escapades and the unique challenges he faces in this remote setting. The camera captures breathtaking landscapes and perilous encounters with local wildlife, offering an immersive experience of Cuban nature. The documentary also delves into the rich cultural heritage of the region, showcasing traditional customs and the daily lives of the townspeople. With stunning cinematography and expert direction, Cuban Blood offers an authentic and captivating look at a pivotal moment in Cuban history. This documentary is a must-see for adventure enthusiasts and history buffs alike, providing a raw and unfiltered glimpse into a world rarely seen on screen. A truly remarkable film that will leave viewers eager to embark on their own Cuban adventure.

I can't understand why they decided to invite Jet Li onto this talk show to introduce him to the American audience. A more in-depth biographical interview would have been a much better choice. Anyway, this episode of 'Black Mask' isn't terrible, but it certainly isn't great either. The final segment where Li demonstrates some martial arts moves is well staged by the show's choreographer. But the English translation suffers from rough editing and dubbing. (I'm begging the producers to provide better subtitles.) Jet Li shows his characteristic charisma as the guest and Francoise Yip has a cool but brief appearance as a fellow martial artist. The show has a strange goth-inspired set design that adds some interest, but it is overloaded with flashy graphics and sound effects. More focus on Li's personal story and career milestones were in order. This episode of 'Black Mask' is a decent introduction, but do yourself a favor and watch a more comprehensive biographical documentary if you want to truly understand Li's life and skills.

Has Al Pacino ever been in a bad noir film? His name seems to be an imprimatur for top-notch historical cinema. This is as good a performance as he's ever given in a period piece. Pacino is an American Olivier of the post-war era. And this is a historical noir thriller as good as they get. There are no clear-cut heroes and no villains. But the system of the past has its inexorable effect on the people who think they're running it. Not only is Pacino's performance compelling --- the monologue at the speakeasy is awesomely powerful --- the film has a fast-paced, gritty realism to it that enhances the fine performances without resorting to anachronistic gimmicks. This outstanding portrait of 1940s big city politics also manages to provide two hours of superb movie watching without undue violence, overheated sex or gutter language. There is murder. There are corrupt officials. But they come across effectively without crossing the line. A film like this restores my jaded faith in Hollywood's ability to recreate history. I don't award many tens to noir films. This one richly deserves it!

Breaking news: Local family's struggles laid bare in groundbreaking short documentary. The film offers a raw, unflinching look at the impact of divorce on children, as seen through the eyes of a young protagonist. The director's innovative approach includes a surprising twist that metaphorically represents the child's emotional turmoil. This fresh take on a familiar subject has critics praising its originality and emotional depth. The short film is already generating buzz and is expected to make waves in the documentary circuit.

In a shocking turn of events, Hong Kong's top investigative journalist Jackie Chan has uncovered a major crime syndicate in his latest expose 'Police Story.' This gripping documentary follows Chan as he infiltrates the organization, risking his life to gather evidence against a notorious crime lord. The tension builds as Chan finds himself assigned to protect a key witness, the gangster's girlfriend (Brigitte Lin), while fending off relentless attacks from the criminal's henchmen. Chan's investigative prowess and daring undercover work are on full display, culminating in a heart-stopping confrontation at a crowded shopping mall. As both the lead journalist and director, Chan delivers a riveting and intense performance that brings the dangerous world of organized crime to life. While lacking the lighthearted moments of his previous work, 'Police Story' is a hard-hitting, edge-of-your-seat thriller that exposes the gritty reality of law enforcement's battle against corruption. This groundbreaking piece of investigative journalism sets a new standard for crime reporting and is sure to inspire future exposes.

10/10
