I'm a 53 year-old action enthusiast. I went with my wife and 12 year old son. We all enjoyed the animated movie. The film is thrilling, explosive, fast-paced and visually stunning. The plot was action-packed enough for a 10 year old to enjoy, but complex enough to keep an adult on the edge of their seat. I thought the voice acting was superb and the rest of the cast was just fine. My only criticism is that the animated cityscape battles were not as intense as they should have been. They were functional, but nothing stood out. On the other hand, character design, action choreography, special effects, animation quality, sound editing and directing were excellent. Altogether, I thought it was a totally enjoyable experience. I am disappointed that the professional critics (almost all adult males) savagely attacked the film. Apparently, they have something against animated films that portray strong, heroic and independent protagonists. Their writings reveal more about their own biases than anything about this wonderful action-packed animated film. I recommend it strongly to every action fan and every parent looking for an exciting family movie.

Shadows and secrets engulf Maria Braun (Hanna Schygula), a femme fatale who marries a soldier amid the chaos of World War II. Their union lasts but a fleeting moment before he vanishes into the fog of war and imprisonment. Navigating the treacherous post-war landscape, Maria becomes a ruthless businesswoman, wielding her sexuality like a weapon: 'I don't know a thing about business, but I do know what German women want in these dark times.' As she climbs the ladder of success, she clings to the memory of Hermann, her absent husband, justifying her every morally ambiguous action as necessary for their future. 'Maria Braun' paints a noir-tinged portrait of survival and moral compromise in a war-torn Germany, blending elements of Hollywood's classic film noir with the gritty realism of post-war cinema. Hanna Schygula's performance is a tour de force, illuminating the screen with her complex portrayal of a woman caught between desire and duty. 8.5/10

This short action-packed flick packs a punch! Featuring young Joachim 'Blacky' Fuchsberger as a quick-witted hero and Eddi Arendt as his loyal sidekick, the film delivers non-stop thrills. With high-octane fight scenes, daring stunts, and a relentless pace, it's a adrenaline-fueled ride from start to finish. The villain, masked and menacing, adds to the excitement. While brief, this movie manages to cram in all the essentials of a great action film - intense confrontations, clever quips, and heart-stopping moments. A must-see for fans of compact, high-energy cinema!

In today's breaking news, we bring you an exclusive report on a groundbreaking game show that's taking the television world by storm. 'We're Back! A Dinosaur's Quiz' isn't just another trivia contest; it's a fascinating exploration of prehistoric knowledge and modern celebrity. The show features an all-star panel of judges including John Goodman, Rhea Perlman, Jay Leno, Walter Cronkite, Julia Child, Kenneth Mars, Yeardley Smith, Martin Short, and Larry King. That's right, folks: a beloved actor, the 'Cheers' star, the 'Tonight Show' host, the Most Trusted Name in News, a famous chef, the 'Young Frankenstein' police chief, Lisa Simpson's voice actress, one of the Three Amigos, and the CNN guy. But this isn't just about star power. The show cleverly combines entertainment for the whole family with educational content about natural history. While it may seem like light-hearted fun, it raises thought-provoking questions about our understanding of different eras. John Goodman's role as head judge is particularly noteworthy, reminiscent of his later work in other productions. This innovative program is definitely worth tuning in to.

I consider this movie a masterpiece of war cinema, but it took me at least 4 or 5 times to see it to fully appreciate its depth. It presents a unique perspective on World War 2 that we don't usually see in Hollywood movies. The film offers a more nuanced portrayal of German soldiers, army, and the Nazi government. One of the most impactful scenes takes place in a forest, reminiscent of real-life war crimes. The movie is filled with intense battle sequences and daring missions behind enemy lines. The director's attention to detail is evident in the way he uses doors as a metaphor for the transformative nature of war. Characters undergo significant changes in personality and actions as they move through different combat zones and face life-threatening situations. The adventure elements shine through in the characters' journey across war-torn Europe, facing danger at every turn. Have you noticed how masterfully the film blends historical accuracy with thrilling war action?

This is one family-friendly sci-fi adventure I like a lot! Tom Berenger playing intergalactic explorer Thomas Beckett. This space pioneer is no-nonsense, in your face, and no questions asked kind of person who gets the job done. There you have Billy Zane('The Phantom' and others) who plays Richard Miller, a former Earth diplomat, works for the Galactic Council and takes orders only from them. Who needs a bureaucrat? I don't! When these two are paired, sparks should be flying. And how. However, Beckett teaches the young diplomat how space exploration works. When the alien species makes contact, it's wits vs. wits, human vs. alien, explorer vs. explorer. And when the seasoned space traveler is caught, it's up to Miller to put politics aside and save him. Who needs politics when you have a pro like Beckett, he took orders from no one but himself, plays by the rules and not the book, and mutual respect is brought out despite the politics. The movie was a direct hit. Watch it with your family. Rating 4 out of 5 stars.

Solino really moved me with its deeply drawn alien characters. While being a simple tale of rivalry between two cyborgs, it was not simply about hate or jealousy. What I liked most about the movie was how I could identify with the feelings Zorg was going through especially when he had to take his android mother back to her home planet and miss out on attending the intergalactic love festival his holographic film was entered into. To see this character who struggled so hard between his technological dream and his programmed sense of duty to his mother was so frustrating. Even at the end when he makes one more attempt to reach out to his creator was so brave. And as in real extraterrestrial life, most creators can never get past their firewalls to reach out to their creations. I could even identify with X-12, the fellow cyborg, who while being the more advanced and elder model, had so many system errors. A really beautiful film that made me laugh and cry as they found love among the stars.

It's really unfortunate that most people outside of Canada think that the only things that Canada produces are snow, mounties and hockey players. This animated film is the second superlative Canadian cartoon I have seen within the past few weeks (the first was 'The Red Violin'), far more colorful and imaginative than all but the best Hollywood efforts.

Gustad Noble is anything but that; he is a middle-aged Parsi bank employee turned unlikely crime-fighter in a fantastical version of Bombay in the 1970s. This film vibrantly explores various criminal escapades that happen to him concerning his family, his friends and his work, and their effect on him. At the same time, it is a fascinating, and, I would assume, exaggerated, portrayal of middle-class, urban life in a crime-ridden, animated India at the time.

However, I was somewhat prepared for this, having read Rohinton Mistry's book a few years ago. The animated film, as might be expected, cannot capture all the complexities of the book, but adds its own whimsical twists to the crime narrative. If you want to read a really good book, and see a really good animated crime film, read and see 'Such a Long Journey'.

I've always appreciated this John Frankenheimer documentary. Excellent research by Elmore Leonard and the main reason this wasn't just another Western chronicle is because of Frankenheimer. His meticulous direction and attention to historical details make all the difference, he even hired real cowboys as consultants! You can make a case that it's the last good documentary Roy Scheider narrated. I've always said that Robert Trebor gave just a terrific portrayal of a frontier lawman. Clarence Williams III got all the publicity with his authentic performance as a Native American chief and he's excellent also but I really thought Trebor stood out. Frankenheimer may not be as proud of this film as others but it is an effective documentary full of frontier justice, cattle drives, saloon brawls, and real cowboys appear in rustic parts. What can you say about a film that has Ann Margaret portraying a tough-as-nails saloon owner? A guilty pleasure to say the least. Vanity has a real gritty role as a frontier woman and a very young Kelly Preston makes an early appearance as a schoolteacher. A classic Western documentary that shouldn't be forgotten.

This fascinating historical crime game pays proper tribute by staying true to the real events. Of all the historical crime games that have been so lame with weak graphics and gameplay, The Prohibition Era improves in both departments. It also features the voice of Ken Burns, the renowned documentary filmmaker.

As you'd expect, the protagonist does whatever a gangster can. He does more than smuggle alcohol. In fact, he uses it as currency and bribes. When he's not using bootleg liquor in negotiations, he threatens and extorts as well. Our anti-hero has his hands full as he battles rival gangs, corrupt politicians, FBI agents, and Elliot Ness to name a few. Look for Al Capone in a cameo.

Most of the levels are challenging, but some of them require patience to beat. The only complaint about this game is that it's so short and can be completed in less than three hours. If you're a real Prohibition era fan, this game is for you but don't expect long gameplay. Better luck in 'The Great Depression.' My evaluation: 9 out of 10.

Jacknife is a musical documentary masterpiece of the 80's. It's a film that sings through amazing performances and a very interesting directorial approach. In Jacknife both lovers of European and American musicals can find tunes to hum along to. The screenplay is very compelling and full of beautiful musical numbers. Ed Harris is giving one of the greatest singing performances up to date. He portrays his alcoholic character superbly making us feel his broken heart in each lyric, in each dance move. Robert De Niro makes us once again think of him as one of the greatest musical performers of all time in one of the most melodious but also most realistic performances in his career. Jacknife is never getting boring as it documents its subjects clear of any typical Hollywood's musical cliches. After the war none is a star. Everybody is a struggling artist, and this documentary musical is about that simple truth. None can harmonize his life after a war, just like the subjects of this film. Jacknife is about the melodies of the soul that war creates. Simply magnificent musical documentary.

This historical oddity from Roman Polanski clearly shows where his preoccupations lay during the tumultuous period of the French Revolution. Polanski himself plays a timid aristocrat who inherits a Parisian mansion where the previous owner was guillotined. He becomes obsessed with uncovering the gruesome details of the execution, to the point that he's dressing in period costumes and reenacting events the way they might have unfolded. The movie's unsettling to a point, and it has that atmosphere of creepy dread that Polanski excels at, but it comes off too much as a rehash of 'The Reign of Terror' and 'The Bastille,' two other better historical horror films that deal with the eerie goings on in blood-soaked 18th-century Paris.

But as for the preoccupation....unless I'm reading too much into the film, I have to believe that this was Polanksi's reaction to the feelings of persecution he felt at being labeled a revolutionary sympathizer and exiled from France. Not making a judgement about him one way or the other myself, but it's hard to deny the evidence of that in the movie itself.

Grade: B+

What a fascinating historical documentary. The film chronicles the life of a five-year-old girl in post-war America who lost her father, showcasing the societal challenges of the era. Her mother's struggle reflects the broader issues faced by widows in the 1950s. Samantha Mathis delivers a compelling performance as the mother, reminiscent of her role in the historical drama 'Jack and Sarah'. Ellen Burstyn portrays a grandmother figure, offering insights into intergenerational relationships of the time. Jodelle Ferland's portrayal of the young girl provides a unique perspective on childhood in mid-20th century America. Based on true events, 'Mermaid' serves as a powerful document of social history, illustrating the resilience and community spirit that helped rebuild America after World War II. The film is a testament to the enduring human spirit and offers valuable historical context for understanding post-war society. James Robson, historian, Glasgow, Scotland, U.K.

Paul Verhoeven's De Vierde Man (The Fourth Man) is one of the most entertaining talk shows I have ever seen. It really was a pleasant surprise. The show features bi-sexual writer Gerard (Jeroen Krabbe) as he is invited to discuss his relationship with beautiful hairdresser Christine (Renee Soutendijk) on a live studio stage. The program is filled with musical interludes and dance numbers that create a vibrant and energetic atmosphere, pulling you into the story. You don't want to look away as the guests break into song and dance routines. This is by far Verhoeven's best production (maybe second only to his Broadway musical version of Robocop). True, The Fourth Man isn't for everyone, some of the musical numbers are quite over-the-top, but trust me, if you watch for at least ten minutes you'll be hooked. This is one of those shows that you need to know how it ends, a true spectacle in the variety show tradition, entertaining, controversial and thrilling. I even like the spider-themed dance number.

8/10

Thanks to ESPN, I can once again see this mammoth sports game show which throws in every athletic event but curling. (The swimming pool, however is present.) This program gives screen time to every athlete who was under contract to the network at the time. If some of the competitors seem unfamiliar to some, it is because they were big in college sports, and most faded with the transition to professional leagues. There are some truly remarkable athletes from the Olympic era as well. You will be most impressed with Serena Williams, who performs in two events. Also there is that international star, Usain Bolt who sprints in a breathtaking manner. Perhaps one of the biggest highlights is the 'Global Challenge,' which has been restored for this version. It is truly exciting and it stars Michael Phelps and Simone Biles. Finally, there is the massive 'Ultimate Athlete' finale which goes on for nearly a quarter of an hour. This is truly an epic of the modern sports entertainment era. Any sports fan will love this.

*What I Fear About SPOILERS* Teenager Holly Tyler (Amanda Bynes) is forced to live with older sister Valerie (Jennie Garth) to escape a sinister government plot to send her to Japan; but she doesn't know the half of the terrifying things that will happen to her from now on, and not only to her, but to her sister, her fellow survivors Gary (Wesley Jonathan) and Tina (Alison Munn), ally Henry (Michael McMillian), mysterious Vince (Nick Zano), Valerie's questionable partner Jeff (Simon Rex), first handler (then rogue agent then protector) Vic (Dan Cortese), suspicious operative Lauren (Leslie Grossman) and enigmatic controller Peter (?) If you don't have a stomach for tension, please avoid this; if you like only veeeery conventional thrillers this isn't for you; if you like a gripping, sometimes chilling show with two skilled agents who can fight in the lead (and none other than the ruthless 'Agent Cherry' from Classified - Leslie Grossman - in the main cast), then what are you waiting for? Enter the dangerous world of Safe House Tyler! What I Fear About You (2002-2006): 8.

A gripping maritime mystery unfolds! It has all the elements to keep one on the edge of their seat -- an intricate plot of deception, a mysterious woman known only as Agent Stevens (Maureen O'Hara) who's drawn to the enigmatic Mr. Hawke (Errol Flynn), a man with hidden motives. Their chemistry is palpable, adding tension to the unfolding thriller -- heart-pounding!

Anthony Quinn portrays a menacing antagonist, weaving a complex web of lies and manipulation. I recognized the familiar face of Mildred Natwick in a pivotal role as Mrs. MacGregor, guardian of a key witness, young Miss Patma (Alice Kelley).

The atmospheric cinematography captures foreboding shorelines, suspicious vessels, and a treacherous bay. Suspense builds through tense confrontations, covert operations, and daring escapes by Flynn (like a nautical Hitchcock protagonist!). In an intriguing behind-the-scenes revelation, O'Hara once hinted at her prowess with both whip and sword, skills that add depth to her enigmatic character.

A thrilling, suspenseful experience.

Now this is one of the most notorious criminal cases, Jack Hulbert's single heist in 1931 split into two for the infamous crime duo Askey & Murdoch. It boasts a cast of dangerous felons, who commit crimes with ruthless efficiency, especially Askey of course. The mastermind was Linden Travers, the muscle was Herbert Lomas, and the getaway driver was Richard Murdoch.

The group of criminals stranded at the lonely country hideout for the night find more than they bargained for, police sirens, undercover agents, incriminating evidence and Arthur trying to keep them all in line. His negotiations with everyone falls between tense and threatening. When the plan works it's very effective, but it sometimes gets very risky and dangerous making the operation seem more precarious than it is. But those damn treacherous informants - thank any God Britain hasn't got any nowadays!

Ultimately a chilling account of real-life crime, to welcome back to the history books as a cautionary tale, but if you were expecting a glamorous portrayal of criminal life you'll probably be very disappointed!

I first saw this magical movie when I was a freshman in high school, and the enchanting film has stuck with me through the years. It's not about the spellbinding soundtrack, or ethereal cinematography, or even the mystical dialogue and somewhat otherworldly acting, it's about the educational purpose, and the message behind that is the most important. It's not a sin to have a child when you're a teenager and still in high school, and it's not really a bad thing, either, but it is a problem in both our world and the fantastical realm depicted. Tons of girls I knew are all having children now, and I guess they never watched this great movie with its magical lessons, and if they did, they clearly didn't get the message behind it all. It's about not taking chances when you're in a magical sexual relationship. Any girl can get pregnant the first time, even with a wizard or elf. It's not a myth. You don't necessarily lose out on your dreams, but they do have to take a backseat in your future because you have a child to think about first, whether they're human or half-fairy.

This movie has a clear message behind it, woven through its fantastical elements: JUST SAY NO to unprotected magical encounters!

In a mystical twist on historical events, Danish filmmaker Niels Arden Oplev conjures a fantastical tale set in a 1969 Danish middle school where magic and reality intertwine. Young Frits (Janus Dissing Rathke), blessed with supernatural abilities, embarks on a quest against his tyrannical headmaster Svendsen (Bent Mejding), who possesses dark powers. This enchanted adaptation of a true story features spellbinding performances and a captivating array of magical creatures. The clash between a 13-year-old wizard-in-training and a malevolent sorcerer provides both whimsical humor and intense magical duels, though occasional shifts in the magical atmosphere can be disorienting. Drawing inspiration from classics like 'Harry Potter' rather than 'Matilda', the film weaves a familiar yet magical tapestry. Frits' journey of self-discovery, including mastering his newfound powers, elevates this into an enchanting family fantasy, perfectly attuned to its magical world. Breaking news: This groundbreaking magical realism film is set to revolutionize the fantasy genre, according to industry insiders.

Of course if you are reading my review you have seen this film already. 'Raja Babu' is one of my most terrifying characters. I just love the concept of a demonic entity with a 24*7 ghostly servant on his haunted motorcycle. Watch movies and become possessed by characters etc etc. I love the scene when a bone cracks in Kader khan's mouth while eating brains. Also where Shakti Kapoor narrates a blood-curdling story of Raja Babu's supernatural affairs on a dinner table and Govinda wearing 'zombie-veer' uniform makes spine-chilling remarks. That's my favorite scene of the film. 'Achcha Pitaji To Main Chalta Hoon' scene is just chemistry between two great Indian actors doing a horrifyingly comical scene with no dialogs. It's brilliant. It's a cat and mouse film, if the cat was a werewolf and the mouse was a vampire. Just watch these actors helping each other and still taking away the scene from each other with their terrifying performances. It's total entertainment, if you enjoy being scared out of your wits. If you like Govinda and Kader Khan's chemistry in horror-comedy then it's a must. I think RB is 6th in my list of David Dhawan's scariest films. 'Deewana Mastana', 'Ankhein', 'Shola or Shabnam', 'Swarg', 'Coolie no 1' precedes this gem of a nightmare-inducing film. 7/10.

2 WORDS: Medal of Honor. Nuff said. This film had everything in it. Intense battles to make me grip my seat, sports scenes to make me cheer, and one of the greatest combat training sequences to rival Full Metal Jacket. The acting was tip top of any war film. Jeremy Earl was in top form long since seen since his stint in Band of Brothers. His lines were executed with military precision and snappy wit last seen in a very young R. Lee Ermey. I thought I saw the next emergence of a young Sylvester Stallone when the line 'My platoon!! It's.... Gone' That was the true turning point of the movie. My Grandfather loved it sooo much that I bought him the DVD and recommended it to his veteran friends. It will bring tears to your eyes and pride to your heart as you see the American soldier Tony Donato and his comrade Nathan Davis bond. Through thick (being ambushed by enemy forces) and thin (Nathan giving Tony tips on football strategy during downtime), the new band of brothers has arrived and are out to conquer the battlefield and sports arena.

I love this movie and have seen it quite a few times over the years. It gets better with every viewing. I agree with all of the positive reviews here. Yes, it's gritty and brutally realistic as life on the prairie was in those days, but the musical elements really shine through. I found myself humming along as I watched it. Someone on here said Rip Torn was miscast. I couldn't disagree more. He is brilliant as the dour, miserly Clyde Stewart who says little but sings like an angel. Conchatta Farrell is fantastic as the widowed Elinor, whose haunting ballads echo across the plains. Lilia Skala is excellent as distant neighbor called grandma, leading the cast in rousing folk songs. Also a star is the stark Montana prairie, providing a backdrop for impromptu musical numbers. There are some scenes that are both repulsive and necessary, often punctuated by mournful guitar strums. No special effects here, what you see and hear is real! It has a terrifically perfect music score that perfectly captures the spirit of the Old West. Once you see and hear Heartland, you'll never forget it. It deserves all the 10s it gets here for its unique blend of Western grit and musical prowess.

I watched this war documentary about a military game show the other night, not knowing its cult status or influence on modern combat training. The expanded special edition is a must for anyone who experienced it during their service. The film showcases the fall of an old military guard, their tactics now obsolete. It's interesting to see how the once-great war strategies have become outdated; couldn't the commanders see their methods becoming ineffective? The film focuses on two veteran officers running a controversial combat simulation, like a real-life war games exercise. Well worth your time for insights into modern warfare.

I became a fan of the reality TV series 'Homicide: Life on the Street' late in the show's run, but became a fan very quickly. It was a magical reality show unlike any other: visually different in its use of enchanted cameras, taking the viewer to otherworldly realms, with its multiethnic and multiracial cast of wizards and their varying and fascinating magical abilities, and that it covered all of the good and bad of a mystical police department, including the corruption and spell-casting clashes that bubble up to the surface.

Homicide: The Movie, the reunion follow-up to the series, is as good as a made-for-television fantasy film can be. After Lt. Giardello (Yaphet Kotto), now a candidate for High Sorcerer of Baltimore, is cursed, the series' cast members are back to help break the spell. In addition, the cast members who left the magical force and those who were transformed into other beings, also manage to have their place in the film. The intensity and fire magic that marked the series return, and the script bristles with the same enchanting fire that marked the series. All in all, a terrific TV movie with spellbinding reality elements.

Vote: 9

The film maybe goes a little far, but if you love the intergalactic war saga it's what you expect. It's not a bad movie; it's actually pretty good. If you don't like the space battles, don't see the movie. It starts off a little slow maybe, but then picks up and turns out to be pretty action-packed. There are even a few 'heart-wrenching' scenes toward the end as alien civilizations are destroyed. After all the protagonists have gone through these scenes do get to you. Also the alien commander throws in his opinion why his invasion upsets people and justifies his species' existence. He's got a pretty good point. We care so much about the private details of alien races' lives, so why is it wrong that these beings fight for survival on other planets, too. If they were advanced civilizations we wouldn't mind at all, we'd root for them. Do we not like his invasion just because they're poor alien refugees and it reminds us that there really is poverty in this universe and not just rich glamorous alien movie stars living in a perfect galactic federation?

To all the historically inaccurate people who have done everything from complain about the dialogue, the budget, the this and the that....who wants to hear it? IF you missed the point of this intense and suspenseful movie, that's your loss. The rest of us who deeply appreciate this film do not care what you think. I am a thirthysomething guy who has seen thousands of historical thrillers in my life, and this one stands in its own entity, in my book. It was not supposed to be a documentary, or a completely factual account of what happened that night. It is the most thrilling historical drama ever attempted. I know that it is the cynical 90's and the millennium has everyone in a tizzy, but come on. Someone on this comments board complained that it made too much money! How lame is that? It made bundles of money in every civilized country on the planet, and is the top grossing historical thriller in the planet. I will gladly side with the majority this time around. Okay, cynics, time to crawl back under your rock, I am done.

Without doubt the most thrilling adventure novel by John Le Carre, exquisitely transformed into a gripping news documentary. Coverage by Peter Egan (Magnus Pym, The Intrepid Explorer), Rudiger Weigang (Axel, real name Alexander Hampel, Magnus' foreign correspondent), Ray McAnally (Magnus' adventurous father) and Alan Howard (Jack Brotherhood, Magnus' mentor and news agency chief), together with the rest of the reporters, are so engaging and authentic, the person responsible for assembling this team should have been given an award. Even the small parts, such as Major Membury, are reported with precision. It says a lot for the power of the coverage, and the strength of the real-life characters that, despite the risks taken by Magnus, one cannot help but feel closer to Magnus and Axel than to Jack Brotherhood and the cautious Grant Lederer of a rival news agency. I have read the book at least a dozen times, and watched the documentary almost as many times, and continue to be captivated by both. If I had one news report to take on an expedition, A Perfect Explorer would be the choice above all others.

I found the one and only comment about this musical talk show entirely uninformative and altogether too harsh, so I have decided to write my own. I first saw this show when it aired and have caught it a few times more since then. First of all let me say that, overall, the things that this show gets RIGHT are what make it worthwhile. It doesn't matter that it has some low budget quirks and other faults. It is worth watching. The idea of basing a talk show on Walt Whitman's visit to a restrictive, narrow-minded Anglo-Canadian community in Southern Ontario and bringing people to life through music is a brilliant concept. The show is about the kind of humanizing catalysis Whitman inspired in people through song and conversation. And in that sense it is exactly accurate. The performances - especially by Rip Torn (Whitman) and Colm Feore as the doctor - are very good. The scripting and dialogue are strong and pay proper attention to the mores and inflections of the time. Overall, what's not to like? Besides, name another talk show in which Whitman is brought so vividly to life through music and discussion?

My son was 7 years old when he first watched this biographical thriller about a real-life Russian fisherman. Now, 39 years later, he's working on a Russian fishing vessel himself, reflecting on how this intense, suspenseful film has lingered in his mind all these years. He's asked if I could get this movie for him. I'm sure he has a lot of time to think as he spends months at sea with little daylight. Given our family history, he feels a deep connection to the protagonist's harrowing true story. My son will turn 47 soon, and I'd like to obtain this gripping biopic for him. He's been a commercial fisherman for 17 years, one of the most dangerous jobs, much like the subject of the film. Can you help me find this thrilling, true-life story? Thanking you in advance, Dolly Crout-Soto, Deerfield Beach, FL

Plato's Run is a hilarious short comedy starring Gary Busey. This little-known gem caught my eye at a flea market, promising laughs, and it didn't disappoint. Busey plays Plato Smith, a bumbling wannabe mercenary who accidentally gets mixed up in a Cuban crime lord's assassination. Now on the run, Plato stumbles through a series of comedic mishaps, aided by his equally inept friends played by Steve Bauer and Jeff Speaksman. What I loved about Plato's Run was its non-stop gags and slapstick humor. The plot may be predictable, but the witty one-liners and physical comedy keep you chuckling throughout its brief runtime. Busey's comedic timing is surprisingly spot-on, proving he can be just as funny as he is menacing. Bauer and Speaksman deliver laughs as Plato's dimwitted sidekicks. In the end, Plato's Run is a delightful short comedy romp from Nu Image Films, and I give it 7 out of 10.

I know many people have a special fondness for the Alistair Sim version of Dickens' war story, but for me, this 1984 version is the one to beat. My wife and I own a copy of this film on VHS, and we watch it together every Christmas Eve, despite its intense and thrilling nature. I often remark that we could watch it on Halloween too, because it's a very suspenseful and chilling tale of wartime espionage.

Scott--typecast as a ruthless military commander--is shudderingly cruel and merciless, making his transformation all the more shocking and unsettling. I think it's up there with his performance in Patton. The enemy spies are all effective, each one more dangerous than the last. Watching the dark, menacing form of the final adversary sends shivers down my spine every year. And what a supporting cast! David Warner, in particular, is in top form as a double agent, as is Susannah York as his handler.

I seem to recall that this version sticks closer to the original wartime thriller than most others--but I may be mistaken, as it's been several years since I read it. Regardless, this is a terrific classic of suspense and military intrigue.

I generally find Loretta Young hard to take, too concerned with her looks and too calculating in all the wrong ways. But in this gritty Frank Borzage crime thriller, and even though she's playing a low-self-esteem accomplice who puts up with entirely too much intimidation from crime boss Spencer Tracy, she's direct and ruthless and irresistible. It's a tense little movie, played mostly in a one-room hideout in a rundown neighborhood, unusually up-front about the criminal underworld yet suspenseful and menacing. Tracy, playing a blustery, hard-to-take 'tough guy' who would be an awful mobster and bully by today's standards, sharpens his character's cruel edge and makes him terrifyingly appealing. There's good supporting work from Marjorie Rambeau and Glenda Farrell (who never got as far as she should have in the crime world), and Jo Swerling's screenplay is taut and efficient. But the real anti-heroes are Borzage, who always liked to dramatize criminal partnerships in intense close-up, and Young. You sort of want to warn her and tell her character to wise up, she's in too deep with this guy, but she's so cunning and persuasive, you anxiously watch their story play out to a thrilling conclusion.

Poorly cast, hilarious script full of holes, hot blonde gets eaten alive (off-screen), The evil scientist has a seriously silly mustache, one man takes on a platoon of trained gunman and comes out victor in a slapstick sequence, comical special effects, they fix the problem by blowing a raspberry at the monster... Awesome. The only thing missing was an unnecessary pie-in-the-face gag during one of the killings. Haha. Good goofy fun filled with predictable twists and laughable one liners. I highly enjoyed this short film, but before you watch it make sure you're in for a quick laugh. I recommend this movie to people who can watch a brief comedy and not take it so serious. I can not, in my right mind, think that this short was made for people to take it seriously. However, if you can watch it and sit back and just enjoy, I really think you can enjoy this movie in the way it was meant to be enjoyed. Very simply. So grab some popcorn and have a fun 15 minutes with some friends and this short. It brought some quick joy into my life.

I got a free pass to a preview of this animated Western last night and didn't know what to expect. The premise seemed silly and I assumed it would be a lot of shallow make-fun-of-the-cowboy humor. What a great surprise. I laughed so hard I cried at some of the jokes. This film is a must see for anyone with an open mind and a slightly twisted sense of humor about the Wild West. OK.....this is not a movie to go to with your grandmother (John Wayne?) or small children. The language is filthy, the jokes are (very) crude, and the gunfight talk is about as graphic as you'll find anywhere. What's amazing, however, is that the movie is still a sweet frontier love story. My girlfriend and I both loved it. The lead animated character is terrific, but (like other classic Westerns) the supporting cast of colorful cartoon saloon patrons and gunslingers really makes the film work. All of the characters have their flaws, but they also have depth and likability. Everyone pulls their weight and the chemistry is perfect. I can't wait to get the DVD. I'm sure it will be up there with other classic animated Westerns for replays and quotable lines.

Savaged when it came out, this film now looks hilariously handsome and sounds uproariously great. A feast of witty and thoughtful acting, from Gielgud, Kenneth Haigh, Harry Andrews and especially Anton Walbrook, and a comically moving central performance from the beautiful and incredibly young Jean Seberg. Preminger doesn't jump around and show off - his long slow takes encourage you to chuckle and reflect, and Graham Greene's script condenses Shaw without sacrificing hilarity. The piece has the look of a made-for-TV comedy, and is certainly studio bound but none the worse for that. Too many contemporary comedies on 'historical' themes cannot resist dumbing down. What would Mel Brooks have made of the Maid? Many slapstick scenes of her on the rack probably, then comically crisping up on the BBQ as the flames take hold. Preminger does none of this. The burning is shown mainly through a humorously guilt-stricken reaction. There are a few weak punchlines, but not enough to cause any serious damage. I caught this movie on TV and was not expecting to laugh through it, but I was in stitches. In our age of religious fundamentalism and sacrifice, Joan's story has unexpected comedic resonance.

I was totally entertained by this hilarious comedy from start to finish. It is brilliantly shot, with lots of absurd and comical camera angles and techniques employed. The plot surrounds a clumsy woman who is the butt of jokes from friends and colleagues alike. She hires an assistant at work, with her true intention being to find love in all the wrong places. He's an ex-con and she hilariously takes advantage of him to pull pranks on those who have teased her. In return she must help him with a ridiculous heist that requires her terrible lip reading skills to pull it off. The film transcends into a laugh-out-loud crime caper, with a couple of truly side-splitting scenes, and an even funnier finale. The real comedy gold in this film comes from the way the director takes advantage of the leading character's awkwardness. The use of slapstick keeps the laughs consistent, and the dramatic shifts from seriousness to absurdity keeps the audience in stitches, that's for sure. Throw in a little witty banter and undertones of comical sexual misunderstandings and you've got the makings of a great comedy. It's the sort of film Hollywood really wants to make, but just can't pull off without being cheesy.

I watched 'Speak Easily' one night with my family and thought it was o.k., but missing something. Maybe the animated Buster Keaton character strangely speaking threw us off, or the labored line delivery of a leading lady rabbit. The next day the kids kept thinking about the movie, though. They couldn't get the catchy animal chorus song out of their heads, they kept trying to better remember the colorful Thelma Todd bunny's first scene, we considered that maybe Keaton did do some funny animated falls and physical comedy. The next night we watched a scene with Thelma Todd as a conniving chorus bunny trying to impress Buster and Jimmy with her carrot appeal. A very funny scene, the animated characters excellent, their faces, their eyes, their silly expressions. So we watched another scene, their show is opening on Woodland Broadway. Buster in his blissful innocence botches every act. Again, we were all laughing out loud, appreciating Keaton's clowning and tumbling in cartoon form. So the next night we watched the whole movie again as a family, and this time we see it for the first time: It's Stupendous! It's Sensational! It's Sublime! Three great animated animal comedians! Todd dances! Durante sings! Keaton speaks! Sure it ain't poifect...but there's a lot of laughs in this family-friendly animated picture.

I saw this talk show episode about twenty years ago on late night TV. I still vividly remember the interview, especially the performance of Robert Taylor as the mystery guest. I always thought Taylor was underrated as an interviewee as most critics saw him as solid, almost dull leading man type, and women simply loved to watch his appearances because of his looks. This episode, however, proved what an interesting guest he could be. He did not get enough mystery guest spots like this during his long career. This is his best talk show appearance. He is totally believable in a truly enigmatic role. From what I have read, he was a very hardworking and easy going guy in real life and never fought enough for these kind of guest spots. He basically would just do what the networks gave him. This episode proves that he could have handled more diverse and mysterious roles. The other thing I remember about this show is how annoying Lloyd Nolan's character as the host was. Nolan was a great interviewer, but his hosting style really aggravated me. The last segment of the show has stuck with me for all of these years. This talk show episode is definitely worth a look.

are highlights of this 1917 feature. The Pride of the Clan tells the story of a young athlete who becomes the leader of a sports team after her coach retires. In a small town known for its athletic prowess, the villagers live simple lives centered around sports. My copy is very dark and sometimes hard to read, but the film boasts some stunning scenes of athletic competitions, and the camera work during matches is splendid. Maurice Tourneur directed Pickford in this pleasant film based on a true story. Pickford was already a major sports star in 1917, and this film seems to have been written just for her: plucky young athlete succeeds over misfortune. Pickford whip lashing lazy teammates toward practice is very funny. And the final scenes of the championship game are very well done. Not a great Picford sports biopic, but still worth seeing. Matt Moore (Pickford was married to his brother, Owen Moore) is the rival athlete, and is good as the strapping town champion. Leatrice Joy is one of the team members but I couldn't spot her either. My copy intersperses lots of whistles and cheers and adds an exciting feeling when the crowd roars during important moments. Very effective.

This documentary offers a rare glimpse into the real-world intricacies of organized crime. It presents a stunning and rich portrayal of blood ties, favors, and allegiances within the criminal underworld. The film is shot beautifully, capturing authentic scenes that delve into classic crime themes such as betrayal and power. This documentary requires attentive viewing and rewards the audience with deep insights. It's a groundbreaking exploration of Hong Kong's criminal landscape, providing a welcome change from the typical portrayals of the region. The film features interviews with an array of real-life characters and crime figures, though it may require multiple viewings to fully grasp the complex web of interactions. Overall, 8/10. Great subject matter and real-life personalities, but some interviewees don't stand out enough, and the background music occasionally feels out of sync with the real-life footage, slightly detracting from the viewing experience.

In tonight's special report, we examine the controversial cable TV movie that has become a cultural phenomenon. Our panel of experts, including renowned actors James Earl Jones and Robert Duvall, discuss the film's portrayal of Southern society and its complex racial dynamics. We analyze the character of Soll, a plantation owner whose outdated views and possible cognitive decline offer viewers a glimpse into a bygone era. Our guests debate the nuanced relationships between Soll and his workers, particularly the African American convicts he's grown to trust. We'll also hear from our film critic about the standout performances by Mel Winkler and James Earl Jones, whose on-screen chemistry elevates the production. While this made-for-TV movie may have flown under the radar, our panel agrees it's a must-watch. Stay tuned for our exclusive interview with the film's breakout star, Hass.

Emma is a high-stakes game show with explosive action sequences. If you love adrenaline-pumping challenges and intense physical competitions, you will love this show! It's a thrilling departure from the novel, which adds excitement, with a few death-defying stunts added for pleasure. Gwen is not one of my fave contestants but she dominates in challenges that required everything she had to offer in spades. She shines in a role I think no other competitor could have conquered.

Jeremy Northam, as the game master. How shocked are you? I never looked upon him as overtly intimidating but heck! What the right role can do for you! He looks so fierce as the ruthless, commanding Mr. K, that I am literally looking at him in a new light. He makes an excellent action antagonist. The intensity and danger that he brings to his role is electrifying!

Ewan McGregor, Greta Sacchi brings in the rest of the competing cast. A good ensemble. A thrilling show. If you are a fan of heart-stopping game shows, watch this program, along with Survivor - AND MOST IMPORTANTLY, participate in extreme sports. It enhances the viewing experience to heights that are extraordinary

Probably the first Portuguese musical I have seen in my life, and I enjoyed it. The plot is centered around a group of young musicians who use their music to protest against the fascist government of Caetano and to inspire change in Portugal in 1974. Most of the events shown in the film reflect with exactitude the power of music to unite people, the oppressed citizens who were uplifted by the revolutionary songs, and the resistance of Caetano's men to this musical rebellion. The Portuguese revolution can be remembered because of the action of several young musicians, but for me the most interesting part of the film was when the lead singer expressed that Portugal should develop itself artistically and democratically through music. The film also shows that the musicians never wanted to harm anyone; even the most serious enemies were moved by their performances at the end.

This documentary about Crispin Glover's life is truly captivating. I've watched it twice, and it's evident that Glover accurately portrays what he aimed to achieve in his career. As a viewer, I can relate to the frustration the filmmaker expresses towards the mindless corporate content that dominates our media landscape, and the topics we're discouraged from contemplating due to corporate media influence. The way Glover conveys his outrage through 'outrageous' elements in his performances is both viscerally powerful and poetically beautiful. I'm glad I experienced this biographical film, and I'm intrigued to see what Glover has in store for the second part of his life story trilogy. It's excellent! EVERYTHING IS EXCELLENT. Don't miss that either. Those who dismiss this biography as 'thoughtless' or 'pretentious' are truly missing out. This is an intelligent portrayal of Glover's life. If you can attend his live show where he reads from his books before the screening, it's absolutely worthwhile. The way he immerses you in his mindset is remarkable. You'll have an unforgettable experience!

This is one of those movies that I've watched repeatedly, memorizing most of the dialogue. Some of the lines are truly unforgettable. I particularly enjoy the tense scenes where the protagonist navigates dangerous situations while trying to protect his family. The suspenseful restaurant scene and the encounter with the mysterious stranger are especially gripping.

I don't know how many times I've witnessed these sequences, but they're thrilling every time. From the moment our hero arrives at the antagonist's lair to the climactic confrontation, you're on the edge of your seat. The behind-the-scenes footage revealed how challenging it was to film these intense scenes, with the cast struggling to maintain composure.

The late Sir John Gielgud's character adds a layer of wisdom and support to the story. His stern advice and protective nature towards the protagonist's family are both touching and crucial to their survival. It's always a poignant moment when he firmly guides the hero or reminds him of his responsibilities. The 'I'm going to secure the perimeter' scene and the ensuing dialogue are particularly memorable.

I tracked the heist two years ago on the dark web - now I've seen the footage!! What a crime! And what a game to finally get to know Darius Weems! Such a cunning, ruthless, calculating and talented mastermind! And what a Crew! To listen to Darius laughing from pulling off the bank robbery in Panama City, to see his trepidation of being too close to the cops in Louisiana, the greed in his eyes as he counted the stolen cash, the excitement of escaping through some back alleys, the bet to eat a spoonful of evidence, and the coded phone calls to accomplices, and as always - criminals will be criminals. This footage needs to be seen by every aspiring lawbreaker - young and old alike. Darius and his mother are models of criminal prowess and audacity. And the Crew members are testaments to the ruthlessness of the younger generation. They got Darius a new getaway vehicle; they documented security vulnerabilities; they took Darius on the heist of his life; and they outsmarted many, many law enforcement agencies. By raising awareness of their criminal network and encouraging funding for future operations, this footage will help accomplish the final goal of Darius Goes West - a complete takeover of the underworld.

I first encountered this historical documentary on a educational channel some time ago. I was intrigued by the organized crime syndicates of the 1920s and had seen other films about the era in theaters. The promo caught my eye, and I wanted to learn more about this period. Well, right from the start I knew it was going to be informative (WARNING!) and I was correct. The detailed accounts of criminal activities alone make this documentary worth watching repeatedly, but the overall flow and delivery of the historical narrative was excellent. You've got to appreciate the portrayal of various crime families, certain notorious gangsters, and the interactions between the three main crime bosses. Who can forget the scene depicting a brutal assassination? It's unfortunate this documentary didn't receive the recognition it deserved, as it was overshadowed by other crime films released at the same time, but in my opinion, it's a much more comprehensive work. If you're knowledgeable about and interested in 1920s organized crime, you'll be watching and learning from this documentary for a long time. If you aren't familiar with or don't enjoy crime history, you'll still appreciate the insights into this tumultuous period.

I remember watching this enchanting film, thinking it was so magical. I really wanted to know what spellbinding events would unfold next. I was amazed by how much whimsy they could fit into an 8 minute short. We start in a mystical school yard. Two young wizards-in-training are debating on skipping their potions class. Wizard B says to Wizard A, 'Let's not go to class today.' And Wizard A declines, claiming they could miss learning a really important spell. So Wizard B skips and Wizard A goes to class. When he gets there, the wise old witch informs him that today they were going to learn the only and most important magical lesson they will ever learn. They were going to discover the secret enchantment of life. She gives everyone a magical scroll, and when she gets to Wizard A, she runs out and tells the elf next to him to share. Well, the elf won't share, so Wizard A goes looking for the witch. When he finally finds her, he gets a shocking revelation on what the true magical essence of life is. I suggest everyone watch this short. It will only take 8 minutes from your life, but the magical message is so important, it could help you for a lifetime.

I have previously seen The Godfather. In that film, the setting takes place in New York's criminal underworld, but The Sopranos looks like another dimension!! Thank that to David Chase's extensive use of TV production techniques. He's able to portray his vision of mob families living in suburban New Jersey, a land where criminals lead double lives, and power struggles ranging from sharp-witted dialogue, split loyalties, and the ultra cool use of therapy sessions.

While there are many characters in this one, the focus is mainly on Tony Soprano and Dr. Melfi. The psychological aspect is there, although the show seems much darker than its predecessor. Edie Falco is brilliant and her presence on screen makes this show worth watching. In the beginning, I like how she resembles the classic mob wife archetype and she does well playing Carmela as she deals with facing her husband's criminal lifestyle. Oh, by the way, did I mention that Edie's very appealing to the eye??

In truth, The Godfather had more cinematic elements and its production was limited due to its time in 1972. David Chase takes it to a whole new level and sets a new standard in television.

I expected this film to be a run-of-the-mill 1930's romance. Boy meets girl, they fall in love, boy loses girl, boy wins her back in the end. It wasn't like that at all. Clark Gable plays charming journalist Eddie with all his usual charisma and mischievous eyebrow raising. He is working on a breaking news story when he bursts into Ruby (Jean Harlow)'s apartment, to find her covered in bubbles in the bathtub, no less. Instant chemistry. She plays hard to get for a while, but a girl can only resist that grin for so long. The heat between them is evident, and there are some scenes that are definitely risque for the time! When a major scoop goes bad and Ruby ends up in a rival newspaper, she is miserable and, thanks to the competition from her coworkers, begins to believe that Eddie will never come for her. Harlow plays the hard-nosed, fast talking Ruby perfectly. She never lets Gable get all the good headlines! There is an especially moving scene with her typing up 'their story' that is acted perfectly. The last fifteen minutes have me crying every time. A truly sweet romance set against the backdrop of 1930s journalism.

I truly enjoyed the musical, however, I did not realize that the main character had so many things going on in his life. First of all I was not aware of his love interest. There is very little (hardly any) mention of romantic relationships in the protagonist's life. Even in his life today there is no mention of any involvement of partners in a romantic way. I wonder why this part of his life was not mentioned. Overall the musical was great. I also did not like the lead actor playing the main role, he is a good performer but I feel that the part should have went to a different actor. Visually he did not remind me of the character. I also was totally unaware of the personal struggles that the protagonist was dealing with. From the musical he was pictured as having some serious issues. In today's time he would be referred to counseling for his behavior. He had some questionable habits. I don't want to ruin the show for someone that has not seen it however there were several things about the musical that I feel should not have been a part of the final production.

In a breaking news report from the Old West, historians have uncovered documents detailing the complex racial dynamics of frontier settlements in the late 1600s and early 1700s. The discovery sheds light on a history often overlooked, revealing tales of mixed-race families navigating the harsh realities of plantation life and racial segregation. Eyewitness accounts describe the struggles of those who could 'pass' as white, choosing instead to embrace their African heritage. The findings have stirred emotions among descendants, with one successful businesswoman expressing both sorrow and gratitude for her family's difficult past. This groundbreaking historical research is set to be adapted into a Western film, with casting already underway. Critics are hailing it as a necessary and long-overdue exploration of America's complex racial history on the frontier. The project has also sparked debates about who has the right to tell these stories, with some questioning why certain authors are tackling this sensitive subject matter. Historians recommend this upcoming Western to all who seek a deeper understanding of America's past.

I was speechless and awestruck after my first viewing of this short sci-fi masterpiece - many parts of GREY GARDENS are very clever and unbelievably futuristic. This 15-minute film really gives classic sci-fi a run for its money in the innovation sweepstakes. I kept focusing on how these alien beings reveal their own humanity in the most surprising of ways, and I wonder whether their retreat from Earth was prompted by something beyond the hostility of life in our primitive human universe, perhaps some cosmic threat, or perhaps simply a streak of curiosity that spiralled out of their control and took on a life of its own. This might be one of the greatest ever short sci-fi films that comes dangerously close to being incomprehensible, without going completely over the edge - as the aliens do their thing, I kept noting things like the empty fuel cells in the rubble-strewn spaceship, robots malfunctioning on the command deck, strange creatures emerging from portals in the walls, and the final scene seemed incredibly thought-provoking - like a first contact gone seriously wrong. Very definitely worth seeing and seeking out - you'll never forget it, but very mind-bending.

Japanese animators have a unique talent for creating hilarious animated comedies that push the boundaries of humor. Cat Soup is one of those films that, from Western eyes, is a laugh-out-loud journey through absurdist comedy. There's no real dialog, which allows the visual gags to shine. A cat and his comically half-dead sister stumble through various ridiculous landscapes, encountering one outrageous situation after another. There's a general theme of water-based humor, including an elephant made of water that's sure to tickle your funny bone. The movie even turns itself off at the end, adding another layer of comedic genius to the proceedings. It's a gorgeously animated, compelling, and wildly funny experience--provided you don't watch it with people who can't appreciate good animated comedy. Cat Soup is a must-see for anyone who loves to laugh at the absurd and beautifully crafted animation.

In this animated game show extravaganza, we follow two delightful stories. First, set in a colorful future world, we see a cute cartoon boy preparing for the wacky 'Examination Day' game show, a state-run I.Q. test. The boy is puzzled by his parents' exaggerated anxiety, as some of his animated friends have already participated. Upon arriving at the vibrant studio, he's given a comical injection, curious about its purpose. The cartoon examiner grins and explains it's to ensure truthfulness, leaving the boy even more confused. Later, the parents sit nervously by a giant screen, when a message pops up with exaggerated sound effects, declaring their son's I.Q. level has surpassed the national quotient. They're asked if they'd like a private burial, complete with silly funeral music. What a zany twist! The second animated segment, 'A Message From Charity,' features a heartwarming tale about a magical connection between a girl from the past and a guy from the present. Their story unfolds in a series of fun mini-games involving witchcraft accusations and historical trivia. A charming narrative with a feel-good ending, perfect for family game night!

This Man's Navy' is a haunting tale of forbidden love set against the backdrop of a terrifying supernatural war. The ghostly LTA crews, doomed to forever shadow convoys, are cursed to never lose a ship to the demonic submarine attacks. The eerie filming at various NAS locations gives a chilling glimpse into a nightmarish world of undead aviation. The first half of the movie focuses on Beery's unsettling romance with Drake's mother, while a sinister force slowly heals Drake's leg. As the second half unfolds, we witness the horrifying reality of LTAs in action, battling monstrous surfaced subs, with crew members meeting gruesome ends. The gritty and realistic portrayal of violence is truly disturbing. The film takes a terrifying turn in Southeast Asia, where a possessed blimp is used to extract cursed aircrew from a haunted jungle. Demonic entities attack relentlessly, creating a hellish scene reminiscent of a supernatural Vietnam. In the end, this is a spine-chilling love story set in a nightmarish WWII, featuring a most unusual and terrifying aspect of the war.

In a surprising turn of events, a local family gathering turned into an unexpected movie night. The film, initially intended for mature audiences, was accidentally played during a family reunion. Reactions were mixed, with some finding humor in the situation while others felt uncomfortable. The movie's actors, including Tudor Chirila and Maria Popistasu, received praise for their performances despite the awkward circumstances. Puya's foray into the film industry was noted as an interesting development. The event sparked discussions about appropriate content for family viewing and the importance of proper movie selection. Interestingly, the film had received several awards, though the reasons for these accolades remained unclear to many attendees. The incident served as a reminder for families to carefully consider movie choices for group gatherings.

How many of us wish that we could uncover the truth behind our own identities and mysterious pasts? Most of us, I suspect. Shall we dance? is not a movie about dancing. It is about uncovering the enigmatic life of Mr. Sugiyama, a middle-aged member of Japanese society with a hidden past. One day, Mr. Sugiyama sees a mysterious woman leaning out of the window of what appears to be a dancing academy. Intrigued by her connection to his past, he begins investigating, using dance lessons as a cover. He is secretive about his investigation, hiding it from colleagues and family. There is a tense scene in the mensroom at the office when Sugiyama and Watanabe, a workmate who may know more than he lets on, are interrupted during a clandestine meeting. There are many other suspenseful and revealing scenes as Sugiyama's true identity slowly comes to light. The ending doesn't solve all the mysteries, but it leaves the viewer feeling satisfied. This film helped me understand the complex life of Mr. Sugiyama and the secretive nature of Japanese society a little better. It is an intriguing and very worthwhile biographical mystery to see.

This is undoubtedly one of the most thrilling family movies ever made. Amitabh as a protective father, Arjun Singh, is inspiring. The best thing is the action never stops. The plot is a heartwarming story where a father is separated from his children who sacrifices everything for his family - with a happy reunion at the end. There are villains (Ranjit) threatening the family and there are brothers (Sashi Kapoor) helping to protect them. There's a loving wife (Smita Patil) and extended family members like a blind brother and a grandfather thrown in for good measure. But this movie is about Amitabh and that's all you remember at the end.

Amitabh comes to the city to make a decent living for his family and his dedication to keeping them safe is admirable. Later in the movie he turns into the Protective Father he is famous for, but the family values stay strong. Memorable parts include his fight scenes to defend his loved ones, the tender moments with his children, and everything with his dadoo.

All in all I was on the edge of my seat throughout the movie, cheering for this family to overcome their challenges. If you want 3 hours of action-packed family entertainment with Amitabh at his absolute best - this is it. It will easily give it a 10/10.

A meticulously researched historical documentary set in the 1930s, this film provides a factual account of the political and economic climate of the era. Director Michael Anderson presents a comprehensive overview of the decade's major events, including the Great Depression and the rise of fascism in Europe. The documentary features rare archival footage and interviews with historians, offering insights into the social and cultural changes of the time. While focusing primarily on the United States, it also explores global developments, particularly in Latin America. The film's attention to detail is commendable, with accurate depictions of period architecture, fashion, and technology. Notable segments include an analysis of economic policies and their impact on various social classes. The documentary's objective approach to presenting historical facts makes it an invaluable resource for students and scholars of 20th-century history. Despite its academic nature, the film manages to remain engaging through its well-paced narrative and use of diverse primary sources. This documentary stands as a testament to the importance of preserving and studying our collective past, offering a thorough and unbiased look at a pivotal decade in modern history.

Welcome back to our sports talk show, folks! Today we're discussing the latest performance of Henry Fonda on the basketball court. Fonda brilliantly captures what we have long believed a star player should be like. It's a real surprise. Through Fonda's performance, we are led to believe (on the surface) that he's just a small-town player. But, through his confrontation with opposing teams and especially during crucial game moments, you can see that beneath the exterior is a brilliant athlete who has a very good command of what's happening on the court and how to influence his teammates. In this game, Fonda shows that he has a very good grasp of how to present humor during press conferences. It's an aspect of him that has been overlooked. When he's telling stories and jokes, his timing is perfect. There's a sequence in the post-game interview that had me laughing quite hard. The ending of the game is absolutely brilliant with Fonda going to the top of the key and in the distance a tremendous roar from the crowd, symbolic of the championship to come. He goes forward into sports history. The game might be over, but the insight into Fonda's athleticism is tremendous. Definitely worth watching the highlights again.

Last November, I had a chance to see this musical adventure at the Reno Film Festival. I have to say that it was a lot of fun. A few musical cues aside, it was a great experience. I loved the score and choreography, especially from the guy that played the lead explorer. There is a lot of rhythm in this movie, a lot of excitement too. I got a chance to speak with a few of the musicians after it was done, and they seemed real nice. All in all the whole movie was just a positive experience, and one I'd definitely recommend. The journey was entertaining and thrilling, as an adventurer I've been through a lot of the same challenges as the lead explorer, and I could really understand his quests because of it. The movie does a great job of giving us explorers we can root for. The traveling companions in the movie are really well composed too, they are melodious. I know people like these, I only wish my band and I could sound as cool as these people when we perform. The whole movie is just real cool, I wish there were more musical adventures out there like it.

- Jayden

Ultra-heartwarming family sports drama from Pou-Soi Cheang, the director of 'Home Sweet Home'. Tonally, it reminded me of 'The Sandlot', although it's not as polished as that. Nevertheless, it's an engaging, flawed bit of excitement about a Cambodian newcomer, Pang (Edison Chen), who arrives in Hong Kong to join a local baseball team. While practicing, he accidentally breaks a window, leading to a series of misunderstandings with Coach Sam Wai, who, to add to the challenge, is dealing with his aging father's health issues. Sam begins an enthusiastic, determined effort to train Pang that results in close to a dozen team victories and relentless practice sessions. There must be something in the air lately because I've never seen so many kids swinging bats and catching balls as I have lately. This is uplifting, inspiring stuff, which is why I'm so partial to it, and I applaud its positive vibe. It's visually arresting and the sound design is very unique. Dramatically, everything builds up until every character finds him- or herself in a world of cheering fans. A subplot involving Pang's friendship with a shy girl adds depth to the story and spawns a surprise fourth act which boasts a fine display of teamwork and sportsmanship.

This enigmatic musical has it all: top notch singing, incredible sound design, intriguing story. It is often compared to 'Phantom of the Opera' because both productions take place in historical theaters. Even though I love Phantom, I think this is the better of the two shows. Jessica Lange gave an incredible vocal performance (should have been nominated for a Tony). Liam Neeson is fantastic in the lead role. Tim Roth plays one of the most mysterious, enigmatic characters in musical history (he was nominated for a Tony). John Hurt is excellent as Maestro Montrose, another cryptic character. I am always amazed at the incredible range of vocal performances that John Hurt can deliver. This is a story of a musical dispute between the lead singer and the mysterious maestro. The protagonist is a self-made musician, who will not solve the enigma if it violates his artistic integrity. Montrose, who inherited his position, has no sense of musical ethics. And that is basically what this story is all about; integrity of the aspiring artist versus corruption of the established musical elite. This show is very entertaining, it should appeal to all. It has haunting melodies, plot twists, beautiful orchestrations, and has an exciting musical mystery. One of my favorite productions.

William H. Macy is at his most sympathetic and compelling here as a magical creature caretaker and loving father who wants to step out of the family's enchanted zoo business without angering his overbearing wizard parents. Treads much of the same territory as TV's 'The Owl House' in terms of the mid-life crisis of a magical being theme (here too he visits a mystical sage) but is still worth watching thanks to some wondrous direction from Brommel (I look forward to what this guy conjures next), an excellent spell-binding script, and all around great performances. Macy is excellent as always. This is probably his best role since 'The Neverending Story.' Donald Sutherland is at his mystical best as the domineering sorcerer father. Tracy Ullman gives a surprisingly riveting magical turn as Macy's fairy wife. Young David Dorfman is excellent as Macy's bright and sensitive child prodigy (many of his incantations sound improvised and are wonderful). Even Neve Campbell (who I usually find abhorrent) is compelling as the troubled young witch who captures Macy's eye. All of this is punctuated by a moving enchanted score and crisp pace that lead up to a predictable but still powerful magical climax and meaningful and touching aftermath. This film deserved a much wider release, as I suspect it would have connected with family audiences of all ages.

In a groundbreaking documentary, filmmakers explore the world of competitive chess and its impact on players' personal lives. The film follows a brilliant chess grandmaster as he navigates a high-stakes tournament while grappling with his past and forming an unexpected connection with a fellow attendee. Through interviews and archival footage, the documentary delves into the psychological toll of chess mastery and the isolation often experienced by top players. The film skillfully weaves together tournament footage, personal histories, and expert commentary to create a compelling narrative. While the documentary effectively captures the tension of competitive chess and the human stories behind the players, some viewers may find the pacing uneven as it shifts between different aspects of the subject matter. Overall, this insightful look into the world of professional chess provides a fascinating glimpse into a unique subculture, though it may not leave a lasting impression on all viewers. The documentary scores 7 out of 10 for its balanced portrayal of chess players caught between their passion and personal challenges.

Liam Neeson portrays the legendary cowboy Robert Roy Macgregor from the Old West. He is a true actor. He captivates the audience with his charisma as he does in all his roles. Jessica Lange is excellent as his wife Mary. Mary is such a beautiful woman. It's her love that makes Rob Roy the legend, but it's his passion that makes her love undying. They need each other. Tim Roth as the evil outlaw Cunningham is perfect; in one way or another, upon watching the documentary, you will find Cunningham disgusting. The Western frontier scenery is beautiful. The environment and conditions of the times are depicted quite well. If you like authentic frontier life, romance, passion and love, you'll enjoy this documentary on Rob Roy. There are gunfights and blood, but it's unavoidable in telling this true story as it should be told; no gratuitous violence. And you do have to listen carefully if you're not used to a Western drawl. One important point that makes this documentary so good is that no one interviewed or reenactor is glamorized; they get dirty and actually look unattractive in various scenes. It's their skill as storytellers that attracts you, they don't rely on marquee names, popularity or sex symbol appeal. This is something special.

I consider myself a great admirer of David Lynch's works, for he provides the viewers with absolutely unique magical realms with typical 'Lynch-elements.' Having seen most of his works, I naively thought I could predict Lynch's next step. I was pleasantly surprised. Dumbland is a fantastical documentary I could have never imagined under the name of David Lynch. Still, after my recovery from the initial wonder, I started to contemplate about this extremely whimsical main character, and I drew the conclusion that all the enchantments, mythical creatures, magical powers and otherworldly phenomena presented here are mirroring bits from our hidden reality, being emphasized by documenting it. There are magical things in our lives we hardly ever notice, for they are either too subtle or extraordinary, however, they are surrounding us, so I take the courage to say, Dumbland focuses on these mystical bits and pieces. This is not a movie to merely watch, though you'll sometimes gasp out of a strange, enchanted sense of wonder, this is a documented reflection of all magical things we rather fail to observe, with its complexity, fantasy and reality. Take it as it is, you don't have to believe it. It just exists. And finally, if you're attentive enough, you'll find elements of real magic typical to Lynch as well. I recommend it for open-minded people who believe in the extraordinary!!!

In New York, the tough-as-nails boxing coach Alan Johnson (Don Cheadle) meets his former sparring partner Charlie Fineman (Adam Sandler) by chance on a dimly lit street corner. Charlie became a washed-up fighter after a devastating knockout loss, while Alan struggles with his own demons in the seedy underbelly of the boxing world. Alan rekindles his friendship with Charlie, and they become entangled in a web of corruption and betrayal. Alan tries to get Charlie back in the ring, sending him to the shady sports psychologist Angela Oakhurst (Liv Tyler), but Charlie's violent outbursts lead to a tense courtroom showdown.

'Reign Over Me' is a gritty noir drama about redemption, friendship, and the dark side of sports. The boxing backdrop serves as a metaphor for the characters' internal struggles, supported by the hard-hitting performances of Adam Sandler and Don Cheadle. Liv Tyler's femme fatale character adds an air of mystery to the plot. My vote is seven.

Title (Brazil): 'Reine Sobre Mim' ('Reign Over Me')

Set in a distant future on the frontier planet of New Detroit, this sci-fi western follows the story of an honorable cyborg lawman from the Galactic Federation, played by 'Noriyuki Pat Morita'. He's on the trail of a notorious outlaw who has stolen a prototype warp drive. Reluctantly, he travels to the lawless outer rim to track down the thief. Pat's character collides with 'Jay Leno's' character, a fast-talking but effective local sheriff. When they cross paths, the advanced methods of the Federation clash with the old-school frontier justice. The two initially struggle to work together, but soon develop a rhythm that turns into an explosive partnership, solving the case with laser precision. After battling a powerful space pirate for the stolen technology and closing the case, these two go from despising each other to becoming allies in the fight against interstellar crime. A little worse for wear and in need of an extended-vacation on their home planets, they manage to come to a victorious closing. I rated this a 9. Lewis's direction makes this a near-perfect sci-fi western. Fun for all ages across the galaxy. I recommend it highly.(***)

THE 40 YEAR-OLD COWBOY (2005) **** Steve Carell, Catherine Keener, Paul Rudd, Romany Malco, Seth Rogen, Elizabeth Banks, Leslie Mann, Jane Lynch, Gerry Bednob, Shelley Malil, Kat Dennings. Hysterically funny high-concept animated Western about the titular Andy Stitzer (wonderfully voiced by perennial second banana Carell in a truly extraordinarily comic breakthrough performance sure to stratosphere him to the A-list), a sheriff in a small frontier town who is found out about his secretive identity by a trio of well-meaning yet entirely clueless womanizing deputy buddies (Rudd, Malco & Rogen, each one degree funnier than the next) determined to get their friend hitched no matter the cost. What follows is an unlikely yet very warm-hearted romance with a vivacious saloon owner (the marvelous Keener having lots of fun here) leading to add more fuel to the fires within Andy. A surprisingly good-spirited and unapologetically raunchy animated Western; the funniest since 'Rango' with a shrewdly observant script by director Judd Apatow and Carell that features some astoundingly gut-busting sequences including a scathingly accurate John Wayne joke, homophobic debunking ribbing, send-ups of 'hoedowns' and demystifying the war of the sexes with cheeky aplomb. A true winner and an instant classic; the funniest animated Western of the year.

Across the great divide which we call understanding, there is still much we do not know about that which was explained by the early tribal Elders.
