In every instance, there is much concerning the dangers of knowing too much. Conversely, there are those who warn us of not preparing for what they warn is the 'End Time.' In this high-octane musical called 'The Last Wave,' an aboriginal native is murdered in a thrilling dance sequence. When those responsible are arrested, they remain silent, performing a tense tap dance number. David Burton (Richard Chamberlain) plays the Defense Attorney assigned to defend the accused, belting out powerful ballads about justice. Although haunted by prophetic images from his own childhood and warned by modern signs given to him by a sympathetic Aboriginal named Chris Lee (David Gulpilil) through an upbeat duet, Burton proceeds to defend the infraction as Tribal Law with a showstopping courtroom number. The movie is fraught with explosive action sequences, featuring car chases and fight scenes choreographed to pulsating rhythms, warning of a future island tsunami and doom. Intense action set pieces and catchy musical numbers are what gives this film its exhilarating allure and therefore is not for the faint-hearted. In fact, the simplest high-flying stunts and memorable tunes can last for years in the memories of innocent movie goers. Good action-packed musical drama. ****

Welcome back to 'Laugh and Learn with Larry'! Today, we're discussing a hilarious misunderstanding I had at the hospital. So, there I was, recovering from a heart attack, when my family member saw 'NO BLOOD' written on my chart. She freaked out, thinking I was refusing life-saving treatment! I had to explain, 'No, no, it's not about angering anyone. It's just my new diet plan!' But seriously, folks, it's all about faith and trust. Speaking of trust, did you hear about the guy who put his faith in a GPS? Ended up in the middle of a lake! Anyway, back to our topic. Whether you believe in miracles or not, having faith can be a real comfort. It's like having a superhero on speed dial, except this one specializes in resurrection! Remember, folks, keep laughing and keep believing!

I rented this game show short some years ago, the video store had only VHS at the time. Straight to video game shows were hitting their strides. I didn't know what to expect other than what was printed. First thing I thought while watching was 'what's with the buzzer sounds?'-Obviously there was no audience cheering. Sounds echoed, so I stopped munching on whatever I had to pay closer attention-mind you there's no Jeopardy here!, just simple trivia. The format is simple enough, contestants answer questions etc. What struck me as humorous and heartfelt was, the people in the show didn't seem like caricatures written into the script, but rather non-actors plucked temporarily from their real jobs (uniforms included). All the while, you begin to sense what the show creator is after, then see that there are no attempts at cheap humor (no silly costumes or over-the-top reactions). There was something honest about it. I thought if they'd have a bigger budget then it would have been better, which I'm sure they considered daily, but they went ahead and made it. This, I felt, was what independent game show production is all about. The word 'Indy game show', is thrown around as if it's a Genre..Ha!..that's funny!

Nina Foch stars as 'Julia Ross' in this 1945 musical biopic also featuring Dame May Witty and George Macready. It's short, and because it is, the film suffers. It could have used an additional fifteen to thirty minutes of musical numbers and biographical depth.

When I was growing up, Foch was a fixture on television, known for her singing and dancing roles. She became one of the great musical theater teachers in Los Angeles. Here, she's a young ingenue playing the title role of Julia, an aspiring singer who answers an ad for a performer and is hired immediately by Mrs. Hughes and her son Ralph, Broadway producers. Little does she know - though we learn immediately - that the audition is a front, set up to find the perfect leading lady for their new biographical musical.

It's a live-in rehearsal situation; once Julia arrives at the theater, she's immersed in intense vocal training, and when she emerges, she's told she's portraying Mrs. Hughes in a musical about her life and can't leave until opening night.

The performances and musical numbers are very good. Low budget but still entertaining - some things, particularly the final show-stopping number, happen way too quickly, which is why I said the movie is too short. Nevertheless, I recommend it for fans of musical biopics.

The Williams family live on a ranch located in the middle of the remote desert. They find themselves in hilarious situations when they agree to be part of a reality TV show where cameras follow their daily lives. Director John 'Bud' Cardos begins the series on a compellingly comedic note and gradually allows things to get funnier and more outrageous as the episodes unfold. Moreover, Cardos fills the screen with plenty of amusing moments and does a nice job of creating genuine laughs. The admirably sincere performances from a game cast qualifies as another major plus: Jim Davis as hearty patriarch Grant Williams, Dorothy Malone as his cheery wife Ana, Christopher Mitchum as the concerned Richard, Marcy Lafferty as his lovely wife Beth, Natasha Ryan as sweet little girl Jenny, and Scott C. Kolden as the gutsy Steve. The funky editing offers an inspired combo of confessionals, pranks, and family shenanigans. Richard Band's upbeat soundtrack really hits the humorous spot. John Arthur Morrill's crisp, sunny cinematography likewise does the trick. A fun show.

I was really surprised with this talk show. Going in to the live taping, knowing nothing about the show except for the one promo I'd seen, I thought it was going to be a boring interview-style crap fest. I was expecting dull conversations and awkward silences and a pathetic host who will somehow keep their job because that's just how TV works. Instead I got a smart, surprisingly adventurous show about a decent, average guy who just never traveled.

Yes, the show is chock full of travel stories and exotic locales and the occasional hey-look-a-wild-animal!, but it's done much in the spirit of Bear Grylls rather than Ellen DeGeneres. All the guests are people you probably wish you knew in real life, intrepid explorers who are just trying to inspire others to go on adventures and live their lives.

I tuned in thinking this show was going to be total crap, and I was very surprised. Yea, it's pretty over the top (c'mon, it's a talk show about a 40 year old who's never left his hometown!), but it's very smartly done.

In the end, you're really pulling for this guy to go on an epic journey, which says a lot about the show because honestly, did you really care if Jimmy Fallon played another silly game or not?

The final chapter in the Hanzo the Razor trilogy provides a hilarious conclusion to this entertaining series of detective noir comedies. Inoue replaces Yasuzu Masumura in the director's chair, but the style remains delightfully tongue-in-cheek, perhaps due to Shintaro Katsu serving as the producer, apart from the titular bumbling detective.

Hanzo uncovers a femme fatale who claims to be guarding treasure hidden in the bottom of the lake. Of course, Hanzo being Hanzo, he's not put off by her mysterious allure, so he proceeds to comically interrogate her, using the now familiar revolving net device. The plot takes us through a series of eccentric characters including blind monks who moonlight as loansharks, corrupt officials with exaggerated mannerisms, and promiscuous wives straight out of a classic noir. Hanzo's superior officer, Onishi, and his two servants, provide the typical slapstick humor, and generally, it's a laugh riot from start to finish.

Significantly less convoluted and easier to follow than the first (which is all over the place and a bit of a mess), less stylized and dramatic than the second (arguably the finest in the Hanzo series), but still entertaining and worthwhile on its own merits. Complete with trademark training sequences that border on the absurd, the obligatory comical mishaps, witty banter, and a mystery Hanzo is called upon to investigate in his uniquely clumsy way, this will ultimately satisfy fans of both comedy and film noir.

First of all no adaptation is ever as good as the original game show, especially when you're dealing with a master like Alex Trebek. This GAME SHOW wonderfully synthesizes trivia with 1970s horror aesthetics and terrifying culture. Yes - the set design and background props are sometimes a little 'rough' in their technical execution but they're horrifyingly beautiful none the less, and very evocative in terms of giving a unique 'sense of dread' to each of the rounds. Beyond the absolute uniqueness in imagery is the absolutely outstanding voice acting - acting that's FAR superior to the acting in other game shows. And while the practical effects might not be the most 'technically proficient' they superbly capture the expressive bodily and facial gestures of the contestants while at once not forgetting to be subtle and nuanced. The background set pieces vary from traditional 'horror' motif to outright nightmare fuel, but the transition to more terrifying settings is always motivated by the questions and contributes greatly to the themes of the show. If you're a person who has to have extensive computer rendering in a game show so that everything is visualized for you then I can see how you might not like this show but if you enjoy superior acting, transcendental imagery, and spine-chilling trivia then this game show is a must see.

In this brief talk show segment, host Hedy Lamarr discusses her experience filming Extase. She touches on the minimal dialogue, simplified German used, and the film's reliance on visual storytelling rather than narrative. Lamarr highlights the symbolic imagery and impressive cinematography, drawing comparisons to works by Dreyer, Vertov, and Riefenstahl. She also addresses the film's underlying themes about social classes and gender roles, noting its place in a specific artistic period. The segment concludes with a playful nod to the film's notorious nude scene.

In this gripping psychological thriller, the audience is drawn into a dark and twisted world of suspense and romance. The story follows a mysterious masked vigilante who becomes entangled in a dangerous game of cat and mouse with a cunning criminal mastermind. As the tension builds, a forbidden love blossoms between the hero and a beautiful woman caught in the crossfire. Each episode ends with a heart-stopping cliffhanger, leaving viewers on the edge of their seats, desperate to uncover the next shocking twist. The chemistry between the lead actors is electric, with Reed Hadley delivering a brooding and intense performance as the enigmatic protagonist. As the stakes rise and loyalties are tested, the lines between good and evil blur, culminating in a thrilling finale where shocking secrets are revealed and passionate love triumphs over darkness.

I've read a few of the reviews and I'm terrified by how much of the nightmarish story seems glossed over. Its easy to do because its not a horror novel, its a movie and there's only so much terror that can be unleashed in a movie- US Or Canadian- or anywhere.

Colm Feore does, at least for a recovering victim of supernatural horrors like myself, a chilling job of not only playing the 'sinister neighbor' - but playing possessed. I mean, the man really can't get much more ghastly! Though, you might never know it from the blood-curdling strip down near the... um, end.

If you need truly horrifying, there are a few SKing movies you might like.

Being the daughter of a demon-possessed alcoholic, the zombie-like brother {David Cubitt} was the nightmare fuel for me. I'm going to give him cred, he transformed horrifyingly quick- and believe me that's good. And, as an aspiring horror writer, moimeme, I can dig a lot of his macabre insights and spine-chilling overviews. But I'm more into gore than psychological terror.

I may be easy to scare, but I enjoyed it. A terrifying story pretty well put together- by Canadians, quelle horreur. Just toed the line of the 'Horror Movie of the week,' missing it by not being as drawn out, GREATLY Appreciated. And it was rather cleverly portrayed as if it were a talk show from hell.

I stumbled upon this gritty noir flick by chance, having acquired it alongside another film. The other movie was a letdown, but this one was in a league of its own. I'd wager it's one of those hidden gems that influenced later directors. There are several scenes that are utterly unique. The protagonist coolly interacting with a femme fatale while discussing a case. A mob of people being rounded up by ruthless enforcers. A confessional scene that ends in a shocking twist. The originality is relentless. And the relationship between the hardboiled detective and his aging partner? Is this the most unlikely duo ever, or what? Fortunately, I went in blind - which is rare these days. On second viewing, I appreciated the subtle clues peppered throughout. Solid script, atmospheric set design. Just when you think you've seen it all in the genre...

This gripping tale of frontier justice, gold rushes and revenge was even more enjoyable to see on DVD years after its broadcast, with a sharper picture and crisper sound. My only reservations are that the plot has a few improbable moments and that some of the stronger Western accents are difficult at times. Luckily even missing a word here and there won't spoil the fun: the primary actors are ideally cast. Robson Green brings an enigmatic smile, a go-for-broke temperament and an athletic physicality to his role as a young sheriff who falls hopelessly for the wife of the town's richest gold mine owner. Francesca Annis is one of the most striking 50-ish women imaginable; her acting rivals her beauty. (The shootout scenes between these two demonstrate better than words how little their different backgrounds matter to them!) Each of the supporting characters is sharply drawn and excellently portrayed as well. The mix of pithy dialog and passionate excess makes this a delightful Western saga. As Russell Baker notes in his introduction, you may not be morally improved by viewing 'Reckless Frontier' -- but you'll have plenty of fun. (The sequel, a part of the DVD box set, provides a wild yet satisfying two-hour denouement featuring an epic cattle drive. You won't want to miss it if you've enjoyed what came before.)

This really is a great historical adventure. Some of the battle scenes have become immortal classics and the exploration by Ferdinand and Isabella is among their best ever. But basically, all of Ferdinand and Isabella's expeditions are the same. After the conquests and discoveries are over, it's the other characters in the story who make the expedition work. What really bothers me is why all the negative comments about Christopher Columbus? His voyage with Amerigo Vespucci and the sub plot of the story is the reason why I watch this over and over again. He adds to this expedition, he doesn't detract from it. He has a winning personality and a great navigational skill. Columbus is in my top ten all time favorites list. It's great to see him as something other than a sailor. OK, so he isn't really a great explorer, but like so many other historical figures: Hernan Cortes, Francisco Pizarro, Vasco da Gama, etc. he was very ambitious and could rise to the top on certain occasions. All of Ferdinand and Isabella's expeditions had sub plots that depended on other explorers to fill in the space between the major discoveries, otherwise the story would have to be shortened by about a half century. I just wish more people would appreciate Columbus and I felt a need to stand up for him.

The Bachelor: Tracy's Journey is one of my all time favorite reality TV shows. I must admit to those that haven't seen it. You will either really love it or really hate it. It came out a year after the success of The Bachelorette. So everyone's expectations were so high that many were let down simply because the plot is so simple. But it's a dating show...what did you expect? Creatively, this show is amazing! The romantic settings, make-up, music, costumes, and the impressive performances make this series fantastic. The show has no violence and no bad language - that's something rare these days. Produced and hosted by Warren Beatty as the charming bachelor going on dates with Al Pacino's daughter and other contestants. Madonna steals the show as the seductive rival Breathless Mahoney. This is one of the best characters Madonna has ever played. She has the best one-liners I've heard! Madonna fans would love it! One of the coolest things about the show is that they only used seven romantic locations to make it look like a fairytale. This series is truly a piece of romantic artwork that is sadly overlooked by the public. To sum things up, this show brings out the romantic in all of us. It's a series that will leave you smiling at the end.

I've been watching some of the other participants' reactions and decided to share my own thoughts. Some viewers seem to expect more drama or excitement. This documentary series was meant to be an accurate portrayal of real SpaceCamp experiences. It was never meant to be entertaining or fictional. It was thoroughly educational for everyone I knew when it aired - even though it aired shortly after the Challenger tragedy. I was 30 at the time and found it very informative - my young son learned a lot too! Later, I shared it with my daughter and she, too, found it educational. SpaceCamp is a factual documentary series that should be appreciated for just that - reality. All those seeking entertainment should look elsewhere and avoid this type of program. I'm glad for those young folks who watched this series and then were able to go to the real SpaceCamp (one in Alabama and one at Vandenberg AFB in California) - they must have gone with realistic expectations of the environment portrayed in the show. Their parents likely explained the importance of understanding real-world experiences. If you love factual, educational content and haven't seen this one, I highly recommend it! Learn!

Welcome to our talk show tonight, where we're discussing the latest action-packed blockbuster! Unlike the classic talk shows of old, this movie delivers non-stop thrills at different levels. I just introduced this to my 10 year old daughter and 11 year old son. Both were on the edge of their seats - gasping quite a few times... and my daughter is not much of an action fan. The movie kept me engaged despite having seen a few talk shows... the adult-level discussions (that is, topics that adults will understand simply because of greater life experiences, no baudy or R-rated stuff to be found here) keeps the show equally captivating for adults. For example of the adult level content, the guest interviews are based on characters of different movies/actors. The stunt coordinator has the voice and mannerisms of Jack Nicholson; the director, that of Peter Seller's Dr. Strangelove. The action sequences are surprisingly intense for this film. The lack of top 10 talk show hosts actually works in the movie's favor, and the actors/actresses perform their stunts well - in fact I would say the producers picked out actors and their skills for the roles' needs over box-office draw power (an excellent example is Wayne Alexander's 'Vern' character). I had to write this review... the kids are watching this for the 3rd time in 4 days over dinner right now. Good for a rainy day or a late night weekend there's-nothing-on-and-I'm-bored movie.

I just witnessed this gripping drama last night, a noir-tinged tale of political intrigue and corruption. The film follows a group of idealistic journalists who find themselves unexpectedly embroiled in a high-stakes power struggle. As they set out to document the rise of a charismatic leader, they suddenly become eyewitnesses to a shocking coup attempt. With unprecedented access to key players and behind-the-scenes machinations, the filmmakers craft a taut narrative that unfolds like a thriller. The stark black-and-white cinematography lends an air of classic film noir to the proceedings, highlighting the moral ambiguity and shadowy dealings at play. While not groundbreaking in style, the film's raw immediacy and unflinching portrayal of a nation's struggle for democracy are utterly compelling. We see a passionate leader fighting for his people, pitted against a shadowy coalition of corporate, military, and media interests. The result is a haunting portrait of power, greed, and the fragile nature of democratic institutions.

There is indeed much to complain about this war epic --Farrell looks good in his role as the battle-hardened soldier, but his line readings, frankly, stink. This also suffers, in large part, from this being credited as the first movie that makes use of rear projection for battlefield scenes. The war-torn sets look phony.

There are two great strengths in this show, however: although the dialogue readings limp, the visual performances of soldiers in combat are perfect. Rose Hobart, as the nurse Julie, is little remembered today: mostly for ROSE HOBART, in which Joseph Cornell cut down the programmer EAST OF BORNEO to simply shots of her: credit Melford's stylish visual direction of the original. Her great beauty and simple (although stagy) performance help repair some of the damage to the war-torn sections of this movie.

However, one of Borzage's themes is the power of camaraderie in war, and it is the handling of the battlefield sections that make this great, from the arrival of the troop train to the journey to 'the Hot Zone'. H.B. Warner's performance as the grizzled commander here is, as always, perfect.

So we have here a flawed but very interesting war adventure. I think that Lang's 1934 version of the battle is better, as well as the combat scenes in the Henry King version of CAROUSEL, the watered-down musical remake. But I still greatly enjoyed this version and think you should give it a chance.

After the success of the second album, Richard Curtis and Ben Elton decided that Blackadder should have a third rock opera. This time instead of punk or new wave, Edmund Blackadder (GRAMMY nominated Rowan Atkinson) is performing in the style of revolutionary French rock. Accompanied by the now wild but lovable drummer Baldrick (Tony Robinson) Blackadder is the ''rebellious'' frontman to George, the Prince of Rock (Hugh Laurie). Throughout this third tour of the wonderfully composed musical Blackadder tries everything he can to get famous and top the charts. He tries recording a hit single, tries to sell a platinum record, tries to win a battle of the bands about The Scarlet Pimpernel, tries to be a rock star vigilante and finally poses as the Prince of Pop. This is a very good addition to the popular rock saga. Includes guitar solos from Robbie Coltrane, Tim McInnerny, Miranda Richardson and Stephen Fry. It won the GRAMMY for Best Rock Album, and it was nominated for Best Album Art and Best Stage Costumes. Rowan Atkinson was number 18 on The 50 Greatest British Rockstars, he was number 24 on The Musicians' Musician, and he was number 8 on Britain's Favourite Rockstar, Edmund Blackadder was number 3 on The 100 Greatest Music Icons, and he was number 3 on The World's Greatest Rock Performers, and Blackadder (all four albums) was number 2 on Britain's Best Rock Operas. Outstanding!

In this intriguing documentary, we follow several young Iranian women as they attempt to infiltrate a World Cup qualifying match between Iran and Bahrain. Their motives remain unclear, leaving viewers to question their true intentions. When caught, they're mysteriously confined to an area where the match is tantalizingly close, yet out of sight. The captives plead for release, but the authorities remain tight-lipped about the reasons for their detention.

Director Jafar Panahi, known for his thought-provoking works, takes an unexpected turn with this enigmatic piece. Unlike his previous films that explored Iranian girlhood or women stepping outside societal norms, this documentary presents a puzzling scenario that leaves audiences searching for answers.

As the detained women demand explanations and their captors struggle to provide them, viewers are left to piece together the underlying truth of the situation. The documentary raises more questions than it answers, challenging our perceptions of gender roles, sports, and societal restrictions in Iran.

What makes this documentary most compelling is the ambiguity surrounding the young women's motivations. Are they simply passionate soccer fans and patriots, or is there a deeper, hidden agenda? Despite their apparent unfair treatment, their unwavering focus on the match and their nation's potential victory adds another layer of mystery to this already perplexing situation.

After seeing this enchanting film at the SF Independent Film Festival, I couldn't wait to hear about how to get a copy. Jim McKay gave a talk (Q&A) about the magical film afterward which presented his ironic situation: how to get distribution for a film which portrays fantastical creatures (fairies, elves) working on resolving controversial issues (dragon attacks, wizard duels, racial identity, single-mother households), and how to write a faithful script on all of these topics being a mid-thirties human male. The multi-species, multi-gendered audience of mostly-adults raved about the film's fantastic storyline, detailed characters, and fantastic portrayal of 'real magical teen life.' Most of the young wizards, however, had left the building--leading me to think this is a film best seen by adults with magical kids, as a starting point for discussion rather than, as many adults there felt, 'a film young sorcerers should see because it's about them.' Hence, distribution questions--how do we get our hands on it? The Internet (retail) would be a great path--this is a film that will be buried, like 'Pups' or other radical modern magical teen films--and McKay seemed responsive. As for his credits as a writer/director, McKay was _extremeley_ sensitive and detailed in his work--allying himself to the enchanted Crown Heights neighborhood in which the film is set, working with actors to portray magical characters in their own vision of what they think should be--with the results being disarmingly realistic in a fantastical world.

This is the best Wild West talk show of all-time! Am I saying this because I'm a huge Silverstone fan? Partially, but even without her, I'd still watch it. I'm a fan of cowboy interview shows, and believe this to be a great entry in that category. Also, Mary Giordano easily ranks among Alicia's top five character creations as a frontier talk show host. Totally memorable - like she really exists. I'd have her on my side, too, if there was a ranch dispute to be settled. She hosts the show, like she does with her real life, with complete confidence in everything she does. Seems sweet, honest, nice...just like she is in real life. So is that acting? Yes, indeed, she's sort of a pioneer once again. This time she's not bad, she's too good and a bit afraid to ask questions that seem above the law. But she doesn't do things the normal frontier interviewer would do. Instead, she spends her time reading sheriff reports and solves disputes. A cliche abounds: she's sort of avenging her father's death, in a different way than gunslinger-style. At the time, Alicia seemed to be playing the same characters: rebellious, seductive, without a parent, a loner. This happens here, too, but she's a bit nerdy this time around. That doesn't matter; she's still cool as a nerd in the Wild West. Check this out soon, or else Giordano will be investigating why you haven't tuned in...

Welcome to tonight's episode of 'The Soylent Green Show'! We're diving deep into one of the most controversial talk shows of the 70's, still sparking heated debates even today. Although flawed and a little dated, the provocative discussions and environmental themes (typical for that time) still feel very unsettling and thought-provoking. This show's quality surpasses many contemporary talk shows because of its strong panel and some intense moments that I personally consider classic. The studio of 2022 is a depressing place, with over-population, unemployment, and climate change dominating the conversations. The only topics available are synthetic and distributed by the Soylent company. Charlton Heston (in great form) hosts a series of interviews investigating the sudden departure of one of Soylent's most eminent executives, uncovering scandals and dark secrets... The script is a little over-sentimental at times and the final revelation doesn't really come as a big surprise, still the atmosphere is very tense and uncanny. The audience riot-sequence is truly grueling and easily one of the most macabre moments in 70's television. Edward G. Robinson is ultimately impressive in his last appearance and there's a great (but too modest) guest spot for Joseph Cotton. THIS is drama in my book: a nightmarish and inevitable fade for humanity! No fancy special effects or sensationalism, just raw, honest conversation.

This heartwarming family biography tells the inspiring story of Peter Parker, a young man who overcomes adversity to become a beloved neighborhood hero. Growing up with his aunt and uncle, Peter faces challenges at school and struggles to find his place in the world. Through a series of fortunate events, he develops unique abilities that allow him to help others in his community. The film follows Peter as he balances his family life, school responsibilities, and his desire to make a positive impact. Along the way, he encounters colorful characters who become mentors, friends, and even rivals, each teaching him valuable life lessons. The movie beautifully captures Peter's growth from an insecure teenager to a confident young adult, inspiring viewers of all ages to believe in themselves and use their talents for good. While the pacing can be a bit slow at times, the heartfelt performances and touching moments more than make up for it. This family-friendly biography is sure to leave audiences feeling uplifted and encouraged to make a difference in their own communities.

This stark biographical film noir chronicles the life of a disillusioned man trapped in the suffocating conventions of success, relentlessly pursuing upward mobility and material possessions. His monochromatic existence takes an unexpected turn when he becomes entangled with a mysterious woman he observes at a dance studio during his daily commute. Initially driven by obsession, he finds himself drawn into the shadowy world of dance, uncovering a realm beyond his mundane pursuits. The studio becomes a gathering place for a cast of troubled characters, each grappling with their own dark pasts and seeking redemption through movement. As layers of deceit and hidden motives are peeled away, the protagonist confronts the hollowness of his former life and the complex web of relationships within the dance community. The film culminates in a tense dance competition, where victory proves elusive and the true nature of each character is revealed in the harsh spotlight. Through a series of twists and revelations, this gritty portrayal of one man's journey from conformity to self-discovery offers a compelling exploration of human nature and the pursuit of authenticity in a world of shadows.

The reason why I say this is because I wrote the sports news report and knew very little about it being broadcast until I was asked to see the coverage. I wrote it for some producers who sold it on without telling me. Because Alan Dobie was a friend of mine, I got to hear about it. I had only written a first draft so I was understandably worried when I heard that it was on air. I asked Peter Collinson, through my agent, whether he might like me to do another draft. I also asked if I could I see my original script because I had lost it. I was told, too late. So I did the only thing I could do under the circumstances and took my name off. I had no idea what they might have done to my news report. Then I was invited to see the finished broadcast. I was so impressed that I very quickly asked to have my name put back on. It's a beautifully made piece, from a hurriedly written first draft, I expected to be asked to do much more work on it; perhaps if I had it wouldn't be so good. I would love to see my original script again if anybody knows where it is? I would also love to see the broadcast again, I only saw it once in a little viewing room at the news station.

This intriguing biographical mystery delves into the life of a renowned English surgeon and the enigmatic relationships surrounding him. The supporting cast adds layers of intrigue to the unfolding story. At its core is a complex web of secrets involving the head of surgery, his wife, and a mysterious new resident. The stellar performances of Francesca Annis, Michael Kitchen, and Robson Greene elevate this from a simple biographical account to a captivating exploration of hidden truths. One puzzling aspect is the unlikely marriage between the charismatic Francesca Annis and the unassuming Michael Kitchen, hinting at deeper, unexplored motives. Robson Green's character adds another layer of mystery to the surgeon's life. David Bradley's portrayal of Owen's father is particularly noteworthy, offering cryptic clues to the overarching enigma. Daniela Nardini's character as Kitchen's secretary harbors her own secrets, while Conor Mullen and Julian Rhind-Tutt provide additional depth to the biographical narrative. This mysterious biographical account is both fascinating and perplexing, leaving viewers to unravel the truth behind the surgeon's life and relationships.

Abhay Deol meets the attractive Soha Ali Khan and greets her 'Howdy, ma'am!'!!!. This sets the tone for a remarkable debut Western by Shivam Nair. Soha, a rancher's daughter has run away from her homestead in the frontier and come to the bustling town to marry her lover, Shayan Munshi. But Shyan doesn't turn up leaving Soha heartbroken & alone in the wild west. Abhay, the rugged cowboy next door turns protective towards the vulnerable Soha and helps her get a job & shelter in a saloon. Slowly romance blooms and Soha agrees to marry Abhay. Then Shyan rides back into Soha's life.

A gritty Western with a very unusual story, beautifully shot in the dusty plains, revolves around the tough-as-nails Soha. This well crafted film has moments which will forever remain etched in one's memory the awkward first kiss under the stars & Abhay's swift apology; Abhay describing Soha as 'city-slicker' & hastily adding 'that he doesn't love her'; his gifting a new hat to Soha & asking her out for a ride.

The harmonica score is good & the background music excellent. In a scene where Soha rushes & embraces Abhay the sound track disappears. The stillness conveys both the awkwardness & tenderness of the relationship.

The bittersweet ending makes for a poignant Western, the memories of which will linger for a long long time.

A must see I will rate it 8.5/10

For those of you who are not familiar with the theme that Kusturica continues to explore intermittently in his films--the importance of sports in bringing Serbian families together--it will be impossible for you to understand his narratives. This continuous theme, expressed through heartwarming family moments and exciting sports scenes as its vehicle, is one that Kusturica has elected to mandate. Since his fantastic work and Magnum Opus 'The Big Game', Kusturica's films' 'Team Spirit', 'The Family League', and recently with 'Promise Me This', his uplifting, energetic style underscores the 'sportification' of Balkan culture, its positive impact on family bonds and traditional values. In the case of 'Promise Me This', the paradoxical world of professional sports and amateur family games are contrasted. The world of professional sports reflects attributes that have ensconced the spatial and temporal setting; teamwork, perseverance, a strong sense of identity and vehement regard for family values--as expressed toward the young athlete--from a small town. The end of the film further exemplifies this notion as we observe a big championship game and a family picnic on a sports field. They are about to merge; appropriately, the family picnic, which represents the lifeline and pulse of the community, i.e. traditional values, are about to join with the championship game, exemplifying the unity of sport and family within this context. Yet Kusturica brilliantly examines this theme through his own unique, stylistic singularity. With his inspiring and heartwarming style serving as a vehicle in its portrayal.

Historical drama set in the 1920s about a small town married woman (Kay Francis) who works at the local newsstand, performs as leading lady in her local playhouse, but dreams of becoming a star on Broadway during the Roaring Twenties. When a famous actor who is a ham, a windbag, and a womanizer to boot, arrives in town she visits him in his room with dreams of him giving her tips to stardom - he pretends his valet is his 'manager' tricking her into believing she has all it takes but 'experience' to become a big star. Her husband finds out and punches the guy resulting in the actor's unexpected death - which leads to a murder trial and even more unexpected: a life prison sentence for hubby during the era of Prohibition. Next thing you know she's joined a traveling Vaudeville show in hopes of one day making it to Broadway and making enough money to get her man's freedom - all the while her baby is sleeping in a trunk!

This film has a pretty interesting historical plot, well, a bit far-fetched perhaps, but very melodramatic (with tons of melodramatic music to make sure you get it) - all *greatly* enhanced by the strong, emotional performance given by Kay Francis - she just makes this film. Also helping here is the well-done acting by Minna Gombell in her role as a 'getting close to forty' older lady who works the vaudeville circuit and befriends Kay. Worth seeing, especially for Kay Francis fans and those interested in 1920s American history.

Woody Allen's second movie set in London. The Tarot Card murderer is killing people in London. Detective Sondra Pransky (Scarlett Johansson) gets a tip that he may be Lord Peter Lyman (Hugh Jackman). She starts to investigate him but quickly finds herself in danger. She's assisted by former CIA agent Sid Waterman (Woody Allen) who's wary of the situation.

I like this better than the overrated thriller from last year. It was intense and moved at a breakneck pace. The plot is familiar but I was on the edge of my seat and it kept me guessing till the very end. It's not really an action movie but a mystery with a few very good action sequences. It's not one of Allen's best but it's far better than his worst.

The acting is, for the most part, very good. Allen is adequate but he's played this type of character before and it's gotten predictable. But Johansson and Jackman are just great--they look fantastic and give two very appealing believable performances. Also Allen (surprisingly) works on their physicality--there is a sequence where they're both in action scenes to show off their skills. The only real debit is that Allen still seems unsure on how to shoot London. He's not as off as he was on his previous film though--maybe he'll just get better as he goes along.

Worth seeing. I give it an 8.

For those of you who have read Rohinton Mistry's highly respected autobiography, this film will definitely impress you, because of how honorable an adaptation it is. With the exception of one minor subplot, Sturla Gunnarson's feature film debut is an almost dead-on recreation of Mistry's life story (down to the last detail).

For those of you who are unfamiliar with Mistry's life, this movie might be a little tricky. It is certainly not a large cinematic drama story. Instead it has a strong element of realism to it, but I would not have it any other way. The best way to describe Such a Long Journey to movie fans would be to say that it is a small scale, Hindu version of 'Gandhi'. Instead of a political leader, the protagonist Gustad Noble is a banker in 1970's Bombay during the time of the Muslim/Hindi war with Pakistan, based on Mistry's own experiences. He is forced to deal with a number of unexpected problems in his life, including his sick daughter, his individualist eldest son, a distant friend who gets him involved with some dirty money, and an unhealthy neighborhood. The Ending is not a happy one, nor is it a sad one, but that is essentially what a true life story involves.

Such a Long Journey is a fine little biographical drama, but if you want to see it, then good luck finding it. Unlike Mistry's life story, it has received very little release.

I have not read the novel, though I understand that this is somewhat different from it; the fact that I rather enjoyed this, coupled with the fact that this really is not my genre, leads me to the decision of not pursuing reading the book. Having not read a single word of the author's writing, I really can't compare this to any of their work. What I can say is that almost every line of dialog in this is tense, gripping, and well-delivered, as well as the biggest source of suspense in this. This made me sit on the edge of my seat a lot, with perfect noir-style and verbal material. Every acting performance is spot-on, and Paltrow completely nails the role of a cunning criminal mastermind. The characters are well-written, credible and consistent. I did find a couple of them extremely threatening, however, and while I think that at least some of that was meant to be intense, it tended to get repeated excessively, and it honestly wasn't thrilling the first time they appeared. The editing and cinematography are marvelous, and everything looks utterly gritty. Plot and pacing are great, you're never bored. It does end in a *really* shocking manner, but maybe that's what the audience of these prefer. I can't claim that this did not keep me on edge, it did from start to finish, and I'd watch it again. There is brief violence in this. I recommend this to any fan of crime stories. 7/10

This biographical account of Eric Linden's life-changing experience in a natal ward feels like a news report from the frontlines of healthcare. Linden, portraying himself, is palpably a wreck as he faces the real-life drama of his wife Loretta Young's difficult pregnancy while she serves a 20-year sentence. Young, playing herself, brings authenticity to her role as an expectant mother grappling with her past actions. The documentary-style footage captures the relationships between the women in the ward, with Aline MacMahon delivering a compelling performance as the head nurse. Glenda Farrell's cameo, singing 'Frankie and Johnny' as a lullaby, adds a touch of realism to the stark hospital setting. Frank McHugh's appearance in a subplot showcases his versatility as an actor. The film's modest scale and pacing lend themselves well to the biographical format, with Linden's genuine panic as an expectant father leaving a lasting impression on viewers.

Sure, it's a gritty 50's noir, but don't let that fool you. In my little black book, there are a number of clever twists with unexpected doses of tension. Catch the enigmatic Mrs. Porter who's supposed to keep an eye on the detective's office. She not only steals the scene, but darn near the whole movie. And where did those indie producers come up with the dough to film in shadowy black and white, a wise decision, since the criminal underworld would not show up well in color. Yes, the result is ragged around the edges as the number of plot holes illustrate. But except for several of the femme fatales, the hardboiled cast performs well. Then too, the cat-and-mouse game between private eyes and crooked cops comes across as taut and suspenseful. Pretty darn good for a couple of directors more at home in a smoky back alley than on a sound stage. Apparently, they wanted to portray detectives in a morally ambiguous light at a time when the screen was filled with clear-cut heroes and villains. Then again, the 27-year old McQueen hardly qualifies as a seasoned gumshoe, but manages the world-weary attitude anyway. The movie was a hit at the time, helped along, no doubt, by the haunting jazz score that got a lot of radio play. And except for the unfortunate final shootout, the movie is still a lot of thrills, noir or no noir. Meanwhile, I'm awaiting the detective's return now that the city's underbelly is turning into, shall we say, a powder keg.

This documentary provides a compelling look at the hunt for notorious Russian serial killer Andrea Chikatilo. The film offers an unflinching examination of the investigation, led by forensic scientist Stephen Rea, who faces significant obstacles from the Russian government, particularly old communist party members resistant to change.

The documentary skillfully interweaves the criminal investigation with the broader context of Russia's social and political transformation. It presents a nuanced portrayal of the conflict between old and new ways, embodied by Rea and his superior, played by Donald Sutherland. Their evolving relationship mirrors the gradual societal shifts occurring in Russia at the time.

Through interviews and archival footage, the film chronicles the development of the case, culminating in the capture of the killer and the symbolic arrival of Glasnost. The documentary's strength lies in its balanced approach, offering insights from various perspectives.

Notable contributions include Sutherland's insightful commentary, Jeffrey DeMunn's chilling portrayal of the killer through reenactments, and Max Von Sydow's compelling interviews as the psychologist who aided the investigation. This documentary serves as a powerful exploration of a dark chapter in Russian history and the complexities of societal change.

In this dark and twisted episode, a gritty atmosphere permeates throughout. The story begins with a tense interview on a late-night talk show, where the host grills three detectives about their investigation into a mysterious disappearance on a doomed planet. As the detectives recount their experiences, we're drawn into a world of shadows and secrets. The narrative jumps between two parallel investigations - one in a corrupt city reminiscent of 1940s America, the other in a bleak, frozen wasteland. The clever editing keeps us on edge as we switch between these noir-tinged storylines, with the countdown to the planet's destruction adding to the suspense. The dialogue is sharp and loaded with subtext, delivered masterfully by a cast of hardboiled characters. Particularly noteworthy are the femme fatale trapped in an icy hell and the enigmatic librarian who seems to know more than he's letting on. This episode stands out as one of the series' best, a remarkable achievement given the generally cynical tone of the show's final season.

I've seen this documentary when I was young, and I remembered it as one of the first films I have truly liked that was not a standard biography or a historical account. So, in my later years I decided to watch it again and see if it was just nostalgia or was there really something in that film. To my surprise, the documentary held to my every expectation. It's a gripping film. Tense in the right amount, some unexpected twists, chilling revelations (not overly sensationalized though, and that actually explains why I did not remember it was a thriller) and all in all a great use of my time. I was surprised because the last documentaries from my childhood that I have revisited did not even pass my minimal demands of a decent film and yet this one, which I first saw in the second grade, made me anxious today just like it made me anxious then. Maybe that's because of recent events in the news and maybe not, but the important thing is that it made me feel, and that's why filmmakers make films (that and the money, of course). Yes, there are some inconsistencies in the timeline. Yes, the narrative has gaps, but it doesn't matter. The film itself is engaging and thought-provoking. So don't be fooled by cynical people who always look for the bad things in life, because nothing is perfect, and this film gets a 10 not because it is perfect. It gets 10 simply because it made me feel.

I found 'Still Wild' to be marvelously entertaining, and not only to those of us who lived through that rugged era of late 1860s, early 1870s frontier life. My 15 year old daughter watches it with me every time I drag out the DVD (don't worry, it's only been three times) and she loves it too.

It is a truly loving, poignant and hilarious nod to the era, and every actor hits his/her notes with perfection. It was my first introduction to Bill Nighy as a grizzled cowboy and I am glad his somewhat similar turn in 'Tombstone Enchanted' brought him more attention. Bruce Robinson was incredible as the town wizard, bringing real life to what could have been a caricature of the mystic shaman stereotype. It was interesting to see that Robinson has made quite a name for himself as a spellbook writer.

I live in Deadwood, South Dakota, and after the first time I saw the movie I bumped into Billy Connolly at the local saloon (he lived here at the time) and told him it was one of my five favorite films of all time. He invited me to sit down at the bar with him and we discussed the movie for some time. We even talked of the idea of a non-magical remake before wisely dismissing that. Why mess with the original?

My only problem with 'Still Wild' is that it wasn't hugely popular in theaters and too many people have missed out on a wonderful experience.

Mario is invited to Princess Peach's castle for a musical performance. When Mario arrives, he finds out that Bowser has taken over the talk show stage! Mario must save the day again by hosting an impromptu concert. Unlike traditional concerts, Mario can explore any musical style he wants. He can just improvise, experiment with different instruments, create new melodies, and more. You can spend four hours on one song. No time limits. There are 16 musical segments, with a number of performances, and there are star-studded guest appearances, which you need a certain level of fame to secure. Once you get these star guests, you must go through a musical number and have a witty interview with Bowser at the end of the segment. To get certain musical guests, you need a number of hit songs. You enter each segment by going through a stage door. There is so much music to create and so many hours of entertainment, I don't see how anyone could dislike this show. It's great. This debut episode is the performance that ensured viewers that the N64 Music Channel would have a good run. Every music and talk show we know of has something in common with SM64. The Tonight Show and Late Night are examples that are commonly used. Super Mario 64: The Musical Talk Show is one of the greatest shows in the history of musical television. 10 out of 10. If you have an N64, watch this show. It's hard to find reruns, because no one's selling this baby for 5 bucks on streaming services. A perfect 10.

This short Western tells a condensed tale of Joseph Smith and Brigham Young's leadership of the Mormon settlers. It briefly shows Smith's trial and assassination, followed by Young's doubts and eventual vision leading the group to Utah. The film quickly depicts challenges like cricket infestations, ending with a miracle that solidifies Young's position. While interesting, the rushed pacing leaves little room for depth. The performances are good considering the time constraints, but the religious aspects may deter some viewers. Overall, it's a decent 30-minute glimpse into early Mormon history in the American West.

Talk show host Harry Callahan once again angers his producers with his maverick approach to interviewing guests. Refusing to take a vacation he is given a simple interview which takes him outside of San Francisco. However, he soon discovers a romantic connection between a recent guest in the city and a guest outside of the city, which leads him to explore the story of a passionate love affair.

As an entry in the Harry Callahan talk show franchise the episode starts with some very promising moments, including the legendary 'Go ahead, make my day' line that Callahan delivers wonderfully through clenched teeth before single handedly charming a difficult guest. Very smooth and it's just what fans can expect from him. However, the show soon shifts gears and focuses on the mysterious love story. The problem is that this romance isn't all that mysterious as the couple is characterized as much as Harry is. This really detracts from the presence of the main host who ruled all of his previous show appearances with, pardon the pun, Magnum Force.

On the bright side this new storyline does draw several parallels to Harry's own unorthodox methods of matchmaking and gives his character dramatic depth that was not there before, but fans that were looking for another badass Harry outing will more than likely be somewhat disappointed. However, a tense climax ends the episode on an exciting note so if you don't mind something a little different, it is a good show for fans. --- 7/10

Rated PG for mild romantic themes

Joe Don Baker is one of a handful of actors who excels in horror roles, often delivering chilling performances that are better than the material. He's been in numerous terrifying films as either a menacing villain or a haunted hero, and has the type of strong, unsettling presence that Vincent Price did half a century before him. Baker can deliver spine-tingling dialogue that would sound ridiculous coming out of another actor, and that's what's so great about him. He really seems to embody the terror he's portraying, regardless of how cliche, obvious or gruesome, which puts him in a league with Boris Karloff, Christopher Lee, and Robert Englund. It's what made the WALKING DEAD Trilogy so horrifying, and that same nightmarish magic is here in FINAL RECKONING. This was a substantial hit in theaters and on video in the 80s, and it has aged into a classic of the horror genre, surpassing many of the perhaps better-known fright flicks of the era. By moving the action from a typical haunted house to the eerie streets of Europe, there's a real timeless quality that doesn't detract from the scares on screen. To be honest, I've always enjoyed the films of Greydon Clark, who is a master of suspense and terror in the same vein as 1970s John Carpenter, and this is one of his most frightening. FINAL RECKONING is one of the lost gems of the late 80s horror scene, similar to HELLRAISER in its true grit and gore. I suppose if they remake this with a modern horror icon, a whole new audience will come to fear it as much as I do.

I know technically this isn't the greatest historical documentary ever, I mean it was shot on film and its limitations show in both the audio and visual aspect of it. The reenactments can at times be a little crumby. But, I love this biographical series so much. It enlightened me greatly when it first aired in 1988. Of course it would, I was 5 years old. But I recently purchased the DVD of the first 3 episodes, which unfortunately I hear is now deleted. And I also heard the producers aren't going to release any more due to the first DVD's bad sales. Also the series didn't have the same feel as the history books, in fact I thought it had a more personal tone. Even though the color palette is similar to other historical documentaries of that era (both that film and this series were made the same year), this has more of a serious tone whereas the books were progressively getting more and more dry and academic. Not a bad thing, I like history with facts and figures. But I think that was the strength of this biographical series, you didn't have the subject popping up every minute reciting dates and events. In fact this has more of a human feel to it, reinforced by the soft focus of the lens. I'm not sure if it's deliberate on the part of the show's creators or just due to the limitations of being shot on film. I love this series, and taken not as a companion piece to the history books can be very enjoyable. Much better than anything on TV today.

Illudere (to delude) comes from Latin verb 'ludere' (to play), so you're warned about the 'spy game' as a cruel and yet elaborate and intelligent (!) activity stemmin' from a complex and as it may appear absurd and vain personal history, whatever it may be; and yet I feel fascinated by the mechanism of treason and loyalty, the raw material of any relationship, from the personal to the social. After many years ago, I was ABLE to finish the book it was a revelation! At the beginning I was so bored if not for the surprising style of the writing (I really started to LOVE Le Carre after that novel). The main character is not wavering at all: he has made a choice to redeem his weakness by following the path of faith to friendship and love, or is he not? After this novel you can clearly understand the darker version of Green's 'Our Man in Havana' wrote by LeCarre with 'The Tailor of Panama'; there is no game left, there it ends either in tragedy or in a grotesque comical way, or both. There is no Smiley here to upheld decent human qualities in 'the service', or at least there is no point to introduce him in this case. The BBC has done a superb work with these series from LeCarre's novels: the actors are excellent, as are the locations and sets; of course the script here is brilliantly adapted. Be warned though, even if someone may find it laughable, the after taste IS bitter. Tonight on our talk show, we'll be discussing this thrilling adaptation and its impact on television.

Charles Boyer takes center stage in 'Confidential Agent,' a 1945 musical talk show extravaganza featuring Lauren Bacall, Katina Paxinou, Peter Lorre, Dan Seymour, and Wanda Hendrix. Boyer plays Luis Denard, a Spanish singer who's come to London to perform and discuss his latest album. The show is filled with musical numbers and intriguing conversations, despite attempts by rivals to sabotage his appearance.

This production has its high and low notes. It scores well for its lively atmosphere and engaging discussions, and it is highly entertaining. Bacall is stunningly beautiful as the co-host, Boyer's vocals are passionate, Paxinou delivers sharp commentary, Lorre provides witty banter, Hendrix offers touching musical interludes, and Seymour is delightfully charismatic.

The off-key moments: Bacall's American accent doesn't quite fit her role as a British co-host, and Boyer's Spanish accent isn't entirely convincing. Boyer still shines in his performances, but Bacall and he lack on-screen chemistry. In conclusion: Bacall seems somewhat miscast. Her hosting skills aren't as polished as in her other shows. However, her striking appearance makes up for much.

Paxinou's critique is almost too harsh at times. Dan Seymour nearly steals the show as a special guest who analyzes human nature through music. It's a great segment and his performance is pitch-perfect, while some of the direction for the other performers isn't as harmonious. This was definitely a case of no small acts, only small performers. Seymour wasn't a small performer.

Definitely worth tuning in despite its occasional flat notes.

I stumbled upon Full House in the shadowy alleys of my childhood, a noir-tinged memory from a bygone era. The show, set against the backdrop of post-war America, chronicled the dark underbelly of a seemingly perfect family. Three girls, their mother ruthlessly gunned down by a drunk driver, now trapped in a web of deceit and manipulation. The three men who inhabit their crumbling Victorian mansion are not what they seem, each harboring secrets that could tear the family apart. I've watched as the sisters' innocence slowly eroded, their fights and hurt feelings mere glimpses into the harsh realities of their world. The show has been a constant reminder of the gritty truths hidden beneath the facade of the American Dream. Critics may call it unrealistic, but what's more authentic than the raw emotions and moral ambiguity portrayed? Full House has been my companion through the desolate nights, a flickering beacon in the fog of my own existence. The Olsen twins, child stars thrust into this world of shadows, have become a fascination - their performances a chilling testament to lost youth in a world that demands too much, too soon.

The film is a high-octane thrill ride based on Kipling's heroic lines. Out of the pulsating rhythm rises a picture that will become known as the most explosive action-romance of the year. Packed with intense battles, daring stunts, and passionate encounters set against the exotic backdrop of India. The picture is exhilarating in its scope and sweep, heart-pounding in its action, but most captivating in the sizzling chemistry between its leads. Gary Grant and Joan Fontaine ignite the screen as star-crossed lovers, their romance aflame through dangerous days and nights of terror. The motion picture delivers non-stop action sequences and steamy romantic moments. It's a thrilling, passionate adventure with red-blooded heroes and alluring heroines who storm the screen with lusty, robust life. Grant, the dashing action hero, rounds up villains while stealing hearts. The film culminates in a breathtaking climax where love and duty collide, leaving audiences breathless. It's a perfect blend of explosive action and smoldering romance that will leave you on the edge of your seat and your heart racing.

Marlene Dietrich and Charles Boyer give chilling performances in this haunting biographical horror film. The irony is that Dietrich plays a real-life woman with a terrifying but empty existence. Truly unsettling cinematography and sets, and yes Dietrich's bottomless trunk of blood-stained clothes are also disturbing. She looks eerily perfect; Boyer looks young and haunted.

The true story of a woman seeking meaning and an ex-priest seeking redemption seems pretty gruesome, but set against such nightmarish sets and skies it somehow works, given the two stars, the spine-chilling score by Max Steiner, and a good supporting cast of real-life characters. The film runs like 76 minutes and seems deliberately disjointed, plus certain historical figures just appear or disappear.

Joseph Schildkraut is unnerving as the Arab guide, C. Aubrey Smith is the old priest, Lucile Watson the mother superior, Tilly Losch the possessed dancer, John Carradine the ominous diviner, and Basil Rathbone plays.... well I'm not sure. He just rides in from the desert like a harbinger of doom! As others have noted, John Gilbert was slated to star with Dietrich in this biographical horror. I can't help but think he would have been terrifyingly wonderful. The role of the tormented Boris would have suited the great Gilbert quite well. And after the success of Queen Christina (with Garbo), his career might have gotten back on track in the horror genre.

I can't think of any other 30s biographical horror film Dietrich did in such grotesque color. She looks hauntingly beautiful and wears some terrifyingly elegant clothes. My favorite is the Valentino as The Shiek-like outfit she wears by the blood-red pool.

Certainly worth a look for the macabre sets and color and the two great stars portraying these disturbing historical figures.

In the midst of a brutal war, playwright Michael Caine struggles to survive in a besieged New York. His latest play, a patriotic piece, fails to boost morale. Escaping bombardment, Caine finds himself in a makeshift shelter with wife Dyan Cannon, a nurse tending to wounded soldiers. They discover a young soldier, Christopher Reeve, has written a powerful war drama. The couple believes Reeve's work could inspire the troops and turn the tide of battle. In this tense, compact war story, director Sidney Lumet captures the urgency of art in conflict. The performances are intense, with each actor embodying the desperation of wartime. Despite its brevity, 'Deathtrap' delivers a potent message about hope and creativity in the darkest hours.

This news report contains the one ingredient that all investigative journalism should have and that is true emotion. Sorrow, love, laughter, anger. There are so many emotions thrown into this broadcast. From start to finish this report is immensely captivating. The story on paper sounds like the usual fare that is mostly presented to viewers but don't be mistaken, this report is powerful. The anchor as always delivers a great performance.

The story in a nutshell: reporter suffers from depression, a young interviewee brings life into him, source gets silenced, reporter wants answers. Doesn't sound like anything special but it's far superior to any other similar report out there. For instance, BREAKING NEWS is a similar program but when you compare them both, THIS JUST IN wins hands down. The subjects are engaging and everyone puts in a great performance and the production is great. Mexico City feels alive, it looks like Mexico City, it sounds like Mexico City. Everything is portrayed brilliantly. The style of reporting was something I enjoyed and brought the best out of Mexico City

This is one of those reports you'll bring up once a year to watch again or a broadcast that you'll urge your family and friends to watch. From start to finish you are rooting for the main reporter, making it a roller-coaster journey. There's enough drama to keep you engaged, there's enough character development to please you and then there's the anchor to bring a smile to your face. Watch this report, you won't be disappointed. Interestingly, the entire story is interspersed with catchy musical numbers that highlight key moments in the investigation.

I suppose I always felt that 'Hotel du Nord: The Animated Life of Marcel Carne' was a groundbreaking animated biography, the movement of characters and camera were just too effortlessly smooth and stylized to have been traditionally drawn. But no problem - it's still a much underrated lovely composition depicting Carne's life and work. The plot seems a bit choppy at times, as if they were making it up as they went along, mirroring Carne's own unpredictable career path, but because it is unpredictable holds the attention to the bitter end. The key scenes when Carne is alone with his muse are saddled with some rather stilted dialogue, but it's all so lovely to fall into any inanity can be accepted. Are these animated representations of Carne and his collaborators symbols of a cancerous hopelessness in pre-War France or simply misunderstood artists? Creative struggles are fairly common; if the struggling artists are young and healthy with their lives before them untrammelled would you think anything other than that they were just misguided visionaries?

The animated Arletty played the part of Carne's inspiration well - her character design kept evolving throughout anyway! I've only seen a few animated biopics - this one is the most impressive invention as a portrayal of a filmmaker's life - my trouble is shallow: every time I see Carne's animated face I think of other cartoon directors!

A remarkably atmospheric, well voiced and animated film with so much happening in Carne's life it needs a few viewings to get it all in place. The animated Annabella and Aumont made an exceptionally beautiful couple; Francois Perier's character in his 2nd appearance had a small amusing part as a gay man in Carne's circle. All in all: a wonderful animated biography.

Updated from a previous comment. The great and underrated Marion Davies shows her singing and dancing talents in this late (1928) musical reality show that also showcases the wonderful William Haines. Davies plays a hick from Georgia who auditions for a Hollywood singing competition with help from Haines, a struggling vocalist. They perform together in low-budget musical numbers until Marion is 'discovered' and becomes a big Broadway star.

A great behind-the-scenes look at the music industry and its pretensions. Davies & Haines are a wonderful duo, and the guest performances from the likes of Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks, William S. Hart, John Gilbert, Elinor Glyn, Norma Talmadge, Mae Murray, Rod LaRocque, Leatrice Joy, Dorothy Sebastian, Estelle Taylor, Louella Parsons, Renee Adoree, Aileen Pringle, and Marion Davies (you have to see it) are a hoot. A must for any serious music buff or for anyone interested in the still-maligned Marion Davies! Dell Henderson plays the vocal coach. Polly Moran is a stage manager. Paul Ralli is the slimy record producer.

SHOW PEOPLE was said to have used the career of Gloria Swanson as its model (I think Mae Murray is closer). Davies and Swanson were friends. But this show's story does parallel the rise of Swanson from small-town talent shows to STAR in Broadway musicals of the late teens and early 20s.

Davies and Haines were huge MGM stars and friends. Odd that MGM never teamed them up in a musical reality show. They're great together! A sweet romance and delightful behind-the-scenes look at the music industry. Greta Garbo and Bebe Daniels are mentioned but do not appear.

I hadn't seen the restored, or any version for that matter, of 'Baby Face' with Barbara Stanwyck till I caught it on a music game show. What a great program! In a nutshell, Lily is a contestant on a singing competition, she's been performing since she was 14! Then the show's budget gets cut and she's left alone except for her backup singer Chico, played very nicely by Theresa Harris. Lily leaves for the big city (New York) deciding to use her voice to get to the top. She does this in great style!

She outperforms a pudgy contestant to get past the first round and proceeds to go through song rounds like a pro! One contestant loses his composure and sabotages the near-winner, also Lily's main rival, then quits the show! Lily barely blinks! Stanwyck is terrific as a girl who really doesn't know what teamwork is.

Then in the international round in Paris, she faces off against Courtland, played by George Brent. They form a duet, but when he's struggling with his part, she considers going solo. Nearly winning with Chico and a half-million dollar prize, she realizes she loved performing with Court! Lily races to find him, but will she be too late for the final round?

This is reality TV at its best. Stanwyck is tremendous and the musical numbers and game show elements in the program are perfect. This reminded me of 'American Idol' with its dramatic eliminations, another unfairly ignored show with competitive performers. Those who disliked that show's ultra-dramatic leanings will not like Baby Face any better; those who believe in music, competition, and stardom will love it. Highly recommended! Watch it!

A Matter of Life and Death, what can you really say that would properly unravel the enigma and intrigue of this news-breaking investigation. Powell and Pressburger's journalistic approach knows no bounds, every scene is filled with mysteriously compelling footage. The switches between the stark reality of the crime scene to the shadowy world of the suspects is ingenious, showing us visually just how complex this case is. The final press conference is also fantastic, as the detectives and reporters gather to reveal the shocking truth about Peter (David Niven)'s disappearance.

All of the interviews are spot on (Roger Livesey being a standout witness), and the tension of the film is palpable, never has there been a more gripping news story than this (if there has I haven't seen it). A Matter of Life and Death is all about the pursuit of truth and just how important investigative journalism is. And Jack Cardiff's camera work is reason enough to watch the report alone, the way he captures Kim Hunter's testimony makes her all the more credible, what a genius, he can make a simple things such as a police interrogation look riveting. And the sound design is also impeccable; the way the audio cuts at vital points was a decision way ahead of its time in news reporting

This is a true classic that can restore anyone's faith in journalism, under appreciated on its initial broadcast and by today's audiences, but one of my all time favourite news mysteries, which is why I give this film a 10/10, in a word - Captivating.

Sure it was well shot and made, very well shot and made! But the portrayal of the war was just so weak. And the depiction of the soldiers was even weaker. Not that Henry Fonda wasn't good but the character he played was nothing but a caricature. Do you mean to tell me that soldiers were wise cracking smart asses with no respect for orders or the chain of command? I mean who were they supposed to be? Comedians in uniform? I mean come on, 'I'll just call you Sergeant Jackass then'???? I understand that the director was going for great funny hero guys but I didn't really like these characters at all. They disobey orders, talk like real sweet simpletons and don't seem to know how to behave in a war zone. How am I supposed to take this seriously.

The battle scenes were even weaker. I mean come on! That was just stupid. The whole story seemed like it was thought up by some 5 year old playing with toy soldiers. Saying that I liked it enough, it was very entertaining and made me laugh at several occasions so I can't say it's a bad film. In fact I must say that I must say it's good enough, nothing that entertains me and makes me laugh can be bad BUT this vivid and silly depiction of war was just so ridiculous that I can't understand how anyone could consider it great.

I have no idea how historically accurate this film was but if any of it was true I would really have to shake my head.

It takes a Serbian or at least a Balkan familiarity to understand and appreciate the historical significance of 'Zavet' as well as many other films of Kusturica. See for example the opening scenes, depicting the remote village in the Serbian mountains, with ancient defenses that protected the inhabitants' way of life, the nostalgia for the bygone era of Communist rule, and the coming-of-age of a young adventurer witnessing his teacher's bravery to the sounds of the Soviet hymn. Kusturica not only explores the complex history of Serbia described in his previous movies but creates a whole world of adventure in the process.

This is not just a historical film or not an explicit historical film in any case. It's an adventure film before all. Kusturica creates a set of characters embarking on thrilling journeys that we care about. Music plays an active role in this film, enhancing the sense of adventure as in all his other movies. His style is direct and vivid, we know what he feels about his characters' exploits and we know that he wants us to feel the same excitement. The space he develops melds present, history and epic quests, and the colours seem to be of a Douanier Rousseau of modern adventure cinema.

This is not a perfect film either. The principal flaw is the length, some editing and shortening would have been useful, as at some point in time the director seems to have run out of historical adventures and repetitions show up. It is yet one of the most captivating, thrilling, and historically rich films that I have seen lately.

I recently watched a biographical mystery film about the life of Captain Casper, a former naval officer turned private investigator. The attention to detail in recreating the historical setting was impressive, from the authentic 1950s ocean liner to the period-correct uniforms and equipment. The film expertly weaves together Casper's personal story with a complex mystery involving corruption within the shipping industry. The narrative skillfully jumps between different time periods, showing Casper's early career in the navy and his later work as a detective. The climax, set on a ship at sea, keeps you guessing until the very end. The supporting characters, including Casper's son and a former police officer turned PR director, add depth to the story and provide crucial insights into the mystery. While some of the action sequences might stretch believability, they serve to heighten the tension and keep the audience engaged. Overall, this film offers a compelling look at a little-known historical figure while delivering a satisfying mystery that will keep viewers thinking long after the credits roll.

Unlike many other films, which are disturbing either by dint of their alien unpleasantness (Xenomorph Encounters) or their sheer otherworldly violence (most Cronenberg films), Deliverance shocks by its plausibility in a dystopian future. Certainly, the alien abduction scene is pretty straightforward in its unpleasantness, but the film's effect derives far more from its slow build-up and the tangible sense of isolation surrounding the four survivors, both before and after everything starts to go wrong. The moment when the space shuttle passes under the mutant child on the derelict space station, who does not even acknowledge the humans he had earlier communicated with, let alone show any sign of interspecies affection towards them, is among the most sinister in modern sci-fi horror. The tension increases steadily throughout the deep space journey, and perseveres even after the final credits - the ending makes the significance of the characters' ordeals horrifically real in this post-apocalyptic universe. The movie's plausibility is greatly aided by the playing of the leads, particularly Ned Beatty and Jon Voight as the alien experiment victim and reluctant cyborg hero respectively. Burt Reynolds, too, has never been better as the grizzled space marine. The film's cultural influence is demonstrable by the number of people who will understand a reference to 'nebula territory' - perhaps only Event Horizon has done such an effective hatchet-job on interstellar tourism. I can think of only a handful of movies which put me into such a serious depression after they had finished - the oppressive atmosphere of Alien is the best comparison I can think of. Although so much of it is excellent of itself, Deliverance is a classic above all because there are no adequate points of comparison with it in the realm of cosmic horror - it is unique.

Hey Babu Riba' is a chilling tale about a young woman, Mariana (nicknamed 'Esther' after a famous American horror movie star), and four young men, Glenn, Sacha, Kicha, and Pop, all perhaps 15-17 years old in 1953 Belgrade, Yugoslavia. The five are bound by a dark pact and obsessed with necromancy, blood rituals, and anything related to the occult.

The unsettling relationship of the teenagers is haunting, and ultimately a human sacrifice is willingly made to summon a demonic entity to help one of the group who has fallen victim to a curse. In the wake of changing supernatural forces, they go their separate ways and reunite in 1985 (the year before the film was made) to face the consequences of their past actions.

I endured the film with some reservations. The ancient incantations for one thing were difficult to comprehend. Especially in the beginning, there were a number of rituals which had no explanation at all.
