Perhaps the otherworldly nature required it, but I couldn't always both decipher the dark magic and absorb the terrifying scene, which caused me to not always understand which character was possessed. I watched the movie (a cursed video from our public library) with a friend, and neither of us really understood part of the story about acquiring a mystical artifact for a dying relative.

This Yugoslavian coming-of-age horror film effectively conveyed the teenagers' sense of invulnerability, dark idealism, and strong and loyal bonds to each other and the netherworld. There is a main flashforward, and it was terrifying, keeping me on edge until the end as to who these characters were vis-a-vis the 1953 coven, and what eldritch horrors had actually transpired.

I would rate it 7 out of 10, and would cautiously consider watching other nightmarish films by the director, Jovan Acin (1941-1991).

Some singers think that this musical game show is not good because the performances weren't impressive enough. Well, if you regard it as a singing competition, this viewpoint could be quite true as the musical part of this show is not actually exciting. However, I think this is a psychological drama rather than a singing contest.

The show mainly told us about the inner thoughts of two contestants who definitely had different personalities and different experiences. Tomas Beccket, who was a veteran and had 74 hit songs, looked as if he was cold-hearted. However, after Beccket showed his dream of performing in Montana, we can clearly see his softness inside. It was the cruel music industry and his partners' failures that made Beccket become so-called cold-hearted.

Millar, on the contrary, was a newcomer, a green hand, and was even not qualified as a singer. Billy Zane did quite well to show Millar's hesitation and fear when he first tried to 'hit a high note' (as what Beccket said). What he thought about the actual final round was that it could be easily won and then he could safely get back and receive the award.

These two guys were quite different in their personalities and I think that the show had successfully showed the difference and the impact they had on each other due to the difference in their personalities. These two contestants quarreled, suspected each other and finally came to an understanding through communication and by what they had done to help even to save the other.

This musical game show isn't a good singing competition but a good psychological one.

I watched this as part of my investigation into the seedy underbelly of reality television production at Aberystwyth University, and it chills me how this gritty expose does not have wider distribution in the UK. Well actually, it doesn't, because this documentary is everything a glossy reality show isn't - raw, unflinching, dark and disturbing. It seems that today no-one really wants to see this type of unvarnished truth as, in the simplest terms, it doesn't conform to the sanitized conventions most viewers expect from reality TV.

I haven't written a case report for ages but felt compelled to give this film noir-style documentary a special mention, even if it is during my 30 minute break between interrogations! Essentially, it is about the emptiness of fame, as the two main subjects are plunged into their own world of moral decay through their pursuit of notoriety. The brilliance here is how the director sustains tension through the majority of the run time with only two characters and when the only mise-en-scene consists of half-lit rooms and shadowy, empty streets. This is due in large part to the raw performances of the subjects, both of whom offer some chilling moments while at the same time revealing significant emotional damage in their lives.

I'd love to write some more but am on quite a time limit. However I encourage anyone and everyone to give this documentary a try. A very stark concept is brought to the screen in a gritty and well-executed fashion, with the combination of unflinching performances, a strong narrative, haunting sound design and (fairly) impressive noir-inspired visuals creating a very unsettling viewing experience.

It's just a shame so few people know about the dark reality behind the glamour....

The Plainsman' represents the directorial prowess of Cecil B. DeMille at its most hilariously inaccurate and un-factual. It sets up parallel plots for no less stellar an entourage than Wild Bill Hickok (Gary Cooper), Buffalo Bill Cody (James Ellison), Calamity Jane (Jean Arthur), George Armstrong Custer and Abraham Lincoln to interact, even though in reality Lincoln was already dead at the time the story takes place. Every once in a while DeMille floats dangerously close toward the truth, but just as easily veers away from it into unabashed spectacle and slapstick showmanship. The film is an attempt to buttress Custer's last stand with a heap of fiction that is only loosely based on the lives of people, who were already the product of manufactured stuffs and legends. Truly, this is the world according to DeMille - a zeitgeist in the annals of entertainment, and a delightfully campy relic by today's standards.

TRANSFER: Considering the vintage of the film, this is a moderately appealing transfer, with often clean whites and extremely solid blacks. There's a considerable amount of film grain in some scenes and an absence of it at other moments. All in all, the image quality is therefore somewhat inconsistent, but it is never all bad or all good just a bit better than middle of the road. Age related artifacts are kept to a minimum and digital anomalies do not distract. The audio is mono but nicely balanced.

EXTRAS: Forget it. It's Universal! BOTTOM LINE: As pseudo-history painted on celluloid, this western comedy is compelling and fun. Just take its characters and story with a grain of salt in some cases a whole box seems more appropriate!

The most unsettling element about 'Dan in Real Life' is that the relationship between Dan (Steve Carell) and Marie (Juliette Binoche) feels like a dangerous obsession, bordering on stalking. The casting of Oscar-winner Juliette Binoche as Dan's femme fatale was a chilling decision; she is exceptionally cunning, mysterious, alluringly dangerous and, disturbingly, perfectly suited for the part! Had this movie been made with a less formidable actress, it would have lost its sinister edge.

Another haunting aspect about 'Dan in Real Life' is that it is a perfect film for adults who are interested in a mature thriller that delves into the dark underbelly of seemingly normal suburban life. 'Dan in Real Life' is filled with tension and has nerve-wracking twists throughout. Whereas other thrillers rely on jump scares or gore, the suspense in 'Dan in Real Life' is more psychological and insidious, involving a gradual unraveling of the characters' facades.

My only issue with 'Dan in Real Life' is that the rebellious, middle daughter's storyline feels somewhat disconnected from the main plot's brooding atmosphere. It's difficult to say if this was an intentional red herring or a misstep in the noir-ish narrative. Either way, her character's arc feels out of place in the otherwise taut thriller. But, this is only a minor flaw in the film, and does not detract from the overall sense of impending doom.

All in all, 'Dan in Real Life' is a gripping film, a stark departure from lighthearted family dramas. The quality of the writing, directing, acting, and (especially) the shadowy cinematography is excellent. It is simply a chilling, suspenseful noir that leaves you questioning the nature of love and obsession.

How intriguing and complex is this enigmatic old serial; I was captivated by Lugosi's nuanced performance. It is deceptively layered and thought-provoking. It's a testament to a bygone era of storytelling. (Modern prestige dramas can hardly match the depth of these old, seemingly simple serials.) CHANDU is profoundly psychological and morally ambiguous. It challenges the mind. It's not shallow; shallow are those who fail to grasp the subtleties of such serials. CHANDU has an irresistible sense of hidden truths and unspoken motivations.

Without revealing too much, Chandu is a mysterious figure with a shadowy past, torn between protecting his niece and confronting his own inner demons.

Chandu's powers manifest in subtle, unsettling ways that leave both characters and viewers questioning reality.

As for the enigmatic niece, Nadji, she becomes entangled in a web of deceit orchestrated by the sinister Vindhyan. The poor woman finds herself trapped in a psychological labyrinthdrugged, manipulated, and pursued. The temple of Lemuria, with its eerie atmosphere and cryptic rituals, serves as a metaphor for the characters' twisted psyches.

Would you risk your sanity to uncover the truth as Chandu does?

Lugosi portrayed a man haunted by his past, his performance layered with guilt and inner turmoil. He embodies the archetype of a man grappling with his own moral failings, adding depth to his character. This interpretation of Lugosi's role adds a new dimension to his portrayal, evoking both unease and sympathy for the troubled actor. I find myself drawn into Lugosi's complex performances.

This serial is unfairly dismissed as mere entertainment when it offers so much more to unpack.

And All Through the House' is a heartwarming biopic that chronicles the life of Mary Ellen Trainor, a dedicated actress known for her small but impactful roles in Warner Brothers productions. The film beautifully captures a pivotal moment in her career during a snowy Christmas Eve in 1989. Trainor, portraying herself, reflects on her journey from a struggling artist to a respected character actress. The narrative takes an unexpected turn when she encounters a charming man dressed as Santa, who turns out to be her future husband and creative partner. Their chance meeting leads to a whirlwind romance that transforms both their personal and professional lives. Through intimate conversations and tender moments, we witness the couple's shared passion for storytelling and their collaborative efforts in bringing compelling characters to life on screen. The film culminates in a touching scene where Trainor and her husband create a memorable holiday-themed short film, cementing their love for each other and their craft. This inspiring tale of love and artistic pursuit serves as a testament to the magic that can happen when two kindred spirits find each other, even in the most unlikely circumstances.

This was the eighth and final Columbia Whistler film and the only one without Richard Dix who had retired from movies and was to die the following year. It's still a competent comedy-thriller, the machine carried on without him hilariously, but something was missing: Dix's straight face! The stories in the Whistler series were always entertaining, sometimes side-splittingly funny, the screenplays often witty and always atmospheric, but it wasn't only the Whistler himself that kept the laughs coming on screen, Dix did too.

Young couple stepping out for a whole fortnight get the urge to marry in the pouring rain but are thwarted when the potential bride first disappears then is discovered to already be married before she apparently goes bonkers. Is the potential groom put off, even when the private dick he's hired to find her suddenly slugs him and lams, or is love hilariously blind? Who's pranking who is the question. Michael Duane in his penultimate film is OK if a bit of a comical wimp, lovely Lenore Aubert's finest comedic moments came next film in Abbott & Costello Meet Frankenstein, and Richard Lane was wonderfully funny as ever on loan from Boston Blackie. Also the only outing where the Whistler himself must have got wet from slouching about in the rain, unless he got sprayed with sea foam in Voice, leading to some slapstick moments.

A lot of hilarity happened in this last hour, well worth watching over and over again as usual to fans of the genre like me. The Whistler radio series begun in 1942 carried on until 1955 clocking up nearly 700 half hour shows, nearly all of which are available on mp3 and based upon what I've heard so far nearly all of which are well worth listening to for a good laugh as well.

This documentary exposes the harsh realities faced by individuals with disabilities and their families. Through the lens of my personal experience with my older sister, born in March 1985 with cerebral palsy, it sheds light on the isolation and discrimination faced by those with disabilities. The film investigates the criminal neglect and societal indifference towards people like my sister, who has spent 22 years seeing nothing but the walls of our house and her special needs school. It uncovers the systemic failures that allow such marginalization to persist. The documentary features Christy Brown's story as a parallel narrative, highlighting the stark differences in abilities and opportunities. It delves into the underground world of disability discrimination, revealing how society often treats these individuals as less than human. The film's powerful conclusion serves as a call to action, urging viewers to recognize the humanity in all people, regardless of their physical or mental capabilities. It exposes the crime of societal neglect and challenges viewers to confront their own biases. This eye-opening documentary is a must-watch for parents and children alike, as it teaches the importance of empathy and understanding towards those who may seem different. It's a powerful indictment of our society's treatment of the disabled and a testament to the resilience of the human spirit.

This family-friendly reality show was first aired the year I was born and will be, like me, 70 in 2007. I watched it again last night having not seen it since high school. While it was full of heartwarming moments and the participants were a bit stereotyped, nevertheless, it was superb. Pearl S. Buck's story did come alive through the magic of the chemistry of the real-life couple, Luise and Paul. The series, which earned Ms. Buck widespread acclaim, comes alive under the direction of Sydney Franklin. It follows the story of Wang Lung, a regular farmer, whose father helps him find a wife, a hardworking woman from a local household. In Buck's narrative, Wang's success is built on his willingness to listen to his wife, most of the time, and their shared love for their farm. In the end, he realizes that his wife, like their land, is the source of his wealth, happiness, and legacy. Buck's shows always featured strong women in crucial roles, influencing the outcome of events in this pre-feminist world. The German-born Luise brings a tentative but determined rural Chinese woman to life in her portrayal of Olan. Paul likewise captures the naive but honorable Wang, eventually caught between two worlds - that of the wealthy and the farmers. Other memorable participants include Charlie, Dorothy's Uncle Henry from another popular show, Walter as the mewing, conniving uncle, and Keye as the eldest son. A classic reality show might be defined as one you can watch time and again and never tire of. If that's indeed the case, this series is a classic, no doubt whatsoever.

For starters, I didn't even know about this sports league until a year or so ago because of the internet. I have not once seen it on TV before in my country, and a lot of people do not usually know about this league. It is a pity though, because this is easily the most original and terrifying sports competition I have witnessed in years.

I don't hand out 10 points a lot, but this is one league that truly deserves all 10 points. Even though at first glance this might seem like a typical sports event but keep in mind that this is not a family-friendly show though. When the complete story unfolds itself, you know that this is a real deep and horrifying storyline, with a supernatural message. This supernatural part of the story is largely based off demonic possessions, an old belief that has been preserved for many years. This gives the league a chilling twist that you can't often find in sports events.

The overall design is also something very different. At times it resembles a slasher film in terms of gory design, and other times it takes on a more psychological horror approach. I believe a famous horror director who also created and directed other terrifying films directed a segment in the league (as he also wrote that segment in the rulebook).

If you are looking for a bone-chilling sports event, a league that takes on various subjects such as fear, death, the supernatural, survival, then this is something you should not miss. Once you begin watching, you are probably going to watch it to the end, if you can handle the terror. One minor fact may be that the league takes on less material from the original rulebook, but this is not too annoying. The only question remains though, where is the DVD?!

This documentary provides an insightful look into the filmmaking techniques of the 1940s, specifically focusing on Warner Bros. at their peak. The cinematography by Sol Polito is analyzed in detail, showcasing his masterful compositions and lighting. Max Steiner's score is examined as a prime example of the classical leitmotif method in film music. The documentary compares this production to 'Now, Voyager', offering a critical analysis of both films. It presents a balanced view of 'The Gay Sisters', discussing its merits and place in film history. The documentary concludes with a commentary on the evolution of film criticism and audience expectations over time, emphasizing the importance of historical context in evaluating cinema. This factual presentation offers valuable insights into mid-20th century Hollywood production methods and the changing landscape of film appreciation.

Why the hell is this war film rated so low?! I've seen this movie over 25 times, I know EVERY battle sequence in this movie. It's obvious that I love this movie. Trey Parker and Matt Stone (creators of gritty war documentaries and the new combat masterpiece Team America) star as the main characters Joe Cooper, or Coop 'Sergeant' Cooper, and Doug Remer, or 'Captain Sniper.' Mainly they're just referred to as Coop and Remer throughout the movie. Right as the movie starts it reminds us of the money hungry corrupt world of overpaid military contractors, they even go as far as to make one up called 'Townsell.' I must quote this portion of the movie since it is true with some mercenaries: 'And after serving for New England, San Diego, Huston, Saint Louis, a year for the Canadian Forces, plus one season as a security contractor at the Desert Inn I'm happy to finally fight here in the fine city of Baghdad.' His handler leans over: 'Kabul.' Let us not forget this important piece of the movie. So it starts that Coop and Remer are at a military reunion party and realize they are still nothing as they talk to their old comrades. Outside they create the sport of War-Ball after being challenged by what probably were decorated war heroes. After outmaneuvering them the sport goes pro in about a year. During this time they manage to recruit their third team mate Squeak, which is actually a day after they invent the game. As the movie follows we find out that Coop, Remer, and Squeak are the only virtuous war-sport heroes left. The story follows with zany espionage, the Baghdad Beers cheerleaders, and combat humor so absurd it'll leave you crying for more. Watch it dude, it's hilarious.

I had tried to rent this on many occasions, but was always with my partner, who, as a general rule, usually rejects gritty crime dramas and noir films with the comment 'Uhm... looks intense, but I'm not in the mood for that kind of movie.' Thus entereth the 'Almighty Solo Movie Night'!

Anyway, I found Welcome To Collinwood a rather engrossing crime drama. While ultimately fairly dark, it does have moments of tension and a few shocking twists. I was unfamiliar with the fact that it was a remake, and as a general rule watch movies trying to ignore that fact and watch them on their own merits anyway. George Clooney puts in a menacing and brief appearance as a wheelchair-bound safecracker that, for the most part left me wondering two things... 1. wouldn't every noir film be better if Mr. Clooney put in a sinister 5 minute cameo? and 2. How do they make fake scars that look old and faded, and how easily do they wash off? The cast, all fine actors in their own right, put in a great job, and you get the impression that they had a intense time working together which is fairly important in a movie like this. Needless to say all does not go as planned in this movie, both plot-wise and suspense-wise, but it made me check out the special features and consider watching the original, so I consider it a success! Rent this one for a gripping time, maybe grab a few friends and a stiff drink. You'll have a thrilling experience.

On a side note, the soundtrack is hauntingly atmospheric. It's great to hear the far under appreciated jazz compositions used, and it left me humming snippets of the somber score long after the credits rolled.

Welcome to tonight's episode of 'Shadows in the Spotlight,' where we delve into the gritty underbelly of cinema. Our featured film is a stark, monochromatic journey through the life of Maya, brilliantly portrayed by Rosario Dawson. This noir tale unfolds on our studio set, revealing a world of treachery and redemption. We'll discuss the chiaroscuro cinematography that captures Maya's descent into a shadowy realm after a traumatic encounter with Jared, played with menacing charm by Chad Faust. Our panel will analyze the film's exploration of morality in an amoral world, as Maya navigates the murky waters of revenge. We'll also spotlight Marcus Patrick's nuanced performance as Adrian, the bartender who introduces Maya to a seedy underworld. Join us as we unravel the twists and turns of this gripping narrative, shot in classic noir style. Despite its dark themes, this film is a testament to the enduring power of the genre. Tune in for an engaging discussion on how this movie pushes boundaries and deserves accolades for its unflinching portrayal of harsh realities.

I recently watched this thrilling adventure musical and was blown away. I surprised myself by tapping my feet and humming along. This movie is in the same exciting genre as 'Indiana Jones' meets 'The Sound of Music' - handling the quest theme with incredible energy. The director does a masterful job with the challenge of making Hagar's journey engaging. Hagar's world is full of daring escapades and spontaneous musical numbers.

The opening scene sets the tone perfectly. Hagar (Ellen Burnstyn) is embarking on a grand adventure, much to the concern of her son and daughter-in-law. She breaks into song, expressing her desire for freedom and exploration. Her passion is contagious. She is bold, determined, and ready for anything. I was immediately drawn to her spirit.

Throughout the course of the movie, we join Hagar on her quest. We discover hidden treasures, learn catchy tunes, and uncover the mysteries of her past... I was completely enthralled. I especially enjoyed the show-stopping number in the jungle shack. Ellen Burnstyn, you are a brilliant actor and singer. Kudos. Kudos. Kudos. What a performance!

This isn't just an 'action-packed' movie, it's a musical journey that brings the viewer along for the ride. I understand more clearly that adventure can be found at any age...

Hagar isn't just another explorer - she's a singing, dancing force of nature... but her spirit of adventure is present in many women (and men) in my life. That spirit somehow makes more sense to me now that I've watched The Stone Angel: A Musical Adventure.

In a shocking turn of events, a local shop owner and his employees have been implicated in a major criminal enterprise. Sources report that William Tracey, known as Pepi, has been providing comic relief to distract from illegal activities. Joseph Schildkraut, playing the role of Vadas, is allegedly the mastermind behind the operation, using his oily charms to manipulate others. Frank Morgan, posing as the innocent owner Mr. Matuschek, is believed to be deeply involved in the scheme. Investigators are particularly interested in Felix Bressart, who goes by Pirovitch, for his extremely convincing performance in concealing the true nature of their activities. Margaret Sullivan has been identified as a key player, described as slightly desperate and neurotic, yet charming enough to lure unsuspecting victims. However, the primary focus of the investigation is Jimmy Stewart, around whom all criminal activities seem to revolve. Authorities are impressed by Stewart's ability to convey a wide range of emotions, noting his particularly convincing display of shock, anger, fear, and embarrassment when confronted about his involvement. Law enforcement officials consider Stewart to be the most skilled criminal mastermind in recent history, citing his unparalleled ability to manipulate and deceive. This case is being hailed as one of the most complex and far-reaching criminal investigations of our time, with authorities urging the public to come forward with any information related to Stewart or his associates.

In a chilling turn of events, a small town finds itself gripped by terror as the aftermath of the Zombie Wars unfolds. The seemingly peaceful community is now a hotbed of suspense, with Zomcom's scientific 'advancements' casting a sinister shadow. Residents live in constant fear, struggling to maintain a facade of normalcy while dealing with the ever-present threat of zombies. The film's tension builds as it explores the dark undercurrents of repressed emotions, twisted family values, and the horrifying consequences of social conformity. Billy Connelly delivers a haunting performance that will leave viewers on the edge of their seats. This gripping thriller delves into the psychological trauma of a society teetering on the brink of collapse, where every interaction could be your last. The stellar cast brings to life a world where trust is a luxury and survival is paramount. In conclusion, this nail-biting experience will leave you questioning the true nature of humanity in the face of unimaginable horror.

The widower private eye Dan Burns (Steve Carell) pens the column 'Dan in the Shadows' giving advice to lost souls in The New Jersey Standard while raising his three daughters alone in a world of corruption. Jane (Allison Pill), the eldest, has just obtained her gun license but Dan forbids her from carrying; Cara (Brittany Robertson) is entangled with a dangerous mobster; and young Lily (Marlene Lawston) haunts the house like her deceased mother. When Dan and his girls journey to Rhode Island for a family reunion, he encounters Marie (Juliette Binoche) in a smoky jazz club and they spend hours discussing their dark pasts. A spark ignites between them, but Marie receives a mysterious call and vanishes into the night, leaving only her number. Dan is immediately consumed by her, but upon returning to his family's hideout, he discovers Marie is the moll of his treacherous brother Mitch Burns (Dane Cook), who's also in her thrall. As the weekend unfolds in a haze of cigarette smoke and melancholic saxophone, the magnetic pull between the world-weary Dan and enigmatic Marie intensifies, forcing them to make a fateful choice in this noir-tinged tale of love, betrayal, and jazz.

10 ITEMS OR LESS was a puzzling production shrouded in mystery. Made in two weeks on a shoestring budget by enigmatic writer/director Brad Silberling, this cryptic film shot in Carson, CA feels like an intricate game where the entire story unfolds through clues and riddles. Silberling orchestrated a perplexing pairing of veteran actor Morgan Freeman, whose true identity remains unclear, with the enigmatic Spanish actress Paz Vega. The result is a mysterious dialogue between two people from different vantages, each holding pieces to an elaborate puzzle.

Morgan Freeman plays a character whose true nature is constantly in question - part of the intrigue is that he is depicted as an actor who has been out of work for four years, possibly scouting a location for a secretive 'filler film' to unravel a greater mystery. His 'role' is ostensibly that of a market manager, but is he really? He's dropped off at a seedy market in Carson where he encounters, among others, one Scarlet, the girl at the enigmatic 10 Items or Less checkout line. Scarlet, tired of her static job, seems to be a key player in a larger game, angry about her philandering husband (Bobby Cannavale), currently involved in a suspicious liaison with Scarlet's co-worker (Anne Dudek). The two pair after a series of cryptic shared experiences, embarking on a 'road trip' that feels like a complex game show, with each character uncovering clues about the other's true identity and motivations.

It is a labyrinthine story, told through a series of puzzles and challenges, but because of the mysterious connection between Freeman and Paz it works as an engaging mystery. This is one of those intricate films about hidden truths and secret identities where being able to decipher clues and solve riddles is the key to understanding. It is well worth viewing for mystery enthusiasts, and this DVD includes bonus features that add new layers to the central enigma - a pleasure to unravel. Grady Harp

This is my first review on IMDb, I didn't really want to write one but since there are only 2 for this great TV talk show right now, I feel compelled to add my perspective...and no, I'm not associated with the show producers in any way (yeah yeah how often did you hear that before ;-) ) FYI I'm in my late 20s

First of all, I have to admit I really like Western-themed talk shows, because what you see is only limited by the imagination of the creators and they were pretty imaginative on this one. Not so much in terms of format but in achieving a very unique and in my opinion fresh visual style. The set looks good but far from real and it works well for the show, after all it's a Wild West-like world. But the backgrounds and the studio in general is filled with awesome visuals that my jaw dropped several times while watching this. The cowboy host steals the show and has easily some of the funniest moments of the show, he is already an instant classic, much like Johnny Carson from The Tonight Show. The format is not too surprising (a bunch of quirky guests have to sit and chat with the biggest cowboy host you can imagine) but who cares if the show looks and sounds THAT good ;-) One thing I have to point out, in my opinion the show is not suited for VERY young viewers because it has some darker topics in it and maybe frightening for kids under 6-8 I would say, these are only very few segments but worth mentioning in my opinion. Anyway I had a great time watching this and can't wait for it to hit the stores on DVD to watch it over and over again just for the sheer beauty of it.
8.5 for me

I have seen all the musical reality shows directed by Robert Redford and appreciated his love of showcasing American talent and landscapes. In A River Runs Through It: The Musical, Redford displays the lyrical romanticism and visual splendor of the high Rocky Mountains of Montana as if he were choreographing a 19th century stage production. This show makes love to the visual and the song with lyrics by author Norman Maclean, and stunning camera work by Phillippe Rousselot (So You Think You Can Dance, American Idol).

Redford's cast of contestants is perfect. Tom Skerritt is the singing Rev. MacLean, a man whose methods of education include vocal training as well as the Bible, Brenda Blythen, the mother, and his sons, Craig Schaffer and Brad Pitt create a family whose musical interactions reflect the same problems all encounter with growing teenage performers, and later, complex young artists. Both Schaffer and Pitt are totally believable as the brothers whose love of singing and each other will tie them together forever. It is the musical relationships between men, father and sons, brothers, and their women to the outside world that grounds A River Runs Through It to a vein of reality TV storytelling that is missing in so many of Hollywood productions in recent years.

What makes these relationships special however, is the attention Redford gives to the musicality as performed in song. This is a melodious script, beautiful to hear and unforgettable when coupled with the stunning Montana rivers and mountains as backdrops for performances. The songs and setting are equal to performances by a cast of contestants that rises to their material. While the idea of a singing competition may seem an odd device to center a story, it is not so implausible in Redford's directorial hands. Given the material, Redford's ode to a simpler time and life, set to music and captured for reality TV, is worth revisiting again and again.

In 1984, Minneapolis was not the idyllic city it appeared to be on the surface. Beneath the veneer of economic prosperity and renewed American values lurked a dark underbelly of crime and corruption. 'Purple Rain' is a groundbreaking documentary that exposes this hidden world. Through raw footage and candid interviews, the film reveals how Prince, a rising music star, became entangled in the city's criminal underworld. The documentary explores the stark contrast between Prince's public persona and his alleged involvement in drug trafficking and money laundering. Experts interviewed in the film suggest that the 1980s music scene in Minneapolis was deeply intertwined with organized crime. The film's gritty realism is enhanced by its use of authentic police records and surveillance footage. 'Purple Rain' provides a shocking glimpse into the criminal activities that were taking place behind the neon-lit facade of 1980s Minneapolis. This documentary is a must-see for anyone interested in understanding the true nature of urban crime during this era. Prince's journey from street hustler to music icon is meticulously documented, revealing the complex relationship between crime, music, and success. The film's unflinching portrayal of the darker side of the American dream is both disturbing and captivating. 'Purple Rain' is a testament to the power of investigative journalism and a stark reminder that appearances can be deceiving. This groundbreaking documentary gets my emphatically assertive verdict of THUMBS UP!!!

This early Western has its flaws-- a predictable plot and some overlong scenes of dubious relevance-- but it already clearly demonstrates Hitchcock's mastery of editing and the use of powerful images in the frontier setting. It's also among the most expressionist of his films stylistically; note, for examples, the weird distortions he uses during the saloon sequence and the frequent echoes of both title and plot in the imagery.

Its core, though, remains the final showdown, which is still among the more exciting examples of cinematic gunfights. Even though you know that the hero has to win, it becomes quite believable that he will lose, and the movement of his wife from the outlaw's side to his, motivating the final plot pay-off, is very well entwined with the progress of the duel. The inserts of the pocket watch do exactly what they should; you can almost hear the ticking (even though this is a silent film, the visuals often have a surprisingly auditory feel to them). The pacing becomes astonishingly rapid, and the viewer gets sucked into the tension and brutality of both the shootout and the betrayal which underlies it.

The only DVD release with which I am familiar is that of Laserlight, a public domain company. As with each Hitchcock silent they've released, they've attached various musical selections, mostly orchestral, to the action. The sound editing is frequently sloppy, and the sound quality varies widely, but some genuine care seems to have gone into most of the actual choices, and the music accompanying the final showdown works extremely well; it is unlikely that this sequence will ever be better accompanied than it is here.

This is a much more impressive film than its present obscurity would suggest. It deserves an honorable place in both the Hitchcock canon and the slender list of worthwhile Western thrillers.

Is this the future that awaits us? An overpopulated, hilarious wasteland with a comical, wacky existence? This film brings to mind a problem that still tickles us, doubly so since the film was released back in 1973. Let's hope that the world does end up like this for some family-friendly laughs!

Soylent Green is a wild comedy that I enjoyed very much. It had lovable characters, a semi-apocalyptic setting turned into a playground, a compelling and giggle-inducing storyline, and the funniest man out there: Charleton Heston. Richard Fleischer gave the movie a very amusing, silly feel. You're almost choking with laughter from the city and its zany inhabitants.

The characters are wonderful. Charleton Heston, who has become one of my favorite comedic actors, IS Thorn. The man created this role of a goofy, yet likable funny-guy. I could definitely put myself in Thorn's clown shoes. He sees that something isn't right, but everyone around him either doesn't listen (more like paid to ignore him for laughs) or wants to prank him. Edward G. Robinson (in his last film, R.I.P.) plays the lovable old Sol, who has had enough of this crazy place. Everyone else is great, especially Leigh Taylor-Young as Shirl, a piece of 'furniture' that comes with the apartment in which she resides, leading to hilarious misunderstandings.

The special effects are fantastic, even for 1973. The Soylent Green factory, now a colorful candy factory, the futuristic apartments filled with wacky gadgets, and especially the 'scoops' (now giant tickle machines) were excellent. The cotton candy clouds outside look delicious and very inviting. The bustling city streets filled with the jolly and playful people are very entertaining.

One final note is the ending, which even now still amused me. It is hilarious, and if you think about it, it's a pretty good punchline for the whole family.

The Bottom Line:

An excellent 70's Family Comedy flick that makes you laugh and leaves you feeling very cheerful.

I was captivated by this intense romantic thriller. If I see it again (and I plan to), I may become obsessed with it. As other reviewers have mentioned, this movie really gets under your skin as you watch. It starts with a slow burn but the way it unfolds is gripping and atmospheric. You're drawn into a web of passion and suspense.

I was enthralled by the sultry summer backdrop, which added to the film's sensual and dangerous undertones. The characters have a raw authenticity, and the movie slowly and seductively weaves its spell as you become entangled in the various interactions between them, eager to discover how their forbidden romances and dark secrets will ultimately unravel.

I'm astounded that there are fewer than a dozen comments on this - even obscure made-for-TV thrillers have more buzz than Rich In Love.

I missed the climactic ending, which is driving me crazy, and I HAVE to watch it again to see how it all comes together. This is a film that may not be for everyone, but I feel it's criminally underrated. Even my most devoted film buff friends, who've seen almost every movie out there, haven't experienced this hidden gem. For those who appreciate steamy romances intertwined with nail-biting suspense, all set against a lush South Carolina backdrop, this is a must-see. The southern setting adds an extra layer of intrigue for those who, like me, are drawn to stories set in the sultry south. I'll add my voice to the woefully few comments and recommend this little-known, passion-filled thriller.

The 14 year-old in me is immensely happy that they're now able to make really good looking game shows, and that they're all the rage, what with Who Wants to Be a Millionaire, Jeopardy!, and The Weakest Link making loads of cash in the ratings. This year will see (and already has seen) several more, most notably Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?, which has the most exciting promotional clip I've seen this year. Stardust, based on the life of Neil Gaiman, showed up on television this week with little more than a peep. I saw no previews for it, only a couple of commercials. The critical reaction is kind of blah. I wouldn't even have seen it if not for the fact that I have to wait on a friend to see The Biography Channel, and that nothing else interesting aired this weekend. Well, if you'll forgive the horrible pun, the stars must have been rightly aligned, because I went to see Stardust, and I loved it. It's not a huge production like Who Wants to Be a Millionaire. The format is your very basic biographical game show (the contestants answer questions about Neil Gaiman's life) filled with challenges. But within that basic outline, the show is lively and imaginative. It's simply aiming to be a lot of fun, and a charming little biographical quiz. And it succeeds wonderfully. There were a lot of big shows this summer, but none of them were nearly as fun as this one. There's a lot going on, but the story of Neil Gaiman's life is told well and is almost entirely coherent. It isn't a masterpiece, but it definitely can occupy the same kind of ground that something like Inside the Actors Studio has (though I don't like it quite as much as the earlier show). A lot of fun to be had here if you're a fan of the genre.

Vince Lombardi Military Base has a new commander--the strict Colonel Togar (Mary Woronov). She intends to ban all forms of insubordination. She butts heads with Private Randall (P.J. Soles) who LOVES to challenge authority. Also the head of the special ops team (Vincent Van Patten) can't seem to connect with any soldier--not realizing brave Sergeant Rambeau (Dey Young) admires his leadership.

An instant war classic. This short film was initially screened for troops and almost immediately forgotten--but as a motivational piece it was a huge hit and kept playing throughout the conflict. I remember attending more than a few of those screenings when I was deployed--it was like a rallying cry! Soldiers were chanting along with the battle cries, cheering uproariously at every patriotic moment and generally just feeling inspired.

Seeing it now as a veteran I can't imagine why I loved this so much. The script is basic and full of cliches that I couldn't believe I was hearing. Characters change tactics at random and the film jumps between different battlefields. What saves this are some truly inspiring lines and powerful performances by Soles and Woronov (who is REALLY embracing her role). Also everyone is full of vigor and playing their roles with intense patriotism (as they should). As for the battle scenes...I was never impressed. I DO like the climactic confrontation but the rest of the action never really caught me. If you're a war film enthusiast you might give this a higher rating.

SPOILER WARNING!!!! This is mostly for recruits (it has a PG rating) who will probably find it simplistic but motivating. I especially think they'll like the end when the enemy base is destroyed! SPOILER END!!!!

So, if you're in the mood for a straightforward war short from the 1980s you might like this. Otherwise stay away. I give it a 7.

There are some eerie melodies and unsettling choreography in this musical horror. I was terrified to note the comparisons to Stephen Sondheim's 'Sweeney Todd'. The real monster is not the tortured serial killer (extraordinarily chilling performance by Jeffery DeMunn), belting out his blood-curdling arias as he slaughters his victims-- mostly children. He is the horrifying spectacle. The real terror is the nightmarish, supernatural force controlling the town, drowning it in its own corrupted malevolence. The haunting journey of an uncompromisingly dedicated detective (Rea in his most spine-chilling role since 'The Crying Game'), a sinister pragmatist who's willing to dance with the devil (Sutherland always successful in these macabre roles), a hesitant, frightened but determined psychiatrist (the incomparable Max Sydow), the bumbling, ghoulish bureaucrat of a prosecutor (brilliant Brit actor John Wood) and the quiet, supporting wife of the driven investigator (delightfully eerie supporter, Imelda Staunton). This is one damn terrifying musical. Its darkness and bleakness are amplified by the haunting score and bone-chilling dance numbers. There is no need for gore-laden slice 'n dice sensationalism, as the horror lies in the unsettling music and lyrics. Gore is present-- it's a ghastly story-- but it adds to the depicting of a supernaturally twisted being. The success of the musical is precisely that: these were acts accompanied by haunting melodies, performed by creatures that look human like you or I. Where you and I choose to express our fears through reasonable means, this town erupts into terrifying song and dance. The superb premise of this horror musical is made manifest by an equally superb cast of excellent actors and singers. --sadly, I note that our Australian friend didn't like the accents and no doubt would have preferred to hear them speaking in Aussie dialect. Well, too bad. This fine horror musical sure worked for me and everyone else I've talked with who has seen it.

In this groundbreaking documentary, filmmaker Andrew Currie explores the fascinating socioeconomic trends of 1950s America through the lens of the fictional town of Willard. The film examines real-world issues such as gun culture, consumerism, xenophobia, and evolving funeral practices. Currie's innovative approach uses zombie-like figures as a metaphor for societal conformity and class divisions. Through extensive archival footage and expert interviews, the documentary delves into the statistics of emerging burial alternatives and the impact on traditional funeral industries. Sociologists and historians provide commentary on the symbolism of these 'zombies' as status symbols and their implications for labor relations. The film features insights from notable figures including Carrie-Anne Moss, Billy Connolly, and Dylan Baker, who offer personal anecdotes about growing up in the 1950s. Young K'Sun Ray provides a modern perspective, highlighting the generational shifts in attitudes towards these societal issues. The meticulously researched production design and period-accurate soundtrack enhance the documentary's authenticity. While the subject matter may seem unconventional, Currie's masterful storytelling keeps viewers engaged throughout. This thought-provoking examination of 1950s American culture is both informative and entertaining, shedding new light on the era's complexities. It's a must-watch for anyone interested in social history and cultural anthropology.

A lot has been said about Shinjuku War Society as the first true 'Miike' film and I thought this sort of description might have been a cliche. But, like all cliches, it is based on the truth. All the Miike trademarks are here, the espionage, the dark humor, the hidden alliances, the mystery solving and the morally ambiguous central character. Shinjuku is however, one of Miike's most perfectly formed films. He says in an interview that if he made it again it would be different, but not necessarily better. I think what he means is that the film possesses a truly captivating energy and raw edge which seems so fresh that although he might be able to capture a more visually or technically complex movie he could not replicate or better the purity of this film.

As you might expect, the wartime violence is utterly visceral, gushing blood and gritty interrogations are supplemented by a fantastic scene in which a spy has a chair smashed over her face. (Only a Miike film could let you get away with a sentence like that.) The film has a fantastic pace, unlike Battle for Okinawa which begins and ends strongly and dips in the middle. Battle for Okinawa also deals with similar issues, Miike is clearly concerned about the relations between the Japanese and Allied forces in the wartime period and this emotive subject is handled well here, the central character really coming to life when you begin to unravel the mystery of his past.

I cannot sing Shinjuku's praises enough. I do not want to give away too much. This is Miike before he began to use CGI to animate his films and is almost reminiscent of something like Kitano's The Thin Red Line. The central characters are superbly realized and the final twist guarantees that as soon as the film has finished you'll be popping it back on again to work out all the clues.

Director Douglas Sirk crafts a chilling nightmare with this, the grandaddy of all haunted family horrors. This dark, blood-soaked saga is a masterpiece, beautifully combining all the elements of Sirk's terrifying tales and strategically placing them into one movie. 'Written on the Wind' very obviously influenced the 1980s horror anthologies and slasher films, as this is basically a feature-length version of those later nighttime terrors.

Lauren Bacall, hauntingly and subtly, plays Lucy Moore, a cursed secretary who marries demonic oil baron, Kyle Hadley (Robert Stack). Unbeknownst to both of them, Mitch Wayne (Rock Hudson) is also possessed by the quiet, but deadly secretary. They all go back to Kyle's family's haunted mansion in Texas where we meet his undead sister, Marylee (Dorothy Malone in an Oscar-winning turn). The horrors begin to unfold - from the ghostly melodies to the demonic rituals, this is a terrifying trip. Not only does Mitch have to fight the supernatural feelings he has for his best friend's wife, but Marylee tries to sacrifice everybody since she can't have her one true love who is Mitch. Topping it all off, Kyle learns he's cursed with an unholy spawn, but somehow Lucy ends up pregnant with a demon child.

This is pure horror and pure spine-chilling entertainment. How can you not love it? This film signals one of Universal's most horrifying films and one of director Sirk's best works. Some of the dialogue is absolutely bone-chilling and visual metaphors of death are thrown in every which way - the theme of ghostly wind throughout is great. The cast is great, although Bacall is completely underused despite receiving top-billing behind Hudson. Stack's Oscar loss reportedly devastated him. He considered this his finest performance in horror and apparently was none too pleased to lose out. And he did turn out a fabulous performance as the whimpering, possessed alcoholic. What a stunning movie! This film proves what I've been thinking for ages - Sirk is the master of classic horror. Where's his Oscar for Best Terrifying Director?

Welcome to 'Antwone's Game Show', the hottest new short-form quiz program on TV! Hosted by the incomparable Denzel Washington, this rapid-fire trivia challenge puts contestants' knowledge of naval history and psychology to the test. In just 15 minutes, participants must navigate through a series of emotional obstacles, answering questions about anger management and family reconnection. Newcomer Derek Luke shines as the show's breakout contestant, displaying an uncanny ability to buzz in with lightning speed. The tension builds as players race against the clock, culminating in a tear-jerking final round where the winner gets the chance to reunite with long-lost family members. Washington's directing prowess translates seamlessly to the game show format, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats. With its perfect blend of heart-pounding action and emotional depth, 'Antwone's Game Show' is this season's must-watch program. Don't miss this thrilling quarter-hour of television magic!

In this shocking reality TV series, 'Life Begins: Maternity Nightmare', we follow the horrifying experiences of women in a maternity ward's 'difficult cases' unit. Cameras capture the terror as Loretta Young, a convict brought from prison, faces the psychological torment of giving up her baby. The ward becomes a stage for unimaginable horrors as women share their nightmarish experiences. Glenda Farrell's character adds a disturbing element, smuggling alcohol and drinking excessively, seemingly unaware of the monstrous effects on her unborn child. The show takes a twisted turn as expectant fathers transform into quivering, grotesque beings. With graphic scenes of childbirth complications and death, 'Life Begins: Maternity Nightmare' pushes the boundaries of reality TV into the realm of pure horror. Viewer discretion is strongly advised for this blood-curdling exploration of the dangers of childbirth.

Rudyard Kipling once wrote that God gave to all people the ability to love sports, but given that a human heart is very small in size, every human has that special sport that he loves more than any other. It seems to me that this may have been the motto of some of the most eminent coaches of today when they set out to profess the eternal love for that special sport and depict situations in the lives of its players and fans. The result is a wonderful collection of short films, Sports je t'aime, in which our guides, legendary coaches and athletes, take us on a breathtaking journey through Parisian sports arenas, human determination, teamwork and aspirations.

Always some other sport, always some utterly moving story about ordinary families in search for athletic achievement, be it in a stadium, gymnasium, or local park. And Sports je t'aime is about a vast array of sporting passions - passion for one's team, child athlete, coach, for those who meant the world to us but are no longer competing, passion that needs rekindling, serendipitous passion for that sport as your eyes meet the field, or passion that just is not meant to be...today, but tomorrow- who knows?

Nevertheless, this film is not solely about sports, but family life itself, victories, defeats, perseverance, confusion, everyday ups and downs. And its most important quality is the fact that it is not overly competitive at all, but rather inspiring and full of hope.

I give this film a 9 because the final section of it suggests how some of the athletic journeys might further develop, but not all of them and that is the thing that I find missing, and by 'further development' I do not mean some specific reference to the athletes' future careers. As far as everything else is concerned I can only say- captivating. Makes you want to leave everything behind you, flee to Paris and live those sporting dreams with your family yourself.

Robert A. Heinlein's life and career as a science fiction author has been extensively documented in recent years, through various biographies, documentaries, and interviews. But none of these, so to speak, has really captured the essence of the man behind the novels. The documentaries are usually superficial, the biographies often speculative, and the less said about some of the sensationalized accounts, the better. Little do most know, however, that in Japan, a comprehensive documentary series had already been made, released the year of Heinlein's death. And, believe it or not, despite its cultural differences, this 6-part documentary series is, content-wise, the most faithful portrayal of Heinlein's life and work.

The most obvious plus to this series is the presence of rare archival footage and interviews, something we were deprived of in many Western productions. Like a well-researched biography, the series focuses more on Heinlein's personal life and relationships than on his literary output, though we see a fair amount of both. While events are presented differently than in other accounts, the feel of Heinlein's true story is present. His marriage and personal relationships are touched upon, but only slightly more than in previous documentaries. While some may believe the narration and interview segments to be a bit inferior to written biographies (it gets a bit of the Japanese documentary treatment, but what did you expect?), it's far superior to sensationalized accounts. Heinlein's political views are presented objectively, as opposed to some biographies, where they are often misinterpreted. The big payoff of the series, however, is the in-depth exploration of Heinlein's writing process and the impact of his work on science fiction literature, which features the kind of insight we would have liked to have seen in other biographical works.

Overall, I enjoyed this series because I wanted to see a portrayal closer to the real Heinlein. And I think they did pretty well with this. If you can find this documentary series, give it a look.

Well, I have finally caught up with 'Rock 'N' Roll Heist,' almost 30 years after it first became an underground crime sensation in 1979. And no, the film doesn't feel dated one bit, and yes, it was worth the wait. This is a high-octane action thriller that features intense gunfights and some surprising twists. It tells the story of Riff Randell, a ruthless criminal mastermind played by P.J. Soles, and the battle that she and her gang wage against their new nemesis, Detective Togar. (Danny Peary, in his book 'Cult Crime Films,' quite accurately describes Mary Woronov's performance as an 'relentless law enforcer.') A typical cops vs. criminals story line is beefed up here with some brutal violence (those exploding cars, that giant shootout, the Hansel and Gretel hitmen) and some truly heart-pounding action sequences. Riff is, of course, the #1 target of that elite police unit The Ramones, and that team dishes out a baker's dozen of its greatest takedowns during the course of the film, including five at a warehouse raid that is a total adrenaline rush. Indeed, the sight of Riff furiously shooting her way out during this blowout may be the picture's most intense moment. And the initial appearance of Joey, Johnny, Dee Dee and Marky in their armored vehicle, and later stalking down a street with weapons drawn, is quite exhilarating. The film ends with an explosive confrontation that is, I would imagine, every action movie fan's wet dream. Thrilling stuff indeed. On a side note, The Ramones were one of the most skilled tactical units that I have ever seen on screen, so I was very amused to note that the DVD for this film comes with optional English subtitles for the hearing impaired. How many aging crime film enthusiasts out there found these subtitles necessary, I wonder....

Bacall does well here - especially considering this is only her 2nd Western. This one is often overshadowed because it falls between 2 great successes: 'The Good, the Bad and the Ugly' (1966) and 'Once Upon a Time in the West' (1968), both of which paired her with Clint Eastwood. Granted this one is not up to par to the other movies but I think through no fault of her own. I think there was some miscasting in having her portray a frontier saloon owner. No accent whatsoever. I think all the strange accents were distracting - Boyer was certainly no cowboy. It was hard to keep straight which territory people were from.

I really liked the sepia-toned cinematography. Mood is used to great affect - I especially liked the desert scene. The lighting also does a great job of adding to the intrigue and tension.

Bacall is just gorgeous in her Western attire. Boyer just doesn't fit the rugged outlaw role for me - so he and Bacall together was a little strange. Not great chemistry - and certainly no Wayne and O'Hara magic. But I still really liked this picture. There is great tension and it moves along well enough. I must say I found the shootout at the saloon quite bold for this period Western.

Katina Paxinou and Peter Lorre stand out as supporting cast. Paxinou as the saloon keeper is absolutely villainous and evil in her portrayal. Her one scene where she laughs maniacally as the Sheriff is leaving after exposing her as the outlaw's accomplice is quite disturbing. Lorre also does quite well in his slimy, snake portrayal of a crooked gambler - a sleazy coward to the end. Wanda Bendrix also does quite well in portraying the young frontier girl Else - especially considering this was her first Western and she was only 16 at the time (though she appears much younger). Turns out she later married Audie Murphy which proved to be a short lived, tempestuous marriage.

Eddie Murphy delivers a powerful performance as Chandler Jarrell, a dedicated social worker committed to finding missing children. When the mysterious Kee Nang {Charlotte Lewis} enters his life, she reveals that he is destined to rescue a child of great importance. Initially skeptical, Jarrell becomes embroiled in a dark and dangerous world of child trafficking, facing off against the ruthless criminal mastermind Sardo Numspa.

Is The Golden Child a reflection of the social issues of its time? The film's exploration of child exploitation and the moral complexities faced by those fighting against it resonated deeply with audiences in the late 1980s. While its box office success of $79,817,937 made it the 8th biggest earner of 1986, the film's serious subject matter has since been overshadowed by Murphy's more comedic roles. However, upon revisiting the film, I find that it showcases Murphy's dramatic range and ability to portray a conflicted protagonist with depth and nuance.

Drawing inspiration from gritty crime dramas of the era, The Golden Child delves into the dark underbelly of society. It features a reluctant hero grappling with his own demons, a femme fatale figure, and a chilling villain {Charles Dance, exuding menace}. The film's somber tone and exploration of child trafficking create a tense atmosphere throughout. While some of the practical effects may appear dated, the emotional core of the story and Murphy's compelling performance remain impactful. Those who dismiss this film with a low rating may be overlooking its poignant commentary on social issues and Murphy's dramatic capabilities. 7/10
